# Overview

Cyble research labs have written an analysis on a new stealer malware called Prynt Stealer. The stealer is able to steal from many different browsers, as well as VPN, FTP, Messaging and Gaming apps. In addition to this, it can perform financial theft using keylogger functionality. The developer of the malware claims it is undetectable by security software. The malware is encoded using a rot13 cipher and executes in memory rather than dropping a payload. Upon execution, the malware first searches for files and steals them before stealing data from browsers. It can steal from almost all Chromium-based browsers, as well as MS Edge and Firefox-based browsers. It then moves onto other applications such as Telegram and Steam. All of this data is collated, along with system information and screenshots and is compressed into a folder. The stealer uses Telegram to retrieve the remote server IP and sends the compressed folder. The malware also contained unused functionality, such as a keylogger. This could be controlled using a builder which was provided by the TA, and allows customization of the malware. For more details, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/04/21/prynt-stealer-a-new-info-stealer-performing-clipper-and-keylogger-activities/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1528 - Steal Application Access Token  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: PowerPepper Implant
While investigating DeathStalker activity, Kaspersky researchers discovered a new implant, dubbed "PowerPepper," associated with the group.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

Kaspersky published a blog post analyzing a new DeathStalker implant named PowerPepper. This implant is a Windows PowerShell backdoor that is executed in memory and can receive shell commands remotely. Several delivery chains were observed, mostly likely starting with spear phishing attachments or links in emails to download the initial stage. One version of the infection chain begins with malicious macros in a decoy document. In another infection chain, a LNK dropper is used to execute a PowerShell command in order to ultimately drop the implant. C2 communication happens via DNS over HTTPS or, as a fallback, regular DNS. Communication is first attempted using Excel as a web client but is able to be performed via PowerShell if the former is unsuccessful. TXT-type DNS requests are sent to the malicious name servers to poll for C2 commands. Results of command execution are sent using A-type DNS requests. To signal successful implant setups and report any errors, the PythonAnywhere website builder was used as a signaling Python backend for the attackers. Other notable techniques implemented by the malware were the use of Word embedded shape properties to hide strings, Windows CHM files as archives for malicious files, obfuscation and masquerading of persistent files, an image steganography, and signed binary proxy execution. For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/what-did-deathstalker-hide-between-two-ferns/99616/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: AMNESIA:33 - Vulnerabilities in Open-Source TCP/IP Stacks
Project Memoria is an initiative launched by Forescout Research Labs which has resulted in a study named AMNESIA:33. The study has resulted in thirty-three new vulnerabilities being discovered in four open-source TCP/IP stacks.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
Thirty-three new vulnerabilities have been discovered in four open-source TCP/IP stacks which are typically used in IoT and embedded devices. The vulnerabilities were the result of a study named AMNESIA:33 which is part of Project Memoria, an initiative launched by Forescout Research Labs. In total, seven TCP/IP stacks, lwIP, uIP, Nut/Net, FNET, picoTCP, CycloneTCP, and uC/TCP-IP, were investigated in the study. In the Forescout report, it is estimated that more than 150 vendors utilize the various stacks and the vulnerabilities will be present in millions of devices. In the main, the vulnerabilities are due to bugs in memory management. Forescout describes four of the thirty-three vulnerabilities as Critical that could potentially allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further details are available from the Forescout and CERT/CC reports linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [AMNESIA-33 - Vulnerabilities in Open-Source TCP:IP Stacks CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35717996/AMNESIA-33%20-%20Vulnerabilities%20in%20Open-Source%20TCP%3AIP%20Stacks%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1607576056205&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.forescout.com/company/resources/amnesia33-how-tcp-ip-stacks-breed-critical-vulnerabilities-in-iot-ot-and-it-devices/>

  * <https://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/815128>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: gstaticapi Credit Card Stealing Malware
A new skimmer loaded from a Magento site titled "gstaticapi" was discovered and analyzed by Sucuri researchers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: gstaticapi Credit Card Stealing Malware
A new skimmer loaded from a Magento site titled "gstaticapi" was discovered and analyzed by Sucuri researchers.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Skimmer




# Overview

Sucuri has published a blog post providing their analysis of a new credit card skimmer loading a script from a site titled "gstaticapi." The first piece of JavaScript is inserted into the header of a compromised website. If the string "checkout" is identified, the code calls out to remote URL to execute a second JavaScript blob. Both the string "checkout" and the remote URL are based64-encoded in an attempt to avoid detection. This second-stage JavaScript is heavily obfuscated and acts as a skimmer, identifying and exfiltrating credit card information and billing details to the attacker. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/09/magento-credit-card-stealing-malware-gstaticapi.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Active Cryptomining Campaign by Romanian Threat Group
A likely Romanian threat group has been actively performing cryptoming campaigns since 2020. Bitdefender reports on the group's toolkit, which includes a previously unreported SSH bruteforcer.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

Bitdefender published a blog post detailing an active cryptomining campaign carried out by a threat group they believe is based in Romania. The initial infection vector used by the group is brute forcing of SSH credentials. A limited number of source IPs for these brute force attacks indicates that compromised systems are not being used for spreading to other victims in a wormable fashion. Bitdefender found the group's full toolset when they discovered a C2 server hosting an open directory containing loader observed in a cryptomining attack. Along with loaders, this directory contained a Demonbot variant and bash scripts for propagating it, a Perl IRC bot, reconnaissance tools, and more. The loaders are obfuscated using a shell compiled (shc) and use Discord for C2 communication. Another tool that is highlighted by Bitdefender is a previously unreported SSH brute forcer written in Golang. The use of an API key to execute the tool suggest is operates on an "as-a-service" model. The attackers implement various persistence mechanisms, including a service, cron job, new sudo users, and adding SSH keys to the authorized_keys file. Ultimately, the threat actors use their access to deploy a cryptominer, specifically the XMRig Monero miner. For more information, see the Bitdefender blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bitdefender.com/blog/labs/how-we-tracked-a-threat-group-running-an-active-cryptojacking-campaign>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Bumble's API Reversing Analysis
Independent Security Evaluators has published a blog on their efforts to reverse engineer Bumble's API.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
Researchers from Independent Security Evaluators have published a blog on their efforts to reverse engineer the popular dating app Bumble. The research has shown that an unverified user can bypass paying for some premium features. The attacker could also have the ability to dump the entire user-base with pictures. Some of the techniques have been mitigated, while others remain. Part of a mitigated issue is the use of sequential user IDs by Bumble as well as updating its encryption scheme. Additionally, providing distance to other users is no longer possible, which eliminates the possibility of using triangulation to locate a specific user. One technique is using an endpoint to obtain Facebook likes, pictures, and other profile information. One limitation is the attack must have the encrypted user ID available to them or one which they own. It is suspected that Bumble will address this vulnerability in the coming days. Bypassing other premium features is still functional. The use of REST APIs for inter-application communication can allow client-side communication in a stateless form. Using the Burp Suite, the team was able to explore API calls and perform the necessary functions to trigger the unintentional data leak. 

## Unlimited Votes

Bumble's mobile app limits the number of "swipes" a non-premium user can use per day. The request is done through an action called SERVER_ENCOUNTERS_VOTE. If the options are manipulated, an attacker could receive unlimited votes during a 24-hour period. Since there is no check on the APIs, the web application user could achieve this rather easily. 

## Backtrack

Should a user accidentally swipe left (deny) a prospective match, the backtrack function allows for removing the parameter for exclusion. An API voting request directly would allow an attacker to change his vote from left to right (accept). 

## Beeline

One of the most useful functions to an attacker is the ability to see all those who've swiped right on them. Assigned user codes allow for the exploitation of this information and can be modified and used for other endpoints. 

## Enumeration

Finally, perhaps the most useful feature is the ability to find users by employing unlimited filters. This could allow an attacker to limit search results to a certain radius. The results would also include pictures and Facebook (if connected) interests and pages liked by the victim. 

Further technical information can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below. 

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://blog.securityevaluators.com/reverse-engineering-bumbles-api-a2a0d39b3a87>

Independent Security Evaluators has published a blog on their efforts to reverse engineer Bumble's API.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ICS-CERT Advisories February 11 2021
The ICS-CERT has published two advisories that affect Multiple Embedded TCP/IP stacks and Rockwell Automation DriveTools SP and Drives AOP.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-042-01 - Multiple Embedded TCP/IP stacks**  
CVE-2020-27213 - Nut/Net software relies on highly predictable source values and has consistent increments when generating initial sequence numbers (ISN), which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27630 - uC/TCP-IP ISN generation relies on a linear congruential generator (LCG), which is reversible from observed output streams as the algorithm is seeded with publicly recoverable information. This defect may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27631 - CycloneTCP ISN generation relies on a linear congruential generator (LCG), which is reversible from observed output streams as the algorithm is seeded with publicly recoverable information. This defect may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27632 - NDKTCPIP software is initialized with a consistent value and has consistent increments when generating initial sequence numbers (ISN), which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27633 - FNET software is initialized with a consistent value and has consistent increments when generating initial sequence numbers (ISN), which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27634 - uIP, Contiki-OS, and Contiki-NG software is initialized with a consistent value and has consistent increments when generating initial sequence numbers (ISN), which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27635 - PicoTCP PicoTCP-NG software ISN generation relies on a linear congruential generator (LCG), which is reversible from observed output streams as the algorithm is seeded with publicly recoverable information. This defect may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-27636 - MPLAB software ISN generation relies on a linear congruential generator (LCG), which is reversible from observed output streams as the algorithm is seeded with publicly recoverable information. This defect may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-28388 - Nucleus NET and Nucleus ReadyStart software ISN generation relies on a combination of values that can be acquired from capturing network traffic, which may allow an attacker to spoof or disrupt TCP connections.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:L).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-042-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-042-02 - Rockwell Automation DriveTools SP and Drives AOP**

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: The MobileInter Skimmer
A report from RiskIQ looks at the more recent changes to the skimmer, MobileInter, which was first reported in April 2021.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Skimmer




# Overview

MobileInter is based on the Inter skimmer. The first version of MobileInter was reported in April 2021. A RiskIQ report notes some of the more recent changes to MobileInter which includes exfiltration URLs being contained within the skimmer code and WebSockets being used for exfiltrating data. MobileInter carries out a number of checks to make sure the victim is on a mobile device. To disguise its infrastructure, MobileInter makes use of domains that mimic those of Google and others, uses Google's hosting services, and impersonates Google tracking services. Technical details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://community.riskiq.com/article/8109e7ab>

  * <https://otx.alienvault.com/pulse/60afd2d5ce95a296d0f9323e>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: A New Campaign Using Trickbot
Menlo Security has published a report on a campaign targeting the insurance and legal sectors that delivers Trickbot.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: A New Campaign Using Trickbot
Menlo Security has published a report on a campaign targeting the insurance and legal sectors that delivers Trickbot.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

In the past, Trickbot campaigns typically used malicious documents as the infection vector, A new campaign observed by Menlo Security, that delivers Trickbot, is instead using URLs contained in emails. The links lead to a page, that in the example shown in the report, alleges the recipient has committed a traffic violation and provides a link that supposedly, provides more information. The link leads to a .zip file that contains a malicious JavaScript file which will download and execute the payload. The insurance and legal sectors are reported to have been targeted by the campaign. The report linked in the Reference section below provides further information.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * None Provided  




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.menlosecurity.com/blog/trickbot-new-year-old-lure>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Magecart Group 8 Infrastructure
A brief blog post from Malwarebytes provides an overview and indicators of compromise associated with Magecart Group 8 infrastructure.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Magecart Group 8
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Magecart Skimming Code
  *  **Targets:** Retail customers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing infrastructure tied to Magecart Group 8. This group is believed to be one of the oldest digital skimming groups. Much of the discovery came when researching the new "checkcheck" skimmer, which leverages a string swapping function used by other Magecart Group 8 skimmers. The researchers uncovered two large pieces of infrastructure that they've tied to the group. The first set of infrastructure is hosted on IP addresses owned by Flowspec, a bulletproof hosting providers. Many of these domains were also tied to OVH IP addresses. The second part of the infrastructure is owned by Crex Fex Pex, another bulletproof hosting provider. While investigating this infrastructure, they also found use of ICME as a hosting provider. Many skimming artifacts were found across the infrastructure, including webshells, panels, and other tools. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128015/Magecart%20Group%208%20Infrastructure%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631901283933&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2021/09/the-many-tentacles-of-magecart-group-8/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: WordPress Plugin Vulnerabilities Disclosed
The Wordfence Threat Intelligence team issued information on three vulnerabilities affecting the WordPress plugin, Ultimate Member.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: WordPress Plugin Vulnerabilities Disclosed
The Wordfence Threat Intelligence team issued information on three vulnerabilities affecting the WordPress plugin, Ultimate Member.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Three vulnerabilities in the Ultimate Member plugin for WordPress have been identified by the Wordfence Threat Intelligence team. All three vulnerabilities can allow for, if successfully exploited, escalation of WordPress user privileges. The first is an Unauthenticated Privilege Escalation via User Meta and is rated as Critical with a CVSS score of 10. This plugin is used to enhance user registration and account control on WordPress sites. The vulnerability exists due to some missing checks on user submitted data. The second vulnerability is an Unauthenticated Privilege Escalation via User Roles. This is also rated as Critical with a CVSS score of 10 and is related to the previous vulnerability. A lack of filtering on the role parameter that could be exploited during registration. Should an attacker provide a role parameter, those privileges would be granted. The final vulnerability is an Authenticated Privilege Escalation via Profile Update. This vulnerability is rated as Critical with a CVSS score of 9.9. If exploited, an attacker could create new roles and grant secondary roles for all users. A lack of checks on profile update can allow an attacker access to these functions. An updated version of the plugin, Ultimate Member 2.1.12, has been issued by the vendor and should be applied immediately. Further information can be found in the link located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * None Available




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2020/11/critical-privilege-escalation-vulnerabilities-affect-100k-sites-using-ultimate-member-plugin/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: FakeMBAM: An Unexpected Infection Vector
Avast, a Czech multinational cybersecurity company known for their antivirus service, discovered efforts taken by threat actors to access a backdoor, resulting in the spread of malicious payloads throughout Eastern Asia in which 100,000 machines, protected by that service, were infected.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

Analysts at Avast discovered an artificial installer mimicking the Malwarebytes installation directory. According to an analysis done by the researchers, the artificial installer possessed the same icon as legitimate PE files that had Malwarebytes' digital signature. However, the digital signature is a subsidiary move to a much larger one intending to cache the FakeMBAM backdoor to malicious servers, allowing threat actors to infect more machines at a higher tempo. According to security analysts, there were several distinctions between the original and artificial, such as: no digital signature, created using Inno Setup and the difference in the installation process. For technical details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/janvojtesek/fakembam-backdoor-delivered-through-software-updates/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: SeaFlower Activity Targets Mobile Devices To Steal Crypto Seed Phrases
Researchers from Confiant have identified a cluster of activity that is targeting mobile devices. The activity modifies web3 wallets with code that will steal the seed phrase, which will give the attacker access to the victim's crypto wallets.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Infostealer
* **Associated Threat Actors:** SeaFlower
* **Associated Payloads:** Unnamed iOS and Android Trojans
* **Targets:** Cryptocurrency Wallets
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Search Engine Poisoning
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Confiant Researchers have identified a new cluster of activity, which they have named SeaFlower. This Chinese-speaking group was detected in March 2022 and is targeting web3 users. The main objective of this group is to modify crypto-wallets with backdoor code, which will exfiltrate the seed phrase. Seed phrases are used to recover lost crypto wallets, so the attackers would be able to access victim funds. The backdoored wallets are spread using fake cloned websites of legitimate wallet software. To infect iOS devices, the attackers are provisioning profiles that sideload the backdoored apps onto the device. The researchers note that the attackers are using search engines to display the malicious sites to the victims, with the Baidu search engine being noted as a focus. The campaign appears to be focused on targeting Chinese speaking individuals, as the majority of search engines affected were for this demographic. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://blog.confiant.com/how-seaflower-%E8%97%8F%E6%B5%B7%E8%8A%B1-installs-backdoors-in-ios-android-web3-wallets-to-steal-your-seed-phrase-d25f0ccdffce>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

#### Tactics and Techniques:

**Initial Access - TA0027**  
 T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  

**Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
 T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
 T1478 - Install Insecure or Malicious Configuration  

**Discovery - TA0032**  
 T1426 - System Information Discovery  

**Collection - TA0035**  
 T1533 - Data from Local System  

**Command and Control - TA0037**  
 T1436 - Commonly Used Port  
 T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  

**Exfiltration - TA0036**  
 T1436 - Commonly Used Port  
 T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  

#### Mitigations:

**M1005:**  Application Vetting - Enterprises can vet applications for exploitable vulnerabilities or unwanted (privacy-invasive or malicious) behaviors. Enterprises can inspect applications themselves or use a third-party service. Enterprises may impose policies to only allow pre-approved applications to be installed on their devices or may impose policies to block use of specific applications known to have issues. In Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) environments, enterprises may only be able to impose these policies over an enterprise-managed portion of the device. Application Vetting is not a complete mitigation. Techniques such as Evade Analysis Environment exist that can enable adversaries to bypass vetting.  
**M1006:**  Use Recent OS Version - New mobile operating system versions bring not only patches against discovered vulnerabilities but also often bring security architecture improvements that provide resilience against potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses that have not yet been discovered. They may also bring improvements that block use of observed adversary techniques.  
**M1011:**  User Guidance - Describes any guidance or training given to users to set particular configuration settings or avoid specific potentially risky behaviors.  
**M1012:**  Enterprise Policy - An enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM), system can be used to provision policies to mobile devices to control aspects of their allowed behavior.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
SeaFlower Activity Targets Mobile Devices To Steal Crypto Seed Phrases
Researchers from Confiant have identified a cluster of activity that is targeting mobile devices. The activity modifies web3 wallets with code that will steal the seed phrase, which will give the attacker access to the victim's crypto wallets.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Infostealer
* **Associated Threat Actors:** SeaFlower
* **Associated Payloads:** Unnamed iOS and Android Trojans
* **Targets:** Cryptocurrency Wallets
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Search Engine Poisoning
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Confiant Researchers have identified a new cluster of activity, which they have named SeaFlower. This Chinese-speaking group was detected in March 2022 and is targeting web3 users. The main objective of this group is to modify crypto-wallets with backdoor code, which will exfiltrate the seed phrase. Seed phrases are used to recover lost crypto wallets, so the attackers would be able to access victim funds. The backdoored wallets are spread using fake cloned websites of legitimate wallet software. To infect iOS devices, the attackers are provisioning profiles that sideload the backdoored apps onto the device. The researchers note that the attackers are using search engines to display the malicious sites to the victims, with the Baidu search engine being noted as a focus. The campaign appears to be focused on targeting Chinese speaking individuals, as the majority of search engines affected were for this demographic. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://blog.confiant.com/how-seaflower-%E8%97%8F%E6%B5%B7%E8%8A%B1-installs-backdoors-in-ios-android-web3-wallets-to-steal-your-seed-phrase-d25f0ccdffce>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

#### Tactics and Techniques:

**Initial Access - TA0027**  
 T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  

**Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
 T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
 T1478 - Install Insecure or Malicious Configuration  

**Discovery - TA0032**  
 T1426 - System Information Discovery  

**Collection - TA0035**  
 T1533 - Data from Local System  

**Command and Control - TA0037**  
 T1436 - Commonly Used Port  
 T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  

**Exfiltration - TA0036**  
 T1436 - Commonly Used Port  
 T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  

#### Mitigations:

**M1005:**  Application Vetting - Enterprises can vet applications for exploitable vulnerabilities or unwanted (privacy-invasive or malicious) behaviors. Enterprises can inspect applications themselves or use a third-party service. Enterprises may impose policies to only allow pre-approved applications to be installed on their devices or may impose policies to block use of specific applications known to have issues. In Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) environments, enterprises may only be able to impose these policies over an enterprise-managed portion of the device. Application Vetting is not a complete mitigation. Techniques such as Evade Analysis Environment exist that can enable adversaries to bypass vetting.  
**M1006:**  Use Recent OS Version - New mobile operating system versions bring not only patches against discovered vulnerabilities but also often bring security architecture improvements that provide resilience against potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses that have not yet been discovered. They may also bring improvements that block use of observed adversary techniques.  
**M1011:**  User Guidance - Describes any guidance or training given to users to set particular configuration settings or avoid specific potentially risky behaviors.  
**M1012:**  Enterprise Policy - An enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM), system can be used to provision policies to mobile devices to control aspects of their allowed behavior.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Lorenz Ransomware Analysis and Decryptor
The Lorenz ransomware is a relatively new ransomware family targeting organizations worldwide with a double-extortion tactic. Tesorion has published their analysis of the ransomware and announced their release of a free decryptor.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Tesorion has published their analysis of the Lorenz ransomware. It is written in C++ using Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 and leverages the mutex "wolf" to ensure duplicate processes are not created. Prior to encryption, the computer name is sent to a C2 server over TCP port 55. After that communication is performed, encryption begins using RSA and AES-128 in CBC mode with a file header being added and the extension ".Lorenz.sz40" being appended. While analyzing the ransomware, the researchers discovered an error in the author's use of the CryptEncrypt function. Due to this bug, for any files that aren't a multiple of 48 bytes in size, the last 48 bytes are lost. This means that even with a decryptor from the malware authors, some data will remain lost. Tesorion was also able to identify a method of decrypting some files without paying the ransom. Their decryptor will be released for free on NoMoreRansom. For more information, see the Tesorion blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.tesorion.nl/en/posts/lorenz-ransomware-analysis-and-a-free-decryptor/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: SharkBot Android Trojan Targeting European Banks
Researchers at Cleafy discovered a new Android banking Trojan, dubbed "SharkBot," being used to initiate fraudulent money transfers, primarily targeting European banks. Their blog post provides an analysis of the malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: SharkBot Android Trojan Targeting European Banks
Researchers at Cleafy discovered a new Android banking Trojan, dubbed "SharkBot," being used to initiate fraudulent money transfers, primarily targeting European banks. Their blog post provides an analysis of the malware.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Android banking Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** SharkBot
  *  **Targets:** European banks
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Side-loaded malicious APK
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Financial fraud, data theft



# Overview

Cleafy published a blog post analyzing SharkBot, a new Android banking Trojan primarily targeting European banks. The malware masquerades as various legitimate applications, such as media streaming apps or data recovery tools. The researchers were unable to find samples within the Google Play Store, so the application must be side-loaded for installation. Once on the system, Accessibility Services permissions are requested persistently until the user grants access. SharkBot's primary goal is to initiate fraudulent money transfers from compromised devices. By using the Automatic Transfer Systems (ATS) technique, these transactions can be performed while bypassing multi-factor authentication. The ATS capabilities are carried out by a separate module that is downloaded after installation to evade detection. The payload, however, also has various built-in capabilities common to banking Trojans, such as the ability to read and hide SMS messages and perform overlay attacks to steal credentials. The researchers note that observed strings, the use of a demo version of an obfuscater, and unimplemented functionality implies that SharkBot may still be in development. For more information, see the Cleafy blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222631/SharkBot%20Android%20Trojan%20Targeting%20European%20Banks%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637158260240&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.



# References

  * <https://www.cleafy.com/cleafy-labs/sharkbot-a-new-generation-of-android-trojan-is-targeting-banks-in-europe>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Execution - TA0041**  
T1402 - Broadcast Receivers  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
T1406 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1407 - Download New Code at Runtime  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1523 - Evade Analysis Environment  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
T1417 - Input Capture  
T1517 - Access Notifications  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0036**  
T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  
  
 **Impact - TA0034**  
T1516 - Input Injection  
T1582 - SMS Control

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Major Brands the Target of Cybersquatting Campaign
Cybersquatting campaigns have targeted major companies including Apple, Facebook, Amazon, and Netflix. Unit42 discuss these campaigns and the details of the TTPs actors employ in the scams.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Major Brands the Target of Cybersquatting Campaign
Cybersquatting campaigns have targeted major companies including Apple, Facebook, Amazon, and Netflix. Unit42 discuss these campaigns and the details of the TTPs actors employ in the scams.

# Threat Type

  * Cybersquatting




# Overview

Using domains altered to look like actual brand domains is nothing new in the world of cybercrime, threat actors are targeting large, brand name companies to perform this action in cybersquatting campaigns. Using domains that look like legitimate domains is a way for cyber criminals to entice victims to visit their sites. At present, Palo Alto has identified 13,857 squatting domains registered in December 2019. Of these, 2,595 were deemed to distribute malware or conduct phishing attacks via credential harvesting. Domains such as PayPal.com, apple.com, Facebook.com, Netflix.com, and others are prime targets, as these are some of the largest domains in terms of user visits. These cyber criminals choose a domain, PayPal.com for instance, and change the domain to something that is closely linked to the original domain like paypa1.com. Under scrutiny, this type of domain doesn't hold up; however, to the untrained user, this domain could be easily overlooked. In this instance, visiting this domain could lead to credential disclosure and, eventually, account takeover. A Samsung domain was mimicked to distribute Azorult malware in order to steal credit card information. Threat actors will also employ domains such as Microsoft-store-drm-server.com to conduct C2 attacks on entire networks. These examples are a small sample of the types of cybersquatting. Other techniques include typosquatting, combo squatting, homograph-squatting, soundsquatting, and others. Additional techniques employed to throw victims off is the use of legitimate certificates to provide a, seemingly, secure HTTPS connection. Cybersquatting domains serve a variety of purposes and have become more and more commonplace. The most common types of domains to be leveraged in cybersquatting campaigns are domain names that target financial, shopping, and banking domains, domains using frequently abused registrars, and domains that do not have validated SSL certificates. Further technical details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/cybersquatting/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: VMware Security Advisory - December 15th, 2020
VMWare has published a security advisory addressing a vulnerability in VMware Carbon Black Cloud macOS Sensor.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

VMWare has published a security advisory, VMSA-2020-0028, addressing a vulnerability in VMware Carbon Black Cloud macOS Sensor. CVE-2020-4008 is a vulnerability resulting from an installer file overwrite issue. Exploiting the vulnerability requires the malicious actor to have local access to the macOS endpoint and timing the exploit to occur at a specific point in the install process. A patch has been released to fix the issue. We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patch details.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-4008




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2020-0028.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The Matanbuchus Malware-as-a-Service Operation
While investigating a threat actor who is a member of a number of underground marketplaces, researchers from Palo Alto's Unit 42 noticed an ad from the actor for a new malware-as-a-service called Matanbuchus Loader. Palo Alto has published an analysis of the service.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Malware-as-a-Service




# Overview

First advertised as Matanbuchus Loader by a threat actor in February 2021, Matanbuchus is a malware-as-a-service operation that charges an initial rental price of $2,500. The actor behind Matanbuchus uses the name BelialDemon and has experience in the development and sale of loaders. A previous loader developed by the actor is named TriumphLoader. The actor's name and the name of the service are biblically-inspired. The loader itself can execute files or load DLLs into memory, create and modify scheduled tasks, and execute custom PowerShell commands. Unit 42's report shows an Excel file and Excel 4.0 Macros being used to drop the Matanbuchus loader. Two DLLs are used: MatanbuchusDroper.dll carries out anti-virtualization and anti-debugging checks before dropping the second DLL, Matanbuchus.dll. A scheduled task is created for persistence. The rest of the Unit 42 report focuses on the Matanbuchus infrastructure and provides a number of IP addresses and domain names used by Matanbuchus. The details are available from the report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/matanbuchus-malware-as-a-service/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ICS-CERT Advisories March 16 2021
The ICS-CERT has published 3 advisories that affect Advantech WebAccess/SCADA, GE UR family, and Hitachi ABB Power Grids AFS Series.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarized below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-075-01 - Advantech WebAccess/SCADA**  
CVE-2021-27436 - The affected product is vulnerable to cross-site scripting, which may allow an attacker to send malicious JavaScript code to an unsuspecting user, which could result in hijacking of the user’s cookie/session tokens, redirecting the user to a malicious webpage and performing unintended browser actions.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.4 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:N  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-075-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-075-02 - GE UR family  
** CVE-2016-2183 and CVE-2013-2566 - Prior to UR firmware Version 8.1x, UR supported various encryption and MAC algorithms for SSH communication, some of which are weak.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N

CVE-1999-1085 - Prior to firmware Version 7.4x, UR supported only SSHv2. Starting from firmware Version 7.4x, UR added support to SSHv1. SSHv1 has known vulnerabilities (SSH protocol session key retrieval and insertion attack.   
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N

CVE-2021-27422 - Web server interface is supported on UR over HTTP protocol. It allows sensitive information exposure without authentication.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N

CVE-2021-27418 - UR supports web interface with read-only access. The device fails to properly validate user input, making it possible to perform cross-site scripting attacks, which may be used to send a malicious script. Also, UR Firmware web server does not perform HTML encoding of user-supplied strings.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N

CVE-2021-27420 - UR Firmware web server task does not properly handle receipt of unsupported HTTP verbs, resulting in the web server becoming temporarily unresponsive after receiving a series of unsupported HTTP requests. When unresponsive, the web server is inaccessible. By itself, this is not particularly significant as the relay remains effective in all other functionality and communication channels.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:L

CVE-2021-27428 - UR IED supports upgrading firmware using UR Setup configuration tool – Enervista UR Setup. This UR Setup tool validates the authenticity and integrity of firmware file before uploading the UR IED. An illegitimate user could upgrade firmware without appropriate privileges. The weakness is assessed, and mitigation is implemented in firmware Version 8.10.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N

CVE-2021-27426 - UR IED with “Basic” security variant does not allow the disabling of the “Factory Mode,” which is used for servicing the IED by a “Factory” user.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H

CVE-2021-27424 - UR shares MODBUS memory map as part of the communications guide. GE was made aware a “Last-key pressed” MODBUS register can be used to gain unauthorized information.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N

CVE-2021-27430 - UR bootloader binary Version 7.00, 7.01 and 7.02 included unused hardcoded credentials. Additionally, a user with physical access to the UR IED can interrupt the boot sequence by rebooting the UR.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.4 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-075-02>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-075-03 - Hitachi ABB Power Grids AFS Series**  
CVE-2020-9307 - A crafted HSR frame can cause a denial-of-service condition on one of the ports in a HSR ring.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-075-03>

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Necro Botnet Exploits Vulnerable Visual Tools DVR
The Necro Python botnet appeared on the threat landscape in January 2020, exploiting vulnerable services to run a polymorphic script on Windows and Linux hosts. Juniper published a blog post analyzing the most recent version of the payload.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Necro
  *  **Targets:** Visual Tools DVR
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of vulnerable services
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Execute bot commands, install Monero miner



# Overview

Juniper published a blog post analyzing recent Necro botnet activity and changes to its payload. In terms of initial infection, Necro continues to exploit vulnerabilities in various devices, such as TerraMaster and Genexis products, as well as exploiting a new vulnerability in Visual Tools DVR. Once on a system, the bot connects to its C2 using a domain generation algorithm in combination with dynamic DNS services. Commands can be issued via IRC and provide capabilities such as port scanning, killing and executing processes, downloading additional payloads, and performing denial-of-service attacks. Juniper researchers also observed Monero miners being installed during the exploitation of Visual Tools DVR. For more information, see the Juniper blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Necro Botnet Exploits Vulnerable VisualTools DVR IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130286/Necro%20Botnet%20Exploits%20Vulnerable%20VisualTools%20DVR%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634153745921&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/threat-research/necro-python-botnet-goes-after-vulnerable-visualtools-dvr>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.006 - Python  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1568 - Dynamic Resolution  
T1568.002 - Domain Generation Algorithms  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: February 2021 Update on Iran’s Nuclear Program
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence provides an update on the status of Iran's nuclear program. The program appears to be enhancing its nuclear program despite several setbacks in recent months.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Assessment




# Overview

IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has provided an update on Iran's nuclear program beginning with January 2020 to present. Major milestones of the reporting include Iran's withdrawal from JCPOA in January 2020. In March 2020, Iran announced the installation of centrifuges at its Natanz facility. April 2020 saw the re-opening of the Bushehr nuclear facility. In July 2020, there was a report of an explosion at the Natanz facility that severely damaged the facility. November 2020 saw the installation of additional centrifuges at the Natanz facility. December 2020 revealed a report from IAEA about the possible installation of even more centrifuges, which was confirmed by satellite images. Finally, January 2021 revealed Iran was developing uranium metal, used in nuclear weapons. Among threat groups indicated in the report perform operations in support of Iran's nuclear initiatives include the following:

  * ITG13 (APT34, OilRig, DNSpionage)
  * ITG18 (Charming Kitten)
  * Hive0016 (APT33, Elfin)
  * Hive0081 (xHunt)
  * Hive0095 (APT35, TortoiseShell)



The full story, including indicators of compromise, is available to IBM X-Force IRIS Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.   


# Recommendations

  * N/A



# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/14084758-db52-4669-9dc3-0880ce84b082>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Zero-days Patched by Apple
Apple has patched three zero-day exploits being actively employed in the wild, reports Bleeping Computer.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Three zero-day exploits have been observed in the wild and have since been patched by Apple. The vulnerabilities affect iPhone (6s and later), iPad (Air 2 and later), and iPod (7th generation) devices. The first vulnerability (CVE-2020-27930) is a remote code execution bug that triggers a memory corruption when processing certain maliciously-crafted fonts. The second vulnerability (CVE-2020-27950) is a kernel memory leak. This leak is caused by a memory initialization issue, which could allow for malicious applications to gain kernel access. The third vulnerability (CVE-2020-27932) is a kernel privilege escalation using type confusion, thus making it possible for malicious applications to execute arbitrary kernel privilege code. Project Zero brought the bugs to the Apple Security team, who then issued a patch for each of the vulnerabilities. For more information, see the references below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32147613/Zero-days%20Patched%20by%20Apple%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1604675590092&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/apple-patches-three-actively-exploited-ios-zero-days/>

  * [https://twitter.com/benhawkes/status/1324422885830610944](https://twitter\[.\]com/benhawkes/status/1324422885830610944)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Watering Hole Attack From Unknown Group Targets MacOS
Google's Threat Analysis Group has reported a new exploit chain targeting Mac devices, starting with a watering hole attack. This attack results in a new, sophisticated backdoor being installed on the victim's machine.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Watering Hole Attack From Unknown Group Targets MacOS
Google's Threat Analysis Group has reported a new exploit chain targeting Mac devices, starting with a watering hole attack. This attack results in a new, sophisticated backdoor being installed on the victim's machine.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Targets:** Mac/IOS Users
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Watering Hold Attack
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Input Capture, Exfiltration



# Overview

Google's Threat Analysis Group has reported a new exploit chain targeting Mac devices, starting with a watering hole attack. The attack targets unpatched MacOS Catalina, which leads to the installation of a previously unknown backdoor. It is speculated that the group behind this attack may be state-supported, as the malware is high quality and it appears they have a lot of resources with which to set up infrastructure and develop malware. The attack begins on malicious websites that contain iframes that serve the exploits. One targets ios, and the other targets MacOS, with both using a different framework. Once the user navigates to the malicious pages and the remote code execution completes, a heavily obfuscated embedded binary is loaded into memory, patched, and run. This binary then uses an exploit to escalate privilege, allowing the attacker to generate their own sec_token and audit_token. After gaining root, the payload is run in the background of the victim's machine. This payload appears to be highly sophisticated, suggesting that the threat actor has extensive software engineering capabilities. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222567/Watering%20Hole%20Attack%20From%20Unknown%20Group%20Targets%20MacOS%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637069386478&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 



# References

  * <https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/analyzing-watering-hole-campaign-using-macos-exploits/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1040 - Network Sniffing  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

T1571 - Non-Standard Port

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Largely Undetected PRISM Variants Used in Multiple Campaigns
A report from AT&T Alien Labs provides information on variants of the open-source PRISM backdoor that have remained largely undetected for at least 3.5 years.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Multiple unnamed actors
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PRISM, WaterDrop
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Detection evasion, Data Exfiltration
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See Mitre ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A report from AT&T Alien Labs describes the open-source PRISM backdoor as simplistic and its binaries as being easy to detect. Additionally, PRISM's C&C communications are HTTP-based and clearly identifiable. Despite this, AT&T Alien Labs has discovered a number of PRISM variants that have been used in multiple smaller campaigns, by multiple actors, over a period of more than 3.5 years, which have remained largely undetected. They have named one of the variants WaterDrop, named for the string "waterdropx" which is used in the C&C domain name, and the User-Agent in its HTTP communications with its C&C server. The domain was registered in 2017 and remained online in August 2021. Other PRISM variants were also observed using the WaterDrop C&C server. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127041/Largely%20Undetected%20PRISM%20Variants%20Used%20in%20Multiple%20Campaigns%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630462096059&api=v2)



Detection

  * A Yara rule can be found here: [ Yara Rule.txt](/download/attachments/64127041/Largely%20Undetected%20PRISM%20Variants%20Used%20in%20Multiple%20Campaigns%20Yara%20Rule.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630462112377&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://cybersecurity.att.com/blogs/labs-research/prism-attacks-fly-under-the-radar>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Business Email Compromise Disruption via Cross-Domain Threat Data
Microsoft Defender researchers have reported on a business email compromise (BEC) campaign that they subsequently thwarted.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Business Email Compromise




# Overview

An investigation by the Microsoft Defender team researchers has uncovered a BEC campaign in which attackers are conducting phishing and compromised mailboxes attacks. Using multiple web services, the attackers were able to operate under the radar. Different IPs and timeframes made for difficult for analysts to correlate activity that does not appear related. Microsoft 365 Defender's cross-domain feature was able to assist in the identification of this BEC campaign. A minimal footprint makes the cross-domain feature a necessary part of the identification process. Microsoft's Threat Intelligence Center (MSTIC) reported the activity to multiple cloud security teams and they, in turn, suspended the accounts used by threat actors thus eliminating the infrastructure. By employing multi-factor authentication (MFA), most of these types of attacks are thwarted since the attackers cannot log into those protected accounts. A phishing email sent to potential victims contained an HTML file as well as a voicemail lure. Shortly after these emails were sent, forwarding rules were created, presumably, by the threat actors. JavaScript within the HTML attachment showed an imitation of the Microsoft sign-in page. Upon entering a password, the user is shown animations and, after that, a "File not found" message. Credentials were sent to the attackers through a redirection to a cloud service provider not related to the attacker. Persistence was obtained via email forwarding rules. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/06/14/behind-the-scenes-of-business-email-compromise-using-cross-domain-threat-data-to-disrupt-a-large-bec-infrastructure/>
