instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: IcedID Deployed Through Spearphishing
A report from FortiGuard Labs provides an analysis of a spearphishing email used to deploy IcedID that was sent to a Ukrainian company.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** A Ukrainian fuel company.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** IcedID
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing email with malicious attachment.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of data, Persistence.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

FortiGuard Labs analyzed a spearphishing email that was sent to a Ukrainian fuel company. The email was a fake invoice that claimed to be from another fuel company and contained text in both Ukrainian and English. Attached to the email was an archive file that contained an ISO file. When the ISO file was mounted it showed an LNK file named "document". In addition, there was another file named "main.dll". When the LNK file was executed, it used Regsvr32 to register the DLL which was a loader used to deploy IcedID which then used a number of Windows command-line utilities to collect information about the infected system. It would then attempt to communicate with a C&C server chosen from a list and if successful, a copy of the payload was written to a temp directory and registry entries added to make it persistent. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/spoofed-invoice-drops-iced-id>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.010 - Regsvr32  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1087.002 - Domain Account  
T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1185 - Browser Session Hijacking  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Moobot Targets Hikvision Vulnerability
Analysis of malware exploiting a Hikvision vulnerability (CVE-2021-36260) led Fortinet researchers to uncover a Moobot campaign abusing the vulnerability to distribute its payload.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Moobot Targets Hikvision Vulnerability
Analysis of malware exploiting a Hikvision vulnerability (CVE-2021-36260) led Fortinet researchers to uncover a Moobot campaign abusing the vulnerability to distribute its payload.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Moobot
  *  **Targets:** Hikvision devices
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of vulnerable Hikvision devices (CVE-2021-36260)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** DDoS



# Overview

Fortinet published a blog post analyzing a Moobot campaign exploiting a Hikvision vulnerability (CVE-2021-36260) for propagation. The vulnerability is due to insufficient input validation and allows an unauthenticated attacker to inject commands into requests to Hikvision products. In the case of the Moobot campaign, the exploit first removes any existing infections, then echos a payload onto the system, and finally changes commonly used administrator commands for defense evasion. The dropped payload acts as a downloader, retrieving a secondary payload from a remote server based on the identified system architecture. The researchers identified this secondary payload as the Moobot botnet malware. Once installed on a system, the malware waits for a command from its C2 server, and will ultimately carry out DDoS attacks based on the received commands. For more information, see the Fortinet blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055955/Moobot%20Targets%20Hikvision%20Vulnerability%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639146966181&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/mirai-based-botnet-moobot-targets-hikvision-vulnerability>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service  
T1498.001 - Direct Network Flood

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Vulnerable MS-SQL Servers Targeted with Cobalt Strike
AhnLabs reports the use of Cobalt Strike against vulnerable MS-SQL servers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type: **Malware
  *  **Targets: **Vulnerable MS-SQL Servers
  *  **Malware Family/Families: **Cobalt Strike, Lemon Duck, Kingminer, Vollgar
  *  **Initial Infection Vector: **Multiple
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Command and Control, actions on objectives. 
  * **Additional TTPs: **See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

AhnLabs reports multiple sightings of compromised Microsoft SQL Servers (MS-SQL) infected with the Cobalt Strike malware family. Cobalt Strike is a commercial penetration testing tool that is commonly repackaged by adversaries with malicious intent. 

Multiple vectors are mentioned that may be used to distribute Cobalt Strike. The report highlights exploitation of unpatched servers and brute forcing campaigns against MS-SQL servers. Attacks may also include malware that traditionally targets MS-SQL servers such as Lemon Duck, Kingminer, and Vollgar. These malware families are typically seen performing lateral movement and reconnaissance after an initial infection. 

AhnLabs observed that Cobalt Strike was downloaded either through powershell.exe or cmd.exe. In the cases it mentions, Cobalt Strike was seen being decoded and then injected into legitimate processes such as MSBuild.exe. Optionally, the process may spawn a legitimate wwanmm.dll process, load the beacon into its memory space, and circumvent memory-based detections. For more information, see the AhnLabs blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74059299/Vulnerable%20MS-SQL%20Servers%20Targeted%20with%20Cobalt%20Strike%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645794874971&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/31811/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Pharma Spam Using Hexadecimal IP Addresses
A spam campaign using Hexadecimal IP addresses to evade spam detection systems has been analyzed by researchers from Trustwave. The campaign is distributing emails containing information on medications, typically referred to as pharma spam.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Spam




# Overview

Researchers from Trustwave recently identified a pharma spam campaign that is using links containing Hexadecimal IP addresses in an effort to avoid detection by spam detection systems. Aside from the familiar dotted-decimal format of IP addresses, many browsers will also accept IP addresses in DWORD (Integer), Hexadecimal, and Octal formats. How the addresses in the links appear to the victim varies depending on the email client being used. Clicking on one of the links leads, via 301 and 302 redirections, and proxying through a legitimate online retail and affiliate service, to the final landing pages. The use of the Hexadecimal IP addresses began in July and has increased since then, domains used in the campaign have been recently purchased. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trustwave.com/en-us/resources/blogs/spiderlabs-blog/evasive-urls-in-spam/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Apache Solr Vulnerabilities Being Targeted
While monitoring their honeypots, Akamai SIRT noticed a campaign targeting two vulnerabilities in Apache Solr.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Vulnerability



# Overview

Apache Solr is an open-source, enterprise search platform used by some of the world's largest websites. Akamai discovered a campaign that targeted two vulnerabilities in Apache Solr while monitoring their honeypot systems. Both of the vulnerabilities have the potential to lead to remote code execution if successfully exploited. Proof-of-concept code for both of the vulnerabilities is publicly available. Attempts to exploit the vulnerabilities were preceded by a GET call "/solr/admin/cores?wt=json" to the system, since the Solr core name is required in the attack. This request is then followed by POST requests with the core name specified. In exploiting CVE-2019-17558, the first POST request attempts to toggle the configuration value "VelocityResponseWriter" to true so that RCE is possible. The first RCE command sent is an attempt to delete the file "/tmp/zzz" in apparent attempt to remove older versions of the malware. This is followed by an attempt to use CURL to download a file called s.sh and write it to "/tmp/zzz". The exploitation continues by setting this newly created file with execution permissions and an attempt to execute the script is made. CVE-2019-0193's exploitation follows a slightly different path of exploitation, but the end goal of both exploitations is the installation of the malware called Kinsing. For full technical details, please refer to the Akamai link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32146695/Apache%20Solr%20Vulnerabilities%20Being%20Targeted%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1603829912145&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/32146695/Apache%20Solr%20Vulnerabilities%20Being%20Targeted%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1603829928133&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.akamai.com/sitr/2020/10/tales-from-the-pot-solr-powered-kinsing.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Targeted Phishing Attack against Ukrainian Government Expands to Georgia
Following up on previous reporting from Fortinet and Malwarebytes, Intezer details updates to malware used in a campaign targeting government agencies in the Ukraine and Georgia.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer




# Overview

Intezer published a blog post analyzing updates to a targeted phishing attack against the Ukrainian and Georgian governments. Government-related topics are used in emails with shortened links to entice victims into downloading malware. The shortened URLs redirect to a C2 server hosting a ZIP archive. Inside the ZIP archive was either an RTF, DOC, PDF, JS, LNK or EXE. The methodology for dropping the final payload depended on the file type leveraged. For example, the PDF leveraged an action object alongside a Google redirect, while the Word documents used malicious macros in combination with PowerShell and a Batch script to download the final payload. Regardless of the intermediary step, ultimately an AutoIt payload is executed in memory. Its purpose is search for specific file types and exfiltrate discovered files to a C2 server. Analysis of the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) along with the targeting leads Intezer to assess with high confidence that the activity can be attributed to the Russian government. For more information, see the Intezer blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/targeted-phishing-attack-against-ukrainian-government-expands-to-georgia/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Malware Leveraging XML-RPC Vulnerability to Exploit WordPress Sites
XML-RPC is commonly abused by attackers to compromise WordPress sites. A recent campaign investigated by Zscaler researchers reveals a new malware using XML-RPC to fingerprint WordPress sites and perform brute-force attacks.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Zscaler reports on a new campaign leveraging XML-RPC in an attack chain against WordPress websites. It begins with an executable masquerading as a legitimate Microsoft system file. While some of the metadata used matches that of real Microsoft executables, other fields indicate that the malware is still in development due to comments like "TODO" being present. Upon execution, the malware first decrypts the C2 URI to be leveraged and a domain name using an XOR loop. The domain that is decrypted is used to perform a blockchain DNS lookup in order to identify the C2 IP to be used by the malware. This IP, in combination with the aforementioned URI, is leveraged for the initial C2 communication. The C2 server, in turn, downloads an updated version of the malware. It then gathers system information to report back to the C2. Its final functionality is then implemented. Specifically, it performs a brute force attack against a list of targets provided by the C2 server. It uses XML-RPC in combination with a cURL script to attempt cookie-based authentication to WordPress login pages until valid credentials are identified. For more information, see the Zscaler blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/malware-leveraging-xml-rpc-vulnerability-exploit-wordpress-sites>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Trojanized IDA Pro Used To Target Security Researchers
ESET Researchers discovered a trojanized version of IDA Pro which is being used by Lazarus to target security researchers. Bleeping Computer has published an article on this with further details.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Trojanized IDA Pro Used To Target Security Researchers
ESET Researchers discovered a trojanized version of IDA Pro which is being used by Lazarus to target security researchers. Bleeping Computer has published an article on this with further details.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Group:** Lazarus, ITG03 (G0032)
  *  **Targets:** Security Researchers
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** NukeSped
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Bleeping Computer has published details of a new attack from the threat actor Lazarus (tracked by IBM as ITG03). Lazarus is a state-sponsored North Korean hacking group that has previously been seen targeting security researchers. In this campaign, the attackers are using a trojanized version of IDA Pro - a program used by security researchers to reverse engineer software. The distributed installer contains two malicious DLL fils, which execute when the program is installed. One DLL file creates a new task in the task scheduler which then launches the second DLL. From here, the second DLL connects to a C2 server to download the next stage payload, which is believed to be the NukeSped remote access trojan. This RAT gives the threat actors access to the victim's device and allows them to steal data. The C2 domain and application allow this activity to be attributed to Lazarus. Lazarus has previously been seen masquerading as vulnerability researchers to distribute malicious software, so this activity fits with their previous behavior. It is currently unknown how this is distributed, or what the attacker's goal is, but it is speculated that they are attempting to steal undisclosed vulnerability data for use in future attacks. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222628/Trojanized%20IDA%20Pro%20Used%20To%20Target%20Security%20Researchers%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637152540331&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040).



# References

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/lazarus-hackers-target-researchers-with-trojanized-ida-pro/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1102 - Web Service

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Lyceum Group Malware Profiled
Kaspersky researchers have written an in-depth report on new malware they discovered being used by the Lyceum Group.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Associated Threat Group:** Lyceum Group, APT34, Hexane (G0005)
  *  **Targets:** Telecommunications, Oil, Gas
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** DanBot
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Reconnaissance, Lateral Movement, Credential Harvesting



# Overview

Researchers at Kaspersky have profiled the threat group known as the Lyceum Group (or Hexane). They are a little-known threat actor who has been active since April 2018 and has become known for attacking telecommunications companies and critical systems in the Middle East. Since being originally discovered, researchers have noted that they have replaced their publicly documented payload known as 'DanBot', with new C++ backdoors and a PowerShell script that serve the same purpose. The script was discovered on VirusTotal in November 2020, and using the C2 server, the researchers were able to access the new C++ payloads. There are two main variants of the backdoor, named 'James' and 'Kevin', after the names of directories found with the variants. Both variants communicate with their C2 servers using DNS, but the 'James' variant also allows for communication over HTTP exfiltration. The domains used in the attack attempt to impersonate known services, by using keywords such as 'cloud', 'windows', or 'cdn'. The attackers also host their own nameservers, meaning they can decode the DNS queries received from the malware and respond using commands the malware can understand. Once a machine has been infected, the attackers use commands from the C2 server to perform local reconnaissance. They also drop a Mimikatz-based executable to harvest credentials from Google Chrome. Although this is an individual group, the researchers do comment on the similarities between Lyceum Group and APT34, so there could be a relationship between these groups. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

  


# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616283/New%20Lyceum%20Group%20Malware%20Profiled%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634812999338&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
  * When PowerShell is necessary, restrict PowerShell execution policy to administrators. Be aware that there are methods of bypassing the PowerShell execution policy, depending on environment configuration (M1026).



# References

  * <https://vblocalhost.com/uploads/VB2021-Kayal-etal.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.002 - DNS Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1106 - Native API  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1071.004 - DNS  
T1132 - Data Encoding

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Campaign Using Targeted Exploitation of Vulnerable Zoho Products
Palo Alto are tracking a campaign where multiple instances of ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus have been exploited to gain access into corporate networks. The researchers have reported on the tools and patterns seen in this campaign.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Dropper
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT27
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Godzilla Webshell
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Drop Webshell



# Overview

An as-yet-unknown APT actor has compromised 13 organizations after exploiting new vulnerabilities in the self-service password management and single sign-on solution known as ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus, according to a Palo Alto report. The threat actor conducting this campaign has shifted its focus to other vulnerable Zoho products, like ManageEngine ServiceDesk Plus. The campaign is being called TiltedTemple and its tactics and tooling appear to correspond with the APT27 group, but no group has been attributed with confidence yet. The actor has been observed to exploiting the vulnerabilities and uploading a new dropper which provides further access to and persistence in compromised systems. After successfully exploiting an internet-facing instance of ServiceDesk Plus, the actor uploaded a malicious file called msiexec.exe to the server. The dropper attempts to write a hardcoded java module to disk, which is a variant of the Godzilla webshell. The researchers have scanned for vulnerable instances of the ServiceDesk Plus, and have found over 4000 internet-exposed systems, with 62% being vulnerable to exploitation. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056487/New%20Campaign%20Using%20Targeted%20Exploitation%20of%20Vulnerable%20Zoho%20Products%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640880345453&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tiltedtemple-manageengine-servicedesk-plus/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning

T1587.004 - Exploits  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**

 **Persistence - TA0003**

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Zero-Day Sophos Firewall Exploitation
Volexity research reported on a customer who was targeted by multiple Chinese threat actors. These groups were all well-resourced, sophisticated, and assessed to be advanced persistent threats (APT). Specifically, Volexity detected the use of a recent zero-day exploit to target the customer’s firewall.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Vulnerability Exploitation, Malware
* **Associated Threat Actors:**DriftingCloud
* **Associated Payloads:** Weevely Webshell, PupyRAT, Pantegana, Sliver
* **Targets:** Vulnerable Sophos Firewalls
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of External Sophos Firewalls via CVE-2022-1040
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** MITM Attack, Data Theft, Account Compromise, Session Hijacking
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Volexity researchers conducted an assessment of a Sophos firewall after detection of suspicious traffic from the device. The investigation suggested the firewall was compromised via the internet-exposed User Portal component.  Researchers identified suspicious and repeated access targeting a valid JSP file (login.JSP). Further analysis of the firewall revealed that the threat actor established a webshell backdoor through modification of a legitimate component file. The threat actor utilized this webshell in order to establish multiple VPN user accounts and associated certificate pairs for legitimate network access persistence. The attacker also modified specific DNS responses on the compromised device to conduct Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) attacks targeting hostnames, which belonged to the victim organization.

The MITM attacks allowed the attacker to conduct credential and session cookie theft from administrative access to the websites' content management systems (CMS). Veloxity's investigation identified multiple instances of successful access, via legitimate session cookies, to the client's CMS admin pages attributed to the attacker. These sessions were used to upload a variation of the Weevely webshell. These webshells then were used to upload additional malware. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://www.volexity.com/blog/2022/06/15/driftingcloud-zero-day-sophos-firewall-exploitation-and-an-insidious-breach/](https://www.volexity.com/blog/2022/06/15/driftingcloud-zero-day-sophos-firewall-exploitation-and-an-insidious-breach/ "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
 T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure

 T1585 - Establish Accounts

 T1588 - Obtain Capabilities 

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

 T1133 - External Remote Services

 T1078 - Valid Accounts

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1569 - System Service

 T1133 - External Remote Services

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1133 - External Remote Services

 T1136 - Create Account

 T1133 - External Remote Services  

**Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
 T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts

 T1078 - Valid Account  
   T1078.004 - Cloud Accounts

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**

 T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
   T1078.001 - Token Impersonation/Theft

 T1055 - Process Injection  
   T1055.001 - Dynamic-link Library Injection

 T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
   T1070.004 - File Deletion  
   T1070.006 - Timestomp

**Credential Access - TA0006**  
 T1557 - Adversary-in-the-Middle

 T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1557 - Adversary-in-the-Middle

**Command and Control - TA0011**

 T1071- Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.001 - Web Protocols 

**Mitigations:**

**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1032:**  Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
**M1035:**  Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

Tell me about the following threat: SAP Security Patch Day - January 2021
The SAP Product Security Response Team has issued an advisory detailing the security vulnerabilities patched its latest release.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: SAP Security Patch Day - January 2021
The SAP Product Security Response Team has issued an advisory detailing the security vulnerabilities patched its latest release.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

 A total of thirty-two vulnerabilities were patched in this release. Issues resolved include code injection, privilege escalation, denial of service, missing authorization check, information disclosure, header manipulation, cross-site scripting, missing encryption, improper input validation, and XML external entity vulnerabilities. We recommend reviewing the advisory linked in the Reference section for further details and allocating testing time prior to updating production systems.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [SAP Security Patch DAy - January 2021 CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35720108/SAP%20Security%20Patch%20DAy%20-%20January%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1610638060866&api=v2)



# Protection

  * CVE-2021-21447: Cross_Site_Scripting
  * CVE-2021-21465: SQL_Injection



# Recommendations

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Bitcoin Addresses Revealed in Phishing Malware Attack Along with Agent Tesla Variant
A new phishing campaign is making the rounds with trojanized Excel documents executing scripts. Fortinet describes how these phishing emails and scripts are being used to reveal bitcoin addresses and install a new variant of Agent Tesla.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

Fortinet reports on a new phishing campaign designed to reveal bitcoin addresses and install a new variant of Agent Tesla. The software being installed is available for $40 on underground forums and marketplaces. The excel file being used as a transport mechanism is attached to an email that contains fake quotation information. The document itself appears blank with worksheets hidden within the document. A password protected VBA project is included and is called upon closing of the document by the intended victim. Two user forms are present with the string "ERROR" presented upon closing. The second form executes code and runs a command-line script. Using several redirects, the malicious code is delivered. The script downloads PowerShell files to deliver Agent Tesla. Additionally, the script is used to add numerous items to the Auto-Run portion of the Registry. A scheduled task is also created at this point. The bitcoin address is obtained via a second VBScript code. The location of the bitcoin address is revealed to the attacker in the form of a response to scripted tasks. The bitcoin address can then be modified in order to replace it with the attacker's address. Finally, all Microsoft Excel and Word processes are killed. Agent Tesla then goes to work gathering sensitive information from a list of pre-defined sources such as credentials from specific applications, a list of which is included in the source article. Cookies are collected from browsers, the system clipboard is dumped, and a key logger is installed and sends back victim keystrokes. Data is sent to the attacker via C2 server over SMTP, FTP, or HTTP. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/phishing-malware-hijacks-bitcoin-addresses-delivers-new-agent-tesla-variant>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Trickbot masrv Module
Trickbot has been continuously evolving despite efforts to shut down the botnet. Kryptos Logic uncovered one of its most recent developments, a module that incorporates Masscan for network scanning.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Kryptos Logic posted their analysis of a new Trickbot module named masrv. The module is delivered as a DLL and executed via its Start and Control export functions. The available commands allow for configuration settings to be obtained, a required library to be installed, and results to be sent to the attacker. Masscan is the open-source tool incorporated to perform the scanning activities. It is able to perform scans based on IP address and port ranges. If the required Npcap library is not present on the victim host, it is downloaded from the C2 server. The researchers were unable to pull down the configuration used by the attacker at the time of research. The blog post notes that there was a function and hard coded IP addresses located in the module's code that indicate a connection to Anchor and Bazar, although it is not necessarily surprising to see a threat actor sharing code between their tools. For more information, see the Kryptos Logic blog post in the Reference section. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Protection

## Yara Rule
    
    
    rule Trickbot__masrvDll  
    {  
    meta:  
    id = "4kWjG0InTDyHiur8cCzPeG"  
    fingerprint = "3e91c19602340a43e026ffdb23b1d6a0c4e186d67f743e962c75aa51ea0c4d1c"  
    version = "1.0"  
    first_imported = "2021-01-29"  
    last_modified = "2021-01-29"  
    status = "RELEASED"  
    sharing = "TLP:WHITE"  
    source = "KRYPTOS LOGIC"  
    description = "Detects Trickbot masrvDll module"  
    category = "MALWARE"  
    malware = "BOT"  
      
    strings:  
    $a = "<http://127.0.0.1:8080/gid/uid/pcap.exe>"  
    $b = "c:\\\\temp\\\\maserv.txt"  
    $c = "Send cmd to server: %s\\r\\n"  
    $d = "HTTP message success: URI=%s DATA=%.*s\\r\\n"  
      
    condition:  
    all of them  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.kryptoslogic.com/blog/2021/02/trickbot-masrv-module/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Blogspot Serves as a COVID-19 Scamming Hotspot
While tracking COVID-19 related campaigns, Netskope identified a scam claiming to provide relief packages in order to obtain ad revenue from visitors to the sites, many of which were hosted on Blogspot.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Blogspot Serves as a COVID-19 Scamming Hotspot
While tracking COVID-19 related campaigns, Netskope identified a scam claiming to provide relief packages in order to obtain ad revenue from visitors to the sites, many of which were hosted on Blogspot.

# Threat Type

  * Scam




# Overview

Netskope reported on a COVID-19 scam campaign that has been active since April 2020 and is targeting a number of different countries. In a some cases, the operators of the campaign registered their own domains; however, most of the scam sites were hosted on Blogspot. Across all of the sites, the same template was used for the site design, allowing the operators to easily stand up new sites on other domains or cloud services as needed. Changes to the template were made in order to target different countries and currencies. Once the site was created, it was distributed to potential victims via Facebook and WhatsApp. Visiting the link leads to a questionnaire to identify eligibility. After completing the questionnaire, victims are asked to share a message with WhatsApp groups in order to receive the payment. The legitimacy of the campaign is reinforced by Facebook comments from fake users claiming they received their payment. After sharing the message 10 times, the victim is redirected to a page that requests their bank account number to finalize the transfer. The researchers note that the bank account numbers are neither stored nor exfiltrated. Instead, victims are redirected to a website serving unwanted ads, allowing the operators to collect ad revenue. Pivoting off the source code in the initially identified sites, Netskope was able to discover references to Blogspot profiles hosting multiple similar scams. For more information, see the Netskope blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.netskope.com/blog/blogspot-serves-as-a-covid-19-scamming-hotspot>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Increased SideCopy Activity Targeting India
Cisco Talos is reporting an increase in activity by the SideCopy APT group. The target of the activity is Indian government personnel.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The SideCopy APT group has been active since 2019 and has primarily targeted India. Cisco Talos is reporting an increase in SideCopy activity targeting Indian government personnel. While SideCopy's infection chain continues to start with emails containing a LNK file, the infection chain has become more convoluted with an increased number of stages and delivering a number of different payloads. Documents and LNK files used to lure victims are often presented as internal documents of the Indian Army. In some cases, the lures use a honeytrap technique, LNK files that display explicit images of women. The current infection chain is composed of the LNK file which leads to an HTA that in turn provides a loader DLL. The DLL loads another HTA leading to either a dropper or actual payload. The payloads, a variety of bespoke and commodity malware, includes CetaRAT, DetaRAT, ReverseRAT, MargulasRAT, Allakore, ActionRAT, Lilith RAT, EpicenterRAT, and Nodachi. Two keyloggers, Xeytan and Lavao, and a number of plugins, including browser credential stealers are also used. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2021/07/sidecopy.html>

  * <https://talosintelligence.com/resources/257>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: RedLine Stealer Disguised as a Windows 11 Upgrade
With the recent release of Windows 11, HP has uncovered a threat actor using a fake installer to distribute the RedLine stealer.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** RedLine
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake Windows 11 installer
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data and credential theft 



# Overview

HP published a blog post analyzing a RedLine stealer campaign using a fake Windows update installer to distribute its payload. The fake site is hosted on a domain appearing to be related to Windows updates and uses content copied from the legitimate Windows 11 website. If users attempt to download the installer from this site, a ZIP file hosted on Discord is downloaded to the victim's system. Within the ZIP archive are several DLLs, an XML file, and a PE file. The PE file is padded with arbitrary data, likely to evade sandboxes and antivirus software. Upon execution, a PowerShell command is executed that spawns a cmd.exe process to perform a timeout. After this timeout, the RedLine stealer payload is downloaded from a remote server and executed. Any stolen data, such as browser credentials, cryptocurrency wallets, and credit card data, is exfiltrated back to a C2 server over TCP. The HP researchers note similarities to another RedLine stealer campaign distributing the payload via a fake Discord app installer. For more information, see the HP blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058737/RedLine%20Stealer%20Disguised%20as%20a%20Windows%2011%20Upgrade%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645042342707&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://threatresearch.ext.hp.com/redline-stealer-disguised-as-a-windows-11-upgrade/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.001 - Binary Padding  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

With the recent release of Windows 11, HP has uncovered a threat actor using a fake installer to distribute the RedLine stealer.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ares: Kronos Banking Trojan Evolved
Zscaler reports on a new variant of the Kronos Banking Trojan dubbed Ares. Though still in development, this addition to the trojan provides new capabilities as explained in the article.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ares: Kronos Banking Trojan Evolved
Zscaler reports on a new variant of the Kronos Banking Trojan dubbed Ares. Though still in development, this addition to the trojan provides new capabilities as explained in the article.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan




# Overview

Kronos, around since 2014, has undergone changes throughout its history. Now word comes about the latest upgrade to the trojan, Ares. Ares is malware with new capabilities such as information exfiltration. Ares is used in conjunction with another variant dubbed Osiris. The two malwares utilize a packer written in C++ called DarkCrypter. This version of DarkCrypter should not be confused with the commercially available packer, also called DarkCrypter. In the new variant, the first 41 strings match older Kronos variants as well as the addition of eight new strings to detect analysis tools such as sandboxes. There are, at the time of this writing, two versions of the packer. The first decrypts using Blowfish. The key size for this decryption is not the standard Blowfish size - 4 through 56 bytes vs. 288 byte fixed length. The second variant uses an embedding technique that uses a compressed format rather than Blowfish encryption. This compression algorithm is identical to Ares. The packer shows itself to be a bitmap image header. This is an obvious ruse and can be seen in photos within the article. Additionally, the actor behind the malware uses BMPack, so named by Zscaler. This packer uses an XOR-based algorithm as well as RC4. Upon decryption, the file appears as a static bitmap. Each structure within the decompressed file holds a different section of a PE file that is stitched together by a custom loader and is, subsequently, executed. Ares itself is under development as evidenced by the constant testing of new plugins and web injects. An embedded DLL module is compressed and placed within the binary. An export is loaded and used to establish persistence by creating a scheduled task that executes every two hours. Though sharing most of the code with Kronos and Osiris, there are several differences. At present, most of the samples of Ares do not communicate with a C2 over TOR. The removal of the TOR component could be used to reduce the malware size. The Ares stealer attempts to extract information from FTP clients, VPN clients, web browsers, cryptocurrency wallets applications, instant messenger clients, and email clients. Ares supports the commands as Kronos and Osiris though some commands have been modified. Further technical details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/ares-malware-grandson-kronos-banking-trojan>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Anubis Malware Being Distributed in the Wild
Infostealing malware, first observed in June 2020, has been deployed in the wild, according to Microsoft Security Intelligence.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer




# Overview

Microsoft Security Intelligence has reported on a new info-stealing malware first observed in the cybercriminal underground that is now being seen in the wild. The malware, called Anubis, uses forked code from Loki to steal vast amounts of data including system info, credentials, credit card details, and cryptocurrency wallets such as Bitcoin and Electrum. This malware should not be confused with the Android banking malware also named Anubis. At present, the new Anubis is being deployed in limited campaigns and contains only a handful of download URLs and C2 servers. This malware uses a text file to exfiltrate data from the victim. Further information will be passed as it is received. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * [https://twitter.com/MsftSecIntel/status/1298752223321546754](https://twitter\[.\]com/MsftSecIntel/status/1298752223321546754)

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Adobe Document Cloud Phishing Campaign
Document sharing services are increasingly being impersonated in order to harvest credentials. In one such case analyzed by Cofense in a recent blog post, Adobe Document Cloud is the targeted service.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published a blog post analyzing a phishing email using an Adobe Document Cloud lure. The email originates from a Gmail account and claims to be from a government agency, providing legitimate contact details to support this. Attached, is what the body of the email states, is a purchase order that can be accessed via Adobe Document Cloud login or by downloading the latest version of Adobe Acrobat Reader, hoping they'll opt for the easier login choice. Opening the attachment results in an HTML page stored locally that gathers its resources from the legitimate Adobe website. After bypassing a popup stating that the document is electronically encrypted and requires the recipient to log in with their email to view, they are directed to a fake Adobe Document Cloud sign in page. Any submitted credentials are exfiltrated to a remote URL controlled by the attacker. Finally, the victim is redirected to the legitimate Adobe Acrobat webpage. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/document-sharing-services-represent-a-vector-for-phishing-campaigns/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Three Quarters of Infusion Pumps Vulnerable To Attack
Unit 42 has done a study of available data on over 200,000 infusion pumps on hospital networks. They found a large number of vulnerable devices, showing that the healthcare sector needs to have a focus on security as devices become more connected.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Three Quarters of Infusion Pumps Vulnerable To Attack
Unit 42 has done a study of available data on over 200,000 infusion pumps on hospital networks. They found a large number of vulnerable devices, showing that the healthcare sector needs to have a focus on security as devices become more connected.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Targets:** Hospital Infusion Pumps
  *  **Vulnerability Type:** Denial of Service, Unauthorized Access



# Overview

Unit 42 has done an in-depth study on the state of security in the healthcare sector. Specifically, in connected devices that are accessible over the internet. The study looked at results from open-source scans of over 200,000 infusion pumps on hospital networks. They found that 75% of the infusion pumps that were scanned had known security issues. Together, the pumps represented almost 40 different known security vulnerabilities, as well as almost 70 other known security issues commonly found in IoT devices. A more alarming statistic was that over 50% of the pumps were vulnerable to two known vulnerabilities that were rated 'critical' and 'high' severity. The majority of vulnerabilities were found to be related to sensitive information leakage. There were also several vulnerabilities that would allow a malicious actor to take a device offline, or give them unauthorized access to the device. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Three Quarter of Infusion Pumps Vulnerable To Attack CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/81134349/Three%20Quarter%20of%20Infusion%20Pumps%20Vulnerable%20To%20Attacl%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1646836892040&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).



# References

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/infusion-pump-vulnerabilities/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1195 - Supply Chain Compromise  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1489 - Service Stop  
T1495 - Firmware Corruption  
T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service  
T1565 - Data Manipulation

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Shuckworm Group Continues To Carry Out Cyber-Espionage Attacks Against Ukraine
The Russia-linked Shuckworm group (aka Gamaredon, Armageddon, and tracked by IBM as hive0051) has continued to conduct targeted cyberintelligence operations against state bodies of Ukraine. Symantec observed Shuckworm activity between July 14, 2021, and August 18, 2021, on an organization in Ukraine. In their blog, Symantec shares a breakdown of the attacker's activity.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Espionage
  *  **Targets:** State Bodies of Ukraine
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Pterodo/Pteranodon 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Maldocs
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Symantec’s Threat Hunter Team, a part of Broadcom Software, observed activity coming out of the Shuckworm group between July 14, 2021, and August 18, 2021. Symantec has provided a breakdown of the attacker's activity which includes the use of freely available remote access tools such as UltraVNC or Remote Manipulator System (RMS), as well as customized malware called Pterodo/Pteranodon. The group is known to send malicious documents via phishing emails. In the observed activity, the Shuckworm group utilized a number of malicious VBS script files. The Security Service of Ukraine (SSU) noted the use of living-off-the-land tools to steal credentials and move laterally on victim networks. Recent activity seen by Symantec is consistent with that documented by SSU. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058219/Shuckworm%20Group%20Continues%20To%20Carry%20Out%20Cyber-Espionage%20Attacks%20Against%20Ukraine%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644019370477&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files (M1038).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/shuckworm-gamaredon-espionage-ukraine>
  * <https://www.broadcom.com/support/security-center/protection-bulletin>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583.002 - DNS Server  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1218.005 - Mshta  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.005 - VNC  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Apple Security Updates March 8 2021
Apple has published security updates for Safari, macOS Big Sur, watchOS, iOS and iPadOS. The updates all address the same, single vulnerability, in WebKit.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Apple has published security updates for Safari, macOS Big Sur, watchOS, iOS and iPadOS. All the updates address a single vulnerability in WebKit, CVE-2021-1844. The vulnerability is caused by a memory corruption issue. A remote attacker, who could convince users to open maliciously crafted web content, could potentially execute arbitrary code on an affected system. Updating to Safari 14.0.3, macOS Big Sur 11.2.3, watchOS 7.3.2, iOS 14.4.1, and iPadOS 14.4.1, mitigates the vulnerability.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-1844 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201222>

  * <https://support.apple.com/kb/HT212223>

  * <https://support.apple.com/kb/HT212220>

  * <https://support.apple.com/kb/HT212222>

  * <https://support.apple.com/kb/HT212221>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: VMware Vulnerability PoC Released
A vulnerability within vCenter Server and another in VMWare ESXi has led to a proof of concept being released showing the ability to exploit unpatched systems. A report from Tenable provides information on the PoC and the vulnerabilities as well as associated patches.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerabilities




# Overview

Remote code execution and mass scanning capabilities have been shown effective in a proof-of-concept released publicly. The vulnerabilities are particularly dangerous given the possible repercussions. They were discovered and disclosed by a security researcher at Positive Technologies. CVE-2021-21972 is an unauthorized file upload vulnerability in the vCenter Server software. With a CVSSv3 score of 9.8 of 10, the vulnerability is critical. If exploited, an unauthenticated, remote attacker could upload a crafted file to the server which is publicly accessible through port 443. This, subsequently, can result in the unrestricted RCE privileges. The default installation of vCenter Server contains the exact plugin that contains the vulnerability. At present, more than 6,700 of these servers are publicly accessible. A second vulnerability in the aforementioned CVE is the capability for mass scanning. This capability was found within a day of the release of the advisory publication. Other vulnerabilities found include CVE-2021-21973, which is a Server Side Request Forgery and CVE-2021-21974, a heap overflow vulnerability which exists in VMware ESXi. Within GitHub, 4 proofs-of-concept scripts were publicly available. On February 23, 2021, VMware released patches for the vulnerable servers. We recommend applying those patches immediately to avoid exploitation. Further technical details of the vulnerabilities and their associated proofs-of-concept can be found within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/42434599/VMware%20Vulnerability%20PoC%20Released%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1614269954818&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.tenable.com/blog/cve-2021-21972-vmware-vcenter-server-remote-code-execution-vulnerability>
  * <https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/collection/VMware-Security-Advisory-VMSA-2021-0002-3ca45f882ceb9244b67a96e8f2923e7c>
  * <https://www.zdnet.com/article/more-than-6700-vmware-servers-exposed-online-and-vulnerable-to-major-new-bug/>

  * <https://swarm.ptsecurity.com/unauth-rce-vmware/#more-2477>
  * <https://github.com/NS-Sp4ce/CVE-2021-21972>
  * <https://github.com/QmF0c3UK/CVE-2021-21972-vCenter-6.5-7.0-RCE-POC>
  * <https://github.com/horizon3ai/CVE-2021-21972>
  * <https://github.com/yaunsky/CVE-2021-21972>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: WeTransfer Phishing Campaign
In a recent phishing campaign identified by Cofense, attackers are attempting to steal WeTransfer or single sign-on (SSO) credentials from victims.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing a WeTransfer phishing campaign. WeTransfer is a free cloud services allowing users to share files. The phishing email claims that the recipient has received files via WeTransfer and must download them from a provided link before it expires. The sender of the email is spoofed so that to the user it appears it came from the legitimate WeTransfer domain, but a closer look at the header indicates that it is not the true source of the email. Visiting the link leads to a fake WeTransfer page, using a similar layout and branding to the legitimate version of the page. As with the legitimate service, WeTransfer credentials are requested, along with alternative login options for Apple, Google, and Slack single sign-on (SSO). Providing credentials leads to the exfiltration of the data to the attacker rather than the expected download of the files. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/document-wetransfer-phish/>
