instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Android Banking Trojan Campaigns
Multiple campaigns that deploy Android banking Trojans through fake apps that have been available on the Google Play store have resulted in more than 300K infections according to a report from ThreatFabric.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware - Banking Trojans and Information Stealers.
  *  **Targets:** Bank and Financial institution customers globally.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Alien, Anatsa, Brunhilda, Ermac, Gymdrop, and Hydra. 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake apps
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Android banking Trojans that have been deployed through fake apps on the Google Play store are the subject of a report from ThreatFabric. According to the report, the apps collectively target more than 700 banks and financial institutions globally and are responsible for more than 300K infections. The apps use many techniques to evade detection, in some cases the actual payload is delivered using an update to the app, post-installation. In other cases, the actors behind an app may not activate the actual banking Trojan until they require more victims in a given geography. The apps may use a number of techniques to evade detection including those to bypass time-based, de-obfuscation, and server-side emulation checking, as well as location checks. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155502/Android%20Banking%20Trojan%20Campaigns%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638423702510&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://www.threatfabric.com/blogs/deceive-the-heavens-to-cross-the-sea.html#appendix-targeted-apps>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1475 - Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means

T1401 - Device Administrator Permissions  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
T1406 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1407 - Download New Code at Runtime  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1523 - Evade Analysis Environment  
T1581 - Geofencing  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0031**  
T1414 - Capture Clipboard Data  
T1417 - Input Capture  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1417 - Input Capture  
T1513 - Screen Capture  
T1533 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0036**  
T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Yanluowang Ransomware Is Now Code-Signed
Trend Micro have investigated some samples of a new ransomware named Yanluowang. They discovered that these samples were code-signed, and included the ability to disable backup and database processes to increase the severity of the ransomware attack.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Yanluowang
  *  **Targets:** United States Corporations
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Encryption, Ransom



# Overview

Trend Micro has discovered samples of the new ransomware known as "Yanluowang", which are code-signed with a valid signature. This ransomware was recently discovered and seems to be targeting US corporations from at least August 2021. It is currently unknown how this ransomware initially infects systems, but Trend Micro speculates that it would be executed via RDP, due to the requirement for certain arguments upon execution. The fact that these samples are code-signed allows the ransomware to appear legitimate to the victim's machine, enabling it to bypass some security measures. Upon execution, the ransomware encrypts files in specified filepaths before dropping the ransomware note. It also terminates processes associated with managing and backing up databases using the Windows API. Finally, it forcefully terminates any virtual machines that are running on the host. For more information, please see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056215/Yanluowang%20Ransomware%20Is%20Now%20Code-Signed%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639654165236&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/l/yanluowang-ransomware-code-signed-terminates-database-processes.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1587.002 - Code Signing Certificates  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: NVIDIA Security Bulletin - November 10th, 2020
NVIDIA published a security bulletin addressing a vulnerability in its NVIDIA GeForce NOW software for Windows.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: NVIDIA Security Bulletin - November 10th, 2020
NVIDIA published a security bulletin addressing a vulnerability in its NVIDIA GeForce NOW software for Windows.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 This vulnerability, CVE‑2020‑5992, results from a vulnerability in the OpenSSL library, which is a software dependency for the application. The OpenSSL library is vulnerable to binary planting attacks by a local user. If successfully exploited, an attacker my be able to execute code or escalate privileges. All versions prior to 2.0.25.119 are vulnerable and a update has been released that fixes the issue. We recommend reviewing the security advisory and applying any applicable updates as soon as possible.  
  


# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [NVIDIA Security Bulletin - November 10th CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982469/NVIDIA%20Security%20Bulletin%20-%20November%2010th%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605281452936&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://nvidia.custhelp.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/5096>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Winston Privacy Vulnerabilities
Winston Privacy Version 1.5.4 is affected by eight vulnerabilities, their advisory indicates. Winston Privacy device is a device that removes URL tracking and blocks ads.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Winston Privacy Vulnerabilities
Winston Privacy Version 1.5.4 is affected by eight vulnerabilities, their advisory indicates. Winston Privacy device is a device that removes URL tracking and blocks ads.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Winston Privacy has issued an advisory identifying eight vulnerabilities that include command injection, cross-site request forgery, improper access controls, insecure cross-origin resource sharing, insufficient authorization, default credentials, and undocumented SSH service. Successful exploitation includes potential code execution, information disclosure, device settings alteration, escalation of privileges, denial of service, and vendor remote access. Updating to version 1.5.8 firmware addresses these issues. According to the advisory, firmware updates default to automatic updates.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: 



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://labs.bishopfox.com/advisories/winston-privacy-version-1.5.4>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: MyloBot Botnet Being Used To Send Extortion Emails
MyloBot is a sophisticated and highly evasive botnet that was first seen in 2018. Minerva Labs researchers have analyzed the newest version of this malware and discovered that it is currently only being used to send extortion emails. The changes seen in the malware have been published in the following report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Botnet
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** MyloBot **  
**
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Extortion Email



# Overview

Minerva Labs have analyzed the latest version of the MyloBot botnet. This malware was first seen in 2018, and is known for using many sophisticated evasion techniques to avoid detection and analysis. In the latest version, it appears that some of these evasion techniques are no longer in use. The first stage of this malware uses anti-debugging techniques using custom exception filters to avoid analysis, and loads an encrypted executable into memory and decodes it. It performs further anti-virtual machine checks and attempts to disable any other malware that may be using the registry for persistence. The malware then gains persistence using the registry and continues the attack. The final stage payload is used to send extortion emails from the victim machine, asking for $2732 in bitcoin. Although this is currently all the campaign is doing, the final stage also seems that it can download additional files, meaning that the botnet may be used as a backdoor in future attacks. for further information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058891/MyloBot%20Botnet%20Being%20Used%20To%20Send%20Extortion%20Emails%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645025808043&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.minerva-labs.com/mylobot-2022-so-many-evasive-techniques-just-to-send-extortion-emails>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1543.003 - Windows Service  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Phishing Campaign Spoofing Mimecast
In an attempt to use inherent trust related to secure email gateways (SEGs), a phishing campaign discovered by Cofense spoofs Mimecast to steal credentials.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense published a blog post regarding a phishing campaign mimicking Mimecast, a secure email gateway (SEG). The phishing email claims that the user's account is almost full and they must log in to extend their disk capacity or risk losing future emails. The link in the body of the email is a Google redirect link, allowing the attacker to hide their phishing page behind a legitimate site. The redirect chain eventually leads to a convincing fake Mimecast login page. Entered credentials are exfiltrated to the attacker while the page refreshes, regardless of the number of attempted logins. It is worth noting the redirects and landing pages involve the use other other legitimate services, such as Microsoft Dynamics and IBM Cloud, reducing the chances of detection; however, Cofense observed these pages being taken down relatively quickly. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/miming-mimecast/>

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/miming-mimecast/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Unexpected Sign-In Attempt Phishing
Several companies across the US, England, and Scotland are reporting a targeted phishing campaign attempting to obtain corporate email account credentials. Cofense reports on their analysis of this campaign.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Unexpected Sign-In Attempt Phishing
Several companies across the US, England, and Scotland are reporting a targeted phishing campaign attempting to obtain corporate email account credentials. Cofense reports on their analysis of this campaign.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published their analysis of a phishing campaign seen targeting organizations in English-speaking countries. The phishing emails are customized using the organization's name in various aspects to appear more legitimate. It is used in the "From" field as part of the sender address, the subject line and in various parts of the email body. The email claims that there was a sign in attempt from a suspicious location and points to an attached file that can be used to review that activity. Opening the attached HTML file leads to a fake sign in page for the company's mail portal, requesting their email address and password. Cofense notes that the images and CSS styles are pulled from a remote website. Entering the credentials results in a POST request to an attacker-controlled URL. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/101-credential-phishing-for-observant-employees/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Korplug Variant Spread Via Phishing Lures
ESET researchers have uncovered a new variant of Korplug, named Hodur. This is being spread by Mustang Panda using phishing lures referencing the invasion of Ukraine.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Spyware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Mustang Panda
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Korplug, Hodur
  *  **Targets:** Diplomatic missions, ISPs, Research entities
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing



# Overview

ESET researchers have been tracking a new variant of Korplug they are calling Hodur. This is being spread by the threat actors Mustang Panda via a phishing campaign. The campaign dates to at least August 2021 and is ongoing. The phishing lures are continually updated and reference current affairs such as COVID-19 restrictions and the invasion of Ukraine. Targets of this campaign are mostly located in East and Southeast Asia with a focus on Mongolia, and the industries targeted include diplomatic missions, ISPs, and research entities. The malicious attachment downloads a legitimate executable, a malicious module, and an encrypted Korplug file. Using DLL search hijacking, the malicious module is executed using the legitimate executable, which then decrypts and executes the payload. for more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/03/23/mustang-panda-hodur-old-tricks-new-korplug-variant/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.003 - Virtual Private Server  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588.006 - Vulnerabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1106 - Native API  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.005 - Indicator Removal from Tools  
T1036.004 - Masquerade Task or Service  
T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
T1055.001 - Dynamic-link Library Injection  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1070.006 - Timestomp  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1564.001 - Hidden Files and Directories  
T1564.003 - Hidden Window  
T1620 - Reflective Code Loading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1025 - Data from Removable Media  
T1039 - Data from Network Shared Drive  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1008 - Fallback Channels  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1132.001 - Standard Encoding  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TurboTax Files Targeted by Mount Locker Ransomware
Bleeping Computer reports on Vitali Kremez's Twitter post about Mount Locker Ransomware targeting TurboTax .tax files.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Advanced Intel's Vitali Kremez has published a Twitter post on Mount Locker ransomware targeting TurboTax files in preparation ahead of tax season. Threat actors are targeting .tax, .tax2009, .tax2013, and .tax2014 files. These extensions are specific to TurboTax. The latest version only targets these files, as far as researchers can ascertain at this point. Kremez states that it seems odd that only specific year returns are being targeted; however, the .tax string would match any other extensions containing that string. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

  * Backup any sensitive tax documents to detachable media and remove the media from computers to ensure the recovery of information. 



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/mount-locker-ransomware-now-targets-your-turbotax-tax-returns/>

  * [https://twitter.com/VK_Intel/status/1329472284889919490](https://twitter\[.\]com/VK_Intel/status/1329472284889919490)

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Recent Supply Chain Attacks
A blog post from Trend Micro details two examples of supply chain attacks as observed by their managed detection and response (MDR) team.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Supply Chain Attack (T1195.002)



 _Attack 1_ **:**

  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** REvil Ransomware (S0496)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Kaseya VSA supply chain
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Ransomware deployment
  *  **Additional TTPs:** DLL sideloading (T1574.002), PowerShell (T1059.001), Certutil (S0160)



 _Attack 2:_

  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Cobalt Strike Beacon (S0154)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Desktop Central agents
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Shell code execution, likely Cobalt Strike Beacon
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Use of GO simple tunnel, persistence via scheduled tasks (T1053.005), PowerShell (T1059.001)



# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post providing an overview of two supply chain attacks that their managed detection and response (MDR) team responded to. The first incident was part of the Kaseya VSA supply chain attack. In this case, the Kaseya agent was used to spawn cmd.exe. This was used to disable Windows Defender, create a copy of certutil, and use it to decode a payload file. The payload was then used to create a version of Windows Defender that is vulnerable to DLL side-loading. Finally, a ransomware payload was deployed. The second incident involved the use of a Desktop Central agent to deploy malware across an environment. A series of executables were used in this case to ultimately execute shell code in memory. This shell code reached out to a remote server, but the server was down at the time of investigation so the follow-on actions are unknown. Analysis of the main executable indicated it was likely a Cobalt Strike Beacon Malleable C&C stager. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59540690/Recent%20Supply%20Chain%20Attacks%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1628622486327&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/h/supply-chain-attacks-from-a-managed-detection-and-response-persp.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Verblecon - A New Loader
A report from Symantec looks at a new loader they describe as sophisticated being used in low-level attacks to install cryptominers and potentially steal Discord tokens.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Verblecon
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration, Cryptomining.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Symantec has reported a new loader named Verblecon they describe as complex and powerful and being used in low-level attacks. The attacks are described as unsophisticated and low-reward. No information is provided on how the malware is being distributed to victims which Symantec described as mostly non-enterprise systems. Verblecon itself is loaded as a server-side JAR file and is polymorphic making it appear different each time it is downloaded. When executed, Verblecon checks that it is not being debugged or run in a virtual machine or sandbox. It then collects information about the system and communicates it to a C&C server. A payload is then downloaded in the form of binary blobs which are decrypted, executed, and injected into dllhost.exe using com.sun.jna. The objective of that attacks appears to be cryptomining but may also involve attempts to steal Discord tokens. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Aggah Campaign Using Zendesk and GitHub to Host Malicious Files
Juniper Threat Labs has reported an Aggah malware campaign that, instead of using the likes of BlogSpot, Pastebin, and WordPress to host its malicious files, is using GitHub and Zendesk.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified ****
  * **Malware Family/Families:** Oski, Agent Tesla (S0331)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious PowerPoint file, delivery vector not specified.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and Exfiltration of sensitive data.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Aggah malware campaigns have in the past been known to host malicious content on legitimate services such as BlogSpot, Pastebin, and WordPress. According to a report from Juniper Threat Labs, an Aggah campaign is now using Github and Zendesk to host malicious files. Juniper analyzed a malicious PowerPoint file that was downloaded from Zendesk. The file contained a macro that used mshta.exe to download and execute a malicious script from Blogspot. One of the operations the script carries out is to add a registry run key that is used to trigger the download of another PowerShell script that contains the Oski infostealer. Another PowerShell script that is downloaded from GitHub installs the Agent Tesla infostealer and RAT. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127356/Aggah%20Campaign%20Using%20Zendesk%20and%20GitHub%20to%20Host%20Malicious%20Files%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631162647868&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/security/aggah-malware-campaign-expands-to-zendesk-and-github-to-host-its-malware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1585 - Establish Accounts  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1546 - Event Triggered Execution  
T1546.003 - Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.005 - Mshta  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1115 - Clipboard Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: OpenSSL Security Advisory March 2021
A Security Advisory for OpenSSL that addresses two vulnerabilities has been published by the OpenSSL Software Foundation. Both of the vulnerabilities have been rated as being of High severity.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Two vulnerabilities have been addressed in a new version of OpenSSL, version 1.1.1k. Both the vulnerabilities have been rated as High by the OpenSSL Software Foundation. One of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-3449) could allow a remote attacker to cause a denial of service condition by sending a maliciously crafted renegotiation ClientHello message from a client. All versions of OpenSSL 1.1.1 are affected by the vulnerability. The other vulnerability (CVE-2021-3450) could allow for a failure to reject certain invalid certificates. OpenSSL versions from 1.1.1h onwards are affected by this issue. Further information is available from the OpenSSL security advisory linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-344, CVE-2021-3450




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.openssl.org/news/secadv/20210325.txt>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New npm Malware With Bladabindi Trojan Spotted
Analysts at Sonatype recently unveiled updated malware within the npm registry, combining typosquatting packages with njRAT.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Over the Thanksgiving holiday, Sonatype discovered two malicious npm packages named jdb.js and db-json.js. According to the analyst, jdb.js contains the credential stealing RAT, njRAT. The npm package contained three files and conducts multiple malicious activities such as: data gathering, reconnaissance, and launching patch.exe which is the njRAT dropper. Before C2 communication is initiated, the malicious executable edits Windows firewall rules to avoid connection and communication issues. The db-json.js package eludes malicious intention by appearing to be a safe and legitimate JSON DB creation package but works in conjunction with the jdb.js package. According to the analyst, what was even more interesting, was the effective implementation of the db-json.js package. After infecting the desired target, the end-user’s machine is then open to a multitude of nefarious acts, granting the attacker the ability to, log keystrokes, alter registry values, inaugurate system shutdown, initially granting a level of C2 to the attacker. Furthermore, putting developers at risk who may be unaware of the malware. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sonatype.com/bladabindi-njrat-rat-in-jdb.js-npm-malware>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Toolset of Threat Actor IAmTheKing
A report from Kaspersky provides information on a threat actor they believe is state-sponsored and have named IAmTheKing. The report provides an outline of the malware families the actor is known to have been using, one of which is named SlothfulMedia.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

KingOfHearts, QueenOfHearts, QueenOfClubs (older variants of this malware family are known as SlothfulMedia), and JackOfHearts, are malware families used by the actor Kaspersky has named IAmTheKing. Kaspersky notes in their report that IAmTheKing has been active for some years and believes the actor to be state-sponsored. The KingOfHearts, which comes in DLL and EXE variants, is a backdoor with basic features. Traces of the malware can be found as far back as 2014. It is believed to have been distributed using malicious documents contained in spear-phishing emails. The KingOfHearts includes routines to detect debugging and virtualized environments. Communications with its C&C servers is carried out over HTTP(S). The QueenOfHearts probably appeared in 2014 and is more widespread than, but very similar to, the KingOfHearts; however, it does not include the anti-analysis routines. It is still being actively developed and communicates with its C&C server over HTTP. The QueenOfClubs is also similar to the KingOfHearts and has a number of links to the QueenOfHearts. The QueenOfClubs provides the ability to launch arbitrary PowerShell scripts. The JackOfHearts is a dropper and used to install the QueenOfHearts. Once a foothold has been attained inside a network, the attackers attempt to move laterally. In the past, IAmTheKing has targeted Russian entities including those in government, defence, development, education, and energy sectors to gather intelligence. Kaspersky more recently observed IAmTheKing involved in attacks on Central Asian and Eastern European countries, and the US DHS reported on IAmTheKing activity in Malaysia and Ukraine. It is not clear whether these are isolated instances, a shift in targeting, or perhaps that the malware has been shared with other groups. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/iamtheking-and-the-slothfulmedia-malware-family/99000/>

It is not clear whether these are isolated instances, a shift in targeting, or perhaps that the malware has been shared with other groups. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/iamtheking-and-the-slothfulmedia-malware-family/99000/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: PLEASE_READ_ME: The Ransomware Devastating MySQL Servers
Researchers at Guardicore began analyzing and monitoring the ransomware campaign targeting MySQL database servers, dubbed PLEASE_READ_ME, and the double extortion tactics rendering the campaign more profitable and scalable.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware 




# Overview

Threat actors behind PLEASE_READ_ME ransomware continue to exploit and leverage double extortion tactics. According to researchers, since the beginning of the new year a total of 92 attacks have been reported from 11 different IP addresses throughout the UK. According to Guardicore, the initial start of the attack begins with password brute-force on the MySQL service. After that, the attacker processes a sequence of queries in the database, gathering data on existing tables and users automatically and with a unique token. Lastly, once the attacker has compromised the victim’s data, it’s sent to the attackers’ server, deleted from the database, and a ransom note demanding payment is generated to the victim.  In addition, threat actors behind the ransomware expose the victims compromised database in an efforts to entice payment. According to Guardicore, this double extortion tactic has proven to be effective, finding almost 83,000 databases previously compromised and 250,000 databases up for auction. In conclusion, Guardicore has assessed the ransomware campaign is untargeted with the intention to infect as many servers as possible, transitory because there is no lateral movement, and it’s simple, with only a script that has the capability to access a victim’s database, steal information and leaving ransom note. For more information, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.guardicore.com/labs/please-read-me-opportunistic-ransomware-devastating-mysql-servers/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Andariel Campaign Targeting South Korea Includes Ransomware
The Andariel APT group is believed to be a state-sponsored, financially motivated, sub-group of the well-known North Korean group, Lazarus. A report from Kasperksy provides information on a recent Andariel campaign targeting South Korea and which included ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Andariel Campaign Targeting South Korea Includes Ransomware
The Andariel APT group is believed to be a state-sponsored, financially motivated, sub-group of the well-known North Korean group, Lazarus. A report from Kasperksy provides information on a recent Andariel campaign targeting South Korea and which included ransomware.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Campaign, APT




# Overview

The Andariel APT group has been conducting a campaign targeting South Korean entities in the construction, home network service, manufacturing, and media sectors. Kasperksy mentions two infection vectors in their report, one being the use of weaponized Word documents. The second is less clear in that the vector could be either a malicious version of a PDF reader or a weaponized PDF. In both cases, a second-stage payload is delivered to the victim. The second stage payload communicates with the campaign's C&C servers. A third stage payload is delivered to selected victims, and in one case, custom-built ransomware was also installed. Kaspersky notes that Andariel has evolved its TTPs and the intention of this campaign was to deliver ransomware. The technical details are available from the Kaspersky report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/andariel-evolves-to-target-south-korea-with-ransomware/102811/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Infostealer Disguised as Well-Known Korean Web Portal File
A Kakao account phishing email led ASEC researchers to uncover an infostealer masquerading as a file related to Naver, a Korean web portal.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer, Phishing
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Infostealer
  *  **Targets:** Korean users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious URL in phishing email
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install malware, data theft



# Overview

ASEC published a blog post analyzing an infostealer discovered targeting Korean users. The file was discovered in connected with a phishing URL targeting Kakao account credentials. Visiting the root URL as opposed to the specific phishing page leads to the download of a ZIP archive. It masquerades as a Naver OTP tool for accessing the Korean web portal. While the fake application is displayed, in the background two malicious executables are dropped. Persistence is established via LNK files in the Startup folder. One of the executables is used for gathering system information and directory listings. The other is a keylogger. Data gathered by these two payloads is staged in a folder created by the malware and exfiltrated via a POST request to a remote server. For more information, see the ASEC blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057115/Infostealer%20Disguised%20as%20Well-Known%20Korean%20Web%20Portal%20File%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642529869094&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/30637/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: BRATA Now Targeting USA and Spain via Google Play
BRATA is an Android RAT and banking Trojan that has been distributed via Google Play to Brazilian users since 2018. McAfee recently observed a shift in targeting to include users in the USA and Spain.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: BRATA Now Targeting USA and Spain via Google Play
BRATA is an Android RAT and banking Trojan that has been distributed via Google Play to Brazilian users since 2018. McAfee recently observed a shift in targeting to include users in the USA and Spain.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Banking Trojan




# Overview

McAfee published a blog post on BRATA's recent updates and shift in targeting. Since 2018, the malware has only targeted users in Brazil; however, new variants have appeared in the Google Play store that include capabilities for targeting users in the US and Spain. The applications masquerade as security scanning apps. On installation, a fake scan is performed and, depending on the language of the device, a link to a supposed application is updated. Portuguese speakers are shown a PDF reader update, Spanish speakers are shown a WhatsApp update, and English speakers are shown a Google Chrome update. Regardless of the lure used, victims are provided instructions for allowing the application access to Accessibility Services. The malware then requests the user enter their pin in order to steal it for later use. A check-in to the C2 server is used to register the victim device, and in response the C2 server provides a list of targeted financial apps and the IP address and port for future C2 communication. The malware provides the attacker with a variety of remote access commands, such as screen capture, application launching, clipboard manipulation, and more. Additionally, if target financial apps are accessed, a phishing URL is used to steal banking credentials. The McAfee researchers also note the updated BRATA variant includes various new obfuscation and evasion techniques. For more information, see the McAfee blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.mcafee.com/blogs/other-blogs/mcafee-labs/brata-keeps-sneaking-into-google-play-now-targeting-usa-and-spain/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Mylobot Generates Large Number of DNS Requests
According to a report from Akamai, in early 2020, the Mylobot malware was generating up to 1.2 Billion DNS queries, per day.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Mylobot is a downloader that issues DNS requests, created by a domain generation algorithm, to locate its C&C servers. According to a report from Akamai, in early 2020, Mylobot DNS queries peaked at 1.2 Billion requests per day, reducing to between 200 and 400 Million requests per day later in the year. Akamai's traffic analysis of infected hosts communicating with the C&C servers suggests the number of infections at least doubled through 2020. There are four parts to the Mylobot download process. The first is the DNS query to obtain the IP address of a C&C server which in turn provides the location from which to download the second stage payload. The second stage payload is then downloaded and executed. The second stage payload in at least some cases is malware named Khalesi. There are four known variations to the DGA domain name patterns which are believed to be four different variants of Mylobot. Further details, including the formats of the domain names, are provided in the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.akamai.com/sitr/2021/01/detecting-mylobot-unseen-dga-based-malware-using-deep-learning.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Agent Tesla IoCs
A Rewterz report provides some IoCs that are associated with the Agent Tesla info-stealing malware and RAT that is being distributed in malspam.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Agent Tesla IoCs
A Rewterz report provides some IoCs that are associated with the Agent Tesla info-stealing malware and RAT that is being distributed in malspam.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Malspam




# Overview

The origin of the Agent Tesla RAT and info-stealing malware dates back to 2014 when it was first observed in the wild. Since then it has become one of the more commonly used info-stealing malware. Rewterz notes that Agent Tesla is typically delivered using malspam, often with COVID19 and WHO themes. The malspam emails are usually themed to appear to be from a legitimate organization with a compressed archive attached. The archive typically contains a malicious executable file masquerading as a PDF which, when executed, will install Agent Tesla. Data obtained by the malware is exfiltrated to a C&C server using SMTP. Further details can be found in the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Malspam




# Overview

The origin of the Agent Tesla RAT and info-stealing malware dates back to 2014 when it was first observed in the wild. Since then it has become one of the more commonly used info-stealing malware. Rewterz notes that Agent Tesla is typically delivered using malspam, often with COVID19 and WHO themes. The malspam emails are usually themed to appear to be from a legitimate organization with a compressed archive attached. The archive typically contains a malicious executable file masquerading as a PDF which, when executed, will install Agent Tesla. Data obtained by the malware is exfiltrated to a C&C server using SMTP. Further details can be found in the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Recent Sandworm Activity
Following up on ANSSI's research into recent Sandworm activity, DomainTools reports on their findings related to the infrastructure used by this threat actor.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

DomainTools has published a report identifying Sandworm infrastructure discovered during their investigation into ANSSI's recent report on the threat group. ANSSI's report discussed the exploitation of Centreon to deliver Exaramel, a known Sandworm tool. The report, however, did not detail any network indicators associated with this activity, causing DomainTools to dig further. They began by looking at the Exim exploitation campaign that the NSA reported on as occurring during an overlapping time period with the Centreon activity. The NSA report provided a few network indicators, specifically two IP addresses and a domain. Pivoting to related domains and IP address resolutions led to several new addresses and domains used by the group. They also discovered a couple bash scripts leveraging this infrastructure for communication. These scripts created a new user and associated SSH configuration, executed Python code, and established persistence. Eventually a secondary payload could be executed, but researchers were unable to retrieve a sample. Subdomains tied to the discovered domains indicate that the infrastructure was also used to host credential phishing pages for mail and social media services. Ultimately, DomainTools was unable to identify infrastructure specifically associated with the Centreon activity described by ANSSI, but they we able to find previously unreported on Sandworm network indicators. For more information, see the DomainTools blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.domaintools.com/resources/blog/centreon-to-exim-and-back-on-the-trail-of-sandworm>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Agent Tesla Malspam Campaign
Italy's CSIRT is reporting that beginning on June 23, a "massive" malspam campaign distributing Agent Tesla was detected.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Malspam




# Overview

 The samples provided in the CSIRT alert show Word documents used to exploit the Microsoft Office vulnerability, CVE-2017-8570. While this vulnerability is old, the CSIRT note that it ranked as the third most exploited vulnerability in the last thirty days. The malspam emails are written in English and purport to be from import-export companies and the attached documents relate to alleged purchase orders. If the documents are opened and exploitation is successful, a PowerShell command is used to download the payload. Data is exfiltrated using SMTP. While two malicious executables, with different hashes, have been observed in the campaign, both exfiltrate data to the same email address. Further details are available from the report in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Prison Phone Service Exposes Inmate and Contact Details
Breach/Leak Notification: An app designed for prison inmates to send messages and make calls had its database exposed. Comparitech details information exposed and actions prison officials and the app maker took in response.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Breach




# Overview

An application owned by a telephone company used by prison inmates to message and call family members suffered a breach due to an exposed database revealing private messages and personal information. The database was not password-protected. Among the data exposed was tens of millions of call logs, private messages, and personal information about the inmates and their contacts. The unsecured database was immediately reported to the parent telecommunications company. A spokesperson for the application company stated: "Telmate, a GTL subsidiary immediately locked down the server as a precaution upon being made aware of a vulnerability in the data system due to the actions of one of our vendors. This vulnerability was swiftly corrected, the data security team was immediately supplemented with the assistance of third-party consultants and we continue to work closely with law enforcement authorities as we conduct further inquiry into this incident. Based on the current facts of the investigation, no medical data, passwords, or consumer payment information were affected. We continue to speak with and notify necessary parties, including the affected Telmate customers – a small subset of all GTL customers – about the incident and the actions we have taken to safeguard data. The security of the data we keep is of the utmost importance to us, and we are committed to doing everything we can to keep it safe." Contained within the database were three indices with 228 million messages, 11 million inmate records, and 79 million admin records, including login details for the app's dashboard. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.comparitech.com/blog/information-security/prison-phone-service-exposes-millions-inmate-records/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Vidar Infostealer Spread Via Malicious Windows 11 ISO Files
ZScaler has published a report detailing a new campaign they have been tracking. This campaign uses malicious Windows 11 ISO files to infect the victim with the Vidar Infostealer.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Vidar
  *  **Targets:** Windows Users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Site
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

ZScaler ThreatLabz has discovered a new campaign spreading the Vidar infostealer. The researchers found newly registered domains that were spoofing the official Microsoft Windows 11 OS download portal. From these sites, the victims could download fake Windows 11 ISO files which are very large, and so can evade network security products. These files are signed with an expired certificate that is likely stolen during the 2019 AVAST compromise. The Vidar samples seen in this campaign are all packed with Themida and are very large in size, as they have been artificially inflated with padding bytes. The malware uses hardcoded URLs as dead drop resolvers, which directs them to various social media accounts on Telegram and Mastadon that host legitimate binaries for credential and data harvesting. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/vidar-distributed-through-backdoored-windows-11-downloads-and-abusing>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1585.001 - Social Media Accounts  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027.001 - Binary Padding  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.001 - Dead Drop Resolver  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: cPanel and WHM Vulnerability
Recorded Future has posted an announcement regarding a vulnerability in cPanel and WebHost Manager (WHM) that could potentially allow an attacker access to the vulnerable site, including PII that may be stored there.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: cPanel and WHM Vulnerability
Recorded Future has posted an announcement regarding a vulnerability in cPanel and WebHost Manager (WHM) that could potentially allow an attacker access to the vulnerable site, including PII that may be stored there.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Recorded Future writes about an issue with two factor authentication (2FA) in cPanel and WHM. This vulnerability, if successfully exploited, could potentially allow an attacker to bypass the security of the site, even to the point of taking over control of the site. Valid credentials, which could be acquired through a phishing attack, are required to exploit this vulnerability. Once an attacker has the required credentials, they could then attempt to brute-force the second of the 2FA factors, which was not rated limited. cPanel has released patches that address this issue and users should update their environment as soon as practical. For more information, please see the link in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.recordedfuture.com/cpanel-whm-vulnerability/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: XCSSET Adapts to macOS 11 and M1-based Macs
Further research into the XCSSET malware has led Trend Micro researchers to discover new versions adapted to target macOS 11 and M1-based Macs.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing new versions of the XCSSET malware, which has been updated to support macOS 11 and M1-based Macs. While macOS 11 supports the execution of software with x86_64 architecture, many developers are updating their software to support ARM64, including the XCSSET developers. One tactic tied to XCSSET is the use of the development version of Safari to load malicious Safari frameworks and JavaScript backdoors. Safari 14 packages for macOS 11 are now being hosted alongside the older versions on the malware's C2 server. With the change in logo design for applications, the malware has also been updated so that the fake logos match the new legitimate logos. To get past new code signing requirements, ad-hoc code signing is implemented with both its fake apps and files and with a custom file opening tool. Updates to malicious AppleScript modules include the addition of Chromium browser support to the bootstrap module, new file names for the replicator module, and the ability to steal confidential data from various sites and replace cryptocurrency wallets by the agent module. All but three binary files used in XCSSET campaigns were changed from Mach-O files with an x86_64 architecture to universal binary files. Further information can be found in the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/d/xcsset-quickly-adapts-to-macos-11-and-m1-based-macs.html>
