instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Vyveva - A New Lazarus Backdoor
A new Lazarus backdoor discovered by ESET researchers, dubbed Vyveva, is being used to attack a company in South Africa.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

An attack against a freight logistics company in South Africa led ESET researchers to the discovery of a new Lazarus backdoor dubbed Vyveva. The researchers have been able to locate and analyze the installer, loader, and main payload, a backdoor with a TorSocket DLL. Although the backdoor has been in use since late-2018, the initial compromise vector is still unknown. Among the capabilities of the backdoor are file exfiltration, timestomping, information gathering, and other backdoor functionality. ESET has surmised the most likely intent of the operation is espionage. The Vyveva backdoor share code similarities with older Lazarus samples. For example, the Vyveva backdoor uses fake TLS in communication, command line execution chains, and encryption and Tor services. ESET can, with high confidence, attribute this activity to Lazarus. The presence of Vyveva indicates an earlier dropper which has not yet been identified. The installer creates a service for persistence of the backdoor loader and the storage of embedded, default backdoor configuration within the registry. The backdoor itself is the main component of Vyveva. This backdoor connects to the C2 servers and executes commands as issued by the threat actors. In their analysis, the researchers were able to identify 23 commands, most being ordinary commands used for file and process operations or information gathering. It also has the ability to upload files and exfiltrate directories recursively. Additionally, the backdoor can also filter on specific file types, such as Office documents only. Configuration is set by the installer and is read from a registry value created by the installer. If the configuration is modified by a C2 server command, the registry is subsequently updated. A Tor library is used to communicate with a C2 server selected at random from the configuration file. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/04/08/are-you-afreight-dark-watch-out-vyveva-new-lazarus-backdoor/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Emotet Attack Spike Warning for Several Countries
A rise in Emotet malware attacks has prompted warnings from cybersecurity agencies in France, Japan, and New Zealand. ZDNet reports on the recent activity in conjunction with the issued warnings.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Emotet Attack Spike Warning for Several Countries
A rise in Emotet malware attacks has prompted warnings from cybersecurity agencies in France, Japan, and New Zealand. ZDNet reports on the recent activity in conjunction with the issued warnings.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

In alerts from cybersecurity agencies in France, Japan, and New Zealand, a rise in Emotet activity has prompted a heightened state of awareness. The activity in question is email spam campaigns purportedly emanating from Emotet infrastructure. The alerts state targets include government and companies in the named countries. The botnet from Emotet has been active in recent weeks and the high activity rate in the three countries has security officials on high alert. New Zealand has been targeted by E3 (one of the three Emotet botnets), while E1, 2, and 3 are all targeting Japan. The amount of activity seen has tripled in the last week. France is targeted but not to the extent of the other two countries. The activity is being seen in the Paris court system prompting the issuance of the alert. All Office documents in France are being prohibited from being delivered to the French Interior Ministry. According to the individual alerts, it appears the activity is the same across the board. As with past Emotet campaigns, the group is following its usual tactic of infecting one victim and spreading through older email conversations. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.zdnet.com/article/france-japan-new-zealand-warn-of-sudden-spike-in-emotet-attacks/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Version of DanaBot
DanaBot briefly declined in activity after June 2020, but in October 2020 Proofpoint researchers observed its return with a new version.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Stealer




# Overview

Proofpoint has published a blog post analyzing a new version of DanaBot that appeared in October 2020, which they believe is version 4 of the malware. The sample they obtained was being distributed via crack websites that offer premium software that has supposedly been cracked to allow free access. Downloading a program from this site provides a ZIP file containing a password-protected archive, which, in turn, contains the dropper payload. This dropper is an executable that drops a stealer component that provides victim system information to the attacker. A second-stage payload is then downloaded that installs an AutoIT cryptominer and the DanaBot payload to the system. The DanaBot payload includes hardcoded configuration information, including the affiliate ID (two of which were discovered by Proofpoint), a version number, embedded hash values, C2 IPs and ports, and a Tor C2 domain. The malware can run in several alternative modes including a TOR mode, process injection mode, and a module mode. Proofpoint's analysis focuses on running mode 0, which is the main component. Available commands from the C2 response include those to get an updated list of C2 addresses, enable a stealer, change to Tor-based C2 communications, exfiltrate arbitrary information from the victim system, obtain a command shell, download and execute additional modules, and more. For more information, see the Proofpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/new-year-new-version-danabot>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Phishing Emails Targeting Naver Credentials
Spoofing a well-known Korean manufacturer, a phishing campaign caught by EST Security was determined to be attempting to obtain Naver credentials.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Phishing Emails Targeting Naver Credentials
Spoofing a well-known Korean manufacturer, a phishing campaign caught by EST Security was determined to be attempting to obtain Naver credentials.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

EST Security discovered a phishing campaign attempting to steal credentials for Naver, a Korean online platform. The initial phishing email spoofs a well-known Korean steel manufacturer and claims to have a quote attached. This attached HTM file, however, is used to redirect users to a phishing page. The phishing page is almost identical to the legitimate Naver login page and requests the user's credentials. Falling victim to this lure will lead to the entered credentials being exfiltrated back to the attacker. In order to increase the legitimacy of the attack, after entering the credentials the victim is redirected to a fake quote hosted on Google Drive in order to make them think the login was successful. For more information, see the EST Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.alyac.co.kr/3325>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cryptomining Campaign Targeting Docker Linux Systems
A cryptomining campaign targeting Docker Linux systems was detected, analyzed, and reported on by SentinelOne.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cryptomining Campaign Targeting Docker Linux Systems
A cryptomining campaign targeting Docker Linux systems was detected, analyzed, and reported on by SentinelOne.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

SentinelOne has published a blog post detailing a cryptomining campaign they observed. The campaign specifically targeted a Docker container running Linux, although the initial access method to that container is not specified. Once on the system, the threat actor executed a shell script that, in turn, downloaded and executed a second-stage script. Performing similar actions, the second-stage attempts to download and execute the final shell script in the sequence. The final shell script is responsible for downloading and executing the final payload. Steganography is used to embed the ELF binary into a JPG image, reducing its detection rate. By extracting and analyzing the payload, the researchers identified the final executable as XMRig, providing the threat actor with a profit via Monero mining. For more information, see the SentintelOne blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/caught-in-the-cloud-how-a-monero-cryptominer-exploits-docker-containers/>

# Threat Type

# Overview

The December security bulletin for Android has been released. In it, forty-six vulnerabilities were addressed. Some of the issues addressed include bypassing user interactions requirements to gain access to additional permissions, execution of arbitrary code, and information disclosure. Tell me about the following threat: Similarities Between the ShadowPad and PlugX Backdoors
Using samples from attacks on systems located in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan, analysts from Doctor Web discovered relationships between the ShadowPad and PlugX backdoors.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Similarities Between the ShadowPad and PlugX Backdoors
Using samples from attacks on systems located in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan, analysts from Doctor Web discovered relationships between the ShadowPad and PlugX backdoors.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

According to a report from Doctor Web, the ShadowPad backdoor may be an evolution of the PlugX backdoor. The Winnti APT group are known to use modified versions of ShadowPad. Indicators from the malware involved in attacks on systems in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan suggest that Chinese APT groups may have been involved in the attacks. Based on similarities found in the code of the ShadowPad and PlugX backdoors, Doctor Web analysts conclude that both backdoors may have been created by the same developers and is a more advanced backdoor than PlugX. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: STIBNITE ICS Threat Activity Group
STIBNITE is an ICS threat activity group identified by Dragos. It has targeted wind generation and government organizations in Azerbaijan.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Spear Phishing




# Overview

Dragos published a blog post providing details on a recently discovered threat activity group dubbed "STIBNITE." This group is responsible for multiple campaigns against the Azeri government and wind generation entities from late 2019 through 2020. Their initial access is gained through spoofed Azeri government sites designed for credential theft or through the use of malicious Microsoft Office documents attached to spear phishing emails. After access is obtained, the group delivers PoetRAT for post-exploitation activity, which allows for file exfiltration, taking screenshots, and command execution. Additionally, STIBNITE uses PypyKatz, a Python-based implementation of Mimikatz, and LaZagne for credential harvesting, which can allow for further lateral movement. They have also leveraged open-source web browser credential theft tools. Dragos notes that while the group has only focused on it infrastructure so far, the gathered data could allow for the compromise of OT infrastructure. For more information, see the Dragos blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.dragos.com/blog/industry-news/new-ics-threat-activity-group-stibnite/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: DirtyMoe Spreading Using Worm Modules
Avast has written an analysis of the DirtyMoe malware. This article focuses on the worm-like capability which allows it to spread without any user interaction.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Worm
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** DirtyMoe
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing/Trojanized installer
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral Movement



# Overview

Avast researchers have been analyzing the DirtyMoe malware. This malware is deployed by either phishing campaigns or malvertising. Alternatively, it uses the PurpleFox exploit kit to exploit a machine and install the malware. Once installed, it can spread without any user interaction. The goal of this worm module is to look for and exploit several known vulnerabilities and install itself into the new machine. DirtyMoe generates targets using a pseudo-random IP generation algorithm, allowing it to expand to machines hidden behind NAT. The generated IPs are scanned for any known vulnerabilities. If the potential victim is deemed exploitable, an attack is prepared and launched. The majority of these infections have been in North America and Europe. The analysts also discovered one worming module in developments that exploited other vulnerabilities but were not yet armed for deployment. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/82641486/DirtyMoe%20Spreading%20Using%20Worm%20Modules%20IoCs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1647623393539&api=v2)



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/martinchlumecky/dirtymoe-5/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1019:** Threat Intelligence Program - A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ITG19 Returns from Hiatus
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence observed a decrease in ITG19 (aka TA505) activity between mid-July to early August 2020. The group has since resumed their operations with new domain registrations and delivery documents.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

  
Between mid-July to early August 2020, IBM X-Force observed a significant downturn in activity associated with ITG19 (aka TA505), observing no sign of newly registered domains. Activity X-Force generally associates with ITG19 restarted in early August with the registration of domains following a typical pattern, along with newly used macro-enabled XLS documents leveraged to deliver malware, and the implementation of fake Microsoft OneDrive and Citrix ShareFile links within phishing emails. X-Force observed this activity targeting commercial enterprises headquartered in the UK, USA, and China, including companies related to wholesale financial markets, infrastructure, accounting, human resource solutions, and professional recruitment. The full story, including indicators of compromise, is available to IBM X-Force IRIS Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.   
  


# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/b53cc6ff-9c80-48fd-894d-cd95f7eac453>

  * To learn more about X-Force IRIS Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/ibm-x-force-incident-response-and-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: NCAS Alert AA21-200A - TTPs of Indicted APT40 Actors
Alert AA21-200A has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System and provides information on APT40’s tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) and indicators of compromise (IOCs).

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

 **From Alert AA21-200A**  
 **Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures of Indicted APT40 Actors Associated with China’s MSS Hainan State Security Department**

This Joint Cybersecurity Advisory was written by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) to provide information on a Chinese Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group known in open-source reporting as APT40. This advisory provides APT40’s tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) and indicators of compromise (IOCs) to help cybersecurity practitioners identify and remediate APT40 intrusions and established footholds.

APT40—aka BRONZE MOHAWK, FEVERDREAM, G0065, Gadolinium, GreenCrash, Hellsing, Kryptonite Panda, Leviathan, MUDCARP, Periscope, Temp.Periscope, and Temp.Jumper—is located in Haikou, Hainan Province, People’s Republic of China (PRC), and has been active since at least 2009. APT40 has targeted governmental organizations, companies, and universities in a wide range of industries—including biomedical, robotics, and maritime research—across the United States, Canada, Europe, the Middle East, and the South China Sea area, as well as industries included in China’s Belt and Road Initiative.

On July 19, 2021, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) unsealed an indictment against four APT40 cyber actors for their illicit computer network exploitation (CNE) activities via front company Hainan Xiandun Technology Development Company (Hainan Xiandun). Hainan Xiandun employee Wu Shurong cooperated with and carried out orders from PRC Ministry of State Security (MSS) Hainan State Security Department (HSSD) intelligence officers Ding Xiaoyang, Zhu Yunmin, and Cheng Qingmin to conduct CNE. Wu’s CNE activities resulted in the theft of trade secrets, intellectual property, and other high-value information from companies and organizations in the United States and abroad, as well as from multiple foreign governments. These MSS-affiliated actors targeted victims in the following industries: academia, aerospace/aviation, biomedical, defense industrial base, education, government, healthcare, manufacturing, maritime, research institutes, and transportation (rail and shipping).

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 
  * IoCs can also be download in STIX format from CISA: <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/AA21-200A.stix.xml>



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa21-200a>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Ryuk Ransomware Infection Chain
Focusing on the infection chain of the main payload, Cybereason published a blog post analyzing the Ryuk ransomware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Cybereason published a blog post analyzing the Ryuk ransomware, its history, and its infection chain. They first discuss the groups evolving TTPs, specifically the variety of malware involved in their infection chains, from Trickbot to EMPIRE, to Emotet. Additionally, they mention their findings indicate that the same threat actor is using Ryuk, Conti, and BazarLoader. Regardless of the malware involved, Ryuk is typically delivered as the final payload. With regard to the infection chain, recently Trickbot or BazarLoader have acted as the main initial infection vectors. Once on the system, the Ryuk payload copies itself and uses process injection for execution. It then uses the device's ARP table to discover target hosts and uses Wake-on-LAN packets in an attempt to mount the C$ to the initial victim machine. Specific services are killed using net.exe, shadow copies are deleted, and persistence is established. The last step before encryption is to use icacls.exe to change the permissions of files and folders on the host. Finally, encryption is carried out on both the local host and the mounted remote drives. The signature .RYK extension is appended to encrypted files. The ransom note, interestingly, contains nothing except the name of the malware and an email address; no instructions are provided. For more information, see the Cybereason blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/cybereason-vs.-ryuk-ransomware>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Ransomware Named Nokoyawa
Trend Micro has published a report that looks at a new piece of ransomware named Nokoyawa, and the similarities it has to the Hive ransomware.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Users in South America, primarily Argentina.
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Nokoyawa
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Possibly spearphishing emails.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

In March, Trend Micro observed new ransomware that has been named Nokoyawa. In a report they have published, Trend Micro note that Nokoyawa may be connected to the Hive ransomware operators as there are significant similarities in the tools used and the order in which steps in the attack chain are carried out. Nokoyawa has been used in attacks targeting South America with Argentina appearing to be the primary target. The initial infection vector is uncertain but it is speculated that the delivery is similar to the manner Hive is distributed spearphishing emails. There is no evidence at this time to suggest that Nokoyawa uses the double extortion technique. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/82641153/New%20Ransomware%20Named%20Nokoyawa%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1647326677640&api=v2)



# Recommendations

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Users in South America, primarily Argentina.
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Nokoyawa
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Possibly spearphishing emails.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

In March, Trend Micro observed new ransomware that has been named Nokoyawa. In a report they have published, Trend Micro note that Nokoyawa may be connected to the Hive ransomware operators as there are significant similarities in the tools used and the order in which steps in the attack chain are carried out. Nokoyawa has been used in attacks targeting South America with Argentina appearing to be the primary target. The initial infection vector is uncertain but it is speculated that the delivery is similar to the manner Hive is distributed spearphishing emails. There is no evidence at this time to suggest that Nokoyawa uses the double extortion technique. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: The Return of Infy
Research carried out by SafeBreach Labs and Check Point identified renewed activity by the Iranian APT group named "Infy".

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: The Return of Infy
Research carried out by SafeBreach Labs and Check Point identified renewed activity by the Iranian APT group named "Infy".

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

In the first half of 2020, new versions of the Foudre malware, which is known to be associated with the Iranian APT group Infy, were identified. Infy is also known as “Prince of Persia”. A new infection method was noted in the campaign. In the past, victims were enticed to click on a link to what was supposedly a video. The new method involves a lure document that uses a macro to extract an embedded SFX package, which is executed when the document is closed and installs the Foudre loader and backdoor. Foudre downloads and installs a new component named Tonnerre that provides functionality beyond that of Foudre. While Foudre and Tonnerre use HTTP to communicate with their C&C servers, Tonnerre uses FTP to exfiltrate data. The most recent version of Foudre covered in the report was observed in October 2020 and has some notable changes over past versions including a revised algorithm for generating domains, an RSA signature file is used to verify a C&C server, and the string "Foudre" was removed and replaced with “Form1”. The documents provided as examples in the report are in Persian, yet oddly for Infy campaigns, there are no victims located in Iran. While the victim count is low, the country with the most victims is Sweden, followed by the Netherlands, Turkey, and the US. Further information is available from the reports linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2021/after-lightning-comes-thunder/>

  * <https://safebreach.com/blog/2021/After-Lightning-Comes-Thunder/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Analysis of a Quantum Ransomware Attack
The DFIR Report has published their analysis of a Quantum ransomware attack that began with an email that had an ISO file attached that contained the IcedID malware.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Ransomware Family:** Quantum
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Intrusion Vector:** Email with malicious attachment delivering IcedID.
  *  **Data Exfiltrated:** No
  *  **Data Encrypted:** Yes ****



# Overview

Beginning with an email that had an ISO attachment that contained the IcedID malware, attackers installed the Quantum ransomware, domain-wide, in under 4 hours, according to a DFIR Report analysis. The ISO file contained two files, the IcedID malware in the form of a DLL and an LNK file that was used to execute it. Once executed, IcedID carried out a number of discovery tasks using built-in Windows utilities and created a scheduled task for persistence. Later, using process hollowing and injection, Cobalt Strike was installed on the host and later used to access LSASS memory to obtain credentials. The attackers carried out a number of discovery operations and then tested the credentials they had obtained on a server using WMI. RDP was then used to connect to the server and deploy a Cobalt Strike Beacon. Other servers were then connected to using RDP and then the ransomware was copied into the C$ share folder on each server. The ransomware was executed using WMI and PsExec. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2022/04/25/quantum-ransomware/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.011 - Rundll32  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1087.002 - Domain Account  
T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
T1614.001 - System Language Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Palo Alto Networks Security Advisories - September 2020
Palo Alto Networks has published nine security advisories that identify nine vulnerabilities in PAN-OS.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Nine security advisories detail nine vulnerabilities that have been patched in Palo Alto Networks' PAN-OS. Of the nine vulnerabilities, one is rated Critical (CVE-2020-2040 PAN-OS with a CVSS score of 9.8), five were rated as High, one was rated as Medium and two were rated as Low. If the buffer overflow vulnerability CVE-2020-2040 is successfully exploited, an attacker could potentially disrupt system processes and execute arbitrary code as root on the system.  
CVE-2020-2036 PAN-OS: Reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability in management web interface  
CVE-2020-2037 PAN-OS: OS command injection vulnerability in the management web interface  
CVE-2020-2038 PAN-OS: OS command injection vulnerability in the management web interface  
CVE-2020-2039 PAN-OS: Management web interface denial-of-service (DoS) through unauthenticated file upload  
CVE-2020-2040 PAN-OS: Buffer overflow when Captive Portal or Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is enabled  
CVE-2020-2041 PAN-OS: Management web interface denial-of-service (DoS)  
CVE-2020-2042 PAN-OS: Buffer overflow in the management web interface  
CVE-2020-2043 PAN-OS: Passwords may be logged in clear text when using after-change-detail custom syslog field for config logs  
CVE-2020-2044 PAN-OS: Passwords may be logged in clear text while storing operational command (op command) history  
For full details and affected versions, please refer to the links in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/29432972/Palo%20Alto%20Networks%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20September%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599850842834&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://security.paloaltonetworks.com/>
  * <https://security.paloaltonetworks.com/CVE-2020-2036>
  * <https://security.paloaltonetworks.com/CVE-2020-2037>
  * <https://security.paloaltonetworks.com/CVE-2020-2038>
  * <https://security.paloaltonetworks.com/CVE-2020-2039>
  * <https://security.paloaltonetworks.com/CVE-2020-2040>
  * <https://security.paloaltonetworks.com/CVE-2020-2041>
  * <https://security.paloaltonetworks.com/CVE-2020-2042>
  * <https://security.paloaltonetworks.com/CVE-2020-2043>
  * <https://security.paloaltonetworks.com/CVE-2020-2044>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: LodaRAT Still Active
Multiple versions of LodaRAT are currently in the wild according to Cisco Talos. New functionality has been added, old obfuscation techniques dropped, and indicators are that the threat actors are actively monitoring infected systems.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Trojan



# Overview

While monitoring LodaRAT, Cisco Talos observed the threat-actor actively monitoring infected systems. Multiple versions of LodaRAT currently co-exist in the wild and the newer versions have been upgraded with new functionality while dropping older obfuscation techniques. One of the new features added to the malware is a hex-encoded PowerShell keylogger. The infection vector in previous campaigns was a malicious Word document that attempted to exploit CVE-2017-11882. The current version of LodaRAT uses a malicious RAR archive as an attachment to phishing emails. Infection of a potential victim relies on the individual actually clicking on the executable within the archive. In the new versions, all obfuscation of the code has been removed. This may have been done since it did not provide a significant enough reduction in anti-virus detection to make it worthwhile. A VBS file, stored as a hex-encoded string, is used to search running processes to ensure only one copy of LodaRAT is running at any given time. For full comparisons of the differences between versions and additional technical details, please see the Talos link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/30770966/LodaRAT%20Still%20Active%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1601416934301&api=v2)



  


# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2020/09/lodarat-update-alive-and-well.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Rook Ransomware
Researchers have uncovered a new ransomware variant, Rook, that is seemingly leveraging leaked Babuk ransomware source code. SentintelOne has published their analysis of the Rook payload and its overlap with Babuk.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Rook Ransomware
Researchers have uncovered a new ransomware variant, Rook, that is seemingly leveraging leaked Babuk ransomware source code. SentintelOne has published their analysis of the Rook payload and its overlap with Babuk.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Non-specific
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Rook
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Delivered via Cobalt Strike or phishing email
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data encryption, data theft



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the Rook ransomware, a new ransomware family based on the Babuk source code. The connection to Babuk is based on significant code overlap, such as the use of specific APIs and functions. The Babuk source code, including its builder, was leaked several times throughout 2021, which is likely how these threat actors obtained it. The payload was seen being delivered by both Cobalt Strike and via phishing campaigns. The ransomware operates similar to most families. It begins by killing processes that may interfere with encryption or are related to security products. It then deletes volume shadow copies, performs encryption, and deletes itself. No persistence mechanisms were observed during SentintelOne's analysis. The threat actors operate on a double-extortion model, threatening to release stolen data on a TOR site if the ransom is not paid. It is unknown at this time whether an affiliate model exists. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056481/Rook%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640810161750&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/new-rook-ransomware-feeds-off-the-code-of-babuk/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

I have encountered the following information: ICS-CERT Advisory ICSA-21-096-01
The ICS-CERT has published an advisory that affects multiple Hitachi ABB Power Grids products.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information, including the list of affected products, is available from the advisory which is summarized below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-096-01 - Hitachi ABB Power Grids Multiple Products**  
CVE-2021-27196 - An attacker with access to the IEC 61850 network with knowledge of how to reproduce the attack, as well as the IP addresses of the different IEC 61850 access points (of IEDs/products), can force the device to reboot, which renders the device inoperable for approximately 60 seconds. This vulnerability affects only products with IEC 61850 interfaces.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-096-01>

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: LodaRAT Improves Espionage Capabilities
LodaRAT has been constantly evolving in order to provide its operators, the Kasablanka Group, with improved espionage capabilities. Cisco Talos reports on some of the most recent developments of the RAT, including a new Android version.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Espionage




# Overview

Cisco has published a blog analyzing a new version of LodaRAT for Windows and the release of an Android version of the tool. Hybrid campaigns were identified that targeted both Windows and Android users in Bangladesh and other countries. The campaigns were connected due to the use of shared C2 infrastructure between the Android and Windows samples. As with previous LodaRAT campaigns, the Windows payload was delivered via a malicious RTF document that uses a memory corruption exploit to download a malicious SCT file. Unlike previous campaigns, however, this campaign used an AppLocker bypass technique to execute the SCT file. The SCT file is responsible for the download and installation of the LodaRAT payload. This new version of LodaRAT added several commands, such as those for RDP remote access capabilities and an improved method of recording audio. The newly discovered Loda4Android has overlapping C2 infrastructure and a similar beacon creation routine and C2 protocol. It provides functionality similar to most Android RAT applications, allowing the operator to spy on user activities and control the device. For more information, see the Cisco Talos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2021/02/kasablanka-lodarat.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Shared Power Banks Used to Take Control of Phones
Yicai Global indicates that shared power banks, used to charge phones in public areas in China, may be infected with malware to either steal victim's data or take control of the device.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Shared Power Banks Used to Take Control of Phones
Yicai Global indicates that shared power banks, used to charge phones in public areas in China, may be infected with malware to either steal victim's data or take control of the device.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan



# Overview

Yicai Global announced in an article that charging stations in China may have been compromised by hackers. They indicate that the compromised station may install a Trojan on Android or iOS devices that are plugged in to recharge the device. One of China's larger shared power bank providers, Energy Monster, stated that their cables are configured only to supply power, not transfer data. Users are warned to take caution when using such public charging stations. When necessary, using your own cable that is known to not be configured to transfer data, is your best option, if possible. For more information, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.yicaiglobal.com/news/hackers-can-take-control-of-phones-via-shared-power-banks-ministry-says->

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Hafnium Group Using Evasive Tarrask Malware In Recent Campaign
Microsoft has been tracking the group Hafnium since early 2021. In this new report, they describe a new evasive malware called Tarrask which is being used in their recent campaign.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Hafnium Group Using Evasive Tarrask Malware In Recent Campaign
Microsoft has been tracking the group Hafnium since early 2021. In this new report, they describe a new evasive malware called Tarrask which is being used in their recent campaign.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Hafnium
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Tarrask
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Telecommunication, ISPs, Data Services
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Microsoft first reported on the Hafnium group in early 2021 where they were behind several attacks using a zero-day vulnerability in Exchange servers. In a recent campaign, they have been seen using a new evasive malware named Tarrask. The malware uses scheduled tasks to establish persistence, masquerading as a "WinUpdate" task. This task was created to re-establish any dropped connections to the C2 server. There is evidence that this malware is run as the SYSTEM user, which was possible as Tarrask can perform token theft to obtain the security permissions associated with the lsass.exe process. With this permission, the security descriptor related to the scheduled task can be deleted meaning it won't appear in the task scheduler and assists with making manual examination more difficult. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/04/12/tarrask-malware-uses-scheduled-tasks-for-defense-evasion/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1134.001 - Token Impersonation/Theft  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036.004 - Masquerade Task or Service  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Hafnium Group Using Evasive Tarrask Malware In Recent Campaign

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: CryptoRom Fraud Campaign Leveraging Fake iOS Cryptocurrency Apps
Since their initial research into the CryptoRom fraud campaign, Sophos has observed expanded targeting and new techniques, which they detail in a recent blog post.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Fleeceware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Campaign:** CryptoRom
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Fake cryptocurrency apps
  *  **Targets:** iOS users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Social engineering
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Fraud



# Overview

Sophos published a blog post detailing updates to the CryptoRom campaign. The threat actor behind this campaign leverages a combination of social engineering and fraudulent apps to turn a profit. First, a relationship is established with victims via dating apps and eventually messaging platforms. Once trust is established, the threat actor asks the user to install a fake cryptocurrency trading app; in this specific case, Bitfinex. In order to bypass Apple's App Store review process, the attacker abuses the Apple Developer Enterprise program, which requires the user to allow a new configuration profile to be installed on their device. Finally, the attacker attempts to convince the victim to make a small investment, continuing to social engineer them until they decide to make a large deposit. With the large transfer in place, the attacker attempts to extort the victim for more funds and eventually withdraws the money for themself. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130355/CryptoRom%20Fraud%20Campaign%20Leveraging%20Fake%20iOS%20Cryptocurrency%20Apps%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634229454108&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).



# References

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/10/13/cryptorom-fake-ios-cryptocurrency-apps/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
 ** **T1478 - Install Insecure or Malicious Configuration

  *  **Associated Payloads:** Fake cryptocurrency apps
  *  **Targets:** iOS users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Social engineering
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Fraud



# Overview

Sophos published a blog post detailing updates to the CryptoRom campaign. The threat actor behind this campaign leverages a combination of social engineering and fraudulent apps to turn a profit. First, a relationship is established with victims via dating apps and eventually messaging platforms. Once trust is established, the threat actor asks the user to install a fake cryptocurrency trading app; in this specific case, Bitfinex. In order to bypass Apple's App Store review process, the attacker abuses the Apple Developer Enterprise program, which requires the user to allow a new configuration profile to be installed on their device. Finally, the attacker attempts to convince the victim to make a small investment, continuing to social engineer them until they decide to make a large deposit. With the large transfer in place, the attacker attempts to extort the victim for more funds and eventually withdraws the money for themself. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130355/CryptoRom%20Fraud%20Campaign%20Leveraging%20Fake%20iOS%20Cryptocurrency%20Apps%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634229454108&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).



# References

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/10/13/cryptorom-fake-ios-cryptocurrency-apps/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
 ** **T1478 - Install Insecure or Malicious Configuration

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: MyKings Clipboard Stealer Analysis
The first of a two-part report from Avast looks at the clipboard stealer used by the MyKings botnet.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: MyKings Clipboard Stealer Analysis
The first of a two-part report from Avast looks at the clipboard stealer used by the MyKings botnet.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Clipboard stealer, Cryptominer, Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** MyKings
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Clipboard stealer, Cryptominer, additional payloads.
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Diversion of transactions, Cryptomining.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to a report from Avast, since 2019 the MyKings operators have raked in some $24 million dollars, or more. Most of the victims have been located in India, Pakistan, and Russia. One of the primary modules used by MyKings since around 2018 is a clipboard stealer. The clipboard stealer uses a series of Regular Expressions to match content in the victim's clipboard. For example, the destination Bitcoin wallet address for a transaction. The clipboard stealer will then replace the destination wallet with a wallet address that is controlled by the MyKings operators to divert the bitcoins to their wallet. MyKings may also use their victims for cryptomining activities. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130377/MyKings%20Clipboard%20Stealer%20Analysis%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634272230445&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/janrubin/the-king-is-dead-long-live-mykings/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1115 - Clipboard Data

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: RealTek Vulnerability Exploited
An exploited in the wild vulnerability exists in certain RealTek products and has been reported by Juniper Threat Labs.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Overview

A remote code execution vulnerability has been seen being exploited in the wild according to Juniper Threat Labs. The vulnerability, CVE-2021-35394, was disclosed by IoT Inspector Research Lab. The attack targets Related RTL8xxx SoC chipsets used in wireless routers and other embedded devices. As of this writing all download servers used in the campaign are operational and attacks continue. One particular item of interest is a UDP server running on port 9034. This particular vulnerability was patched in another vulnerability dated 2015, however this patch simply provided a mitigation technique of verification of command strings containing a prefix of "orf". This mitigation technique is ineffective due to the inclusion of the "orf" prefix to any injected command string. By including the "orf" prefix, the command is ingored and a shell script is downloaded, renamed, and executed. Specific architectures targeted are ARM (v5 and v7), MIPS (both big- and little-endian), and SuperH. The executables seen are variants of the Mirai botnet. IP addresses in this campaign overlap with those seen in other campaigns. The previous attacks focuses on HTTP; UDP allows more attacks utilizing fewer resources. More information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below. 

# Vulnerability Details

### Type of Vulnerability (OS, Software, Hardware)

  * Remote Code Execution
  * Realtek RTL8xxx SoC Chips



### CVE Details

  * CVE-2021-35394
  * Insertion of "orf" prefix to commands



### Seen in the Wild

  * Yes
  * No attribution available



### Proof of Concept

  * Seen in the wild



# Post-infection Actions

### Malware Installed?

  * Yes
  * Mirai Botnet



### Malware Capabilities

  * Botnet control



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A full list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127167/RealTek%20Vulnerability%20Exploited%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630692746793&api=v2)



# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-35394



# Protection

  * Look for specified Indicators of Compromise within your network.
  * Consider closing the UDP server running on port 9034.
  * Check logs for commands containing "orf" prefix.
  * Apply latest patches to all hardware and software.



# References

  * <https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/threat-research/realtek-cve-2021-35394-exploited-in-the-wild>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583.005 - Botnet  
T1584.005 - Botnet  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1133 - External Remote Services  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Threat Actors Use Canva Templates for Credential Phishing
While not their first time seeing such activity, Cofense reports on a significant increase in the use of Canva in phishing campaigns.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Threat Actors Use Canva Templates for Credential Phishing
While not their first time seeing such activity, Cofense reports on a significant increase in the use of Canva in phishing campaigns.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published a blog post reporting on a recent increase in the use of Canva, a design platform, as part of a phishing campaign. They observed two variations in the initial stage of distribution of the phishing link. The first version delivered comes with a PDF attachment that contains a link to an image hosted on Canva. The second version includes the Canva link directly in the body of the email. Regardless of the method used to distribute this link, users are directed to an image on Canva. The image may use any number of lures, such as document sharing themes. Clicking on the image, as it requests, leads to a phishing page hosted on a compromised website. The fake login pages vary but all have the same goal of gathering victim credentials for email services. Cofense notes that one of the main reasons attackers likely began to use Canva, as opposed to more well known services such as Google Drive or Dropbox, is that the other services tend to take down the malicious files more quickly than Canva. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/threat-actors-use-canva-templates-for-credential-phishing/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Analysis of Infrastructure used by DarkSide Affiliates
Investigation into infrastructure used by DarkSide affiliates led RiskIQ researchers to discover additional indicators of compromise (IoCs).
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

RiskIQ has published a report detailing their findings based on investigation into DarkSide affiliate infrastructure. Their search specifically uncovered new indicators of compromise (IoCs) associated with the affiliates UNC2465 and UNC2628. Connections between the infrastructure detailed include shared registrants, domains hosted on the same IP addresses, and payloads hosted on the same domain. In the case of UNC2465, RiskIQ discovered EMPIRE and SMOKEDHAM infrastructure tied to the domains associated with the group's DarkSide activity. Additionally, they were able to identify the use of Shopify to host malware by the group, which had not previously been reported on. UNC2628 infrastructure included that related to BEACON, Sodinokibi, CobaltStrike, and spyware. Much of the infrastructure analyzed in the article is still active despite DarkSide's cease in operations. This infrastructure may be leveraged for other malware campaigns or could eventually be shut down. For more information, see the RiskIQ article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://community.riskiq.com/article/fdf74f23>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: HTML Attachment Phishing Email
A phishing email containing no content except an HTML attachment was detected and analyzed by Cofense researchers.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing



# Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing a phishing email using only an HTML attachment as a lure. The email was sent free a SendGrid SMTP relay, which decreases its chances of being blocked by secure email gateways due to legitimate uses of the service. The email body contains no content with only an HTML file attached. Opening the HTML file displays a page using both Sharepoint and OneDrive branding. Links to view or download a business-related PDF file are provided. Both links lead to a pop-ip login page requesting an email and password. If credentials are entered, the data is exfiltrated to the attacker; meanwhile, the victim is redirected to a legitimate PDF with a name matching the one listed on the phishing page. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/html-phishing-email/>
