instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Evolution of Fake Alert and Technical Support Scams
Sophos has published an article on the various "scarevertising" methods in play today, including "fake alerts", technical support scams, and browser locks.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Scams, Browser Locks, Scarevertising



# Overview

As the Sophos article states, "For nearly as long there have been web advertising networks, there have been malicious web ads." A lot of work has been accomplished by browser vendors to protect the user, but there are still unscrupulous ad networks that do not monitor or restrict what is being sent to the user. Some ads use a "pop-under" technique to bypass any "pop-up" restrictions that the browser may have employed. These "pop-under" techniques may deploy JavaScript or Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) features to convince the user their system has a real problem that only the contents of the ad can resolve. Technical support calls of the past, where a potential victim was cold-called over the phone, have evolved to use web pages, maliciously designed, that pull the victim to the fake call center for "assistance with their problem". It isn't just the desktop being attacked, either. Mobile devices have similar attack patterns. Ads on mobile devices may lead to tech support scams or to PUAs (Potentially Unwanted Applications). The PUAs may even reside in Google's or Apple's app stores because there's no real malicious code within the app to trigger anti-malware detection software. For more technical details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/29432396/Evolution%20of%20Fake%20Alert%20and%20Technical%20Support%20Scams%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599685244864&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2020/09/09/faking-it-the-thriving-business-of-fake-alert-web-scams>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Magniber Ransomware Evolving To Infect Chrome and Edge
The ransomware Magniber has historically only infected Internet Explorer. A report by the ASEC analysis team details how the ransomware is now infecting users of Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Magniber Ransomware Evolving To Infect Chrome and Edge
The ransomware Magniber has historically only infected Internet Explorer. A report by the ASEC analysis team details how the ransomware is now infecting users of Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Magniber
  *  **Targets:** Users of Chrome, Edge, and IE.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Sites
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encyrption and Extortion



# Overview

The ASEC analysis team has been tracking the ransomware known as Magniber and its distribution methods. This ransomware is traditionally spread by exploiting Internet Explorer vulnerabilities and continues to be spread in this way. However, Magniber has recently been seen on both Microsoft Edge and Google Chrome. When the distribution pages are navigated to on these browsers, the user is asked to install an APPX file which is supposed to update the browser. Interestingly, the APPX file for both browsers contains a valid certificate, so the installation is allowed to go ahead. The result of this operation is a malicious executable and DLL file, which work together to download the ransomware and execute it in memory. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056966/Magniber%20Ransomware%20Evolving%20To%20Infect%20Chrome%20and%20Edge%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642174506730&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Ensure extensions that are installed are the intended ones as many malicious extensions will masquerade as legitimate ones (M1047).
  * Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files (M1038).



# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/30645/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Infostealer Campaign Targets Energy and Oil & Gas Sectors
Researchers at Intezer uncovered a sophisticated email campaign targeting energy, oil & gas, and electronics companies in order to deploy infostealing malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Infostealer Campaign Targets Energy and Oil & Gas Sectors
Researchers at Intezer uncovered a sophisticated email campaign targeting energy, oil & gas, and electronics companies in order to deploy infostealing malware.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer, RAT




# Overview

Intezer published a blog post analyzing a global email campaign targeting energy, oil & gas, and electronics companies. The geographies of the organizations varied, but most of the targets were located in South Korea. The campaign begins with a sophisticated email spoofing other businesses within the industry of the target company and appearing to be legitimate business correspondence, such as a request for quote or invoice. Attached is an IMG, ISO, or CAB archive, all of which can be used to evade email security defenses. Opening the attached file reveals an executable, which, if opened, leads to the installation of a information stealer or RAT. Final payloads observed include Formbook, Agent Tesla, Loki, the Snake Keylogger, and AZOrult. For more information, see the Intezer blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/research/global-phishing-campaign-targets-energy-sector-and-its-suppliers/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ryuk and BazarBackdoor
Cofense reports on the correlation between the Ryuk ransomware and the BazarBackdoor as its download and deployment vector.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ryuk and BazarBackdoor
Cofense reports on the correlation between the Ryuk ransomware and the BazarBackdoor as its download and deployment vector.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

According to a Cofense report, the Ryuk ransomware has moved from its previously used Trickbot for downloading and deploying malware to the BazarBackdoor. As with previous Ryuk infections, the initial vector remains emails disguised as legitimate internal communications with relevant information to entice a user to click a link or open a malicious attachment. BazarBackdoor uses a special type of communication to avoid possible detection and to communicate with its C2 servers. The communication includes DNS lookups for .bazar domains. The C2 nodes frequently serve as payload delivery locations and, once contacted, additional information is collected and transmitted to the threat actors. Most often, the payloads delivered are Ryuk ransomware, reconnaissance tools, and Cobalt Strike payloads. Due to the close relationship between Ryuk and TrickBot, and TrickBot and Emotet, it cannot be ruled out that Ryuk could be delivered by Emotet in future attacks. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/the-ryuk-threat-why-bazarbackdoor-matters-most/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Unsecured AWS Bucket Reveals 39 Million Records
Breach/Leak Notification: An online marketing company's database was left unsecured on an AWS server. CyberNews reveals the discovery of the records and the potential implications of the unsecured data.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Unsecured AWS Bucket Reveals 39 Million Records
Breach/Leak Notification: An online marketing company's database was left unsecured on an AWS server. CyberNews reveals the discovery of the records and the potential implications of the unsecured data.

# Threat Type

  * Leak




# Overview

The CyberNews research team uncovered an unsecured data bucket containing a database within an AWS server. The database belongs to a marketing firm, View Media. On July 29, Amazon closed the bucket and the data is no longer visible. Within the bucket were 700 statements of work for email and direct mail campaigns, along with 59 CSV and XLS files containing nearly 39 million records of U.S. citizens. About 2/3 of those records were unique. This information could later be used for targeting of potential victims in later scam attempts such as phishing, spam attacks, and identity fraud. "On August 24, we contacted View Media for an official comment regarding the leak. However, we received no response from the company." Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://cybernews.com/security/online-marketing-company-exposes-data-of-millions-americans/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Zeoticus 2.0 Ransomware
Researchers recently discovered a new version of the Zeoticus ransomware. SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing this ransomware family and the newest samples.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the Zeoticus ransomware, specifically focusing on the recently discovered version 2.0. The ransomware is sold on underground forums as a custom build for Windows Operating Systems. Unlike many modern ransomware families, Zeoticus does not contain any C2 mechanisms, allowing for it to run fully offline. Based on forum postings, the update to Zeoticus focuses on increasing speed and efficiency of the encryption processes. Additionally, the ability to target specific file extensions was added. Like most ransomware, the infection chain begins with processes that could interfere with encryption being killed. Zeoticus also covers its track by deleting its own binaries using the ping utility. As with previous versions, persistence continues to be established via a Registry Run key. While version 1.0 of the ransomware used a desktop wallpaper to provide the ransom note, this version mounts a new volume containing the note in an HTML file. Victims are requested to email the operators for further instructions. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/zeoticus-2-0-ransomware-with-no-c2-required/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Google Mail Merge Impersonation
A recent phishing campaign detected by Abnormal Security attempts to steal Outlook credentials through a Google Mail merge lure.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Abnormal Security published a brief report on a recent phishing campaign targeting Outlook credentials. The initial lure claims that there is an attempt to merge a new email address into the recipient's Google account and that the recipient should decline the request if they don't recognize the email address. Visiting the decline request link leads to a convincing Google page asking the user to validate the activity. Following through on this prompt leads to the final landing page, a fake Outlook Web App login page, which will exfiltrate gathered credentials to the attacker if submitted. For more information, see the Abnormal Security blog post in the Reference section.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-055A
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency malware analysis report, AR21-055A, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report provides information on the webshell which is designed to be uploaded to an Accellion File Transfer Appliance (FTA) server.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-055A
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency malware analysis report, AR21-055A, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report provides information on the webshell which is designed to be uploaded to an Accellion File Transfer Appliance (FTA) server.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Webshell




# Overview

This Malware Analysis Report (MAR) analyzes a malicious Hypertext Preprocessor (PHP) webshell file submitted to CISA for analysis. The webshell is designed to be uploaded to an Accellion File Transfer Appliance (FTA) server, a secure file transfer application used by customers to send large files. The webshell leverages a Structured Query Language (SQL) injection vulnerability to install itself onto the impacted FTA server. The webshell provides threat actors with the ability to locate files, obtain file metadata, and download files stored on the Accellion FTA server.

This webshell has been used in recent cyberattacks targeting users of Accellion FTA. For more information on these attacks, refer to Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA21-055A.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 
  * IoCs can also be download in STIX format from CISA: <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/MAR-10325064.r1.v1.WHITE_stix.xml>



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: From PUA/PUP to Cobalt Strike on a Corporate Network
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence researchers recently analyzed a Cobalt Strike infection on a corporate network that originated from a Potentially Unwanted Application/Potentially Unwanted Program (PUA/PUP) that an employee installed on their workstation.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, PUA/PUP




# Overview

IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence researchers recently analyzed a Cobalt Strike infection on a corporate network that took place after an employee installed a PUP/PUA package on their workstation. The employee downloaded the PUA/PUP package after being redirected away from a compromised website to a webpage presenting a lure for a software update. This software package, in turn, downloaded the Legion Loader malware and an IcedID downloader, which later led to the attack on corporate servers with Cobalt Strike Beacon. This case highlights the importance of user education on the dangers of installing PUA/PUP packages that can be laced with malware and guarding against the installation of unapproved applications on a device that has access to the corporate network. The full story, including indicators of compromise, is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below. 

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/6b5ebc85-5176-4c05-88e4-1dfb317422ad>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Digital-Only Banks Targeted In New Phishing Campaign
Digital-only banks are becoming more prevalent, and with this, they are becoming targets for scams and fraud. This blog post on Bushido Token Threat Intel explores one campaign targeting a bank in the UK.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Digital-Only Banks Targeted In New Phishing Campaign
Digital-only banks are becoming more prevalent, and with this, they are becoming targets for scams and fraud. This blog post on Bushido Token Threat Intel explores one campaign targeting a bank in the UK.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Monzo Customers
  *  **Lure:** Monzo Login Page
  *  **Compromised Data:** Banking Credentials
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Threat actors are targeting digital only banks as they are becoming more and more common. Bushido Token Threat Intel has published a blog post exploring one campaign targeting the online bank Monzo. The attack targets the mechanism by which a customer verifies their device for use with the bank - using a "golden link" which allows for the first login. The attack follows common phishing patterns, with the page copying Monzo's pages to get the users to enter their credentials and PIN. Along with the victim's name and phone number, the attacker will be able to access the compromised account. Upon exploration of the infrastructure behind the phishing site, the researcher discovered sites also targeting the bank Revolut. There was evidence that this attack was orchestrated by the threat actor "Cazanova", who offers phishing as a service. For more information, please see the link in the reference section

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058973/Digital-Only%20Banks%20Targeted%20In%20New%20Phishing%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645111572603&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Proactively reset accounts that are known to be part of breached credentials either immediately, or after detecting bruteforce attempts (M1018).



# References

  * <https://blog.bushidotoken.net/2022/02/mobile-banking-phishing-campaign.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.002 - GUI Input Capture

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Buer Loader Malware-as-a-Service
Ryuk actors appear to be adding a new malware-as-a-service offering to their toolset, the Beur loader. Sophos provides an analysis of this malware and its recent usage in Ryuk campaigns.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Loader




# Overview

Sophos has published a blog post analyzing the Beur loader and its recent appearance in Ryuk campaigns. This loader is offered as malware-as-a-service that offers payloads, C2 hosting, and technical support, as advertised in forum posts. A C2 panel provided by the service allows attackers to deliver files to endpoints and track their successful infections with details about each host. The specific infection chain that the Sophos article focuses on is that observed as part of Ryuk campaigns. The infection chain is relatively similar to those using Emotet or Trickbot's Bazar loader for access instead. A spear phishing email provides a link to a file hosted on a legitimate cloud storage platform, such as Google Docs or Constant Contact. If a user opens the downloaded file, a macro drops an executable on the system. This executable is the packed installer for the Beur loader payload. Once installed, if it passes anti-analysis and regional checks, the loader establishes communication with its C2 server. From this point the attacker can deliver further payloads to the victim system. The Ryuk operators used the loader to first deliver a Cobalt Strike beacon, which, in turn, was used deliver the final ransomware payload. Similar emails that appear to be a part of the same campaign were seen delivering Bazar or ZLoader instead, both of which have been used in Ryuk attacks in the past. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2020/10/28/hacks-for-sale-inside-the-buer-loader-malware-as-a-service/>

Tell me everything you know the following threat: Chrome Browser Updates - February 02 2021
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for six vulnerabilities. Of the six CVE numbered vulnerabilities noted in the advisory, Google has rated one as Critical, four as High, and one as Medium.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
Google has released an update, version 88.0.4324.146, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for six vulnerabilities. Of the six CVE numbered vulnerabilities noted in the advisory, Google has rated one as Critical, four as High, and one as Medium. instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New AdLoad Campaign Undetected by XProtect
As Apple puts more protections in place, malware must adapt to evade detection. SentinelOne reports on the AdLoad malware's successful attempts to avoid Apple's XProtect detection system.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New AdLoad Campaign Undetected by XProtect
As Apple puts more protections in place, malware must adapt to evade detection. SentinelOne reports on the AdLoad malware's successful attempts to avoid Apple's XProtect detection system.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Adware, Bundleware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** AdLoad
  *  **Targets:** macOS systems
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious file download (T1204)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install adware/bundleware
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Installer masquerades as Flash Player, persistence via launchd job (T1053.004), persistence via launch agent (T1543.001), Zsh script (T1059.004)



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the most recent AdLoad samples, which have been updated to evade Apple's defense systems. AdLoad is an adware loader targeting macOS system that has evolved since its appearance in late 2019. The dropper for AdLoad masquerades as an Adobe Flash Player update in the form of a .app file mounted as a DMG. Many of these files are signed with a valid signature or even notarized by Apple, assisting in its ability to evade detection. Once on the system, AdLoad establishes persistence via the user's LaunchAgents folder and, if privileges are obtained, via a launchd job. A Zsh script is used during the installation process to execute the final payload from the /tmp directory. As of right now, Apple's existing XProtect signatures do not detect this variant of AdLoad. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/61374531/New%20AdLoad%20Campaign%20Undetected%20by%20XProtect%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629139596227&api=v2)



# Protection

## Yara Rules
    
    
    private rule Macho  
    {  
        meta:  
            description = "private rule to match Mach-O binaries"  
        condition:  
            uint32(0) == 0xfeedface or uint32(0) == 0xcefaedfe or uint32(0) == 0xfeedfacf or uint32(0) == 0xcffaedfe or uint32(0) == 0xcafebabe or uint32(0) == 0xbebafeca  
    }  
      
    rule adload_2021_system_service  
    {  
        meta:  
            description = "rule to catch Adload .system .service variant"  
            author = "Phil Stokes, SentinelLabs"  
            version = "1.0"  
            last_modified = "2021-08-10"  
            reference = "https://s1.ai/adload"  
        strings:  
            $a = { 48 8D 35 ?? ?? 00 00 48 8D 5D B8 BA B8 00 00 00 48 89 DF E8 ?? ?? FB FF 48 8B 43 08 48 2B 03 66 48 0F 6E C0 66 0F 62 05 ?? ?? 00 00 66 0F 5C 05 ?? ?? 00 00 0F 57 C9 66 0F 7C C0 48 8D 7D A0 0F 29 0F F2 0F 59 05 }  
        condition:  
            Macho and all of them  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/massive-new-adload-campaign-goes-entirely-undetected-by-apples-xprotect/>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
New AdLoad Campaign Undetected by XProtect
As Apple puts more protections in place, malware must adapt to evade detection. SentinelOne reports on the AdLoad malware's successful attempts to avoid Apple's XProtect detection system.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Adware, Bundleware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** AdLoad
  *  **Targets:** macOS systems
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious file download (T1204)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install adware/bundleware
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Installer masquerades as Flash Player, persistence via launchd job (T1053.004), persistence via launch agent (T1543.001), Zsh script (T1059.004)



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the most recent AdLoad samples, which have been updated to evade Apple's defense systems. AdLoad is an adware loader targeting macOS system that has evolved since its appearance in late 2019. The dropper for AdLoad masquerades as an Adobe Flash Player update in the form of a .app file mounted as a DMG. Many of these files are signed with a valid signature or even notarized by Apple, assisting in its ability to evade detection. Once on the system, AdLoad establishes persistence via the user's LaunchAgents folder and, if privileges are obtained, via a launchd job. A Zsh script is used during the installation process to execute the final payload from the /tmp directory. As of right now, Apple's existing XProtect signatures do not detect this variant of AdLoad. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/61374531/New%20AdLoad%20Campaign%20Undetected%20by%20XProtect%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629139596227&api=v2)



# Protection

## Yara Rules
    
    
    private rule Macho  
    {  
        meta:  
            description = "private rule to match Mach-O binaries"  
        condition:  
            uint32(0) == 0xfeedface or uint32(0) == 0xcefaedfe or uint32(0) == 0xfeedfacf or uint32(0) == 0xcffaedfe or uint32(0) == 0xcafebabe or uint32(0) == 0xbebafeca  
    }  
      
    rule adload_2021_system_service  
    {  
        meta:  
            description = "rule to catch Adload .system .service variant"  
            author = "Phil Stokes, SentinelLabs"  
            version = "1.0"  
            last_modified = "2021-08-10"  
            reference = "https://s1.ai/adload"  
        strings:  
            $a = { 48 8D 35 ?? ?? 00 00 48 8D 5D B8 BA B8 00 00 00 48 89 DF E8 ?? ?? FB FF 48 8B 43 08 48 2B 03 66 48 0F 6E C0 66 0F 62 05 ?? ?? 00 00 66 0F 5C 05 ?? ?? 00 00 0F 57 C9 66 0F 7C C0 48 8D 7D A0 0F 29 0F F2 0F 59 05 }  
        condition:  
            Macho and all of them  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/massive-new-adload-campaign-goes-entirely-undetected-by-apples-xprotect/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: MosaicRegressor - UEFI Malware
Kaspersky has published a report on MosaicRegressor, malicious code implanted in the UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) chip that is used to load a system at boot time.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: MosaicRegressor - UEFI Malware
Kaspersky has published a report on MosaicRegressor, malicious code implanted in the UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) chip that is used to load a system at boot time.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, UEFI-based, Bootkit, Espionage



# Overview

While investigating UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) firmware images, Kaspersky noticed some peculiarities. They found two DXE drivers and two UEFI applications in an unusual proximity with their assigned GUID values. Further probing lead to the discovery that the leaked source code for HackingTeam’s VectorEDK bootkit may have been the basis of the code they found in the image. These modules would, when the system turned on, begin a process that would write a file "IntelUpdate.exe" to the Startup folder on the system. Each time the system was booted, if that file had been removed by the user or other means, the malware would replace it. While their research into this issue did not reveal the infection vector, they did suspect it may have been the result of physical access and booting the system from a USB key that contained a Q-flash update utility and the malicious UEFI image. Once the system is running, modules are downloaded and installed if they do not exist already. Combined, these modules make up what Kaspersky labeled as "MosaicRegressor" framework. MosaicRegressor consists of a multi-stage and modular framework. The primary purpose of the malware is espionage and data gathering. For full technical details, check out Kaspersky's report in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32145651/MosaicRegressor%20-%20UEFI%20Malware%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1602092371507&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/32145651/MosaicRegressor%20-%20UEFI%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1602092382658&api=v2)



# Protection

## IBM

  * CVE-2018-0802: CompoundFile_OLE_Equation_Size_Exec



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/mosaicregressor/98849/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: FLASH Lapsus$ Group Heists Ramp Up
Hive0115, also known as Lapsus$, is a suspected cybercriminal threat group active since at least December 2021. Reportedly, Hive0115 has been conducting data destruction and data theft attacks against organizations in various industries including government, telecommunications, media, and technology.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# X-Force Executive Update

 **Serial: 2022-IRIS-13044| Date:** **2022-03-22** **| TLP: GREEN**





# Threat Type

  * Data Theft, Extortion, Insider



# Overview

Hive0115 initially appeared to focus a majority of operations on Portuguese speaking victims across Latin America. In January 2022, Hive0115 claimed responsibility for the disruption of SIC, the largest media conglomerate in Portugal. The attackers defaced numerous websites and disabled the internet streaming component of the victim's broadcasts. Hive0115 claims to have gained access to SIC’s Amazon Web Services account. In December 2021, the Brazilian Ministry of Health reported being a victim of a cyber attack in which COVID vaccine databases were deleted and data was stolen. Hive0115 claimed responsibility for this attack. Hive0115 claimed to have unauthorized access to the Ministry of Health's Amazon Web Service cloud environment. In February 2022, technology company Nvidia acknowledged being the victim of a cyber attack involving the theft of proprietary company data. Hive0115 claimed responsibility for the attack and demanded that Nvidia make its device drivers open source and remove the LHR technology that makes it harder for crypto miners to utilize Nvidia GPUs. In March 2022, electronics manufacturer Samsung disclosed that a data breach has led to the theft of internal company data including the source code for Galaxy smartphones. This announcement came just days after Hive0115 posted 190GB of data belonging to Samsung.

On March 10, 2022, Hive0115 posted a message to their Telegram channel recruiting insiders willing to sell remote access to major corporate and internet service providers. This has led some researchers to believe that Hive0115 is gaining initial access via malicious corporate insiders. According to recent IBM research, in 40% of insider related incidents that X-Force responded to from 2018 through 2020, the insider was confirmed or likely had administrative access to some area of the network.

On March 20, 2022, Hive0115 claimed it had stolen source code from Microsoft for Bing, Cortana, and other projects. A day later, the group posted a zip archive containing at least partial source code for over 250 projects belonging to Microsoft. Additionally, the leak contained internal company emails and documentation.

On March 22, 2022, Hive0115 posted screenshots of what they claimed to be access to Okta's administrative console. Okta, being a provider for authentication and access management services, has a foothold in numerous organizations for which Hive0115 can use as a jump off point for further attacks. 

It is speculated that another possible initial infection vector utilized by Hive0115 is phishing emails however that is not confirmed at this time. Early media reporting of Hive0115 activity suggested that the group was deploying ransomware in an attempt to extort victims. However, more recent evidence suggests that the group does not use ransomware as part of its operations. Instead, Hive0115 exfiltrates data and threatens victims with release or subsequent deletion of the original data set.

Hive0115 makes extensive use of Telegram to post updates about their activity. To date, they have over 33,000 subscribers and they use the platform to announce attacks, leaks, and requests to their followers.

## Recent Activity:

Victim

| 

Region/Country

| 

Industry

| 

Month/Year Reported  
  
---|---|---|---  
Brazil Ministry of Health| Brazil| Government| December 2021  
Correios| Brazil| Government| December 2021  
Impresa| Portugal| Media| January 2022  
Claro| LATAM| Information - Wired and Wireless Telecommunications Carriers| January 2022  
Vodaphone PT| Portugal| Information - Wired and Wireless Telecommunications Carriers| February 2022  
Cofina| Portugal| Media| February 2022  
Mercado Libre| LATAM| E-commerce| March 2022  
Nvidia| Global| Semiconductor and Other Electronic Component Manufacturing| March 2022  
Samsung| Global| Semiconductor and Other Electronic Component Manufacturing| March 2022  
Ubisoft| France| Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services| March 2022  
Microsoft| US| Information - Software Publishers| March 2022  
LG Electronics| Korea| Communications Equipment Manufacturing| March 2022  
Okta| US| Information - Software Publishers| March 2022  
  
# Conclusion

Hive0115 has been extremely active since first surfacing in December 2021. There has been increased reporting of this group conductingattacks targeting various organizations to include large organizations with mature security operations. At this time, we have not seen reports of Hive0115 using malware to conduct operations and instead it is likely relying on stolen credentials and/or insider access to gain initial access. Once inside, the attackers can masquerade as a legitimate user to exfiltrate data.

# Recommendations

  * Utilize [zero trust approaches](https://www.ibm.com/security/zero-trust) and architectures to mitigate potential damages due to insider threats.
  * Compartmentalize all information in an effort to keep those without a need to know from sensitive information.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Do not install unapproved apps on a device that has access to the corporate network.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# References

<https://therecord.media/lapsus-ransomware-gang-hits-sic-portugals-largest-tv-channel/>

<https://www.reuters.com/technology/brazils-health-ministry-website-hit-by-hacker-attack-systems-down-2021-12-10/>

<https://www.theverge.com/2022/3/1/22957212/nvidia-confirms-hack-proprietary-information-lapsus>

<https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hackers-leak-190gb-of-alleged-samsung-data-source-code/>

[https://securityaffairs.co/wordpress/128912/cyber-crime/lapsus-ransomware-is-hiring.html?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=lapsus-ransomware-is-hiring](https://securityaffairs.co/wordpress/128912/cyber-crime/lapsus-ransomware-is-hiring.html?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=lapsus-ransomware-is-hiring)

<https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/microsoft/lapsus-hackers-leak-37gb-of-microsofts-alleged-source-code/>

[https://www.ibm.com/downloads/cas/YNAPDA6B](https://xfti-confluence.dal1a.cirrus.ibm.com/pages/createpage.action?spaceKey=IIR&title=7&linkCreation=true&fromPageId=82641678)

<https://www.wired.com/story/lapsus-hacking-group-extortion-nvidia-samsung/>

[https://twitter.com/vxunderground/status/1484665958476271617?s=20&t=VULomNldDopDLa9jbbApJQ](https://twitter.com/vxunderground/status/1484665958476271617?s=20&t=VULomNldDopDLa9jbbApJQ)

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Android Trojan Targets Banking Users In Malaysia
A blog post from Cyble analyzes a banking Trojan specifically targeting users in Malaysia in an attempt to steal SMS messages and online banking credentials.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Android banking Trojan 
  * **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Malicious APK
  *  **Targets:** Malaysian banking users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake "Cleaning Service Malaysia" app
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential theft, SMS stealing



# Overview

Cyble published a blog post analyzing a banking Trojan targeting Malaysian users. The malware masquerades as an Android booking application for a Malaysian cleaning company. Once on the device various intrusive permissions are requested, with the RECEIVE_SMS permissions being heavily abused in particular. The payload abuses this permission to listen for incoming messages and upload any that are received to a C2 server. Additionally, the fake application is designed to steal victim data. It uses the cleaner booking application theme to request payment details, specifically via online banking. Navigating to the payment screen provides victims with a list of Malaysian banks to choose from. Selecting a bank then leads to a fake version of its login page. Any entered credentials are subsequently exfiltrated to the attacker. For more information, see the Cyble blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055785/Android%20Trojan%20Targets%20Banking%20Users%20In%20Malaysia%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638820789074&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.



# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2021/12/01/banking-trojan-targets-banking-users-in-malaysia/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Execution - TA0041**  
T1575 - Native Code  
  
 **Persistence - TA0028**  
T1402 - Broadcast Receivers  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0031**  
T1411 - Input Prompt  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0036**  
T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  
  
 **Impact - TA0034**  
T1400 - Modify System Partition

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: COVID Themed Spam Delivers NJRat
A report from VIPRE Labs shows that while Coronavirus/COVID-19 spam began a downward trend in September, cybercriminals continue to exploit the pandemic. VIPRE provides an analysis of a recent spam email that uses Coronavirus vaccine release information as its lure.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Spam




# Overview

A spam email using coronavirus vaccine information release information as its lure was analyzed by VIPRE Labs. The email claims to be from the World Health Organization (WHO) and has a .cab file attached. The sending domain is shown as "wh0.com", note the zero, and has no relationship to the WHO, whose domain is "who.int". The email also contains lines of very small text that are a collection of random words, possibly included with the intent of evading anti-spam systems. The .cab files contains a single executable file named “Server.exe”. This file actually a variant of the NJRat (aka Bladabindi) Trojan. When executed, Server.exe creates a copy of itself in the system temp folder, names the copy “System32.exe” and executes it, then terminates. To run without restriction, System32.exe sets SEE_MASK_NOZONECHECKS to “1” and then creates permissions for itself in the system firewall. Persistence is achieved through three registry entries. It will then begin communicating with its C&C server, send information about the victim system to the server, and kill certain processes. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.vipre.com/malicious-covid-19-vaccine-email-contains-remote-access-trojan/>

output:

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Mirai Malware Variants Continue to Target Linux
The Crowdstrike research team assesses that Mirai malware variants targeting Linux are increasing. According to Crowdstrike, these Mirai variants continue to compromise systems to populate their botnets.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Linux Devices
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Brute Force, vulnerability exploitation.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Various ****
  * **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

The Crowdstrike report details a number of capabilities of Mirai variants, but focuses on instances that are targeting 32-bit x86 Linux systems. There is a significant increase in Mirai variants that target Linux systems that enterprise environments use as servers and networking endpoints. Crowdstrike research indicates that threat actors are targeting the Linux x86 monoculture because it is easier to target these devices as the Mirai code does not have to be continually updated. Additionally, the targeting and compromise of Linux servers provide more computing “power” for the botnet. The researchers at Crowdstrike go on to point out that the Mirai variants still utilize brute force attacks to gain initial access, but also exploit new vulnerabilities like the recent vulnerability in Log4j. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * [https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/linux-mirai-malware-double-on-stronger-chips/?&web_view=true](https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/linux-mirai-malware-double-on-stronger-chips/?&web_view=true "Follow link")



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1110 - Brute Force  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1090 - Proxy

  
 **Mitigations:**

 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1036:** Account Use Policies - Configure features related to account use like login attempt lockouts, specific login times, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Renewed SideWinder Activity in South Asia
SideWinder is an APT that targets South Asian government and military organizations with espionage campaigns, likely acting in Indian interests. DeepEnd Research reports on the most recent wave of activity from this threat group.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Renewed SideWinder Activity in South Asia
SideWinder is an APT that targets South Asian government and military organizations with espionage campaigns, likely acting in Indian interests. DeepEnd Research reports on the most recent wave of activity from this threat group.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Spyware, APT




# Overview

DeepEnd Research published a blog post analyzing the most recent wave of SideWinder APT activity. This specific campaign appears to target government entities in Nepal. Their research began with the discovery of a server hosting shell code. This shell code was determined to be the second stage payload, specifically a Meterpreter payload. Using this sample they were able to trace it back to a first stage payload likely delivered by HTA spear phishing email attachments. The HTA file downloads a spyware payload that steals logins from browsers and files from user folders to exfiltrate back to the C2 server. Additionally, the server hosted many credential phishing landing pages targeting various Nepalese government organizations. These pages leveraged the legitimate versions of login pages to load resources in order to make it appear more realistic. One of the most interesting pages was that created for a new target, the Election Commission of Nepal. This is noteworthy given recent news associated with the upcoming Nepalese elections. Finally, the researchers note the discovery of mobile malware being developed by the group, but it appears to be in the testing stage. For more information, see the Deep End Research blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <http://www.deependresearch.org/2021/03/renewed-sidewinder-activity-in-south.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Squirrelwaffle Loader Delivers Cobalt Strike
A report from Zscaler ThreatLabz provides an analysis of a malspam campaign and a new loader named Squirrelwaffle that is being used to deliver Cobalt Strike.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Squirrelwaffle Loader Delivers Cobalt Strike
A report from Zscaler ThreatLabz provides an analysis of a malspam campaign and a new loader named Squirrelwaffle that is being used to deliver Cobalt Strike.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Squirrelwaffle loader, Cobalt Strike (S0154)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious documents delivered via Malspam campaign.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions: Unspecified**
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A malspam campaign that has been running since mid-September is distributing a new loader named Squirrelwaffle, according to a report from Zscaler ThreatLabz. The payload delivered by Squirrelwaffle is Cobalt Strike. The infrastructure used to host Squirrelwaffle is known to have been used to distribute the Qakbot banking Trojan. The malspam is using an email thread hijacking technique that has been used in the distribution of Emotet and Qakbot. The spam emails contain a link that leads to an archive file that contains a malicious Word or Excel file. Macros in the documents either drop a VBS file used to download the Squirrelwaffle DLL or download the DLL directly. The DLL is executed by either rundll32.exe or regsvr.exe. Once executed Squirrelwaffle begins communicating with its C&C server and downloads a Cobalt Strike stager that in turn delivers a Cobalt Strike beacon. ThreatLabz notes that while Squirrelwaffle employs techniques similar to previous Emotet campaigns, it is unclear whether a known threat actor or a new group, has developed and is distributing Squirrelwaffle. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129072/Squirrelwaffle%20Loader%20Delivers%20Cobalt%20Strike%20IoCs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1632981297383&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/squirrelwaffle-new-loader-delivering-cobalt-strike>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1106 - Native API  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
T1569 - System Services  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1137 - Office Application Startup  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

Tell me about the following threat: Service NSW Breach Report
Breach / Leak Notification: A breach report from Service NSW (Australia) discloses that an attack on Service NSW email accounts resulted in attackers obtaining 3.8 million documents, in total, 738 gigabytes of data.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Service NSW Breach Report
Breach / Leak Notification: A breach report from Service NSW (Australia) discloses that an attack on Service NSW email accounts resulted in attackers obtaining 3.8 million documents, in total, 738 gigabytes of data.

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"Service NSW is in the final stages of analysis into the cyber attack earlier this year on 47 staff email accounts and we're now working to notify customers who had personal information in the breach. The investigation has taken 4 months and required a highly technical approach to identify the exact amount of customer information in the 3.8 million documents (738 gigabytes of data) stolen from the email accounts. This rigorous first step surfaced about 500,000 documents which referenced personal information."

# Reference

  * <https://www.service.nsw.gov.au/cyber-incident>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Crytominer and DDoS Bot Malware Loaded Onto Docker Image
Trend Micro is reporting that Alpine Linux Docker images are being attacked and loaded with crytominer and DDoS bot code. A similar attack in May of this year was also reported by Trend Micro.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Crytominer and DDoS Bot Malware Loaded Onto Docker Image
Trend Micro is reporting that Alpine Linux Docker images are being attacked and loaded with crytominer and DDoS bot code. A similar attack in May of this year was also reported by Trend Micro.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptominer, Bot, DDoS



# Overview

Reminiscent of an attack Trend Micro reported on in May of this year, they are now reporting on a similar attack. Docker images, based on Alpine Linux, are being attacked. Should the attack be successful, the server is infected with a cryptominer and DDoS bot malware. Infection begins on an exposed Docker server by creating a Docker container and running a script that retrieves an XMI file, which is really a bash script inside the container. This script then attempts to move laterally across the network, targeting hosts listed in the known_hosts file in the .ssh directory. Hosts listed in this file are systems this host / user has connected to in the past over an SSH connection. In some cases, the remote host might have this system's public key in their authorized_keys file, thus a connection could be made without knowing login credentials. The XMI script also downloads and executes other commands, such as those needed to set up cron jobs and services for persistence. Other commands in the script were commented out, such as one that appears to attempt to connect to SSH servers through brute-forcing the password. Trend Micro noted that the cryptocurrency wallet was the same one seen in campaigns that attempted to exploit a Confluence vulnerability (CVE-2019-3396) and an Apache Struts vulnerability (CVE-2017-5638). The XMI script then drops a cryptominer malware package and the DDoS bot. For more technical details, please see the Trend Micro article in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/29431538/Crytominer%20and%20DDoS%20Bot%20Malware%20Loaded%20Onto%20Docker%20Image%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599672212428&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Crytominer and DDoS Bot Malware Loaded Onto Docker Image
Trend Micro is reporting that Alpine Linux Docker images are being attacked and loaded with crytominer and DDoS bot code. A similar attack in May of this year was also reported by Trend Micro.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptominer, Bot, DDoS



# Overview

Reminiscent of an attack Trend Micro reported on in May of this year, they are now reporting on a similar attack. Docker images, based on Alpine Linux, are being attacked. Should the attack be successful, the server is infected with a cryptominer and DDoS bot malware. Infection begins on an exposed Docker server by creating a Docker container and running a script that retrieves an XMI file, which is really a bash script inside the container. This script then attempts to move laterally across the network, targeting hosts listed in the known_hosts file in the .ssh directory. Hosts listed in this file are systems this host / user has connected to in the past over an SSH connection. In some cases, the remote host might have this system's public key in their authorized_keys file, thus a connection could be made without knowing login credentials. The XMI script also downloads and executes other commands, such as those needed to set up cron jobs and services for persistence. Other commands in the script were commented out, such as one that appears to attempt to connect to SSH servers through brute-forcing the password. Trend Micro noted that the cryptocurrency wallet was the same one seen in campaigns that attempted to exploit a Confluence vulnerability (CVE-2019-3396) and an Apache Struts vulnerability (CVE-2017-5638). The XMI script then drops a cryptominer malware package and the DDoS bot. For more technical details, please see the Trend Micro article in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/29431538/Crytominer%20and%20DDoS%20Bot%20Malware%20Loaded%20Onto%20Docker%20Image%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599672212428&api=v2)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Lazarus Malware Exploiting INITECH Security Software
ASEC Labs has discovered a new malware infecting over 40 companies. This malware is attributed to the Lazarus group and exploits a process belonging to security software from INITECH.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Lazarus Malware Exploiting INITECH Security Software
ASEC Labs has discovered a new malware infecting over 40 companies. This malware is attributed to the Lazarus group and exploits a process belonging to security software from INITECH.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Downloader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Lazarus
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Korean Companies, Defense, Chemical
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Malware Download



# Overview

ASEC labs recently spotted malicious activity coming from a process belonging to security software from INITECH. The process was confirmed to be legitimate, but an investigation showed that a malicious DLL file was injected into the legitimate process for execution. This malicious DLL contains code to reach out to a URL and download and run additional malware. The malware also contains code to inject into other processes, such as svchost and rundll32, but there is no additional code for these processes. This suggests the malware is unfinished and may be under development. The scope of this campaign appears to be broadening to major Korean companies in sectors including the defense and chemical sector. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/33801/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Transparent Tribe Operation Targeting Indian Government
Transparent Tribe is a suspected Pakistani APT that targets government and military personnel in India. Lab52 reports on a recent campaign that leverages COVID-19 lure documents to install the PeppyRAT malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Transparent Tribe Operation Targeting Indian Government
Transparent Tribe is a suspected Pakistani APT that targets government and military personnel in India. Lab52 reports on a recent campaign that leverages COVID-19 lure documents to install the PeppyRAT malware.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** RAT, APT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Transparent Tribe
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PeppyRAT
  *  **Targets:** Indian government and military personnel
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious IMG file
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote command execution



# Overview

Lab52 published a blog post detailing a recent Transparent Tribe campaign targeting government and military personnel in India. The initial payload is a malicious IMG file containing a decoy PDF document, a shortcut file, and executable. The decoy document uses a COVID-19 theme and is displayed upon execution of the shortcut. Meanwhile, the executable, which the researchers identified as PeppyRAT, runs in the background. The executable file uses embedded Python commands to load and run a Python script in memory. The Python code subsequently gathers a list of running processes and other system information, which is exfiltrated to the attacker via an HTTP POST request. Persistence is established via a secondary executable in the Windows startup folder. This secondary executable is responsible for retrieving the next-stage payload, a Windows DLL capable of receiving commands from the C2 server.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057569/New%20Transparent%20Tribe%20Operation%20Targeting%20Indian%20Government%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643141600602&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://lab52.io/blog/new-transparentribe-operation-targeting-india-with-weaponized-covid-19-lure-documents/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.006 - Python  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1568 - Dynamic Resolution

I have encountered the following information: Phishers Impersonate Pfizer in RFQ Scam
A report from INKY details the use of Pfizer look-alike domains and a request for quotation (RFQ) theme in an attempt to social engineer targets.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Unknown
  *  **Lure:** Fake request for quotation spoofing Pfizer
  *  **Payload:** PDF attachment
  *  **TTPs:** Spoofing Pfizer
  *  **Compromised Data:** Banking details



# Overview

INKY published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign spoofing Pfizer and using a request for quotation (RFQ) theme. A series of domains containing the word "pfizer" were registered via NameCheap leading up to the campaign starting. The body of the emails claim that Pfizer is requesting a quote for various expensive industrial engineering supplies. Attached is a PDF providing further fake details under the guise of a Pfizer RFQ. Recipients are requested to email a seperate Pfizer lookalike email address with their quote. It is likely the secondary stage of the campaign is to obtain banking details from those who fall victim to the lure. For more information, see the INKY blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056451/Phishers%20Impersonate%20Pfizer%20in%20RFQ%20Scam%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640635590618&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.inky.com/blog/fresh-phish-phishers-impersonate-pfizer-in-request-for-quotation-scam>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1598 - Phishing for Information  
T1598.002 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1585 - Establish Accounts  
T1585.002 - Email Accounts

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: FBI FLASH Alert CP-000142-MW and PYSA Ransomware
The FBI has issued a FLASH Alert (CP-000142-MW) regarding a recent increase of PYSA ransomware targeting education institutions in 12 U.S. states and the United Kingdom.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Ransomware, Data-theft




# Overview

The FBI has issued a FLASH (FBI Liaison Alert System) Alert (CP-000142-MW) regarding a recent increase of PYSA ransomware targeting education institutions in 12 U.S. states and the United Kingdom. The initial attack vector is often via phishing emails, but PYSA, also known as Mespinoza, has additionally been known to gain unauthorized access to victim networks by compromising Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) credentials. Data stolen by the unidentified cyber actors has been uploaded to [mega.nz](http://mega.nz), a cloud storage and file sharing service. They have specifically targeted higher education, K-12 schools, and seminaries. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://seclists.org/educause/2021/q1/336>

  * <https://digital.nhs.uk/cyber-alerts/2020/cc-3633>
  * <https://www.sapphire.net/news-views/pysa-ransomware/>
