instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Ursnif and Cerberus Automate Fraudulent Bank Transfers
IBM Trusteer researchers continually monitor the evolution and attack tactics in the banking sector. In a recent analysis, our team found that an Ursnif (aka Gozi) banking Trojan variant is being used in the wild to target online banking users in Italy with mobile malware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

In a recent analysis, IBM Trusteer researchers found that an Ursnif (aka Gozi) banking Trojan variant is being used to target online banking users in Italy. Recent campaigns in Italy deliver Ursnif to business email recipients in attachments that purport to carry invoices, delivery notices, or other business correspondence. Once infected by the Ursnif malware and upon attempting to access their online banking account, victims are advised, via web injection, that they need to download a security app. A QR code is provided to obtain the app from a fake Google Play page. If the QR code fails, the victim is asked to provide their mobile number and they will receive an SMS message with the download link. The app contains the Cerberus Android malware. Cerberus is used by Ursnif’s operators to receive two-factor authentication codes sent by banks. Ursnif allows the attacker to change the international bank account number (IBAN) and bank identifier code (BIC) numbers from legitimate transactions to an IBAN of an account under the attacker's control. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securityintelligence.com/posts/ursnif-cerberus-android-malware-bank-transfers-italy/>

  * Malware




# Overview

In a recent analysis, IBM Trusteer researchers found that an Ursnif (aka Gozi) banking Trojan variant is being used to target online banking users in Italy. Recent campaigns in Italy deliver Ursnif to business email recipients in attachments that purport to carry invoices, delivery notices, or other business correspondence. Once infected by the Ursnif malware and upon attempting to access their online banking account, victims are advised, via web injection, that they need to download a security app. A QR code is provided to obtain the app from a fake Google Play page. If the QR code fails, the victim is asked to provide their mobile number and they will receive an SMS message with the download link. The app contains the Cerberus Android malware. Cerberus is used by Ursnif’s operators to receive two-factor authentication codes sent by banks. Ursnif allows the attacker to change the international bank account number (IBAN) and bank identifier code (BIC) numbers from legitimate transactions to an IBAN of an account under the attacker's control. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securityintelligence.com/posts/ursnif-cerberus-android-malware-bank-transfers-italy/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The Klingon RAT
The Klingon RAT is written in Go and exhibits very little code reuse. According to a report from Intezer, the operators of the RAT are financially motivated.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

is written in Go and exhibits very little code reuse. According to a report from Intezer, the operators of the RAT are financially motivated.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

 is written in Go and exhibits very little code reuse, which Intezer notes is uncommon in a RAT. Of note is an extensive list of anti-virus processes (in excess of 650) that Klingon will terminate if it finds them running. Persistence is achieved using multiple registry entries and a scheduled task. Multiple methods to bypass UAC are used to achieve privilege escalation. Communications with Klingon's C&C servers are encrypted using TLS. The RAT functionality includes the ability to start a SOCKS proxy, a reverse shell, or an RDP server, execute a binary file, and run PowerShell commands. No information on the methods used to distribute Klingon is provided in the report. The purpose of the malware is to obtain a victim's financial data which can then be used by the operators. The technical details are available from Intezer's report which is linked in the Reference section below.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Zeppelin Ransomware Attacks
The Zeppelin ransomware is known to have been used in attacks against healthcare and IT services providers in 2019. In late August 2020, Juniper Threat Labs observed a new campaign distributing Zeppelin and using a new Trojan downloader.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Juniper Threat Labs observed a new campaign distributing Zeppelin in late August, 2020. A new Trojan downloader has been implemented which, according to Juniper, is "largely undetected by antivirus applications". Malicious Word documents, which are presented as invoices, are used as the initial infection vector. A victim would need to enable macros for the document's malicious VBA code to begin executing. The initial macro writes a .vbs file to the local system, which is then executed when the document is closed. When executed, the .vbs script downloads the Zeppelin ransomware which is in turn executed after a pause. The pause is an attempt to evade automated sandbox analysis. Zeppelin does not infect systems which are located in Belarus, Kazakhstan, Russia, or Ukraine. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/threat-research/zeppelin-ransomware-returns-with-a-fresh-wave-of-attacks>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories March 18 2021
The ICS-CERT has published 3 advisories that affect Johnson Controls Exacq Technologies exacqVision, Hitachi ABB Power Grids eSOMS, and Hitachi ABB Power Grids eSOMS Telerik.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ICS-CERT Advisories March 18 2021
The ICS-CERT has published 3 advisories that affect Johnson Controls Exacq Technologies exacqVision, Hitachi ABB Power Grids eSOMS, and Hitachi ABB Power Grids eSOMS Telerik.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarized below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-077-01 - Johnson Controls Exacq Technologies exacqVision**  
CVE-2021-27656 - exacqVision Web Service can expose sensitive information to an actor who is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-077-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-077-02 - Hitachi ABB Power Grids eSOMS**  
CVE-2021-26845 - A vulnerability exists in the eSOMS reporting function that could allow an unauthorized user to gain access to report data if the URL used to access the report is discovered.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-077-02>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-077-03 - Hitachi ABB Power Grids eSOMS Telerik**  
CVE-2019-19790 - Path traversal in RadChart in Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX allows a remote attacker to read and delete an image with extension .BMP, .EXIF, .GIF, .ICON, .JPEG, .PNG, .TIFF, or .WMF on the server through a specially crafted request.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2019-18935 - Progress Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX through 2019.3.1023 contains a .NET deserialization vulnerability in the RadAsyncUpload function. This is exploitable when the encryption keys are known.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2017-11357 - Progress Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX before R2 2017 SP2 does not properly restrict user input to RadAsyncUpload, which allows remote attackers to perform arbitrary file uploads or execute arbitrary code.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2017-11317 - Telerik.Web.UI in Progress Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX before R1 2017 and R2 before R2 2017 SP2 uses weak RadAsyncUpload encryption, which allows remote attackers to perform arbitrary file uploads or execute arbitrary code.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2017-9248 - Telerik.Web.UI.dll in Progress Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX before R2 2017 SP1 and Sitefinity before 10.0.6412.0 does not properly protect Telerik.Web.UI.DialogParametersEncryptionKey or the MachineKey, which makes it easier for remote attackers to defeat cryptographic protection mechanisms, leading to a MachineKey leak, arbitrary file uploads or downloads, XSS, or ASP.NET ViewState compromise.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2014-2217 - Absolute path traversal vulnerability in the RadAsyncUpload control in the RadControls in Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX before Q3 2012 SP2 allows remote attackers to write to arbitrary files, and consequently execute arbitrary code, via a full pathname in the UploadID metadata value.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2014-4958 - Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX RadEditor control 2014.1.403.35, 2009.3.1208.20, and other versions allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary web script or HTML via CSS expressions in style attributes.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-077-03>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/44007854/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20March%2018%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1616132099395&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TA505 and CL0P
A posting on the Deutsche Telekom blog looks at the relationships between TA505 and the operators of the CL0P ransomware, along with some of their activities throughout the past year.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, APT




# Overview

A posting on the Deutsche Telekom blog looks at some of the activities of TA505 and the operators of the CL0P ransomware throughout the past year. TA505 is also known as CHIMBORAZO, Evil Corp, GOLD TAHOE, Graceful Spider, Sector J04, and Temp.Warlock. The group known as FIN11 may also be TA505 or a subgroup of TA505. IBM X-Force tracks TA505 as ITG19. According to Deutsche Telekom, the operators of the CL0P ransomware may also be a subgroup of, or managed by, TA505. Another group known as Silence appears to have some form on relationship with TA505. These subgroups may also be simple clients of TA505 as TA505 tends to focus on gaining access to targets. They may then sell access to the victim's network or hand off to a subgroup or client who conducts further operations, such as the deployment of the CL0P ransomware. Deutsche Telekom noted three waves of spam from TA505 in 2020. The first wave ran January through February, the second June until September, and the last run in early December. TA505 spam is typically sent during weekdays, whereas the CL0P deployments more often occurred on a Friday or Saturday. The emails may contain a link or an HTML attachment, which lead the victim to a malicious document. If the document is opened and macros are enabled, the infection chain begins. CL0P ransoms tend to be based on the revenue of the victim company and a victim's sensitive data will have been exfiltrated prior to the ransomware being executed. The ransom notes are customized to the victim and the CL0P operators maintain a portal where victims can negotiate or pay ransoms. If a victim does not pay the ransom, their sensitive data will be made public on the portal. Further details are available from the Deutsche Telekom blog posting linked to in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.telekom.com/en/blog/group/article/inside-of-cl0p-s-ransomware-operation-615824>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Ransom DDoS Campaign Returns
A previous alert from Radware in October 2020 detailed a DDoS extortion campaign impacting their customers. Recently, these threat actors returned to the same targets.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * DDoS, Extortion




# Overview

  
Radware published an advisory describing recent DDoS extortion activities targeting their customers. DDoS extortion campaigns threaten to disrupt a target's availability if the requested ransom is not paid. This campaign appears to be a follow up to previous attacks that occurred in August 2020. The new ransom letters reference the previous attacks. Furthermore, they were specifically targeted towards organizations who did not previously respond to the extortion attempts. The researchers are confident it is the same threat actor as details of the targeted companies were not previously revealed so only the original actors would know who to send the ransom notes to. DDoS attacks began within hours of the letters being sent with the same methodology used as the original campaign. For more information, see the Radware advisory in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * <https://www.radware.com/security/ddos-threats-attacks/threat-advisories-attack-reports/ddos-extortions-back/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Bogus CSS Injection Leads to Stolen Credit Card Details
An antivirus alert led Sucuri researchers to discover a malicious script designed for stealing credit card details injected into a Magento database.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Stealer




# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing malicious code injected into a Magento database. Often with Magento databases, default credentials and admin URLs are used to obtain initial access. The JavaScript injection in this case was found with over 18,000 lines injected into one of the databases, done so in order to hide itself from the administrator panel in the web interface. It uses script tags to load and execute a remotely hosted file with a CSS extension. This file contains legitimate FontAwesome content but it is commented out, leaving only a line of code to load a secondary file, again with a CSS extension. This additional file contains the malicious JavaScript responsible for scraping credit card data to exfiltrate back to attackers. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/01/bogus-css-injection-leads-to-stolen-credit-card-details.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Pysa Inadvertently Exposes File Keyword Targets
Pysa ransomware has exposed a PowerShell script that shows the types of data the group attempts to steal during attacks, reports Bleeping Computer.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Ransomware Family:** Pysa
  *  **Targets:** N/A
  *  **Ransom Demand:** N/A
  *  **Intrusion Vector:** N/A
  *  **Data Exfiltrated:** N/A
  *  **Data Encrypted:** N/A
  *  **Data Published:** N/A



# Overview

A PowerShell script employed by the Pysa ransomware group has allowed researchers to ascertain the types of files the group looks to exfiltrate during a cyberattack. The MalwareHunterTeam has shared the PowerShell script with Bleeping Computer and shows what type of data to search for and exfiltrate from the victim machine or server. The script scans each drive for folders in which the names match strings in a pre-defined list. The script then uploads the data to a drop server. In all, 123 keywords are contained within the script to include insurance information, login credentials, tax forms, student information, social security numbers, and other financial and personal data. Other terms are dealing with fraud, crime, and governmental types of information are also contained within the list. In addition to Pysa, Conti is also employing a pre-defined list of search terms in their operations. The complete list of terms and other details are located in the article within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/ransomware-gangs-script-shows-exactly-the-files-theyre-after/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Golang RAT
Bitdefender researchers identified a new Golang RAT being delivered via exploitation of CVE-2019-2725, an Oracle WebLogic RCE vulnerability.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Exploit




# Overview

Bitdefender has published a blog post analyzing a new Golang RAT. This malware uses CVE-2019-2725, an Oracle WebLogic RCE vulnerability, as an initial infection vector. Although WebLogic servers typically should not be public facing, when the vulnerability was identified so were tens of thousands of exposed servers, many of which remain unpatched. Using this CVE, a Golang payload is downloaded to the system. This payload is responsible for downloading, executing, and updating the RAT. For updating, it monitors a remote URL to identify when changes have been made and the new version should be downloaded. Persistence is established using a startup script created by this initial payload. Additionally, it regularly checks that the RAT is still running and restarts it if not. The RAT payload sends a check-in message to its C2 that contains system information, such as the OS, hardware details, and IP address. It supports two commands, one to execute shell commands and the other to download and run a binary. Although there are only a couple available commands, they allow for extensive capabilities, and the malware still appears to be in early development stages. Based on infrastructure and code overlap, Bitdefender believes this campaign is related to the previously reported PowerGhost campaign. For more information, see the Bitdefender blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.bitdefender.com/2020/10/theres-a-new-a-golang-written-rat-in-town/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-039A - SUNBURST
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency malware analysis report, AR21-039A, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report provides information on the SUNBURST malware, which is associated with the supply chain compromise of Solar Winds.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

 **From the Malware Analysis Report (AR21-039A)**  
 **MAR-10318845-1.v1 - SUNBURST**

This report provides detailed analysis of several malicious artifacts associated with a sophisticated supply chain compromise of SolarWinds Orion network management software, identified by the security company FireEye as SUNBURST.

After being delivered as part of certain SolarWinds updates, a trojanized version of the “solarwinds.orion.core.businesslayer.dll” containing SUNBURST malware is installed by a legitimate SolarWinds installer application. The modified dynamic-link library (DLL) contains an obfuscated backdoor that allows a remote operator to execute various functions on the compromised system, as well as deploy additional payloads and exfiltrate data. The embedded SUNBURST code encrypts its outbound communications to the remote operator using XOR encryption and modified Base64 encoding. To maintain a low profile, the SUNBURST code will not run if it detects certain security software running on the target system.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-039a>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Egregor RaaS Continues To Present Problems
Sentinel Labs reports on Egregor ransomware. Egregor is based on the Sekhmet malware family. Egregor activity was first seen in September 2020.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, RaaS



# Overview

Sentinel Labs reports on a malware package based on the Sekhmet malware family called Egregor. It has been active since September 2020. It is thought that Egregor was used in attacks against GEFCO, Barnes & Noble, Ubisoft, as well as others. Some security experts also believe that there are ties between Maze affiliates (Maze is now defunct), ProLock, LockBit, and Egregor. Distribution of Egregor is primarily through Cobalt Strike that has been installed on victim using RDP exploits, phishing, as well as other means. Other delivery methods reported include exploiting vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange, the VBScript Engine, and Adobe Flash Player (see CVEs section below). Systems using a primary language that falls within a language white-list (see below) are excluded from infection. As is becoming common, Egregor also exfiltrates the victim's data to its command and control server. This is achieved using an open-source application called Rclone. This data is used to force the victim to pay the ransom else it will be publicly disclosed. After the victim's files have been encrypted, the victim is presented with a ransom note directing them to a TOR-based payment portal. For additional details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Exclusion List

  * Armenian
  * Azerbaijani
  * Belarusian
  * Georgian
  * Kazakh
  * Kyrgyz
  * Romanian
  * Russian
  * Tajik
  * Tatar
  * Turkmen
  * Ukrainian
  * Uzbek



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33983830/Egregor%20RaaS%20Continues%20To%20Present%20Problems%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606334283255&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/33983830/Egregor%20RaaS%20Continues%20To%20Present%20Problems%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606334302870&api=v2)

## IBM

  * CVE-2018-8174: Script_IE_DoubleKill
  * CVE-2018-15982: Swf_Flash_Player_Corruption_224

# Recommendations

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/egregor-raas-continues-the-chaos-with-cobalt-strike-and-rclone/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Rampant Kitten and Espionage
Check Point Research has been monitoring an ongoing espionage campaign by Iranian threat actors who have been targeting Iranian expats and dissidents for a number of years.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Rampant Kitten and Espionage
Check Point Research has been monitoring an ongoing espionage campaign by Iranian threat actors who have been targeting Iranian expats and dissidents for a number of years.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Espionage, Info-Stealer, Backdoor



# Overview

Iranian expats and dissidents have been under surveillance by Iranian threat actors for a number of years, a Check Point article indicates. Their investigation of a number of sightings is the basis of their claim that these attacks are from the same threat-group. They discovered a document, supposedly concerning the ongoing struggle between the Iranian regime and the Revolutionary Cannons, a Mujahedin-e Khalq movement. The document in question uses an external template technique that is loaded from a remote server. The template contains malicious macro code that begins operating once the victim opens the document. The macro code begins executing a batch file that attempts to download and execute the next stage payload. If Telegram is installed on the system, this payload attempts to extract three additional executables stored in its resources. One of the executables is a loader, the second is an infostealer package, and the third is an update to Telegram. Persistence for the malware is based on Telegram's internal update procedure. SOAP, a web-based messaging protocol, is used in command and control communications. The primary goal of the malware used is to steal as much information as possible from the victimized system. Telegram Desktop and KeePass, a password storage application, are the two main targets for the malware. Another tool discovered during their investigation was a backdoor for Android devices. The disguise this app uses is as a service to help Persian speakers in Sweden get their driver’s license. This app retrieves SMS messages, forwards two-factor SMS messages to an attacker controlled phone, steals contacts and account details, records the phone's surroundings, Google account phishing, as well as returns device information (installed apps, running processes, etc.) to the command and control servers. For more details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/30769519/Rampant%20Kitten%20and%20Espionage%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600451078411&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/rampant-kitten-an-iranian-espionage-campaign/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Phishing Campaign Aiming to Steal One-Time Passwords
ZScaler researchers discovered a sophisticated phishing campaign targeting customers of top Indian banks, in an attempt to install malware which would be able to steal one-time passwords from the user's mobile device.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Targets:** Indian Banking Customers
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

ZScaler researchers discovered a sophisticated phishing campaign targeting customers of top Indian banks. The phishing campaign is designed to capture the customer's banking credentials and install malicious SMS stealers on the user's phone or tablet. These websites are convincing fakes of the banks and contain forms meant to harvest victim data. The form attempts to collect the account number, name, mobile number, as well as bank card information. Once all of this has been entered, the site attempts to download an android app onto the device, with the user being informed that the app is a banking support app. The app is named SBOI Quick Support. Once the app is installed, it requests permissions to send/view messages from the phone. Lastly, after all the permissions are granted, the app displays a fake form for submitting a complaint number. In the background, the app monitors all messages that the device receives and exfiltrates them along with device information to the C2 server. This campaign aims to retrieve the banking details and monitor the victim's device for any one-time passwords that may be received from the bank, allowing the attackers complete access to the victim's accounts. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68617319/Phishing%20Campaign%20Aiming%20to%20Steal%20One-Time%20Passwords%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635864489831&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).

  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).

  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.



# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/how-phishing-campaign-targeting-indian-banking-users-distributing-sms>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**

T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application

T1566 - Phishing

 **Execution - TA0041**

T1204.002 – User Execution: Malicious File

 **Discovery - TA0032**

T1422 – System Network Configuration Discovery

T1426 - System Information Discovery

 **Collection - TA0009**

T1409 - Access Stored Application Data

T1412 - Capture SMS Messages

 **Impact - TA0034**

T1448 – Carrier Billing Fraud

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Targets:** Indian Banking Customers
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

ZScaler researchers discovered a sophisticated phishing campaign targeting customers of top Indian banks. The phishing campaign is designed to capture the customer's banking credentials and install malicious SMS stealers on the user's phone or tablet. These websites are convincing fakes of the banks and contain forms meant to harvest victim data. The form attempts to collect the account number, name, mobile number, as well as bank card information. Once all of this has been entered, the site attempts to download an android app onto the device, with the user being informed that the app is a banking support app. The app is named SBOI Quick Support. Once the app is installed, it requests permissions to send/view messages from the phone. Lastly, after all the permissions are granted, the app displays a fake form for submitting a complaint number. In the background, the app monitors all messages that the device receives and exfiltrates them along with device information to the C2 server. This campaign aims to retrieve the banking details and monitor the victim's device for any one-time passwords that may be received from the bank, allowing the attackers complete access to the victim's accounts. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68617319/Phishing%20Campaign%20Aiming%20to%20Steal%20One-Time%20Passwords%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635864489831&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).

  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).

  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.



# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/how-phishing-campaign-targeting-indian-banking-users-distributing-sms>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**

T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application

T1566 - Phishing

 **Execution - TA0041**

T1204.002 – User Execution: Malicious File

 **Discovery - TA0032**

T1422 – System Network Configuration Discovery

T1426 - System Information Discovery

 **Collection - TA0009**

T1409 - Access Stored Application Data

T1412 - Capture SMS Messages

 **Impact - TA0034**

T1448 – Carrier Billing Fraud

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: CopperStealer Malware Distributed in Fake Cracks
A report from Trend Micro looks at a new version of the CopperStealer information-stealing malware that is being distributed in fake cracks downloaded from websites.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Information-stealing malware
* **Targets:** Users of software cracks
* **Malware Family/Families:** CopperStealer
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake software cracks downloaded from websites
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of information, enabling of RDP on victim system
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

CopperStealer is information-stealing malware that is being distributed in fake software cracks according to a report from Trend Micro. Typically, when a victim downloads the fake crack it arrives as an archive file which contains a second encrypted archive and text file with the archive's password. Once decompressed the victim is presented with an executable file that installs CopperStealer. It collects information from a number of web browsers and other applications and also enables remote access to the victim's computer using RDP. The collected data is exfiltrated to a dedicated Telegram channel. The new version of CopperStealer has changed some features, most notably is the move away from the use of a domain generation algorithm (DGA) that was used to randomize its C&C domains. The C&C domains are now retrieved from an encrypted configuration file that is hosted on a third-party webpage. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/f/websites-hosting-fake-cracks-spread-updated-copperstealer.html>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
 T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
   T1588.001 - Malware  
 T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
   T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
   T1608.005 - Link Target  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1195 - Supply Chain Compromise  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1204 - User Execution  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
   T1027.002 - Software Packing  
 T1078 - Valid Accounts  
   T1078.003 - Local Accounts  
 T1112 - Modify Registry  
 T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
 T1556 - Modify Authentication Process  
   T1556.004 - Network Device Authentication  
 T1562 - Impair Defenses  
   T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
   T1562.004 - Disable or Modify System Firewall  

**Credential Access - TA0006**  
 T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
 T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
   T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
 T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
   T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  
 T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1005 - Data from Local System  
 T1074 - Data Staged  
   T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
 T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
   T1560.001 - Archive via Utility  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
 T1568 - Dynamic Resolution  
   T1568.001 - Fast Flux DNS  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1015:**  Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1027:**  Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1032:**  Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
**M1035:**  Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1046:**  Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Flowspec Enables Cybercrime World to Thrive
RiskIQ has published an analysis on a new "bulletproof hosting service" dubbed Flowspec.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malicious Hosting Service




# Overview

In service since 2018, Flowspec is touted as a "bulletproof hosting provider" and is used as a one-stop-shop for facilitating phishing campaigns, malware delivery, Magecart skimmers, and other malicious infrastructure. The IP space allows for the targeting of banks and domain names that spoof gaming communities as well as Amazon. The service facilitates payment of Magecart skimming by hosting several domains. Malware hosted includes banking trojans, ransomware, various backdoors, and more. The service is both on underground forums and the clear web. Services offered include bulletproof servers, proxies, protected RDP, jabber server, webmail, secure VPNs, and others. Beginning in August 2021, RiskIQ noticed the move to the Tor network. The domains hosted on Flowspec have been known to spoof banks, online gaming platforms, and video games. A large number of domains contain the word steam indicating the targeting of the Steam gaming platform. Additionally, at least 19 domains associated with Magecart have been observed. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.riskiq.com/blog/external-threat-management/flowspec-bulletproof-hosting/>

Apple has published security updates for macOS and Safari.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 The macOS updates are available for macOS Big Sur 11.0.1, macOS Catalina 10.15.7, and macOS Mojave 10.14.6. The Safari updates are available for macOS Catalina and macOS Mojave. The most serious potential impact from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities is the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further details are available from the advisories linked in the Reference section below.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Evolution of GADOLINIUM Attacks
Focusing on the group's activity over the last couple years, Microsoft reports on a threat actor they call GADOLINIUM.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

Microsoft has published a blog post analyzing the activities of GADOLINIUM, a nation-state threat actor. Most recently the group has shifted their focus away from the maritime and health industries and towards higher education and regional government organization in the Asia Pacific region. Before discussing recent activity, the researchers mention activity from 2016 and 2018 leveraging TechNet and GitHub, respectively, to issues C2 commands. Broken down by attack phase, the rest of the blog post focuses on their 2019 and 2020 campaigns. In both cases, spear-phishing emails were used for initial access. At first they leveraged Access 2013 databases to execute a VBA dropper that, in turn, loads a .NET DLL payload. This DLL payload leverages the Outlook Task API for C2 communication. In 2020, they instead used a PPT attachment to drop a .dotm file. In this case, the .dotm file runs a secondary payload that downloads and decrypts a PNG file. The PNG file is responsible for running PowerShell commands that interact with the Microsoft Graph API for further actions. Along with using the Microsoft Graph API to download additional modules, the OneDrive API is used to execute commands and exfiltrate results. After the infection chain is complete, the attacker performs a variety of post-compromise actions, such as credential dumping, lateral movement, and privilege escalation. Both the custom LazyCat malware and web shells were seen in use. Microsoft notes that the group's infrastructure included several Azure Active Directory applications that have since been suspended. For more information, see the Microsoft blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2020/09/24/gadolinium-detecting-empires-cloud/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Malicious VPN Apps Masquerading as Popular Vendors
VPN apps have become more and more popular over the past year with increased remote work. Zscaler found a new campaign taking advantage of this trend to distribute the Raccoon stealer via fake VPN websites and installers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer




# Overview

Zscaler published a blog post analyzing a malware campaign distributing the Raccoon stealer via fake VPN installer packages. Look-alike websites related to popular VPN vendors, such as NordVPN, were stood up on infrastructure monitored by Zscaler researchers. Clicking the download link on these fake sites downloads a payload that has been packaged using the Inno Installer. The package does, in fact, contain the legitimate NordVPN installer; however, alongside this executable are a series of malicious scripts and binaries. The VBScript executed by the Inno Installer setup file is used to initialize the infection process. It is simply responsible for executing the three BAT files included in the package. The first BAT script disables Windows security software, the second decrypts and extracts a binary payload, and the final script performs clean up of all components created during the installation. Analysis of the .NET binary dropped by the second BAT script reveals multiple layers of obfuscation that eventually lead to the final payload, the Raccoon stealer. Hundreds of samples using this methodology for distribution were discovered, with multimedia and security software applications also being spoofed. Alternate final payloads are possibly being distributed by these additional samples. For more information, see the Zscaler blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/threat-actors-distribute-malicious-vpn-apps-masquerading-popular-vendors>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Oracle Security Alert Advisory - CVE-2020-14750
Oracle has published a security alert addressing a remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle WebLogic Server.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Exploit




# Overview

Oracle has published a security alert addressing a remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle WebLogic Server, CVE-2020-14750. This alert was published with an out-of-band update due to the fact exploit code as been publicly released. This, combined with its severity and impact, makes it likely to be exploited by threat actors. CVE-2020-14750 also allows for code execution by a remote, unauthenticated attacker and has been assigned a CVSS 3.1 score of 9.8. Versions 10.3.6.0.0, 12.1.3.0.0, 12.2.1.3.0, 12.2.1.4.0, 14.1.1.0.0 of Oracle WebLogic server are affected and a patch has been released to fix the vulnerability. The advisory notes that this vulnerability is also related to CVE-2020-14882, which was addressed in the October 2020 Critical Patch Update. We recommend reviewing the Oracle security advisory, linked to in the Reference section, and applying any applicable patches as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32147227/Oracle%20Security%20Alert%20Advisory%20-%20CVE-2020-14750%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1604347327763&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.oracle.com/security-alerts/alert-cve-2020-14750.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: VMware Security Advisory - VMSA-2020-0027
VMware has published security advisory, VMSA-2020-0027, which addresses a single command injection vulnerability, rated as Critical, in VMware Workspace One Access, Access Connector, Identity Manager, and Identity Manager Connector.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
VMware has published security advisory VMSA-2020-0027 that deals with a single vulnerability in VMware Workspace One Access, Access Connector, Identity Manager, and Identity Manager Connector. The vulnerability (CVE-2020-4006) could allow an attacker who can authenticate to the admin account on port 8443, to potentially execute commands on the underlying operating system. The commands could be executed with unrestricted privileges. Updates to mitigate the vulnerability are yet to be provided. Workarounds are provided in the advisory. Further details, including affected versions, are available from the advisory linked in the Reference section below. We recommend implementing the workarounds at the earliest opportunity.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33983115/VMware%20Security%20Advisory%20-%20VMSA-2020-0027%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606194567570&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2020-0027.html>

  * <https://kb.cert.org/vuls/id/724367>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: QR Codes Delivering Malicious Chrome Extension
A Twitter user has reported seeing malicious QR codes that are circulating on the platform, which are being used to spread malware. This blog post on the G Data Blog explores the outcomes of using the QR codes and the malware they distribute.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: QR Codes Delivering Malicious Chrome Extension
A Twitter user has reported seeing malicious QR codes that are circulating on the platform, which are being used to spread malware. This blog post on the G Data Blog explores the outcomes of using the QR codes and the malware they distribute.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Adware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Choziosi Loader **  
**
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** QR Codes to False Downloads
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Revenue from Ad Injection



# Overview

This G Data blog post analyzes the malware being distributed on Twitter via QR codes. These QR codes are being advertised as links to pirated software and games. In reality, these QR codes lead to download sites for an ISO file, which the user is encouraged to download. The ISO file contains two components. The first is an encrypted PowerShell script, which downloads a malicious chrome extension and installs it on the victim machine. The second is an executable file that decrypts the PowerShell script and installs it as a scheduled task which runs every ten minutes. The executable also shows an error message to the user to trick them into thinking the installation of their pirated software failed. The chrome extension is highly obfuscated and seems to be serving advertisements to victims, which are fetched from the C2 server every thirty minutes. The malware also hijacks search requests made to popular search engines. Evert three hours, metrics on the user's activity are sent to the C2 server. This appears to be the only functionality so far, but the analyst speculates that the loader could be used to deliver more destructive malware in the future. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058263/QR%20Codes%20Delivering%20Malicious%20Chrome%20Extension%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644248486111&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Set a browser extension allow or deny list as appropriate for your security policy (M1038).
  * Only install browser extensions from trusted sources that can be verified. Browser extensions for some browsers can be controlled through Group Policy. Change settings to prevent the browser from installing extensions without sufficient permissions (M1033).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.gdatasoftware.com/blog/2022/01/37236-qr-codes-on-twitter-deliver-malicious-chrome-extension>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Critical GitLab Vulnerability Exploited In The Wild
GitLab have published details on a critical vulnerability which would allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code. This is patched, but research shows a large number of unpatched instances accessible online.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Targets:** GitLab Instances
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public Facing Application
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown 



# Overview

GitLab published a security release on April 14, 2021, to address a critical remote code execution vulnerability in the service's web interface. The vulnerability was originally identified by GitLab as an authenticated vulnerability caused by passing user-supplied photos to the service's embedded version of ExifTool. ExifTool's mishandling of the files could allow a remote attacker to run arbitrary commands as the git user. Since being published, the vulnerability has been upgraded to critical, as it has become clear that authentication is not required to exploit it. There have since been multiple exploits for CVE-2021-22205 published, and it is being actively exploited in the wild. Patches for the GitLab vulnerability have been available for over six months. However, an examination of GitLab instances that are accessible via the internet indicates that a significant proportion are still susceptible. GitLab users should update to the most recent version as soon as possible. Furthermore, GitLab should ideally not be an internet-facing service. Consider putting your GitLab behind a VPN if you need to access it from the internet. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/70221996/Critical%20GitLab%20Vulnerability%20Exploited%20In%20The%20Wild%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636386402028&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Web Application Firewalls may be used to limit exposure of applications to prevent exploit traffic from reaching the application (M1050).



# References

  * <https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2021/11/01/gitlab-unauthenticated-remote-code-execution-cve-2021-22205-exploited-in-the-wild/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.004 - Exploits  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: APT37 Using Self Decoding to Inject RokRat
A malicious document examined by MalwareBytes Labs has shown the ability to use VBA self-decoding in order to inject RokRat into victim machines.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A file with an embedded macro that uses a VBA self-decoding technique built in decodes itself in memory of Microsoft Office without actually writing the script to disk. After this step, a variant of RokRat is embedded into Notepad. Using new techniques for this APT has provided unique insight into the evolving TTPs of APT37. Previously, the APT has used Hangui Office documents as its targeting mechanism, which is commonly used in South Korea. First introduced in 2016, the self-decoding process uses a macro within a macro that is decoded and executed. The technique uses an IF/THEN series of instructions to decode and execute the payload. In order to check for the possibility of execution, the macro checks for bypass ability within VBOM. If an exception is triggered in the checks process, VBOM needs to be bypassed. This is the IF clause. If no exception exists, the ELSE clause kicks in and allows for dynamic macro execution. Once VBOM is bypassed, a mutex is created in the victim's machine. Speculation on this step centers around whether the victim is only infected once. A new application process is created and loaded in invisible mode. Deobfuscation is accomplished via a defined loop. This step provides the memory infiltration macro and makes a call to its main function. Within the infected notepad.exe is the payload download from an nefarious link which then links to a Google drive link. Anti-analysis techniques are employed, as with previous versions of the malware. Capturing screen shots, gathering system info, exfiltration, credential stealing, and file and directory management are the functions it performs once running. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-analysis/2021/01/retrohunting-apt37-north-korean-apt-used-vba-self-decode-technique-to-inject-rokrat/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Analysis of the Jester Stealer
A report from Cyble Research Labs provides an analysis of an information stealer named Jester Stealer that first emerged being sold on underground forums in July 2021.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Information stealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Various
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Jester Stealer
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of data.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Jester Stealer is .NET-based information-stealing malware that began being sold on cybercrime forums as early as July 2021. A report from Cyble Research Labs provides an analysis of Jester Stealer. Since it emerged it has had some seven updates and in each update, additional capabilities have been added. A builder can be supplied by the Jester Stealer developers that provides the ability to create custom binaries and can hide the executable file using a different extension. To help evade detection Jester Stealer has anti-sandbox and anti-VM features. It collects system information and can steal data from a range of applications including chat messengers, crypto wallets, email clients, gaming software, passwords managers, VPN clients, and web browsers. Collected data is held in memory and is not written to disk. The data is exfiltrated through TOR and then delivered to a Telegram bot. In case the data was not able to be transferred using TOR, a fallback is used to send the data to the public file-sharing service, AnonFiles. Once exfiltration has been successfully completed, Jester Stealer deletes itself from the system. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: BancoEstado Shuts Down Branches - Possible Ransomware Attack
Breach / Leak Notification: According to a media report, the Chilean bank, BancoEstado, temporarily shutdown all its branches due to a ransomware attack. The report cites a source as saying the REvil, aka Sodinokibi, ransomware was involved in the attack which used a spear-phishing email to gain a foothold.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: BancoEstado Shuts Down Branches - Possible Ransomware Attack
Breach / Leak Notification: According to a media report, the Chilean bank, BancoEstado, temporarily shutdown all its branches due to a ransomware attack. The report cites a source as saying the REvil, aka Sodinokibi, ransomware was involved in the attack which used a spear-phishing email to gain a foothold.

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"BancoEstado, one of Chile's three biggest banks, was forced to shut down all branches on Monday following a ransomware attack that took place over the weekend...Details about the attack have not been made public, but a source close to the investigation told _ZDNet_ that the bank's internal network was infected with the REvil (Sodinokibi) ransomware. The incident is currently being investigated as having originated from a malicious Office document received and opened by an employee. The malicious Office file is believed to have installed a backdoor on the bank's network. Investigators believe that on the night between Friday and Saturday, hackers used this backdoor to access the bank's network and install ransomware."

# Reference

  * <https://www.zdnet.com/article/chilean-bank-shuts-down-all-branches-following-ransomware-attack/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Emotet Chronicles
Kaspersky has published a report chronicling what is known about Emotet malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Emotet Chronicles
Kaspersky has published a report chronicling what is known about Emotet malware.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan



# Overview

According to Kaspersky, Emotet was first discovered in June 2014 by Trend Micro. Emotet is a malware package designed to steal banking credentials. Initial targets were German and Austrian bank users. At that time, the infection vector was bank-related spam with either weaponized attachments or links to ZIP files with the loader install. November of that year saw additional modules added that could modify HTTP(s) traffic, collect Outlook email addresses, and steal credentials in Mail PassView, among others. December saw unresponsive command and control servers as attacks dropped off. The following January saw a public RSA key and encrypted embedded strings. Swiss bank clients were also added to the victim list. June 2015 saw the beginning of another shutdown of the command and control servers. December of 2016 saw a new outlook for Emotet with the ability to infect victims using the RIG-E and RIG-V exploit kits. In February 2017, it was discovered that Emotet had included a spam module in its tool set. Banking clients in Poland were added in April's spam emails. May saw a change in the spam attachment used in the attack. This was the first time a weaponized Microsoft Word document (or a link to one) required the victim to enable macros. It was also the first time that Emotet began installing the banking Trojan Qbot (or QakBot), although the number of installs were not numerous. June saw Emotet begin to use a network spreading technique to infect other systems on the local network. In July, Emotet changed from using GET requests to using POST requests. The list of brute-force passwords used significantly increased in August. IBM X-Force announced in November that Emotet was now spreading IcedID. In January of 2018, Emotet began installing the banking Trojan Panda (also known as Zeus Panda). In April, Emotet added a module to spread laterally over wireless networks. In June, Emotet began a relationship with Trickbot (also known as Trickster). The ability to access computers behind NAT and convert them into command and control proxies was added in July. Installing Ryuk by Emotet began in August. October saw a brief suspension of command and control servers as well as an update to the Outlook exfiltration module. Another suspension of command and control servers began in November with a resumption beginning in January of 2019. March saw modifications to the HTTP protocol used in command and control communication. In April, data exfiltration (topics, mailing lists, message contents) began showing up in Emotet spam emails. From May until August, command and control servers went down once more. In November and February, additional minor changes were made to the headers in the HTTP protocol. Infections declined in February, not to resume until July. After starting back up in July, public reports indicated that the links in the spam emails were replaced with benign images and memes instead of the malicious Emotet payload. In a few days, this issue was corrected and Emotet began flowing again. For full details on the Emotet history, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35717728/Emotet%20Chronicles%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1607375773201&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/the-chronicles-of-emotet/99660/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Arid Viper Campaign Targets Palestine
Arid Viper is an APT focused on espionage and was first reported on in 2015. Cisco has published a blog post about a recent campaign by the group targeting Palestinian entities and activists.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** APT, RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Arid Viper
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Microscopia
  *  **Targets:** Palestinian entities and activists
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing via an unknown vector
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft, remote command execution



# Overview

Cisco published a blog post analyzing an Arid Viper APT campaign targeting Palestinian entities and activists with the Micropsia malware. The exact infection vector is unknown, but targets will receive a link or file through social engineering. Upon execution, the Microscopia malware displays a politically-themed decoy document while establishing persistence via the Startup folder. It then gathers system information that is base64-encoded and sent to the C2 via an HTTP POST request. From this point on, the attackers can issue commands from the C2 server. Capabilities include executing commands, taking screenshots, and downloading files from a remote server. For more information, see the Cisco Talos blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058303/New%20Arid%20Viper%20Campaign%20Targets%20Palestine%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644343345663&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/02/arid-viper-targets-palestine.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1132.001 - Standard Encoding
