instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: DoJ Allows FBI Login to Exchange Server WebShells
In a ruling on April 13, 2021, the U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) allowed the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) to log into exploited Microsoft Exchange Servers in order to disrupt and remove web shells providing backdoor access to the servers.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

According to multiple sources, including the DoJ, the FBI has been permitted to log into, copy, and remove malicious web shells from vulnerable Microsoft Exchange Servers. Throughout January and February 2021, threat actors have been exploiting a zero-day vulnerability in an effort to gain access to these servers. The vulnerability allowed for the installation of web shells for continued access. Although many owners of the vulnerable servers were able to remove the web shells, many more still appear to be vulnerable to this zero-day exploit. Some of the vulnerable server owners attempted to remove the web shells but were, ultimately, unsuccessful. The FBI then conducted the removal by issuing a command through the web shell to delete only the web shell itself as identified by its unique file path. This action did not include the patching of the servers in question but only the removal of the malicious web shells. Officials from the DoJ and FBI are urging owners to patch the affected systems immediately by reviewing Microsoft's remediation guide published in March in a Joint Advisory. Many security sources are urging owners to not only patch vulnerable systems but to remove any web shells left behind. Further details can be found in the links located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdtx/pr/justice-department-announces-court-authorized-effort-disrupt-exploitation-microsoft>

  * <https://therecord.media/fbi-operation-removed-web-shells-from-hacked-exchange-servers-across-the-us/>
  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/nsa-discovers-critical-exchange-server-vulnerabilities-patch-now/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Tmanger RAT
While investigating TA428 activity, NTT Security researchers identified a new RAT, dubbed "Tmanger", being used by the group.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Tmanger RAT
While investigating TA428 activity, NTT Security researchers identified a new RAT, dubbed "Tmanger", being used by the group.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

NTT Security has published a blog post detailing the , which was discovered in use by TA428, a Chinese APT. The attack chain began with the deployment of Poison Ivy and Cotx RAT to gain remote control of the victims host. The threat actor then moved laterally by exploiting the EternalBlue vulnerability. It was at this point they deployed the new . The payload is comprised of three components: SetUp, MloadDll, and Client. First, SetUp decodes various data to be used in later installation steps. The MloadDll is then inflated and saved in System32. To establish persistence the DLL uses either a service, if admin privileges are obtained, or via a Registry Run key otherwise. Either method leads to the execution of the DLL, which begins by generating the RC4 key that will be used to decrypt configuration data. The decoded configuration data is the C2 address and port number. The DLL also inflates and executes the final payload, named Client. The final payload gathers hosts information and sends the information to its C2 server. It can then receive C2 commands that allow for the attacker to perform file operations, start processes, keylog, screen capture, and more. For more information, see the NTT Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://insight-jp.nttsecurity.com/post/102gi9b/pandas-new-arsenal-part-1-tmanger>

The attack chain began with the deployment of Poison Ivy and Cotx RAT to gain remote control of the victims host. The threat actor then moved laterally by exploiting the EternalBlue vulnerability. It was at this point they deployed the new . The payload is comprised of three components: SetUp, MloadDll, and Client. First, SetUp decodes various data to be used in later installation steps. The MloadDll is then inflated and saved in System32. To establish persistence the DLL uses either a service, if admin privileges are obtained, or via a Registry Run key otherwise. Either method leads to the execution of the DLL, which begins by generating the RC4 key that will be used to decrypt configuration data. The decoded configuration data is the C2 address and port number. The DLL also inflates and executes the final payload, named Client. The final payload gathers hosts information and sends the information to its C2 server. It can then receive C2 commands that allow for the attacker to perform file operations, start processes, keylog, screen capture, and more. For more information, see the NTT Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://insight-jp.nttsecurity.com/post/102gi9b/pandas-new-arsenal-part-1-tmanger>

Tell me everything you know the following threat: Drupal core - Critical - Remote code execution - SA-CORE-2020-012
Drupal has released a security advisory detailing a remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2020-13671).
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Drupal has released a security advisory (SA-CORE-2020-012) detailing a critical remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2020-13671). The vulnerability is due to the improperly sanitization of file names for uploaded files. This could lead to files with the incorrect extension being served up as the wrong MIME type. In some hosting configurations the files could be executed as PHP. As Drupal has rated this issue as critical, it is advised to update as soon as possible. This update would be an excellent time to verify that additional plug-ins are also up to date. Versions affected and patched versions can be found in the link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982875/Drupal%20core%20-%20Critical%20-%20Remote%20code%20execution%20-%20SA-CORE-2020-012%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605731731129&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.drupal.org/sa-core-2020-012>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: PsExec Privilege Escalation in Windows Fixed
Microsoft has finally fixed a vulnerability initially disclosed by a Tenable researcher back in January 2021.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

A component of Microsoft's Sysinternals utility was found in January 2021 to be vulnerable to privilege escalation. According to the release notes from Microsoft: "This update to PsExec mitigates named pipe squatting attacks that can be leveraged by an attacker to intercept credentials or elevate to System privilege. the -i command line switch is now necessary for running processes interactively, for example with redirected IO."  The local privilege escalation allows for the escalation to SYSTEM if PsExec is executed either locally or remotely. This vulnerability was shown to work from Windows 10 to Windows XP. This vulnerability was exploitable all the way back to v1.72. The researcher, upon disclosing the vulnerability, gave Microsoft ninety days in which to address it. The company did not release a patch within that window and, therefore, the researcher released the flaw as well as a fully working PoC. On March 23, 2021, Microsoft issued a micro patch to address the issue and has since been tested and confirmed as working. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/microsoft-fixes-windows-psexec-privilege-elevation-vulnerability/>

  * <https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/sysinternals-blog/tcpview-v4-0-psexec-v2-33-winobj-v3-02-and-sysmon-v13-02/ba-p/2230549>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: PerSwaysion Campaign Uses Legitimate Services to Trick Users
Group-IB Threat Intelligence team has published a timeline of a phishing campaign using an up-trending technique whereby they use legitimate file-sharing sites to guide victims to the phishing site. After compromise, the attacker uses the email account to send out further phishing emails.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Targets:** Financial Services, Legal, Consulting
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Group-IB Threat Intelligence team has been tracking a new phishing campaign using a phishing technique that is becoming more common. The technique uses Microsoft file-sharing services, such as Sway, Sharepoint, and OneNote. This property is why the campaign is being called PerSwaysion. This campaign has been seen in multiple countries across North America, Europe, and Asia. Phishing emails in this campaign typically work in 3 phases. The first phase is an email with a PDF attachment claiming to be an Office 365 notification that a file has been shared with the victim. If the user clicks on the link in the PDF, they are then taken to a file hosted on a legitimate file-sharing site, such as Sway. The attacker abuses Sway's default borderless view and a specially crafted presentation page to make it seem as if the user has landed on a valid Office 365 login page. The link on this page directs the user to the final phase, which is a false login page on the attacker-controlled infrastructure. Once the user's details are entered, the attacker receives a notification email and the victim is served an 'access denied' page. After the credentials have been stolen, the attackers log into the compromised email account and dump all of the available emails. They then use the victim's details to generate new phishing PDFs that will seem legitimate, before sending them out to external targets on the victim's contact list. These targets are generally hand-picked to be high-profile members of businesses other than the victim's organization. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155151/PerSwaysion%20Campaign%20Uses%20Legitimate%20Services%20to%20Trick%20Users%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637762050748&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction (M1017).
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc (M1021).
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries (M1031).



# References

  * <https://blog.group-ib.com/perswaysion>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1586 - Compromise Accounts  
T1586.002 - Email Accounts  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: DirtyMoe Malware Introduction
Researchers from Avast have provided a breakdown of the DirtyMoe malware, a variant of the NuggetPhantom malware. The malware uses PurpleFox as its exploit kit.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: DirtyMoe Malware Introduction
Researchers from Avast have provided a breakdown of the DirtyMoe malware, a variant of the NuggetPhantom malware. The malware uses PurpleFox as its exploit kit.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A recently discovered malware, DirtyMoe, was analyzed by researchers from Avast. This malware focuses on cryptojacking and DDoS attacks. It also runs as a Windows service with system-level privileges using EternalBlue and other exploits. Threat actors are able to use remote control to configure DirtyMoe to fit their individual wishes. The actual malware downloads an encrypted payload and injects that payload into itself. DirtyMoe employs self-defense and hiding techniques at both the local and malware levels and uses a Windows driver that employs rootkit capabilities such as service, registry entry, and driving hiding. Additionally, selected files can be hidden and have the ability the inject an arbitrary DLL into newly created processes. The C2 configuration is not built into the malware but is, instead, retrieved by a DNS request to a hardcoded DNS server(s). Other abilities of the malware include reconnaissance through port scanning and vulnerability database queries. The preferred exploit kit is PurpleFox. The malware makes several registry changes and/or additions. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/martinchlumecky/dirtymoe-1/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ToxicEye RAT Analysis
A recent report from BlackBerry provides a technical analysis of ToxicEye, an open-source RAT that leverages Telegram for C2 communication.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ToxicEye RAT Analysis
A recent report from BlackBerry provides a technical analysis of ToxicEye, an open-source RAT that leverages Telegram for C2 communication.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

BlackBerry has published their analysis of the ToxicEye RAT. This RAT appeared on the scene in mid-2020 and the source code is currently publicly available on GitHub. One of the most notable characteristics of this RAT is its usage of the Telegram API for C2 communication. The payload is a C++ program compiled into a .NET executable with no obfuscation or packing. At the time of compilation, the attacker configures the RAT to leverage their Telegram API token and chat ID for C2 communication. Prior to carrying out its malicious activities, ToxicEye performs anti-AV, anto-sandbox, and anti-VM checks. Persistence is then established via a scheduled task masquerading as a Chrome update. Once running on the system, its main function is to harvest sensitive information, including credit cards, web history, bookmarks, cookies, files, and Telegram, Discord, and Steam application data. Additional functions are included for privilege escalation, obtaining persistence, gathering system information, downloading additional files, keylogging, and more. The final action performed by the RAT is to cause a blue screen error (BSOD), rendering the victim system unusable. For more information, see the BlackBerry blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.blackberry.com/en/2021/05/threat-thursday-this-rat-keeps-a-toxiceye-on-your-data>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: In-the-Wild Exploits Seen Targeting MS Exchange
New reports from Volexity and Microsoft detail an in-the-wild exploit being seen across multiple industries. Microsoft has released out of band updates to address the vulnerabilities.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: In-the-Wild Exploits Seen Targeting MS Exchange
New reports from Volexity and Microsoft detail an in-the-wild exploit being seen across multiple industries. Microsoft has released out of band updates to address the vulnerabilities.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

## ***UPDATE April 12, 2021***

CISA has provided an analysis of further samples of the China Chopper Webshell, which may be in use against Microsoft Exchange servers. Further information can be found in the Reference section below or [here](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-102a).

## ***UPDATE March 25, 2021***

  
US-CISA and DHS have issued additional information about China Chopper Webshells which may be in use against Microsoft Offline Address books. These latest samples are inline with other samples previously examined. There are subtle differences in the code used for the creation of the shells. We recommend you read the reports and apply any and all patches available as well as examining your environment for any evidence of these or any other potentially nefarious webshells. Further information can be found in the Reference section below or [here](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-084a) and [here](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-084b). 

## ***UPDATE March 16, 2021***

  
Yesterday, Microsoft released a one-click Exchange On-Premises Mitigation tool. This tool is not designed to replace patching of vulnerable servers, it is merely meant to help those who've not yet had opportunity to patch these systems. This tool includes the latest Microsoft Safety Scanner and will mitigate CVE-2021-26855. The tool performs three operations: mitigate against current known attacks using CVE-2021-26855 using a URL Rewrite configuration, scan the Exchange Server using the Microsoft Safety Scanner, and attempt to reverse any changes made by identified threats. Further detailed guidance can be found in the Reference section below or [here](https://msrc-blog.microsoft.com/2021/03/15/one-click-microsoft-exchange-on-premises-mitigation-tool-march-2021/).

## ***UPDATE March 15, 2021***

  
The Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency released 7 malware analysis reports on webshells seen throughout its investigation. The findings indicate that each webshell observed also contains some form of backdoor as well as the webshells themselves. These webshells could, if implanted, allow attackers to execute JavaScript code on compromised servers. The reports are linked in the Reference section or just below this update.

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072a](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072a)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072b](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072b)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072c](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072c)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072d](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072d)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072e](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072e)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072f](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072f)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072g](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072g)




## ***UPDATE March 12, 2021***

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and Cybersecurity Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) have published a joint advisory detailing further information on the Microsoft Exchange Server attacks. According to the FBI and CISA, multiple nation-state actors and cybercriminals are likely exploiting the previously mentioned vulnerabilities. Should these attackers successfully exploit these vulnerabilities, they have the ability to gain persistence and control of the affected network. The possibility exists of the sale of compromised network access on the dark web. These networks can contain valuable research, technology, PII, and sensitive information from multiple sectors. The agencies assess the attackers will continue to exploit these vulnerabilities in order to steal information, encrypt data for ransom, or, in a worst case scenario, execute a destructive attack against compromised networks. The report also notes the types of industries currently or previously having seen attacks as "local governments, academic institutions, non-governmental organizations, and business entities in multiple industry sectors, including agriculture, biotechnology, aerospace, defense, legal services, power utilities, and pharmaceutical". Additionally, this targeting is consistent with targeting activity by Chinese cyber actors. Further details can be found in the link located within the reference section below or [here](https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2021/210310.pdf). 

## ***UPDATE #3 March 10, 2021***

WeLiveSecurity is reporting that at least 10 APT groups are attacking the vulnerabilities in Exchange. Among the APTs and malware listed are: LuckyMouse, Tick, Winnti Group, Calypso, Websiic, Tonto Team (CactusPete), Mikroceen (Vicious Panda), ShadowPad (unconfirmed), "Opera" Cobalt Strike, and DLTMiner. There is also speculation that some of the ATPs and threat actors may be piggybacking off webshells left by other APTs who may have already successfully exploited the vulnerable servers, though this is unconfirmed. Further information can be found in the link located within the Reference section below or [here](https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/03/10/exchange-servers-under-siege-10-apt-groups/). 

## ***UPDATE #2 March 10, 2021***

Recorded Future reports on the evolution of the exploitation of the Microsoft Exchange Server vulnerabilities. Indications are that the exploitation attempts are coming from multiple groups simultaneously. Some of the groups mentioned in the article are state-sponsored APTs while others are simply cybercrime groups. One such group has been using the flaws to insert webshells to install DLTminer malware for the purposes of cryptomining. According to the article, "the ever-increasing number of attackers had moved into indiscriminate mass-exploitation against any Exchange server left connected to the internet without a patch, with the number of hacked servers being estimated in the realm of “astronomical” and tens of thousands, per US government sources. Security agencies have observed intrusions in the Netherlands, Czech Republic, and Norway in addition to the U.S. Other, larger countries have issued national security alerts to patch on-premises servers as soon as possible in order to avoid exploitation. There is speculation these countries may already be seeing attempts to exploit the vulnerabilities. At present, at least 1,500 infected systems have been seen by at least one security firm. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section or [here](https://therecord.media/attacks-on-exchange-servers-expand-from-nation-states-to-cryptominers/). 

## ***UPDATE #1 March 10, 2021***

Palo Alto's Unit 42 has released additional details on the China Chopper webshells and changes made to the shell during the exploitation of these vulnerabilities. Additionally, a Yara rule was released which helps to identify templates used for the China Chopper webshell as they exist in OAB configurations. This webshell is injected into a pre-existing OAB ASPX page. Researchers warn that any on-premises Exchange servers exposed to the internet should assume scanning is/has been accomplished numerous times. Indications from analysis show several clusters of threat actors are continuously attempting to exploit vulnerable servers. Further details can be found in the link located within the Reference section below or [here](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/china-chopper-webshell/).

## ***UPDATE March 9, 2021***

Microsoft has released emergency updates for unsupported versions of Microsoft Exchange. Though unsupported, the company released these updates to address only the newest vulnerabilities as stated in this document. Further information can be found in the link below or [here](https://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-exchange-attacks-now-microsoft-rushes-out-a-patch-for-these-unsupported-exchange-servers-too/).

  


***UPDATE March 8, 2021***

FireEye has [published](https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2021/03/detection-response-to-exploitation-of-microsoft-exchange-zero-day-vulnerabilities.html) analysis of the processes and inner workings of the vulnerabilities and related malware. Researchers have identified a web shell named help.aspx which contained code to help identify endpoint security products such as FireEye xAgent, CarbonBlack, and CrowdStrike Falcon. A second web shell named iisstart.aspx was seen approximately twenty days after the first web shell. This web shell, partially obfuscated, has more capabilities, functions, and is generally more advanced than the previous shell. This particular version allowed for the execution of arbitrary commands and the upload, deletion, and viewing of files. The analysis confirmed the files indicate the signature match for China Chopper. One particular command seen was the attempt to delete the administrator user from Exchange Organizations administrators group. The team verified Microsoft's information regarding the post-exploitation activity such as credential theft by dumping LSASS, the use of 7-zip compression for exfiltration, the use of Exchange PowerShell Snap-ins for the exfiltration of mailbox data, and the use of offensive tools such as Covenant, Nishang, and PowerCat for remote access. Finally, analysis revealed the ever changing naming of the web shell on each intrusion. We will provide further details as they are presented.

  


***UPDATE March 6, 2021***

According to CISA, Microsoft has released (CISA and Microsoft links below) an updated [script](https://github.com/microsoft/CSS-Exchange/tree/main/Security) for scanning the Exchange log files for IoCs for the vulnerabilities. We recommend running the script against any Exchange servers within your organization as soon as possible.

## ***UPDATE March 5, 2021***

IBM Security family PAM Content Update [4103.03231](https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/xpu/XPU%204103.03231) contains 4 new events, 0 new moderate event responses, and 0 new aggressive event responses. The new signatures, HTTP_Exchange_Cookie_Auth_Bypass, HTTP_Exchange_VirtualDirectory_Cmd_Injection, HTTP_Exchange_Cookie_SSFR, and HTTP_Exchange_VirtualDirectory_Upload, apply to the Microsoft Exchange vulnerabilities, CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065.

## ***UPDATE #3 March 3, 2021***

CISA has published an alert, AA21-062A, regarding the Exchange vulnerabilities. The URL is located in the Reference section below.

## ***UPDATE #2 March 3, 2021***

An URL has been added to the Reference section for the Dubex report on the exploit.

## ***UPDATE March 3, 2021***

A blog from Rapid7 contains more details on this zero-day attack and how to address the issues allowing the zero-day to proliferate. In the blog, researchers reveal the tools employed in the attacks to be China Chopper Webshell and ProcDump being used against LSASS. Additionally, the team provided a link for the proof-of-concept code that allows for the exposure to the public internet. 

## ***Original Post - Update March 2, 2021***

Multiple zero-day exploits targeting vulnerabilities in on-premises versions Microsoft Exchange servers have been used in attacks in the wild. Microsoft describe the attacks as limited and targeted. According to a report from Volexity, the attacks appear to have started as early as January 6, 2021. The report notes that the attackers are using a remotely exploitable server-side request forgery (SSRF) vulnerability (CVE-2021-26855) to steal the contents of a victim's mailbox. The vulnerability does not require authentication. If the Exchange server is a single machine, the attacker must know the targeted user's domain SID in order to access the mailbox. In multiple server configurations, the attacker only needs the email address of the intended victim. In both cases, the attacker must know the FQDN of the internal Exchange servers. The vulnerability can be exploited by sending a specially crafted HTTP POST request to the server with an XML SOAP payload. Volexity has also observed this attack being conducted on OWA. In addition, Volexity reports that the attackers chained the SSRF vulnerability with a remote code execution vulnerability in the Exchange servers and installed webshells on the compromised servers.

Microsoft, Volexity, and Dubex have collaborated on this research and attribute the activity to HAFNIUM, a Chinese state-sponsored group. Victimology and TTPs as the basis for attribution. According to Microsoft, HAFNIUM has primarily targeted entities in the United States. The targeted industry sectors include defense contractors, higher education institutions, infectious disease researchers, law firms, NGOs, and policy think tanks. HAFNIUM typically uses leased virtual private servers (VPS) located in the United States to conduct operations.

Microsoft has issued emergency out of band updates to address these critical vulnerabilities in Exchange. Microsoft is urging customers to update on-premises systems immediately. In keeping with Microsoft's recommendation, IBM also urges customers to immediately patch affected systems.

  * [CVE-2021-26855](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-26855) is a server-side request forgery (SSRF) vulnerability in Exchange which allowed the attacker to send arbitrary HTTP requests and authenticate as the Exchange server.
  * [CVE-2021-26857](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-26857) is an insecure deserialization vulnerability in the Unified Messaging service. Insecure deserialization is where untrusted user-controllable data is deserialized by a program. Exploiting this vulnerability gave HAFNIUM the ability to run code as SYSTEM on the Exchange server. This requires administrator permission or another vulnerability to exploit.
  * [CVE-2021-26858](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-26858) is a post-authentication arbitrary file write vulnerability in Exchange. If HAFNIUM could authenticate with the Exchange server then they could use this vulnerability to write a file to any path on the server. They could authenticate by exploiting the CVE-2021-26855 SSRF vulnerability or by compromising a legitimate admin’s credentials.
  * [CVE-2021-27065](https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-27065) is a post-authentication arbitrary file write vulnerability in Exchange. If HAFNIUM could authenticate with the Exchange server then they could use this vulnerability to write a file to any path on the server. They could authenticate by exploiting the CVE-2021-26855 SSRF vulnerability or by compromising a legitimate admin’s credentials.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

## ***UPDATE April 12, 2021***

CISA has provided an analysis of further samples of the China Chopper Webshell, which may be in use against Microsoft Exchange servers. Further information can be found in the Reference section below or [here](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-102a).

## ***UPDATE March 25, 2021***

  
US-CISA and DHS have issued additional information about China Chopper Webshells which may be in use against Microsoft Offline Address books. These latest samples are inline with other samples previously examined. There are subtle differences in the code used for the creation of the shells. We recommend you read the reports and apply any and all patches available as well as examining your environment for any evidence of these or any other potentially nefarious webshells. Further information can be found in the Reference section below or [here](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-084a) and [here](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-084b). 

## ***UPDATE March 16, 2021***

  
Yesterday, Microsoft released a one-click Exchange On-Premises Mitigation tool. This tool is not designed to replace patching of vulnerable servers, it is merely meant to help those who've not yet had opportunity to patch these systems. This tool includes the latest Microsoft Safety Scanner and will mitigate CVE-2021-26855. The tool performs three operations: mitigate against current known attacks using CVE-2021-26855 using a URL Rewrite configuration, scan the Exchange Server using the Microsoft Safety Scanner, and attempt to reverse any changes made by identified threats. Further detailed guidance can be found in the Reference section below or [here](https://msrc-blog.microsoft.com/2021/03/15/one-click-microsoft-exchange-on-premises-mitigation-tool-march-2021/).

## ***UPDATE March 15, 2021***

  
The Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency released 7 malware analysis reports on webshells seen throughout its investigation. The findings indicate that each webshell observed also contains some form of backdoor as well as the webshells themselves. These webshells could, if implanted, allow attackers to execute JavaScript code on compromised servers. The reports are linked in the Reference section or just below this update.

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072a](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072a)

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072g](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-072g)




## ***UPDATE March 12, 2021***

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and Cybersecurity Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) have published a joint advisory detailing further information on the Microsoft Exchange Server attacks. According to the FBI and CISA, multiple nation-state actors and cybercriminals are likely exploiting the previously mentioned vulnerabilities. Should these attackers successfully exploit these vulnerabilities, they have the ability to gain persistence and control of the affected network. The possibility exists of the sale of compromised network access on the dark web. These networks can contain valuable research, technology, PII, and sensitive information from multiple sectors. The agencies assess the attackers will continue to exploit these vulnerabilities in order to steal information, encrypt data for ransom, or, in a worst case scenario, execute a destructive attack against compromised networks. The report also notes the types of industries currently or previously having seen attacks as "local governments, academic institutions, non-governmental organizations, and business entities in multiple industry sectors, including agriculture, biotechnology, aerospace, defense, legal services, power utilities, and pharmaceutical". Additionally, this targeting is consistent with targeting activity by Chinese cyber actors. Further details can be found in the link located within the reference section below or [here](https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2021/210310.pdf). 

## ***UPDATE #3 March 10, 2021***

WeLiveSecurity is reporting that at least 10 APT groups are attacking the vulnerabilities in Exchange. Among the APTs and malware listed are: LuckyMouse, Tick, Winnti Group, Calypso, Websiic, Tonto Team (CactusPete), Mikroceen (Vicious Panda), ShadowPad (unconfirmed), "Opera" Cobalt Strike, and DLTMiner. There is also speculation that some of the ATPs and threat actors may be piggybacking off webshells left by other APTs who may have already successfully exploited the vulnerable servers, though this is unconfirmed. Further information can be found in the link located within the Reference section below or [here](https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/03/10/exchange-servers-under-siege-10-apt-groups/). 

## ***UPDATE #2 March 10, 2021***

Recorded Future reports on the evolution of the exploitation of the Microsoft Exchange Server vulnerabilities. Indications are that the exploitation attempts are coming from multiple groups simultaneously. Some of the groups mentioned in the article are state-sponsored APTs while others are simply cybercrime groups. One such group has been using the flaws to insert webshells to install DLTminer malware for the purposes of cryptomining. According to the article, "the ever-increasing number of attackers had moved into indiscriminate mass-exploitation against any Exchange server left connected to the internet without a patch, with the number of hacked servers being estimated in the realm of “astronomical” and tens of thousands, per US government sources. Security agencies have observed intrusions in the Netherlands, Czech Republic, and Norway in addition to the U.S. Other, larger countries have issued national security alerts to patch on-premises servers as soon as possible in order to avoid exploitation. There is speculation these countries may already be seeing attempts to exploit the vulnerabilities. At present, at least 1,500 infected systems have been seen by at least one security firm. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section or [here](https://therecord.media/attacks-on-exchange-servers-expand-from-nation-states-to-cryptominers/). 

## ***UPDATE #1 March 10, 2021***

Palo Alto's Unit 42 has released additional details on the China Chopper webshells and changes made to the shell during the exploitation of these vulnerabilities. Additionally, a Yara rule was released which helps to identify templates used for the China Chopper webshell as they exist in OAB configurations. This webshell is injected into a pre-existing OAB ASPX page. Researchers warn that any on-premises Exchange servers exposed to the internet should assume scanning is/has been accomplished numerous times. Indications from analysis show several clusters of threat actors are continuously attempting to exploit vulnerable servers. Further details can be found in the link located within the Reference section below or [here](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/china-chopper-webshell/).

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Mirai Botnet Abusing Log4j Vulnerability
The Mirai botnet often implements new functionality as easily-exploitable vulnerabilities are discovered. In a report from Akamai, researchers detail Mirai's recent addition of Log4j exploits to their arsenal.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Exploit
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Mirai botnet
  *  **Targets:** Systems vulnerable to Log4Shell
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Log4j vulnerabilities
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install additional payloads



# Overview

Akamai has published a blog post analyzing recent samples of Mirai that indicate the botnet is now exploiting the recent Log4j vulnerabilities. Using the unauthenticated remote code execution vulnerability, the Mirai scanner attempts to contact an LDAP server for the purpose of downloading a Java payload. At the time of research, the related Log4j exploit payloads and scripts were no longer available for download, limiting the analysis capabilities. Older samples contain remote code execution exploits for various applications, while most recent samples appear to focus on Log4j specifically. Each exploit target involves the use of two functions, one for establishing a network connection and one for executing the exploit payload. Patches have been released for the Log4j vulnerabilities and should be applied as soon as possible. For more information, see the Akamai blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057177/Mirai%20Botnet%20Abusing%20Log4j%20Vulnerability%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642622205893&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Update Apache Log4j to patch CVE-2021-44228 (see VMSA-2021-0028.8).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.akamai.com/blog/security/mirai-botnet-abusing-log4j-vulnerability>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

Tell me about the following threat: Chrome Browser Update - March 12 2021 - Exploit in the Wild
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for five vulnerabilities. An exploit for one of the vulnerabilities exists in the wild.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Chrome Browser Update - March 12 2021 - Exploit in the Wild
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for five vulnerabilities. An exploit for one of the vulnerabilities exists in the wild.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Google has released an update, version 89.0.4389.90, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for forty-eight vulnerabilities. An exploit for the one of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-21193) exists in the wild. Google has rated this vulnerability as High. The most serious potential impact from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities is the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further information is available from the release notes which are linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-21191, CVE-2021-21192, CVE-2021-21193 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2021/03/stable-channel-update-for-desktop_12.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: SEO Spam Links in Nulled Plugins
In an attempt to save money, website owners will often download and install free, nulled software. Sucuri reports on one case of nulled software being used to distribute SEO spam links.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, SEO Spam




# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing a nulled WordPress plugin distributing SEO spam links. In this specific case, the nulled (cracked) software was the Smart Grid Gallery Plugin. The malicious code was found injected into a PHP file associated with the plugin. It simply used two hex encoded strings that, when decoded, insert two hidden div sections to the affected website. These div sections simply contain links to external websites. Investigation of these websites revealed that they are fake sites likely used to increase SEO rankings and generate profit via referral programs. Over 7,000 sites were identified as containing references to these external domains. The researchers were also able to identify the source of the malicious plugin, which was hosted on a free themes website. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/12/seo-spam-links-in-nulled-plugins.html>

Tell me about the following threat: TA505 Campaign IoCs
A report from Rewterz provides IoCs that are associated with an active TA505 campaign. TA505 is also known as EvilCorp and are tracked by IBM X-Force as Hive0065.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TA505 Campaign IoCs
A report from Rewterz provides IoCs that are associated with an active TA505 campaign. TA505 is also known as EvilCorp and are tracked by IBM X-Force as Hive0065.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

TA505 is a threat group known to have been operating since at least 2014 and are considered to be financially motivated. TA505 is also known as EvilCorp and is tracked by IBM X-Force as Hive0065. As noted by Rewterz, the group typically target financial and retail institutions using malspam and a variety of malware. The TA505 campaign Rewterz are reporting is using Office Templates that contain malicious macros and use the Get2 downloader to deliver malware. Further information is available from the report linked in the Referrence section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.rewterz.com/rewterz-news/rewterz-threat-alert-ta505-active-iocs>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: PortDoor Backdoor
While analyzing recent samples of the RoyalRoad weaponizer, Cybereason researchers discovered a new backdoor, dubbed "PortDoor," targeting a Russia-based defense contractor.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: PortDoor Backdoor
While analyzing recent samples of the RoyalRoad weaponizer, Cybereason researchers discovered a new backdoor, dubbed "PortDoor," targeting a Russia-based defense contractor.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, APT




# Overview

Cybereason published a blog post analyzing a new backdoor, dubbed "PortDoor," used in a campaign targeting a Russia-based defense contractor. The campaign in which the backdoor was discovered began with a RoyalRoad payload attached to a spear-phishing email written in Russian. The document appeared to be related to the manufacturing of underwater vehicles but instead was simply used to drop a Microsoft Word add-in file to the Word startup folder. This add-in file is the PortDoor backdoor payload. C2 communication occurs either using TCP over raw sockets or via HTTPS using the CONNECT method, and the data is encrypted using AES. It provides privilege escalation capabilities via an access token theft technique. It awaits further instructions from the C2 server, with potential commands including those for process and file operations. Various anti-analysis techniques are used by the malware, such as dynamic API resolving, anti-debug checks, and string encoding. While attribution to a particular group could not be made, similarities in techniques and targeting lead the researchers to believe the backdoor was likely being developed by an APT acting on behalf of Chinese-state interests. For more information, see the Cybereason blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/portdoor-new-chinese-apt-backdoor-attack-targets-russian-defense-sector>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Zoho ManageEngine ServiceDesk Plus Vulnerability Exploited in the Wild
A joint alert (AA21-336A) from CISA and the FBI advises that a vulnerability in Zoho's ManageEngine ServiceDesk Plus is being exploited in the wild.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability, Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unpatched versions of Zoho ManageEngine ServiceDesk Plus.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unspecified webshells.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2021-44077
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Deployment of webshells, Lateral movement, Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Zoho's ManageEngine ServiceDesk Plus is IT help desk software that includes asset management features. Versions 11305 and prior (ServiceDesk Plus Cloud versions are not affected) are affected by a vulnerability (CVE-2021-44077) that could allow remote attackers to execute arbitrary code. The vulnerability was addressed in an update that was released by Zoho on September 16. According to a joint alert (AA21-336A) from CISA and the FBI, the vulnerability is being exploited in the wild. APT actors are noted as being among those who have been exploiting the vulnerability. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055950/Zoho%20ManageEngine%20ServiceDesk%20Plus%20Vulnerability%20Exploited%20in%20the%20Wild%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639116646058&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A list of Yara rules can be found here: [ Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/74055950/Zoho%20ManageEngine%20ServiceDesk%20Plus%20Vulnerability%20Exploited%20in%20the%20Wild%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639116692884&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Update ManageEngine ServiceDesk Plus to a fixed version.
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://www.cisa.gov/uscert/ncas/alerts/aa21-336a>
  * <https://pitstop.manageengine.com/portal/en/community/topic/security-advisory-authentication-bypass-vulnerability-in-servicedesk-plus-versions-11138-and-above>
  * <https://pitstop.manageengine.com/portal/en/community/topic/security-advisory-for-cve-2021-44077-unauthenticated-rce-vulnerability-in-servicedesk-plus-versions-up-to-11305-22-11-2021>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1136 - Create Account  
T1505 - Server Software Component  
T1505.003 - Web Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.003 - NTDS  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1087.002 - Domain Account  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
T1560.001 - Archive via Utility  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

  * A list of Yara rules can be found here: [ Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/74055950/Zoho%20ManageEngine%20ServiceDesk%20Plus%20Vulnerability%20Exploited%20in%20the%20Wild%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639116692884&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Update ManageEngine ServiceDesk Plus to a fixed version.
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://www.cisa.gov/uscert/ncas/alerts/aa21-336a>

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ICS-CERT Advisories February 09 2021
The ICS-CERT has published ten advisories that affect GE Digital HMI/SCADA iFIX, Advantech iView, Siemens SINEMA Server & SINEC NMS, Siemens RUGGEDCOM ROX II, Siemens TIA Administrator, Siemens JT2Go and Teamcenter Visualization, Siemens SCALANCE W780 and W740, Siemens SIMARIS configuration, SIMATIC WinCC Graphics Designer, and Siemens DIGSI 4.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-040-01 - GE Digital HMI/SCADA iFIX**  
CVE-2019-18243 - The affected product allows a local authenticated user to modify system-wide iFIX configurations through the registry. This may allow privilege escalation.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2019-18255 - The affected product allows a local authenticated user to modify system-wide iFIX configurations through section objects. This may allow privilege escalation.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:H/A:N).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-040-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-040-02 - Advantech iView**  
CVE-2021-22654 - The affected product is vulnerable to a SQL injection, which may allow an unauthorized attacker to disclose information.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2021-22658 - The affected product is vulnerable to a SQL injection, which may allow an attacker to escalate privileges to ‘Administrator’.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-22656 - The affected product is vulnerable to directory traversal, which may allow an attacker to read sensitive files.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2021-22652 - Access to the affected product’s configuration is missing authentication, which may allow an unauthorized attacker to change the configuration and obtain code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-040-02>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-040-03 - Siemens SINEMA Server & SINEC NMS**  
CVE-2020-25237 - When uploading files to an affected system using a zip container, the system does not correctly check if the relative file path of the extracted files is still within the intended target directory. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to create or overwrite arbitrary files on an affected system.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-040-03>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-040-04 - Siemens RUGGEDCOM ROX II**  
CVE-2018-12404 - A cached side-channel attack during handshakes using RSA encryption could allow for the decryption of content. This is a variant of the adaptive chosen ciphertext attack (AKA Bleichenbacher attack) and affects all Network Security Services (NSS) versions prior to NSS 3.41  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.9 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2018-18508 - In NSS before v3.36.7 and before v3.41.1, a malformed signature can cause a crash due to a NULL dereference, resulting in a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).

CVE-2019-11745 - When encrypting with a block cipher, if a call to NSC_EncryptUpdate was made with data smaller than the block size, a small out-of-bounds write could occur. This could cause heap corruption and an exploitable crash.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2019-17006 - In NSS before v3.46, several cryptographic primitives had missing length checks. In cases where the application calling the library did not perform a sanity check on the inputs, exploitation of this vulnerability could result in a crash due to a buffer overflow.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 9.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2019-17007 - In NSS before v3.44, a malformed Netscape certificate sequence can cause NSS to crash, resulting in a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).

CVE-2020-1763 - An out-of-bounds buffer read flaw was found in the pluto daemon of libreswan from Versions 3.27 to 3.31. An unauthenticated attacker could use this flaw to crash libreswan by sending specially crafted IKev1 informational exchange packets. The daemon respawns after the crash.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-040-04>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-040-05 - Siemens TIA Administrator**  
CVE-2020-25238 - The affected product has improper access controls, which may allow an attacker to execute code with SYSTEM privileges.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-040-05>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-040-06 - Siemens JT2Go and Teamcenter Visualization**  
CVE-2020-26998 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing PAR files. This could result in a memory access past the end of an allocated buffer. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to leak information.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-26999 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing of PAR files. This could result in a memory access past the end of an allocated buffer. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to leak information.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-27000 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing BMP files. This can result in a memory-corruption condition. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-27001 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing BMP files. This can result in a memory-corruption condition. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-27002 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing PAR files. This could result in a memory access past the end of an allocated buffer. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to access data in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-27003 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing TIFF files. This could lead to pointer dereferences of a value obtained from untrusted source. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-27004 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing CGM files. This could result in a memory access past the end of an allocated buffer. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to access data in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-27005 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing TGA files. This could result in an out-of-bounds write past the end of an allocated structure. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-27006 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing PCT files. This could result in a memory-corruption condition. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-27007 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing HPG files. This could result in a memory access past the end of an allocated buffer. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to access data in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-27008 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing PLT files. This could result in a memory access past the end of an allocated buffer. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to access data in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-28394 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing RAS files. This could result in a memory access past the end of an allocated buffer. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to access data in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-26989 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing PAR files. This could result in an out-of-bounds write past the end of an allocated structure. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-26990 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing ASM files. A crafted ASM file can trigger a type-confusion condition. An attacker can leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-26991 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing ASM files. This could lead to pointer dereferences of a value obtained from untrusted source. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25178 - An issue was discovered in Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK before v2021.11. A stack-based buffer overflow vulnerability exists when the recover operation is run with malformed DXF and DWG files.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25177 - An issue was discovered in Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK before v2021.11. A type-confusion issue exists when rendering malformed DXF and DWG files.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25176 - An issue was discovered in Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK before v2021.11. A NULL pointer dereference exists when rendering malformed DXF and DWG files. This could allow attackers to cause a crash, potentially enabling a denial-of-service attack (crash, exit, or restart).  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25175 - An issue was discovered in Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK before v2021.11. A type conversion issue exists when rendering malformed DXF and DWG files. This could allow attackers to cause a crash, potentially enabling a denial-of-service attack (crash, exit, or restart).  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25174 - An issue was discovered in Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK before v2021.12. A memory corruption vulnerability exists when reading malformed DGN files. This could allow attackers to cause a crash, enabling a denial-of-service condition (crash, exit, or restart).  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25173 - An issue was discovered in Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK before v2021.12. A memory allocation with excessive size vulnerability exists when reading malformed DGN files, which could allow attackers to cause a crash, enabling a denial-of-service condition (crash, exit, or restart).  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-040-06>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-040-07 - Siemens SCALANCE W780 and W740**  
CVE-2021-25666 - Sending specially crafted packets through the ARP protocol to an affected device could cause a partial denial-of-service condition, preventing the device from operating normally for a short period.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:L).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-040-07>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-040-08 - Siemens SIMARIS configuration**  
CVE-2020-28392 - During installation to default target folder, incorrect permissions are configured for the application folder and subfolders, which may allow an attacker to gain persistence or potentially escalate privileges if a user with elevated credentials logs onto the machine.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.4 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:L).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-040-08>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-040-09 - SIMATIC WinCC Graphics Designer**  
CVE-2020-10048 - An attacker could bypass the password protection of protected files due to an insecure password verification process, which may allow access to protected content without authentication.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.2 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-040-09>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-040-10 - Siemens DIGSI 4**  
CVE-2020-25245 - Several folders in the %PATH% are writeable by normal users. As these folders are included in the search for DLLs, an attacker could place a DLL file with code executed by SYSTEM.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-040-10>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/40992854/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20February%2009%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1613012962232&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

ICS-CERT has released a medical security advisory addressing two vulnerabilities in GE Healthcare Imaging and Ultrasound products.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



CVE-2020-25175 is an unprotected transport of credentials vulnerability and CVE-2020-25179 is an exposure of sensitive information to an unauthorized control sphere vulnerability. Potential impacts of successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities are unauthorized access, exposure of sensitive information, such as patient health information (PHI), and arbitrary code execution. No patches have been released to address these issues but GE has provided mitigation advice to prevent these vulnerabilities from being exploited.

We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for mitigation advice.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR20-239C - FASTCASH
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) malware analysis report, AR20-239C, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report is a joint publication from Department of Homeland Security, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the Department of Defense. The report provides information on the North Korean man-in-the-middle bank transaction modification malware, FASTCASH.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR20-239C - FASTCASH
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) malware analysis report, AR20-239C, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report is a joint publication from Department of Homeland Security, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the Department of Defense. The report provides information on the North Korean man-in-the-middle bank transaction modification malware, FASTCASH.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

 **From the Malware Analysis Report (AR20-239C)**  
 **MAR-10257062-1.v2 - North Korean Remote Access Tool: FASTCASH for Windows**

  


This Malware Analysis Report (MAR) is the result of analytic efforts between the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the Department of Defense (DoD). Working with U.S. Government partners, DHS, FBI, and DoD identified Remote Access Tool (RAT) malware variants used by the North Korean government. This malware variant has been identified as FASTCASH for Windows. The U.S. Government refers to malicious cyber activity by the North Korean government as HIDDEN COBRA. For more information on HIDDEN COBRA activity, visit https://www.us-cert.gov/hiddencobra.

FBI has high confidence that HIDDEN COBRA actors are using malware variants in conjunction with proxy servers to maintain a presence on victim networks and to further network exploitation. DHS, FBI, and DoD are distributing this MAR to enable network defense and reduce exposure to North Korean government malicious cyber activity.

This MAR includes malware descriptions related to HIDDEN COBRA, suggested response actions and recommended mitigation techniques. Users or administrators should flag activity associated with the malware and report the activity to the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) or the FBI Cyber Watch (CyWatch), and give the activity the highest priority for enhanced mitigation.

This submission included two unique files. The first file is a malicious application, which can be utilized to inject a dynamic link library (DLL) into a remote Windows process. The second file is a malicious Windows DLL. The DLL contains two functions that can hook callbacks to the Windows application programming interfaces (APIs) "Send" and "Recv" within a targeted process. These hook functions are utilized to intercept traffic received by the target process. In received Financial Messages, the malicious functions will look for targeted Primary Account Numbers (PAN) to deliver a custom response. It appears the malware will target a system on a bank infrastructure, which is designed to process automated teller machine (ATM) transactions.

This updated report included an additional sample that is used by advanced persistent threat (APT) cyber actors in the targeting of banking payment systems. The sample is a man-in-the-middle bank transaction modification malware. Once the malware is injected into an executable, it takes control of the send and receive functions in order to identify, log, and modify ISO 8583 messages. ISO 8583 is an international standard for financial transaction card originated interchanged messaging. This functionality enables the actor to withdraw more money than is actually available. The malware specifically targets ISO 8583 Point of Sale (POS) system messages, ATM transaction requests, and ATM balance inquiries. The sample uses code from open source repositories on the Internet and modifies the parsing code to support Extended Binary Coded Decimal Interchange Code (EBCDIC) encoding. EBCDIC is a character encoding format like the more commonly ASCII.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. for Yara Rules.



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-239c>
