instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Remcos RAT Delivered via Visual Basic
Remcos RAT is leveraging new tactics in recent campaigns. Malwarebytes published a blog post detailing the new behaviors being observed.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Remcos RAT Delivered via Visual Basic
Remcos RAT is leveraging new tactics in recent campaigns. Malwarebytes published a blog post detailing the new behaviors being observed.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type** : RAT

  *  **Associated Threat Actors** : Unknown

  *  **Associated Payloads** : Remcos ([S0332](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332/))

  *  **Initial Infection Vector** : Finance-themed malspam ([T1566.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/001/))

  *  **Post-Compromise Actions** : Remote control, steal sensitive information

  *  **Additional TTPs** : PowerShell Scripts ([T1059.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001/)) Visual Basic Scripts ([T1059.005](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/005/)), Registry Run Keys/Startup Folder ([T1547.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1547/001/)), communication with Non-Standard Port ([T1571](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1571)), payloads hosted on Archive.org ([T1102](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1102/)), payload injected into aspnet_compiler.exe ([T1055.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/002/))




# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post detailing the most recent tactics being used by the Remcos RAT. The threat actors are still leveraging ZIP and IMG attachments on financially-themed malspam emails as an initial infection vector. These archives, however, now contain a Visual Basic script instead of an executable file. This script kicks off an infection chain that involves multiple stages of PowerShell downloading and executing additional obfuscated VB scripts. The final script is responsible for injecting an embedded PE file into aspnet_compiler.exe. The executable is the Remcos RAT, which provides its operator with the ability to fully control the victim system and steal sensitive information. The various Visual Basic scripts were all hosted on the legitimate Archive.org to evade detection. Additionally, all samples of the final payload called back to an IP address and port, but no C2 communication was observed. For more information, see the Malwarebyes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-analysis/2021/07/remcos-rat-delivered-via-visual-basic/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ACTINIUM Targeting Ukraine
Microsoft has published a report on the activities of a threat actor they have named ACTINIUM that has been targeting organizations located in Ukraine.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian government entities including the judiciary, law enforcement, and military as well as attacking non-profit organizations and NGOs.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** DinoTrain, DesertDown, DilongTrash, ObfuBerry, ObfuMerry, PowerPunch, Pterodo (S0147), QuietSieve.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing emails with malicious documents attached.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral movement, collection, and exfiltration of information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

ACTINIUM is the name Microsoft has applied to a threat actor they previously tracked as DEV-0157 and is also known publicly as Gamaredon. ACTINIUM has been operating for close to 10 years. In the last 6 months, Microsoft has observed ACTINIUM targeting Ukrainian government entities including the judiciary, law enforcement, and military as well as attacking non-profit organizations and NGOs. The Ukrainian government has attributed ACTINIUM to the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) and has been operating from Crimea. Microsoft reports that ACTINIUM's objectives are cyber espionage, maintaining and using their access to move laterally into related organizations. While a number of vectors may be used to compromise their targets. Microsoft notes one method in its report, that being the use of spearphishing emails with malicious documents attached that use remote template injection to begin the infection chain. The spearphishing emails and documents are typically themed to an organization that is familiar to the target. A number of payloads are deployed and these include DesertDown, DinoTrain, DilongTrash, ObfuBerry, ObfuMerry, PowerPunch, Pterodo, QuietSieve. In some cases, UltraVNC has been deployed to provide more interactive remote access. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058528/ACTINIUM%20Targeting%20Ukraine%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644546386402&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/02/04/actinium-targets-ukrainian-organizations/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.002 - Tool  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1199 - Trusted Relationship  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002  
** T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
ACTINIUM Targeting Ukraine
Microsoft has published a report on the activities of a threat actor they have named ACTINIUM that has been targeting organizations located in Ukraine.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian government entities including the judiciary, law enforcement, and military as well as attacking non-profit organizations and NGOs.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** DinoTrain, DesertDown, DilongTrash, ObfuBerry, ObfuMerry, PowerPunch, Pterodo (S0147), QuietSieve.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing emails with malicious documents attached.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral movement, collection, and exfiltration of information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

ACTINIUM is the name Microsoft has applied to a threat actor they previously tracked as DEV-0157 and is also known publicly as Gamaredon. ACTINIUM has been operating for close to 10 years. In the last 6 months, Microsoft has observed ACTINIUM targeting Ukrainian government entities including the judiciary, law enforcement, and military as well as attacking non-profit organizations and NGOs. The Ukrainian government has attributed ACTINIUM to the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) and has been operating from Crimea. Microsoft reports that ACTINIUM's objectives are cyber espionage, maintaining and using their access to move laterally into related organizations. While a number of vectors may be used to compromise their targets. Microsoft notes one method in its report, that being the use of spearphishing emails with malicious documents attached that use remote template injection to begin the infection chain. The spearphishing emails and documents are typically themed to an organization that is familiar to the target. A number of payloads are deployed and these include DesertDown, DinoTrain, DilongTrash, ObfuBerry, ObfuMerry, PowerPunch, Pterodo, QuietSieve. In some cases, UltraVNC has been deployed to provide more interactive remote access. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058528/ACTINIUM%20Targeting%20Ukraine%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644546386402&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/02/04/actinium-targets-ukrainian-organizations/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories February 02 2021
The ICS-CERT has published two advisories that affect Rockwell Automation's MicroLogix 1400 and Siemens SIMATIC HMI Comfort Panels and SIMATIC HMI KTP Mobile Panels.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-033-01 - Rockwell Automation MicroLogix 1400**  
CVE-2021-22659 - A remote unauthenticated attacker may be able to send a specially crafted Modbus packet allowing the attacker to retrieve or modify random values in the register. If successfully exploited, this may lead to a buffer overflow resulting in a denial-of-service condition. The FAULT LED will flash RED and communications may be lost. Recovery from denial-of-service condition requires the fault to be cleared by the user.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-033-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-033-02 - Siemens SIMATIC HMI Comfort Panels & SIMATIC HMI KTP Mobile Panels**  
CVE-2020-15798 - Affected devices with enabled Telnet service do not require authentication for this service. This could allow a remote attacker to gain full access to the device.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-033-02>

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-22659, CVE-2020-15798




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Further NOBELIUM Information From Microsoft
In a follow-on from its prior blog postings on NOBELIUM activity, Microsoft has published another blog post on NOBELIUM. This post focuses on the toolset used by NOBELIUM in the early stages of an attack.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

In a blog post, Microsoft reference four tools, BoomBox, EnvyScout, NativeZone, and VaporRage, used by NOBELIUM during the early stages of gaining a foothold in a target entity. The tools have been observed in use since February 2021. BoomBox is a downloader that downloads components from Dropbox. It also uploads reconnaissance information to Dropbox. EnvyScout is also a dropper typically delivered to the victim as an attachment to a spearphishing email. It has multiple components including an obfuscated ISO, and others the carry out functions such as credential-harvesting, tracking, and deobfuscating files and writing them to disk. Multiple variants of EnvyScout are detailed in the blog post. NativeZone is a loader that uses rundll32.exe to load components. VaporRage is described as a shellcode downloader that contacts a legitimate, but compromised, Wordpess site, and registers the system as compromised. If the system is of interest to the attackers, it downloads a shellcode blob from the same site, decodes, and executes it in memory. In addition, Microsoft notes that NOBELIUM use a number of custom Cobalt Strike Beacon loaders which Microsoft will track under the name NativeZone. Further information is available from the blog post linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/05/28/breaking-down-nobeliums-latest-early-stage-toolset/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Pastebin-like Service Used in Multiple Malware Campaigns
Attackers have begun using a new pastebin-like service, paste.nrecom.net, to store malware payloads. Loaders, which are delivered as attachments in phishing emails, are used to download the payloads. The attacks have targeted multiple industries sectors including banking, shipping, and supply chain.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Spear Phishing




# Overview

  
Threat actors have reconstructed the conventional tactic of using legitimate web services to host malware payloads by exploiting a new pastebin-like service, paste.nrecom.net. The service operates on the open-source package, [Stikked](https://github.com/claudehohl/Stikked). While the service allows only text pastes, binary data can be encoded and stored as plain text. According to Juniper Threat Labs, it is "the first time, we have seen threat actors use paste.nrecom.net". Juniper Threat Labs mentioned various malware that threat actors hosted on paste.nrecom.net including LimeRAT, W3Cryptolocker, and Redline Stealer. However, it was observed that AgentTesla is one of the more common malwares hosted on the service. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.




# References

  * [https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/threat-research/new-pastebin-like-service-used-in-multiple-malware-campaigns](https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/threat-research/new-pastebin-like-service-used-in-multiple-malware-campaigns)

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Guildma Campaign Targeting South America
In an entry in the SANS InfoSec Handlers Diary post, researcher Renato Marinho reports a campaign using the Guildma banking Trojan that is targeting South America, primarily Brazil.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Guildma, also reported as Astaroth, is a banking Trojan that is used to target Latin America, typically Brazillian users. In a SANS InfoSec Handlers Diary post, researcher Renato Marinho provides information on a recently discovered campaign that is using a new variant of the Guildma banking Trojan. The campaign uses phishing emails that contain a link to a ZIP file. The ZIP file contains an LNK file which is named so that it appears to be a PDF file. If the LNK file is executed, it runs the Windows binary "Finger.exe". Finger connects to a Finger server under the control of the attackers, the returning data from which is passed to "cmd.exe" and executed. This results in the creation of a JavaScript file containing VB Script which is executed and downloads five files using "bitsadmin.exe". One of the downloaded files, named "ctfmon.exe", is a copy of the legitimate Windows binary "coregen.exe" which uses a technique called Signed Binary Proxy Execution to load another of the downloaded files, "helper.dll". If it is successfully loaded, helper.dll loads the remaining DLL files "log32.dll" and "log33.dll". Log32.dll is responsible for some system checks, anti-debugging and anti-vm operations, and C&C communications. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/diary/rss/27482>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Threat Group POLONIUM Abusing OneDrive
Microsoft has published details of a threat group they are tracking as POLONIUM. This group is a Lebanon-based group and could be affiliated with the Iranian government.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Implant
* **Associated Threat Actors:** POLONIUM
* **Associated Payloads:** CreepyDrive, CreepyBox, CreepySnail
* **Targets:** Israeli Organizations
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Microsoft has detected activity from a new threat group they are tracking as POLONIUM. This group is based in Lebanon and has targeted more than 20 organizations based in Israel. The researchers speculate that this group could be working on behalf of the Iranian government. The group seems to target IT companies to possibly compromise downstream companies, which can include law firms, aviation and defense organizations, and critical manufacturing. The group has been using cloud services, such as OneDrive for data exfiltration and C2 operations. They also use a series of custom implants which are called CreepyDrive and CreepyBox. CreepyDrive is a basic implant allowing for the upload and download of files and appears to have no persistence mechanism. Beyond the custom tools, they also use commodity tools such as plink to set up a tunnel to the attacker infrastructure. Although the initial access method is not currently clear, nearly 80% of victims were using Fortinet appliances. This could suggest that a vulnerability was being exploited for access. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/06/02/exposing-polonium-activity-and-infrastructure-targeting-israeli-organizations/>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  

**Execution - TA0002**  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
   T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
 T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1102 - Web Service  

#### Mitigations:

**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1102 - Web Service  

#### Mitigations:

**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

PRIVATELOG, and its installer, STASHLOG, are part of a new malware family discovered by Mandiant.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** New family
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Not attributed
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PRIVATELOG and STASHLOG
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified
  *  **Additional TTPs: See Mitre ATT &CK framework below.**



# Overview

A report from Mandiant provides their analysis of PRIVATELOG, and its installer, STASHLOG, which are part of a new malware family Mandiant discovered. An unusual feature of the malware is that it uses Window's Common Log File System (CLFS) to hide a second-stage payload. The majority of the strings in the malware are obfuscated and STASHLOG uses control flow obfuscation techniques to make static analysis more difficult. Mandiant has not yet been able to obtain samples of any payloads delivered by PRIVATELOG. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127098/New%20Malware%20-%20PRIVATELOG%20and%20STASHLOG%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630556357568&api=v2)

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).

  * <https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2021/09/unknown-actor-using-clfs-log-files-for-stealth.html>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.013 - Process Doppelgänging  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry

Tell me everything you know the following threat: JBS USA Cybersecurity Attack
JBS, the largest meat supplier in the United States, has published a media statement indicating they have fallen victim to a cyber security attack.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Breach




# Overview

JBS, a major US meat supplier, published a media statement regarding a cyber security attack against their networks. The servers impacted were those that support their North American and Australian IT networks. In order to prevent the attack from continuing and spreading, JBS shut down affected systems, impacting operations and potentially causing major supply chain issues. The media statement indicated that backup servers were not affected and are being used to restore systems. The White House's statement on the incident believes it is likely a Russian-based threat actor responsible, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) is assisting in the investigation. X-Force is monitoring the situation closely and will provide updates to this collection if any additional information is released. Further information can be found in the articles linked to in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Another LILIN DVR 0-day Used to Spread Mirai
Previously targeted by various botnets, a new 0-day vulnerability has been identified in LILIN DVR devices. 360 Netlab discovered this 0-day as part of Mirai activity and their recent blog post discusses the technical details of the vulnerability.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Exploit, Botnet




# Overview

360 Netlab published a blog post analyzing a 0-day vulnerability in LILIN DVR that was discovered being exploited by Mirai samples. Based on their findings, almost 7,000 devices remain vulnerable to this 0-day, which has since been patched by Merit LILIN. The exploit used by Mirai is leveraged in combination with default credentials for infection. Specifically, the vulnerability allows for remote code execution based on a web service that runs a command line program against provided parameters. However, one of the passed parameters is not validated, so it can be leveraged to pass a shell command of the attacker's choice that will be executed in shared memory. The patch released by Merit LILIN ensures that this vulnerable parameter includes the expected content type. It is recommended that LILIN DVR/NVR users update their devices and ensure strong login credentials are configured. For more information, see the 360 Netlab blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/another-lilin-dvr-0-day-being-used-to-spread-mirai-en/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malspam Campaign Leveraging US Election
According to a report from Malwarebytes Labs, a malspam campaign seeking to leverage uncertainty around the US election is underway.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

As the US election has been of high public interest, it's no surprise that bad actors have been attempting to leverage it in malspam. Malwarebytes Labs has reported on a campaign that is using a theme of interference in the electoral process as a lure. The emails come as replies to existing threads, have a spreadsheet attached that is crafted to appear as if it were a Docusign file, and attempts to induce the victim to enable macros. If macros are enabled, a QBot payload is downloaded and installed on the victim system. QBot will then go to work exfiltrating data and emails from which can be extracted threads for use in further emails or campaigns.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/cybercrime/2020/11/qbot-delivered-via-malspam-campaign-exploiting-us-election-uncertainties/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: VMware Security Advisory - November 18th, 2020
VMware has published security advisory VMSA-2020-0025 that addresses multiple vulnerabilities in the SD-WAN Orchestrator.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
VMware has published security advisory VMSA-2020-0025 that addresses six vulnerabilities in the SD-WAN Orchestrator. Of the vulnerabilities, three are rated by VMware as Important, and three as Moderate. Successfully exploited, the vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to access data, execute files, carry out a Pass-the-Hash attack, escalate privileges, and execute arbitrary code on the underlying operating system. SD-WAN Orchestrator versions 3.x and 4.x are affected by the vulnerabilities. Further details are available from the advisory linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982960/VMware%20Security%20Advisory%20-%20November%2018th%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605841380241&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2020-0025.html>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
SAP Security Patches - March 2021
SAP has released its March 2021 security patches for a variety of products. Each product and a link to details on the vulnerability are listed below. In all, 13 security notes were released. Of these, 4 are rated critical, 1 is rated high, 5 are rated as medium, and 4 are updates to previously released patches. The most serious post-exploitation action, if the vulnerability is exploited, is remote code execution. In addition, privilege escalation, accessing sensitive files, and other nefarious actions are possible.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Gallium Expands Targeting With New PingPull Tool
Palo Alto's Unit 42 has analyzed a new remote access Trojan named PingPull that is being utilized by a possibly state-sponsored APT group named Gallium.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Malware, Espionage
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Gallium, aka Softcell
* **Associated Payloads:** PingPull RAT
* **Targets:** Organizations in the government, finance, and telecommunications sectors located in Africa, Europe, and Southeast Asia.
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of information
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Gallium is a threat group that has been targeting organizations in Africa, Europe, and Southeast Asia. Gallium has historically targeted the telecommunications sector but has expanded its targeting to include the finance and government sectors. According to a report from Palo Alto's Unit42, Gallium is likely to be a Chinese state-sponsored group. The new PingPull RAT used by Gallium comes in three main variants, each of which uses one of three protocols, HTTP(S), ICMP, or raw TCP, for C&C communications. The use of ICMP helps PingPull helps hide its connections to C2 servers as few organizations monitor ICMP traffic. PingPull malware is coded in C++ and gives the threat actor the ability to execute commands and access a reverse shell on compromised hosts. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/pingpull-gallium/](https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/pingpull-gallium/ "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
 T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
   T1583.004 - Server  
 T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
   T1588.002 - Tool  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1078 - Valid Accounts  
 T1133 - External Remote Services  
 T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
 T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
   T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
   T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1078 - Valid Accounts  
 T1136 - Create Account  
   T1136.002 - Domain Account  
 T1505 - Server Software Component  
   T1505.003 - Web Shell  
 T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
   T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
   T1027.002 - Software Packing  
   T1027.005 - Indicator Removal from Tools  
 T1036 - Masquerading  
   T1036.003 - Rename System Utilities  
 T1550 - Use Alternate Authentication Material  
   T1550.002 - Pass the Hash  
 T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
   T1553.002 - Code Signing  

**Credential Access - TA0006**  
 T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
   T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
   T1003.002 - Security Account Manager  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
 T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
 T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
 T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  

**Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
 T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1005 - Data from Local System  
 T1074 - Data Staged  
   T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
 T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
   T1560.001 - Archive via Utility  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
 T1090 - Proxy  
   T1090.002 - External Proxy  
 T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
 T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
   T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1015:**  Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1020:**  SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1027:**  Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1032:**  Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1035:**  Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1041:**  Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1046:**  Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1052:**  User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1052:**  User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Targeted RTM Attacks using Quoter Ransomware
The Russian-speaking RTM threat group has launched a new campaign against Russian transport and finance organizations. Kaspersky reports on their usage of new techniques to include ransomware and extortion.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Targeted RTM Attacks using Quoter Ransomware
The Russian-speaking RTM threat group has launched a new campaign against Russian transport and finance organizations. Kaspersky reports on their usage of new techniques to include ransomware and extortion.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Kaspersky has published a blog post analyzing a recent campaign carried out by the RTM threat group against Russian transport and finance organizations. The campaign, as with previous ones, begins with the distribution of a the RTM banker via business-themed phishing emails. With the banker installed, the attackers move laterally across the network with legitimate remote access tools, such as RMS, and custom malicious utilities. In the past, their ultimate goal was to access computers owned by accounting employees and use the banker payload to substitute banking details. However, in this campaign, if those attempts fail backup plans are in place to ensure they can still turn a profit. If the banker infection is unsuccessful, the first backup function is to install a ransomware payload dubbed "Quoter." The ransomware encrypts the files on all previously infected computers and leaves a ransom note. If, after a period of time, the ransom is not paid or the encryption fails, an extortion letter is then sent to the victims claiming that data has been stolen and that if a payment isn't made, the data will be posted publicly. Notably, organizations in Russia are not typically targeted with ransomware, so this is highly unusual behavior. For more information, see the SecureList blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.ru/new-targeted-attacks-rtm/100720/>

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.ru/new-targeted-attacks-rtm/100720/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Researchers Create Tool to Spot Cryptography Mistakes
Researchers from Columbia University have created a tool that allowed them to identify more than 300 applications on the Google Play store with errors in cryptography code. ThreatPost has taken a closer look at this analysis and provided insight into a new tool used in its research.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Cryptography, Malware




# Overview

Columbia University researchers have created a new tool which allows for the detection of unsafe cryptographic code within apps in the Google Play Store. Using this tool, the researchers were able to identify more than 300 applications using unsafe code. Broken hash functions, bad passwords, reusing passwords multiple times, HTTP URL connections, and "badly-derived" keys for encryption are detectable using this tool. Using this tool, the research team analyzed 1,780 of the most popular apps on the Play Store. Hundreds of the apps were breaking one or more of these rules and, in some cases, multiple rules. The most common rules circumvented include unsafe PRNG, broken hash functions, and operation mode CBC. Upon notification of all discovered apps, only 18 responded, eight responded with "useful feedback." CRYLOGGER is an open-source tool available on a GitHub repository. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://threatpost.com/cryptobugs-found-in-numerous-google-play-store-apps/159013/>

  * <https://github.com/lucapiccolboni/crylogger>

QNAP published five security advisories addressing eight vulnerabilities affecting QNAP NAS devices.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



QSA-20-12 and QSA-20-16 address cross-site scripting and command injection vulnerabilities in QTS and QuTS hero. If successfully exploited, remote attackers may be able to execute arbitrary code on vulnerable devices.

QSA-20-13, QSA-20-14, and QSA-20-15 address cross-site scripting vulnerabilities in Music Station, Multimedia Console, and Photo Station, respectively. If successfully exploited, remote attackers may be able to execute arbitrary code on vulnerable devices.

Tell me everything you know the following threat: Xen Security Advisories March 5 2021
Two security advisories have been published for Xen. The most serious vulnerability addressed in the advisories could potentially allow an attacker to cause a denial of service condition on the host system.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further details are available from the advisories linked below.

Xen Security Advisory CVE-2021-28038 / XSA-367  
Linux: netback fails to honor grant mapping errors  
Impact: A malicious or buggy networking frontend driver may be able to crash the corresponding backend driver, potentially affecting the entire domain running the backend driver. In a typical (non-disaggregated) system that is a host-wide denial of service (DoS).  
<https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/advisory-367.html>

Xen Security Advisory CVE-2021-28039 / XSA-369  
Linux: special config may crash when trying to map foreign pages  
Impact: A Dom0 or driver domain based on a Linux kernel (configured as described above) can be crashed by a malicious guest administrator, or possibly malicious unprivileged guest processes.  
<https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/advisory-369.html>

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-28038, CVE-2021-28039




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Diavol Ransomware - Possibly Linked to Wizard Spider
When investigating the binaries used in a ransomware attack, one of the binaries turned out to be a new ransomware family FortiGuard Labs has named Diavol.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Diavol is a new ransomware family that was discovered and named by FortiGuard Labs during an investigation. Two ransomware binaries were found, one of them (locker64.dll) confirmed to be Conti (v3), the other, Diavol (locker.exe). It is not known how the compromise that led to ransomware being on the victim system was carried out. The ransom note left on the system claims that data was exfiltrated from the victim system but, FortiGuard researchers did not find any such functionality in Diavol samples. Unusually for ransomware, Diavol does not use an asymmetric encryption algorithm, rather, it uses user-mode Asynchronous Procedure Calls with no symmetric encryption algorithm which is substantially slower. As is more typical of current ransomware, Diavol terminates running processes that lock files though the FortiGuard Labs report notes errors in Diavol's hard-coded configuration. The report speculates that Diavol may be a new tool used by the Russian APT group, Wizard Spider. The report contains further details and is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/diavol-new-ransomware-used-by-wizard-spider>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Technical Analysis of PureCrypter
Zscaler has posted a technical analysis of a new loader that is being utilized by a threat actor to download remote access trojans (RAT). The new malware is considered to be a fully-featured loader.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Loader
* **Associated Threat Actors:** PureCoder
* **Associated Payloads:** AgentTesla, Arkei, AsyncRAT, Azorult, DcRAT, LokiBotStealer, Nanocore, RedLineStealer, Remcos, SnakeKeylogger, WarzoneRAT
* **Targets:** Unknown
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing, Malicious Microsoft Office Document
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Zscaler researchers have observed a loader that has been utilized to download a number of remote access trojans (RAT). This malware is known as PureCrypter and is being utilized by the threat actor, PureCoder. The loader has been available for sale since March of 2021. The first stage is a fake console application that uses a .NET assembly from a C&C server. The second stage typically has a fake extension that includes jpg, png, or log and a legitimate appearing file name. PureCrypter achieves persistence by utilizing registry keys and changing the value name and value data. Additionally, PureCryter uses reversed, compressed, and encrypted payloads that make it difficult for many anti-virus solutions to detect. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/technical-analysis-purecrypter](https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/technical-analysis-purecrypter "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

#### Tactics and Techniques:

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
   T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  

**Execution - TA0002**  
   T1204.001 - Malicious Link  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
   T1027.002 - Software Packing  
   T1036.001 - Invalid Code Signature  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1005 - Data from Local System  

#### **Mitigations:**

**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: The Return of TA542 and Emotet
A report from Proofpoint looks at the return of TA542 and the group's distribution of Emotet malware. In early February, TA542 appeared to cease distribution of Emotet and began distributing it again in mid July.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Returning from a hiatus that began in February, Proofpoint reports that TA542 began their spam campaigns distributing the Emotet malware again in mid July, 2020. According to Proofpoint, the first day of a TA542 campaign can see almost a million messages blocked. Some changes have been observed in TA542's TTPs. One is that the primary payload is now a Qbot affiliate, partner01. Prior to the hiatus, the primary payload was the Trick affiliate "morXX". The Emotet module for sending email can now attach both malicious and benign attachments. The lures used in the campaigns range from generic issues to hot topics such as COVID-19. The hijacking of email threads and the localization of languages in emails has been continued, along with the use of malicious Word documents attached to emails. To a lesser extent, TA542 has used PDF, JavaScript, and Zip attachments, and links to malicious Word documents in the emails. The malicious links typically point to compromised hosts. The main countries targeted include Austria, Canada, Germany, Switzerland, United Kingdom, and United States. According to Proofpoint, TA542 has been experimentally targeting other countries including India, Indonesia, the Philippines, Sweden, and others. Further information is available in the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/comprehensive-look-emotets-summer-2020-return>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cobalt Mirage Conducts Ransomware Operations in U.S.
Secureworks researchers released a report detailing their investigation into possible activity involving the Cobalt Mirage threat group. Reporting indicates that this threat actor is connected to Iran and has been active since June 2020.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cobalt Mirage Conducts Ransomware Operations in U.S.
Secureworks researchers released a report detailing their investigation into possible activity involving the Cobalt Mirage threat group. Reporting indicates that this threat actor is connected to Iran and has been active since June 2020.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type: Ransomware**
  *  **Associated Threat Actors: Cobalt Mirage, Cobalt Illusion, Phosphorous, TunnerVision**
  *  **Associated Payloads: BitLocker, DiskCryptor**
  *  **Targets: U.S. philanthropic organization**



# Overview

Secureworks Counter Threat Unit (CTU) has recently collected intelligence based on incident response investigations and open-source reporting. The researchers have received reflections that indicate that Cobalt Mirage has been conducting offensive cyber operations in Israel, the U.S., Europe, and Australia. Cobalt Mirage has been linked to the Iranian threat group Cobalt Illusion and past activities have also been reported as Phosphorous and TunnelVison. IBM X-Force has connected activities between these groups and tracks them as ITG18.

Secureworks CTU is tracking separate clusters of activity involving Cobalt Mirage. Clusters A and B seem to have two separate goals for operational focus. Cluster A operations include BitLocker and DiskCryptor to conduct ransomware attacks for financial gain. Cluster B is assessed to be conducting targeted attacks to collect intelligence. Reporting indicates that this threat actor group scans internet-facing servers for unpatched flaws in Fortinet appliances and Microsoft Exchange Servers. Reporting also indicates that Cobalt Mirage targeted U.S. local government networks in March of this year and leveraged vulnerabilities in Log4shell. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.secureworks.com/blog/cobalt-mirage-conducts-ransomware-operations-in-us>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

####  **Tactics and Techniques:**

####  **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1098 - Account Manipulation  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1114 - Email Collection  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

 **Mitigations:**

 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Cobalt Mirage Conducts Ransomware Operations in U.S.
Secureworks researchers released a report detailing their investigation into possible activity involving the Cobalt Mirage threat group. Reporting indicates that this threat actor is connected to Iran and has been active since June 2020.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type: Ransomware**
  *  **Associated Threat Actors: Cobalt Mirage, Cobalt Illusion, Phosphorous, TunnerVision**
  *  **Associated Payloads: BitLocker, DiskCryptor**
  *  **Targets: U.S. philanthropic organization**



# Overview

Secureworks Counter Threat Unit (CTU) has recently collected intelligence based on incident response investigations and open-source reporting. The researchers have received reflections that indicate that Cobalt Mirage has been conducting offensive cyber operations in Israel, the U.S., Europe, and Australia. Cobalt Mirage has been linked to the Iranian threat group Cobalt Illusion and past activities have also been reported as Phosphorous and TunnelVison. IBM X-Force has connected activities between these groups and tracks them as ITG18.

Secureworks CTU is tracking separate clusters of activity involving Cobalt Mirage. Clusters A and B seem to have two separate goals for operational focus. Cluster A operations include BitLocker and DiskCryptor to conduct ransomware attacks for financial gain. Cluster B is assessed to be conducting targeted attacks to collect intelligence. Reporting indicates that this threat actor group scans internet-facing servers for unpatched flaws in Fortinet appliances and Microsoft Exchange Servers. Reporting also indicates that Cobalt Mirage targeted U.S. local government networks in March of this year and leveraged vulnerabilities in Log4shell. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Increase in Travel-Themed Phishing
As the world reopens to travel, it is not surprising that Palo Alto has identified an increase in travel-themed phishing, which they detail in a recent blog post.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Travel industry and customers
  *  **Lure:** Travel notice or services
  *  **Payload:** Phishing link
  *  **Compromised Data:** Account credentials, payment information, customer data
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Varies



# Overview

Palo Alto published a blog post discussing an increase in travel-themed phishing campaigns, aligning with an increase in ability to travel again post-COVID. Their data specifically revealed an increase in travel-themed phishing URLs being created since early 2021. These URLs were likely related to numerous campaigns, with the blog post providing two specific examples. The first is the use of these travel-themed URLs to assist in the delivery of the Dridex malware. The URL is used by a macro in an Excel spreadsheet that is either attached to the email or hosted on Dropbox. The researchers also observed a campaign targeting travel industry organizations and customers with Firebase-hosted web applications. The type of data that may be accessed during these phishing attempts ranges from account credentials to customer data to payment information. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127996/Increase%20in%20Travel-Themed%20Phishing%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631893249357&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/travel-themed-phishing/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: TFlower Ransomware Using MATA Framework
New research reveals a connection between the Lazarus Group and TFlower; specifically, TFlower's usage of a MATA framework variant in a recent campaign.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, Ransomware




# Overview

A report from Sygnia indicates a connection or collaboration between Lazarus and TFlower. The TFlower ransomware is deployed using the MATA backdoor, which is a well-known Lazarus commodity. The latest variant has not previously been seen in campaigns to this point. In addition to the MATA backdoor, the threat actors behind TFlower employ MATA in order to clear forensic evidence and evade detection through identifying and tampering with security products that may be installed on the target system. The MATA backdoor consists of a three-pronged approach - an initial loader (EXE), loader (DLL), and the payload (DAT). The malware is loaded by the EXE file, which then injects the DLL into svchost.exe and also modifies the LSA security package to achieve persistence through a modified registry value. The loader then decrypts the payload stored within the DAT file, which is loaded on startup or when the AddSecurityPackage Windows API function is called. This file is loaded by lsass.exe to achieve persistence. Finally, the payload is an encrypted binary that implements backdoor functionality. C2 server addresses are encrypted within a binary configuration blob which is hard-coded within the DAT payload. More than 200 certificates and 130 IP addresses are affiliated with MATA. Analysis reveals that 95% of the functionality within the DLL match functions in the MATA framework. Further technical details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.sygnia.co/mata-framework>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Inside a TeamTNT server
A report from Anomali Threat Research provides a look at the content of a TeamTNT server and the malware and tools it contained.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Bots, Backdoors, Crypotminers
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TeamTNT
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Various
  *  **Targets:** Cloud environments
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Vulnerabilities and misconfigured systems.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The content of a server, believed to be used by TeamTNT to host malware and tools, and provide IRC services, was discovered by Anomali Threat Research. TeamTNT has been operating since around April 2020 and typically target cloud environments to use for cryptomining. The server has been in use by TeamTNT since around August 2021 and as of October 5th, 2021, remained in use. The systems TeamTNT are known to have targeted include AWS, Docker, GCP, Linux, Kubernetes, and Windows. Once TeamTNT has compromised a system, they will deploy an IRC bot and cryptomining software. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129824/Inside%20a%20TeamTNT%20server%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633669922066&api=v2)

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.anomali.com/blog/inside-teamtnts-impressive-arsenal-a-look-into-a-teamtnt-server>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

T1496 - Resource Hijacking
