instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Fake COVID-19 Survey Hides Ransomware
The Threat Intelligence Team at MalwarebytesLabs recently observed phishing attacks conducted by the APT group, Silent Librarian; targeting universities and colleges worldwide. An attack against the University of British Columbia (UBC) by Silent Librarian, unusually, involved ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Fake COVID-19 Survey Hides Ransomware
The Threat Intelligence Team at MalwarebytesLabs recently observed phishing attacks conducted by the APT group, Silent Librarian; targeting universities and colleges worldwide. An attack against the University of British Columbia (UBC) by Silent Librarian, unusually, involved ransomware.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

The APT group, Silent Librarian are well known for targeting educational facilities with phishing campaigns used to obtain user credentials. In an attack against the University of British Columbia (UBC) which MalwarebytesLabs attributes to Silent Librarian, instead of attempting to obtain user credentials, the goal was to install the Vaggen ransomware. The attackers leveraged mailproof.com services to create legitimate email accounts that were then used to register accounts in Box.net and Dropbox. The emails sent to victims contained a link to a malicious document hosted on the free services. Analysis revealed that the malicious phishing document utilized template injection to download and execute a remote template that contained a malicious macro; as well as notified via the canarytokens.com website. The final payload was the Vaggen ransomware that encrypts user’s files and drops a ransom note on the Desktop, demanding a payment equivalent to $80 USD to be paid in Bitcoin. For more information, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/cybercrime/2020/10/fake-covid-19-survey-hides-ransomware-in-canadian-university-attack/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Citrix Vulnerability Exploited To Deliver Webshell
Crowdstrike recently investigated an incident in which the threat actor PROPHET SPIDER exploited a vulnerability in Citrix software to deliver a webshell. The technical details of this have been published in a report.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Citrix Vulnerability Exploited To Deliver Webshell
Crowdstrike recently investigated an incident in which the threat actor PROPHET SPIDER exploited a vulnerability in Citrix software to deliver a webshell. The technical details of this have been published in a report.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** PROPHET SPIDER
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public Facing Infrastructure
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Further Tool Download



# Overview

Crowdstrike has published the details of an incident in which PROPHET SPIDER deployed a web shell. PROPHET SPIDER is a cybercriminal group that has been active since 2017. In this incident, they exploited a vulnerability in the Citrix ShareFile Storage Zones Controller service to upload code that will execute arbitrary commands. After infection, the actors tested the connection and then downloaded a reverse shell tool from GitHub. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/prophet-spider-exploits-citrix-sharefile/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1505.003 - Web Shell  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New PurpleFox Backdoor
According to a report from Trend Micro, the PurpleFox exploit kit has added a new backdoor, an additional privilege escalation exploit, and its rootkit has undergone some optimization.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New PurpleFox Backdoor
According to a report from Trend Micro, the PurpleFox exploit kit has added a new backdoor, an additional privilege escalation exploit, and its rootkit has undergone some optimization.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** FoxSocket
  *  **Targets:** Users in the Middle East
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Privilege escalation, Persistence, C&C communication.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

While investigating activity related to a PurpleFox operator, Trend Micro discovered that a new backdoor and privilege escalation exploit that targets CVE-2021-1732 has been added to PurpleFox. In addition, PurpleFox's rootkit has undergone some optimization. The new backdoor, which Trend Micro has named FoxSocket, has a notable feature in that it uses WebSockets for its C&C communications. Using WebSockets allows for bidirectional messaging using a single TCP session (keepalive messages are used to maintain the session) which may help avoid detection. The C&C traffic is encrypted using AES. Trend Micro believes that users in the Middle East are currently being targeted with PurpleFox. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616374/New%20PurpleFox%20Backdoor%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634875914408&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/j/purplefox-adds-new-backdoor-that-uses-websockets.html>

 **Execution - TA0002**

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**

T1055.001 - Dynamic-link Library Injection

T1574.007 - Path Interception by PATH Environment Variable

T1574.009 - Path Interception by Unquoted Path  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit

T1027.005 - Indicator Removal from Tools

T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
T1564.001 - Hidden Files and Directories  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials

 **Discovery - TA0007**

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Phishing Email Using FINRA Lookalike Domain
FINRA published a notice regarding a phishing campaign using a FINRA theme to lure victims into providing sensitive information.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

 The email is being sent via a recently-registered, lookalike domain attempting to spoof FINRA. The email claims a compliance request has been issued and the recipients will face penalties if the request is not completed. The body of the email uses FINRA branding and organization information in order to increase its legitimacy. Visiting the link will request the user provide sensitive information, which will ultimately be sent back to the attacker. FINRA has since requested the registrar suspend the domain. For more information, see the FINRA notice in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.finra.org/rules-guidance/notices/21-20>

# Overview

 This vulnerability, CVE-2020-16016, is reportedly due to "inappropriate implementation in base," and few other details are provided outside its "high" severity rating. The new version of Chrome is 86.0.4240.193 and will be rolling out automatically to users over the coming days/weeks. We recommend ensuring patches are applied where applicable as soon as possible. instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: WatchDog - A Two Year Cryptomining Operation
A more than two-year cryptomining operation has been underway and has collected more than $32K to date. Palo Alto's Unit 42 details the years long scam and provided a comprehensive list of IoCs, TTPs, and other salient details.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: WatchDog - A Two Year Cryptomining Operation
A more than two-year cryptomining operation has been underway and has collected more than $32K to date. Palo Alto's Unit 42 details the years long scam and provided a comprehensive list of IoCs, TTPs, and other salient details.

# Threat Type

  * Cryptomining




# Overview

Operation WatchDog is a two-year cryptomining campaign that has been active since at least January 2019. At present, the campaign has brought at least 209 Monero (XMR), or roughly $32K. Composed of mostly of Windows and Unix/Linux cloud instances, the operation has compromised and used at least 476 compromised computer systems. The miner is made up of a three-part GoLang binary set and bash or PowerShell script files. Each binary has a specific function with the first emulating the Linux watchdogd daemon, which ensures the actual mining doesn't hang, overload, or terminate. The second retrieves a list of IP address net ranges prior to enabling the targeted exploitation operations of vulnerable NIX or Windows systems. Finally, the last binary initiates the mining process on either of the aforementioned operating systems. This mining process is initiated via custom configurations from the bash or PowerShell script. As long as GoLang is installed on the target system, the miner can perform operations across operating systems, making it particularly effective in its infiltration across a network. Interestingly, WatchDog does not rely on a third-party host for its payload. This is how the campaign has remained active for more than two years. As of this writing, there is no indication of cloud compromise or credential theft; however, this not to say the attackers will not attempt to obtain such information. Technical details of the operation can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/watchdog-cryptojacking/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Tax-Based Phishing Campaign(s)
Tax season is upon us and, with that, threat actors are ramping up their campaigns to gather information from unsuspecting victims regarding their "tax debts." Fortinet takes a look at some of the latest campaigns seen.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Using old techniques such as phishing emails, threat actors are targeting individuals with threats of bogus tax bills, changes in regulations due to COVID, and other schemes. In examples obtained by Fortinet, indicators of invalid emails are apparent such as misspellings, titles that do not exist, and, perhaps most importantly, emails from the IRS. The IRS does not send emails to citizens. The only IRS-initiated correspondence is in the form of mailed letters. The emails in question have attachments and/or links just as most other phishing emails. In using keywords such as taxes and COVID, the actors hope to entice victims into downloading a malicious Excel binary workbook which, in turn, attempts to download and execute a DLL. This method has been used by the Trickbot group. During the same week, a second email was analyzed. This email contains a link to download a "full text" document. This email contains both spelling and grammar mistakes as most do. The link redirects several times before using a script to download a zip file from a legitimate judicial domain of the U.S. government. The zip file contains a VBS file that is malicious in nature but attempts to appear as junk code. The file attempts to connect to a C2 that is no longer active which could indicate the campaign has ended. More information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/did-you-file-your-taxes-yet>

The emails in question have attachments and/or links just as most other phishing emails. In using keywords such as taxes and COVID, the actors hope to entice victims into downloading a malicious Excel binary workbook which, in turn, attempts to download and execute a DLL. This method has been used by the Trickbot group. During the same week, a second email was analyzed. This email contains a link to download a "full text" document. This email contains both spelling and grammar mistakes as most do. The link redirects several times before using a script to download a zip file from a legitimate judicial domain of the U.S. government. The zip file contains a VBS file that is malicious in nature but attempts to appear as junk code. The file attempts to connect to a C2 that is no longer active which could indicate the campaign has ended. More information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/did-you-file-your-taxes-yet>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Recent Atlassian Confluence and Oracle WebLogic Exploit Campaigns
Exploit chains are commonly leveraged by botnets to spread their infections. A recent blog post from Trend Micro details two such campaigns targeting Atlassian Confluence and Oracle WebLogic vulnerabilities.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Recent Atlassian Confluence and Oracle WebLogic Exploit Campaigns
Exploit chains are commonly leveraged by botnets to spread their infections. A recent blog post from Trend Micro details two such campaigns targeting Atlassian Confluence and Oracle WebLogic vulnerabilities.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Muhstik, Kinsing, Tsunami Backdoor
  *  **Targets:** Vulnerable Confluence and WebLogic servers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of public-facing application
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing two campaigns exploiting server-based vulnerabilities to distribute botnet malware. The first campaign involves the Muhstik botnet and exploits CVE-2021-26048, a recent Atlassian Confluence OGNL injection vulnerability. The exploit allows for remote code execution, in this case for the purpose of downloading a script from a remote server. The initial script subsequently downloads a Trojan shell script and the Tsunami IRC backdoor. The backdoor access provides the attacker the ability to move laterally and perform denial-of-service (DoS) attacks while the Trojan shell script is responsible for executing the XMRig miner. The second exploit campaign observed involved the Kinsing botnet spreading via CVE-2020-14750, an Oracle WebLogic remote code execution vulnerability. As with the Muhstik infection, the initial exploit downloads a shell script. This shell script performs several defense evasion techniques and ultimately installs the Kinsing malware. Kinsing is capable of receiving C2 commands from the attacker, running a cryptominer, and moving laterally via SSH. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post and technical brief in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130496/Recent%20Atlassian%20Confluence%20and%20Oracle%20WebLogic%20Exploit%20Campaigns%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634563490920&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/j/tracking-cve-2021-26084-and-other-server-vulnerability-exploits.html>
  * <https://documents.trendmicro.com/assets/pdf/Technical-Brief---Tracking-CVE-2021-26084-and-Other-Server-based-Vulnerability-Exploits-via-Trend-Micro-Cloud-One-and-Trend-Micro-Vision-One.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.003 - Cron  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.002 - Clear Linux or Mac System Logs  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.004 - SSH  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: An Analysis of Monero Miner Variants And Techniques
Trend Micro has published details of the various vulnerabilities being used to spread cryptomining malware, as well as the techniques used to perform the attacks. To evade some detections, the malware uses popular services such as GitHub to download malicious scripts.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: An Analysis of Monero Miner Variants And Techniques
Trend Micro has published details of the various vulnerabilities being used to spread cryptomining malware, as well as the techniques used to perform the attacks. To evade some detections, the malware uses popular services such as GitHub to download malicious scripts.

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Cryptojacker
* **Associated Threat Actors:**Unknown
* **Associated Payloads:** Multiple Monero Miners
* **Targets:** Unknown
* **Initial Infection Vector:**Pre-Authentication RCE
* **Post-Compromise Actions:**Crypto-Mining

Overview
========

Trend Micro has published details of the various vulnerabilities being used to spread cryptomining malware, as well as the techniques used to perform the attacks. In the vulnerabilities listed, it is noted that they are all well-documented and have several proofs of concept published. The samples investigated in this project worked on both Windows and Linux systems. This fact, coupled with the wide range of CVEs used, allows attackers to establish a presence on many hosts, making the campaigns very lucrative. One method of note was the use of valid content delivery mechanisms to bypass IP allowlists. In the Windows samples, a compromised service would download the miner scripts from commonly-used, legitimate sites, such as GitHub or Netlify. This traffic is encrypted, meaning it could be missed by IDS/IPS systems, and the domains are unlikely to be blocked in most environments. Analysis of the wallets associated with the miners shows that these samples are active in the wild and are continuing to spread and mine for cryptocurrency. For more information, see the Red Canary blog post and report in the References section.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

CVEs
====

* A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/74055971/An%20Analysis%20of%20Monero%20Miner%20Variants%20And%20Techniques%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639153580962&api=v2)

Recommendations
===============

* Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
* Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
* Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
* Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040).

References
==========

* <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/l/vulnerabilities-exploited-for-monero-mining-malware-delivered-via-gitHub-netlify.html>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  

**Impact - TA0040**  
 T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Zerologon Exploit Live and In The Wild
A Windows vulnerability is being actively used in the wild on targets. Bleeping Computer reports on Zerologon and the available patch.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Exploit




# Overview

A vulnerability that results in the escalation of privilege in the Netlogon process is being used in the wild. CVE-2020-1472 was addressed as part of the August 2020 Patch Tuesday event. When exploited, attackers have the ability to elevate privileges to domain administrator and, effectively, take over a domain. A series of tweets from Microsoft confirms this exploit is being used and warns users to patch their systems immediately. According to Microsoft, "Microsoft is actively tracking threat actor activity using exploits for the CVE-2020-1472 Netlogon EoP vulnerability, dubbed Zerologon. We have observed attacks where public exploits have been incorporated into attacker playbooks." The tweets contained three samples used in the attack. The samples are written as .NET executables and can be found on VirusTotal. The attack will change the NTLM hash to 31d6cfe0d16ae931b73c59d7e0c089c0, an empty password. We urge users to apply the August 2020 patches as soon as possible to prevent this attack from occurring in vulnerable networks. IBM X-Force is actively tracking this threat in a related collection and further details can be found in the links located in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-1472




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/microsoft/microsoft-hackers-using-zerologon-exploits-in-attacks-patch-now/>

  * [https://twitter.com/MsftSecIntel/status/1308941504707063808](https://twitter\[.\]com/MsftSecIntel/status/1308941504707063808)
  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/microsoft/windows-zerologon-poc-exploits-allow-domain-takeover-patch-now/>
  * <https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/collection/Microsoft-Netlogon-Vulnerability-CVE-2020-1472-Potential-Exploit-974989e2263f1f3415c463388b84121a>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Android Infostealer PJobRAT Targets Indian Military Personnel
A report from 360 Fiberhome Lab provides an analysis of the Android infostealer, PJobRAT. It is believed PJobRAT was in a campaign targeting Indian users with military backgrounds.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Android




# Overview

The first development versions of PJobRAT surfaced sometime in late 2019. A 360 Fiberhome Lab report speculates that a campaign using PJobRAT and targeting Indian users with military backgrounds began in January 2019. PJobRAT arrives in a fake app which pretends to be an Indian dating app named Trendbanter. The method of the app's distribution is unclear but 360 Fiberhome Lab speculates that it may be distributed through military-related forums. PJobRAT searches for a number of different document types including doc, docx, pdf, ppt, ppt, xlsx, and xls. Files that are located are uploaded to a remote server using Firebase Cloud Messaging and HTTP. Other fake applications disguised as Signal, HangOn Messenger, and others, are reported to use the same server. PJobRAT can also upload a device's address book, audio, video, and image files, lists of installed apps and files stored externally, the Whatsapp contact list and messages, as well as WiFi and location information. 360 Fiberhome Lab has been unable to attribute the malware and campaign to any specific actor. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.360.cn/post/analysis-of-PJobRAT.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Sysrv-hello Infection Method
The Sysrv-hello botnet malware family has recently gone through a series of updates. Netlab 360 reports on the most recent update, which adds a new method of propagation.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, Cryptomining




# Overview

Netlab 360 has discovered a new variant of the Sysrv-hello botnet malware with an added propagation method. While Sysrv-hello can target both Linux and Windows systems, only the shell script file that targets Linux has been updated with this variant. Two additional modules will now be downloaded by the script, a Python program and an executable. The Python program iterates over files on an infected machine to identify web files. If discovered, an iframe that downloads the executable file is injected into the web file. This means visitors to websites being hosted on the victim server will be infected by this file. The researchers determined the executable is an XMRig coin miner that will abuse the victim host to mine Monero for profit. For more information, see the Netlab blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/threat-alert-new-update-from-sysrv-hello-now-infecting-victims-webpages-to-push-malicious-exe-to-end-users/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Sodinokibi Attack Analysis
Beginning in April 2019, one of the most prolific ransomware pieces, Sodinokibi, has been making a name for itself with high-profile attacks. Trend Micro provides an analysis of a typical Sodinokibi attack.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

A typical Sodinokibi attack begins with malspam emails, phishing emails containing attachments or links, RDP access using valid accounts, compromised websites, and exploits. With some campaigns, the use of CVE-2019-2725 was employed and the ransomware was loaded into the memory of PowerShell using reflective-load and not through binary execution. Other vulnerabilities (CVE-2018-13379 and CVE-2019-11510) were used as well as valid accounts. Threat actors were able to drop and execute anti-AV and exfiltration tools and Sodinokibi using these techniques. The ransomware uses RDP and PsExec for lateral movement. These are usually signs of targeted attacks and are also used to drop and execute the ransomware and various components. The threat actors use PC Hunter and Process Hacker to kill services and processes, focusing on antivirus services and processes in particular. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/a/sodinokibi-ransomware.html>

A typical Sodinokibi attack begins with malspam emails, phishing emails containing attachments or links, RDP access using valid accounts, compromised websites, and exploits. With some campaigns, the use of CVE-2019-2725 was employed and the ransomware was loaded into the memory of PowerShell using reflective-load and not through binary execution. Other vulnerabilities (CVE-2018-13379 and CVE-2019-11510) were used as well as valid accounts. Threat actors were able to drop and execute anti-AV and exfiltration tools and Sodinokibi using these techniques. The ransomware uses RDP and PsExec for lateral movement. These are usually signs of targeted attacks and are also used to drop and execute the ransomware and various components. The threat actors use PC Hunter and Process Hacker to kill services and processes, focusing on antivirus services and processes in particular. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/a/sodinokibi-ransomware.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Watering Hole Distributed macOS Malware
ESET has published an analysis of the exploit chain and malware used in watering hole attacks that may have targeted activists in Hong Kong.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Activists located in Hong Kong.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** DazzleSpy backdoor.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Watering hole exploiting Webkit vulnerability.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Privilege escalation, Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Multiple vulnerabilities in macOS were used in a watering hole attack that possibly targeted activists in Hong Kong. If a macOS user running version 10.15.2 or later visited the watering hole site, they would be directed to JavaScript code that exploited a WebKit vulnerability that allowed for code execution. Following successful exploitation, a Mach-O local privilege escalation vulnerability (CVE-2021-30869) was then exploited to provide root access. A backdoor named DazzleSpy was then installed. C&C communications were carried out using a custom JSON-based protocol and secured using base64 encoding, and TLS. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058041/Watering%20Hole%20Distributed%20macOS%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643761049766&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/01/25/watering-hole-deploys-new-macos-malware-dazzlespy-asia/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Molerats Campaign Targeting the Middle East
A Molerats campaign that began in February 2021 is the subject of a report from Proofpoint.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Molerats Campaign Targeting the Middle East
A Molerats campaign that began in February 2021 is the subject of a report from Proofpoint.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, etc... 




# Overview

Molerats, referred to by Proofpoint as TA402, is also known as the Gaza Cybergang. Molerats has been operating since 2011 and has primarily targeted government entities located in Israel, Palestine, and the wider Middle East. Molerats are believed to operate from the Middle East. The current campaign began sending spear-phishing emails, weekly, in February 2021 but beginning in March, ceased the sending of emails for two months before resuming in June. Proofpoint speculates the cessation of emails may be due to Ramadan or the situation between Gaza and Israel through that time period. The campaign is targeting organizations with diplomatic relationships and government entities in the Middle East. The spear-phishing emails sent by Molerats are usually written in Arabic and contain either links or an attached PDF file which is also written in Arabic. The theme of the emails and PDFs typically relate to geopolitical topics relating to the Middle East and in particular, the Gaza conflict. If the attached PDF is opened and macros are enabled, a passworded RAR file that contains an executable file will be dropped onto the system. In other cases, links to a Google Scripts file are used. In all cases, geofencing is used to make sure the victim is located in a region of interest. Users outside the regions of interest are directed to benign websites. The malware delivered in the campaign is referred to by Proofpoint as LastConn and is believed to be an updated version of the SharpStage malware. LastConn is used to carry out reconnaissance and exfiltrate data. Further details are available from the Proofpoint report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/new-ta402-molerats-malware-targets-governments-middle-east>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: SCADA Modbus Reconnaissance Increases
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has observed an increase in reconnaissance activity targeting the port associated with SCADA Modbus, highlighting an increasing threat to ICS-based networks.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Reconnaissance, Information Leakage




# Overview

IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence analysts have identified a persistent trend within our data that points to a very large increase in reconnaissance activity targeting port 502. This port is commonly used by Supervisory Controls and Data Acquisition (SCADA) Modbus, an application layer messaging protocol used to provide client/server communication between connected Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) devices in an industrial network. Between January and April of 2021, IBM observed a 1,600 percent increase in this activity compared to the total volume of reconnaissance activity for all of 2020. This trend highlights the increasing threat to ICS-based networks, and we encourage clients to review risk mitigations for securing SCADA Modbus. The full report, including mitigation advice, is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# CVEs

  * Associated CVEs can be found in the full report, available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/49ac3fb1-5414-4582-a5ab-1b0562be7a77>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: SideWinder Uses South Asian Issues for Spear Phishing and Mobile Attacks
SideWinder is an APT that targets the South Asia region, specifically government and military organizations. The group has been particularly active in 2020, and Trend Micro reports on several tactics they have observed in use by the group this year.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Backdoor




# Overview

Trend Micro has published a blog post analyzing recent SideWinder activities targeting Nepalese and Afghan government and military organizations. The first set of activity reported on is related to Windows backdoors being spread through various malicious document types. These include RTF files that exploit the CVE-2017-11882 vulnerability, LNK files, PDFs, Word Documents, and Zip archives. Regardless of the series of file types leveraged, all the infection chains lead to the execution of JavaScript code that drops a backdoor/stealer to the ProgramData folder, which will either be directly executed or run by a scheduled task. The backdoor uses DLL sideloading for execution of the malicious code. Once running on the system, it can perform its main function of downloading and executing a .NET executable, stealing system information and reporting it to the C2 server, and exfiltrating files. The second attack observed was a spear-phishing campaign. This campaign was discovered when the researchers identified subdomains on the servers hosting the aforementioned malicious documents that were mimicking mail servers associated with target organizations. Hosted on these domains were phishing pages that were based off of the legitimate version of the target organization's webmail login pages. After entering credentials, victims were redirected to either the legitimate webmail login page or to a document or website hosting news content regarding Covid-19 or South Asian territorial disputes. Also found on these servers were Android APK files. While some are benign applications that appear to be for testing, the themes indicate targeting of users in South Asia. Furthermore, applications developed using JavaPayload for Metasploit were observed. The applications load extra code from a remote server, however the researchers were unable to obtain this code at the time of investigation. Due to the lack of other components in this application, they believe the group is still developing these applications before use. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/l/sidewinder-leverages-south-asian-territorial-issues-for-spear-ph.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Delta Plus Ransomware
While investigating smaller ransomware actors, McAfee researchers uncovered an actor distributing a ransomware payload dubbed "Delta Plus."

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Delta Plus
  *  **RaaS Operation:** No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake application installers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Data Theft



# Overview

McAfee published a blog post analyzing the Delta Plus ransomware as a part of an investigation into small ransomware actors. The ransomware was discovered due to a hit on a Babuk payload signature. The reason it was detected as Babuk is because it was based on leaked Babuk source code. The Bitcoin address, actor email addresses, and ransomware name were edited for the actor's purpose, but the payload remained the same. McAfee notes that prior to leveraged leaked Babuk code, the actor attempted to write their own ransomware but it was simple and easy to analyze. Investigating domains contacted by the payload led to the discovery of an open directory containing additional tools, such as scripts for defense evasion and privilege escalation. Further pivoting on the network infrastructure led to what is likely the initial infection vector, fake Flash and AnyDesk installers, along with an exfiltration tool and other payloads. For more information, see the McAfee blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130649/Delta%20Plus%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634655653585&api=v2)

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Delta Plus Ransomware
While investigating smaller ransomware actors, McAfee researchers uncovered an actor distributing a ransomware payload dubbed "Delta Plus."
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Delta Plus
  *  **RaaS Operation:** No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake application installers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Data Theft



# Overview

McAfee published a blog post analyzing the Delta Plus ransomware as a part of an investigation into small ransomware actors. The ransomware was discovered due to a hit on a Babuk payload signature. The reason it was detected as Babuk is because it was based on leaked Babuk source code. The Bitcoin address, actor email addresses, and ransomware name were edited for the actor's purpose, but the payload remained the same. McAfee notes that prior to leveraged leaked Babuk code, the actor attempted to write their own ransomware but it was simple and easy to analyze. Investigating domains contacted by the payload led to the discovery of an open directory containing additional tools, such as scripts for defense evasion and privilege escalation. Further pivoting on the network infrastructure led to what is likely the initial infection vector, fake Flash and AnyDesk installers, along with an exfiltration tool and other payloads. For more information, see the McAfee blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130649/Delta%20Plus%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634655653585&api=v2)

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ICS-CERT Security Advisories - October 20th, 2020
The ICS-CERT has released two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in Rockwell Automation and Hitachi ABB Power Grids products.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  




ICSA-20-294-01 addresses three buffer overflow vulnerabilities in Rockwell Automation 1794-AENT Flex I/O Series B devices. These vulnerabilities exist in different device components but all could allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to cause a denial-of-service condition, if successfully exploited.

ICSA-20-294-02 addresses an improper authentication vulnerability in Hitachi ABB Power Grids XMC20 Multiservice-Multiplexer products that, if successfully exploited, could allow an attacker to remotely take control.

We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patches and mitigation advice.

# CVEs

A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32146239/ICS-CERT%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20October%2020th%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1603216501910&api=v2)

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-294-01>
  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-294-02>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Clop Ransomware Back with New Victim Data Leaked
Even as a series of arrests coordinated by various countries, the Clop ransomware gang appears to be back in business. Bleeping Computer has the latest on the resurrection of this group of threat actors.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

A joint effort between the National Police of Ukraine, the Korean National Police Agency, and the U.S. led to the arrest of members of the Clop ransomware gang. Those arrests led to the seizing of property, money, computer equipment, documents, and other high-end items such as cars. But with these arrests, the Clop ransomware gang is back in action after a brief hiatus. About a week after the arrests, new victim information was found on their ransomware data leak site, CLoP^-LEAKS. Authorities believe there were no arrests involving core actors behind the gang, thus allowing the group to continue operations. There is speculation that the unwanted law enforcement attention could lead to an abandonment or slowing of the group, as has been seen in other ransomware groups. The group has been operating since March 2019 and has used a variant of the CryptoMix ransomware. The gang gains a foothold into the victim network and spreads laterally while stealing documents and data. Once the data has been harvested, the ransomware encrypts the data on the victim hard drive. In its most recent reported attack, the gang stole data from Accellion FTA file transfer devices using a zero-day and demanded a $10+ million ransom. Victims of the attack included energy company Shell, cybersecurity firm Qualys, Flagstar Bank, the University of Miami, and the University of California. Ukrainian police estimate damages to be in the range of $500 million total. More information can be found in the post located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

  * Perform regular backups to critical infrastructure and data.
  * Store backups offsite of offline.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/clop-ransomware-is-back-in-business-after-recent-arrests/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: PHP Malware Reinfecting Files
A PHP malware family is reinfecting cleaned files using a malicious process running on a web server. Sucuri details how this attack works in a blog post.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware 




# Overview

Using a malicious process implanted on a web server, threat actors are able to use PHP to reinfect cleaned files. Initially, the malware attempts to lock infected files, thus preventing owners from cleaning them. The tool is capable of locking files, modifying locked files, and divulging phpinfo and php_version. The functions execute specific actions and handle the creation and processing of background files. The attacker submits an HTTP request with a specific parameter to the PHP script thereby spawning the exec function. This allows the exec function to execute a shell command through PHP. The attacker can then use another function to create malicious background processes. This command, nohup, allows the process to continually run and bypasses limitations in the php.ini file from killing the process. Upon execution, the malicious php file is deleted automatically to prevent detection. The only way left to detect the malware is through the viewing of running processes. The background malware process reduces the timestamp of the file by 400 days in order to make it more difficult to conduct log auditing. Further details can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/09/the-hidden-php-malware-that-reinfects-cleaned-files.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: GOLDBACKDOOR Discovered in Spear-Phishing Campaign
Stairwell, a cybersecurity company, has released details of malware they discovered from a spear-phishing campaign. The NK News has shared multiple malicious artifacts with them from the campaign that targeted journalists who specialize in reporting focused on the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea). They have named one of the artifacts, which is a new malware sample, as GOLDBACKDOOR.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Journalists who specialize in the DPRK
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** BLUELIGHT, GOLDBACKDOOR
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote Command Execution, File Downloading, File Uploading, Keylogging
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

NK News, an organization that focuses on news regarding North Korea, was targeted in a spear-phishing campaign believed to originate from APT37 which is known for targeting journalists. The attackers had gained prior access to an email account of a former director at South Korea's National Intelligence Service (NIS) and had utilized content from past conversations with NK News founder Chad O'Carroll. The attack deployed a backdoor. Artifacts of the malware were provided to the cybersecurity company Stairwell by NK News. Embedded in the backdoor are a set of API keys used with the Microsoft Azure cloud computing service. Stairwell has named the backdoor GOLDBACKDOOR. The key focus of the backdoor is on exfiltrating data with file collection and keylogging. For more detailed information, please see the report in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://stairwell.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Stairwell-threat-report-The-ink-stained-trail-of-GOLDBACKDOOR.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

#### Tactics and Techniques:

  
 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
T1591.002 - Business Relationships  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1585 - Establish Accounts  
T1585.002 - Email Accounts  
T1586 - Compromise Accounts  
T1586.002 - Email Accounts  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1078.004 - Cloud Accounts  
T1199 - Trusted Relationship  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.002 - Bidirectional Communication  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
GOLDBACKDOOR Discovered in Spear-Phishing Campaign
Stairwell, a cybersecurity company, has released details of malware they discovered from a spear-phishing campaign. The NK News has shared multiple malicious artifacts with them from the campaign that targeted journalists who specialize in reporting focused on the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea). They have named one of the artifacts, which is a new malware sample, as GOLDBACKDOOR.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Journalists who specialize in the DPRK
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** BLUELIGHT, GOLDBACKDOOR
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote Command Execution, File Downloading, File Uploading, Keylogging
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

NK News, an organization that focuses on news regarding North Korea, was targeted in a spear-phishing campaign believed to originate from APT37 which is known for targeting journalists. The attackers had gained prior access to an email account of a former director at South Korea's National Intelligence Service (NIS) and had utilized content from past conversations with NK News founder Chad O'Carroll. The attack deployed a backdoor. Artifacts of the malware were provided to the cybersecurity company Stairwell by NK News. Embedded in the backdoor are a set of API keys used with the Microsoft Azure cloud computing service. Stairwell has named the backdoor GOLDBACKDOOR. The key focus of the backdoor is on exfiltrating data with file collection and keylogging. For more detailed information, please see the report in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: REvil Group is Back
The REvil ransomware gang is back after a 2-month hiatus following its self-imposed shut down after the July 4th Kaseya attacks reports news outlets.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware Group




# Overview

A mere 2 months after a self-imposed shutdown, REvil is back on the ransomware scene and already wreaking havoc. According to its Happy Blog, the group has resumed attacking organizations and leaking exfiltrated data on the Dark Web. The group has reactivated its Tor payment/negotiation and data leak sites. According to Bleeping Computer, all victims previously attacked had their payment timers reset in order to pay the ransom or risk the sensitive data being leaked. The group has published screenshots of new victim data on its data leak site. Over the past year, the group has attacked at least 360 US-based organizations according to Emsisoft threat analyst Brett Callow. The group claimed, in a chat between what is believed to be a security researcher and a representative of the group, they simply took a break. The previous "leader" of REvil, "UNKN" or "UNK", has disappeared, according to the operator during the chat session. With the group being back in action, some of the victims previously attacked have a chance to get their data back after a leaked decryptor was found to be ineffective. For more information, please see the links located within the Reference section and the MITRE ATT&CK framework below.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zdnet.com/article/revil-ransomware-group-resurfaces-after-brief-hiatus/>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/revil-ransomware-is-back-in-full-attack-mode-and-leaking-data/>

 **Execution - TA0002**

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
T1134.001 - Token Impersonation/Theft  
T1134.002 - Create Process with Token  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1069 - Permission Groups Discovery  
T1069.002 - Domain Groups  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1489 - Service Stop  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Android Surveillanceware, Hornbill and SunBird Released by Pro-India APT Named Confucius
New Android surveillanceware has been discovered by the Lookout Threat Intelligence team. It is targeting Pakistani users in an effort to ex-filtrate data and audio communications recordings. Domains used in the campaign point to the campaign being carried out by APT group, Confucius.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Data Theft, RAT, APT




# Overview

The Lookout Threat Intelligence team has discovered two new android malware packages they named Hornbill and SunBird. Both have the purpose of ex-filtrating data, which includes data and audio recordings of communications, from the android device. The Lookout team analyzed over 18GB of ex-filtrated data which revealed locations of the infected devices. Notable targets included individuals in the Pakistani military and government. It is believed the advanced persistent threat group (APT) Confucius is behind the campaign. Confucius has been known to to be pro-India actor pursuing Pakistani and other South Asian targets since 2013. The group has been known to name their malicious apps similar to legitimate phone chat apps. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Do not install phone applications from unofficial app stores.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.lookout.com/lookout-discovers-novel-confucius-apt-android-spyware-linked-to-india-pakistan-conflict>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Malicious CHM Files Used to Target Korean Users
Ahnlab's ASEC team has published a report that provides an analysis of Windows Help Files (.chm) that are being used to distribute malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Malicious CHM Files Used to Target Korean Users
Ahnlab's ASEC team has published a report that provides an analysis of Windows Help Files (.chm) that are being used to distribute malware.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Korean users
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious .chm files.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Deployment of unspecified payloads.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Windows Help Files (.chm) are being used to target Korean users, according to a report from Ahnlab's ASEC team. While the delivery mechanism is not stated, the victim receives an archive file that contains multiple files, and in some cases an additional archive file. Some of the files within the archive are benign but the .chm files contain malicious code that results in the creation of a file that when executed uses PowerShell to download additional files. Persistence is achieved by creating an LNK file which is then executed on startup by a registry run key. The payloads that would be downloaded were not able to be obtained. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/34313/>

T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  


 **Mitigations:**

####  **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.
