  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Trojanized Installer
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Avast researchers have come across a version of the infostealer named Racoon Stealer that uses Telegram infrastructure to store and update the C2 address. This password stealer comes in many forms and is able to steal passwords from browsers, email clients, and crypto-wallets. It can also download and execute files sent from the C2 server. This stealer is distributed either by downloaders or through fake game hacks and mods. Once executed, the malware checks the user's location and will not execute if the victim is in Russia or some eastern European countries. The URLs for the telegram gates are hardcoded and are encrypted with a hardcoded key. This URL is contacted to retrieve the real C2 server address which is encoded in Base64 and decrypted using another hardcoded key. The makers of this malware are native Russian speakers, as they communicate in Russian on forums, and the exclusion of former USSR countries built into the malware. The researchers identified over 25,000 samples related to Racoon stealer over the last year. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Raccoon Stealer Using Telegram for C2 Updates IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/82641051/Raccoon%20Stealer%20Using%20Telegram%20for%20C2%20Updates%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1647267028217&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/vladimirmartyanov/raccoon-stealer-trash-panda-abuses-telegram/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
T1614.001 - System Language Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1568 - Dynamic Resolution  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Android  Credential Stealer - ERMAC
Cyble Research Labs has published a report on a new variant of the credential-stealing Android malware, ERMAC 2.0.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Android Malware
  *  **Targets:** Users of 467 various Android apps.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** ERMAC
  *  **Initial Infection Vector: Fake app.**
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential stealing.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

ERMAC is credential-stealing malware for Android devices. Version 1.0 of ERMAC was discovered in August 2021 with the actor behind ERMAC renting it out for $3,000 per month with version 2.0 becoming available around March 2022, now being rented for $5,000 per month. Cyble Research Labs have published a report of their analysis of ERMAC 2.0 which has increased the number of applications it targets from 378 in version 1.0 to 467 in 2.0. ERMAC is installed through third-party sites. In Cyble's analysis, it was found on fake sites impersonating a Polish food delivery platform. A link to download what is purported to be the legitimate site's app is provided. It has also been observed masquerading as browser updates. The fake app seeks 43 different permissions when installed. Once installed, it sends a list of the applications installed on the infected device to its C&C servers. The C&C server responds with a list of targeted applications and an encrypted HTML phishing page ERMAC will use to carry out overlay injections. When the victim interacts with a targeted application, the overlay injection is used to obtain the victim's credentials which are then sent to the C&C server. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/05/25/ermac-back-in-action/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
T1406 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0031**  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
  
 **Discovery - TA0032**  
T1421 - System Network Connections Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1432 - Access Contact List  
T1507 - Network Information Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel

 **Mitigations:**

 **M1001:** Security Updates -Install security updates in response to discovered vulnerabilities. Purchase devices with a vendor and/or mobile carrier commitment to provide security updates in a prompt manner for a set period of time. Decommission devices that will no longer receive security updates. Limit or block access to enterprise resources from devices that have not installed recent security updates. On Android devices, access can be controlled based on each device's security patch level. On iOS devices, access can be controlled based on the iOS version.  
 **M1005:** Application Vetting - Enterprises can vet applications for exploitable vulnerabilities or unwanted (privacy-invasive or malicious) behaviors. Enterprises can inspect applications themselves or use a third-party service. Enterprises may impose policies to only allow pre-approved applications to be installed on their devices or may impose policies to block use of specific applications known to have issues. In Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) environments, enterprises may only be able to impose these policies over an enterprise-managed portion of the device. Application Vetting is not a complete mitigation. Techniques such as Evade Analysis Environment exist that can enable adversaries to bypass vetting.  
 **M1006:** Use Recent OS Version - New mobile operating system versions bring not only patches against discovered vulnerabilities but also often bring security architecture improvements that provide resilience against potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses that have not yet been discovered. They may also bring improvements that block use of observed adversary techniques.  
 **M1011:** User Guidance - Describes any guidance or training given to users to set particular configuration settings or avoid specific potentially risky behaviors.  
 **M1012:** Enterprise Policy - An enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM), system can be used to provision policies to mobile devices to control aspects of their allowed behavior.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Phorphiex Botnet
A report from Microsoft looks into the Phorphiex botnet and provides some insights into the more recent evolution of Phorphiex.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Botnet, Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Originally discovered in 2010, the Phorphiex botnet remains active and has evolved through the years. A report from Microsoft provides information on the more recent changes to Phorphiex's TTPs and a shift to a more global distribution. Microsoft reports that while Phorphiex historically targeted Japan, it is now more global in its targeting and has been observed in 160 countries. One of the more significant changes is a move from static domains used for hosting C&C servers, to favoring DGA (Domain Generation Algorithm) hostnames, and IP addresses. Phorphiex's more traditional activities were spam and extortion but, in recent years has also been used to install cryptominers and deliver ransomware such as Avaddon, BitRansomware, GandCrab, Knot, Nemty, and Pony, as well as other assorted malware. The distribution methods used to propagate Phorphiex have over the years included being installed by other malware, phishing emails, and worm techniques using instant messaging and USB drives. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/05/20/phorpiex-morphs-how-a-longstanding-botnet-persists-and-thrives-in-the-current-threat-environment/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Povlsomware Ransomware
Povlsomware markets itself as a proof-of-concept (POC) ransomware designed to test security vendor products. Trend Micro reports on some interesting capabilities associated with the malware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing the Povlsomware ransomware. This ransomware is open-source, hosted on GitHub, and advertises itself as a proof-of-concept (POC) designed to test security vendor products. It operates much like most ransomware families, deleting backups, encrypting user files while avoiding system directories, and displaying a ransom note to the victim. Interestingly, the ransomware does not append a new extension to the encrypted file names, so the files do not look different when viewed in a directory. One of the most significant features of this ransomware that the researchers note is particularly concerning is its compatibility with Cobalt Strike. Specifically, it is capable of being executed by Cobalt Strike's execute-assembly function, which allows a payload to be run through memory from a Cobalt Strike server without dropping a payload onto the victim system. This decreases the chances of detection and analysis. Due to its purpose as a POC tool, the code does not include any capabilities to spread across a network or destroy devices, but its open-source nature could allow a malicious actor to add that functionality. While there is no evidence of this ransomware being used in the wild by malicious threat actors, its public availability presents the threat of such activity. For more information, see the Trend Micro article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/c/povlsomware-ransomware-features-cobalt-strike-compatibility.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: FontOnLake is New Sophisticated and Stealthy Malware
ESET researchers have analyzed a new sophisticated malware being used on targets in Southeast Asia. They have named this malware FontOnLake, and it was first seen in 2020.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Southeast Asia
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** FontOnLake
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

ESET researchers have discovered a new piece of sophisticated malware that was first observed in the May of 2020. This malware utilized custom modules and targets Linux systems. It has been named FontOnLake and is being continually developed and includes functionality such as remote access and credential harvesting. Every instance of infection of FontOnLake has been accompanied by a rootkit which serves to conceal its presence. The malware also uses patched legitimate binaries such as the Linux 'cat' command, which are used to load components. The researchers theorized that this malware is only being used in targeted attacks because of the advanced design and low prevalence. FontOnLake consists of three main parts - trojanized applications, backdoors, and rootkits. The trojans are used to load the backdoors and rootkits and are also able to collect sensitive data. Three backdoors have been seen used in FontOnLake infections, and perform functions such as exfiltration, file manipulation, serving as a proxy, and executing shell commands and python scripts. Finally, the rootkit can conceal this behavior by hiding processes and files and hiding network connections, whilst also downloading and executing more malware. The samples of this malware seen in the wild, and the C2 server locations suggest that this malware is being used to target victims in Southeast Asia. All samples used unique C2 infrastructure with varying non-standard ports, which have been taken offline since being uploaded to VirusTotal. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129960/FontOnLake%20is%20New%20Sophisticated%20and%20Stealthy%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633957567540&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/10/07/fontonlake-previously-unknown-malware-family-targeting-linux/>
  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/eset_fontonlake.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
T1059.006 - Python  
T1106 - Native API  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts  
T1554 - Compromise Client Software Binary  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1222.002 - Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
T1564.001 - Hidden Files and Directories  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1556 - Modify Authentication Process  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021.004 - SSH  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1008 - Fallback Channels  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1071.002 - File Transfer Protocols  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1132.001 - Standard Encoding  
T1568 - Dynamic Resolution  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Custom PowerShell RAT Targeting Germany in New Campaign
Malwarebytes Labs has published a report on a new campaign targeting Germans seeking information about the Ukraine crisis. The final payload of this campaign is a custom PowerShell RAT.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Custom PowerShell RAT Targeting Germany in New Campaign
Malwarebytes Labs has published a report on a new campaign targeting Germans seeking information about the Ukraine crisis. The final payload of this campaign is a custom PowerShell RAT.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Remote Access Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unnamed PowerShell RAT
  *  **Targets:** German Citizens
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Site
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Malwarebytes Labs has analyzed a new custom PowerShell RAT being used to target German citizens. The attack starts on an expired Germain domain that was a legitimate collaboration platform. The attackers registered this domain and used it to host a fake version of the local government site. The site encourages the user to download a file that claims to contain information on the war in Ukraine but is really a Microsoft HTML help file. Upon execution, the users will receive an error message, but a Base64 encoded PowerShell command is executed in the background. It downloads two files which are executed as the final payload, which is the PowerShell RAT. This RAT can download and upload files, execute PowerShell scripts, and execute commands. The C2 domain is another Germain domain to avoid suspicion. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/05/custom-powershell-rat-targets-germans-seeking-information-about-the-ukraine-crisis/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Emotet Aided by Trickbot
A report from Qualys provides a brief analysis of a current version of Emotet and notes that its distribution is being aided by Trickbot.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Emotet, Trickbot
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malspam and Phishing emails.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Emotet has a storied history since it first appeared in 2016 to its takedown last year when it disappeared from the landscape for some ten months. It returned in November last year when it was observed being used in a phishing campaign. Qualys is reporting that its distribution is being aided by Trickbot. The Qualys report notes some of the changes in a current version of Emotet, the most notable of which is a change from RSA to Elliptic Curve Cryptography. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056792/Emotet%20Aided%20by%20Trickbot%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641880229737&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017)



# References

  * <https://blog.qualys.com/vulnerabilities-threat-research/2022/01/06/emotet-re-emerges-with-help-from-trickbot>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1087.003 - Email Account  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.004 - Credential API Hooking  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Romanian Gas Station Network Hit by Ransomware
Bleeping Computer has published an article detailing a ransomware attack against Romania's petroleum provider, Rompetrol. The attack has halted gas station service throughout the country.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Romanian Gas Station Network Hit by Ransomware
Bleeping Computer has published an article detailing a ransomware attack against Romania's petroleum provider, Rompetrol. The attack has halted gas station service throughout the country.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

A ransomware attack against Romania's petroleum provider has crippled the country's Fill&Go service and websites. Bleeping Computer states the actors behind the attack are the Hive ransomware gang. This is unconfirmed however, the ransom note left on the network is indicative of Hive activity. Hive has asked for a multi-million dollar ransom be paid in exchange for restoration of the affected network and petroleum stations. The company still has access to its email network as of today (3/7/22). The parent company of Rompetrol, KMG International, has already informed the Romanian National Directorate of Cyber Security (DNSC) of the attack. "To protect the data, the company has temporarily suspended the operation of the websites and the Fill&Go service, both for the fleets and for the private customers," states the petroleum provider. The provider goes on to state that activity at Rompetrol stations is carried out normally by paying with cash or bank card. Hive is believed to be responsible for an average of three breaches of companies per day since June 2021. It has since been learned that a $2M ransom has been demanded in exchange for a decryptor and a promise not to leak allegedly stolen data, says Bleeping Computer. Further details will be provided as they come in. The associated article is located below in the Reference section. 

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/rompetrol-gas-station-network-hit-by-hive-ransomware/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Bitcoin Mining Threats
Cryptocurrency is gaining ground as a legitimate currency. Bitcoin, the most popular cryptocurrency, and others are under attack from various mining malware. SeqRite analysts have provided information on some of the most prevalent miners seen.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Cryptojacking




# Overview

Numbering 2.5 million attacks in 2020, cryptojacking malware has become some of the more common forms of attack in the cyber world due to the potential for financial gain. Some of the most common cryptojacking malwares are Kings Miner, Blue Mockingbird, and Lemon Duck Miner. Kings Miner saw its peak in March 2020 attacking Windows-based servers, removing competing malware families and securing the backdoor through which the attacker entered. Blue Mockingbird launched a campaign against millions of servers in India. The malware used in the attack is a multi-component malware which, in turn, delivered cryptocurrency malware. Lemon Duck Miner, first identified in 2019, is written in Python and utilizes code from various open-source projects. It showed an increase in infections in 2020. The malware spreads rapidly and uses the resources of infected machines to mine cryptocurrency. Cryptocurrency miners are different from ransomware in that the infected machines are used for their resources to mine cryptocurrency which can cause slow running systems, crashes, and productivity issues. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.seqrite.com/blog/cryptocurrency-malware-bitcoin-mining-threats-you-need-to-know-about/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: BazarLoader and Cobalt Strike Leading to Conti Ransomware
An article from the DFIR Report provides an analysis of a ransomware attack that began with a spearphishing email and ended with domain-connected hosts having their files encrypted.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Ransomware Family:** Conti
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransom Demand:** Unspecified
  *  **Intrusion Vector:** Spearphishing, Maldoc in an attached ZIP file.
  *  **Data Exfiltrated:** Yes
  *  **Data Encrypted:** Yes
  *  **Data Published:** Unknown
  *  **Additional TTPs: **See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A ransomware attack that occurred in August is the subject of an analysis from the DFIR Report. The attack likely began with a spearphishing email that had a password-protected ZIP file attached. The ZIP file contained a malicious document that, when opened, extracted and executed a malicious .HTA file that, in turn, downloaded a BazarLoader DLL which was then loaded into memory. Within two hours of the compromise, the attackers were manually gathering information about the environment. During the second day of the compromise, the attackers used RDP to access the backup server. In all, they spent four days carrying out their reconnaissance and using Rclone exfiltrated data of interest to the Mega file-sharing site. On the fifth day, the backup server was used to deploy the Conti ransomware using a batch script that mounted the C$ dir of each host to be encrypted and drop the ransom note in each directory in which files were encrypted. Unusually, the attackers do not appear to have interacted with the Domain Controllers which would be the typical hosts used to deploy ransomware domain-wide. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155475/BazarLoader%20and%20Cobalt%20Strike%20Leading%20to%20Conti%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638539328791&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2021/11/29/continuing-the-bazar-ransomware-story/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information  
T1590.005 - IP Addresses  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.005 - Mshta  
T1218.010 - Regsvr32  
T1218.011 - Rundll32  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1087.001 - Local Account  
T1087.002 - Domain Account  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.001 - Remote Desktop Protocol  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
T1567.002 - Exfiltration to Cloud Storage  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155475/BazarLoader%20and%20Cobalt%20Strike%20Leading%20to%20Conti%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638539328791&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2021/11/29/continuing-the-bazar-ransomware-story/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information  
T1590.005 - IP Addresses  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.005 - Mshta  
T1218.010 - Regsvr32  
T1218.011 - Rundll32  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1087.001 - Local Account  
T1087.002 - Domain Account  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.001 - Remote Desktop Protocol  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
T1567.002 - Exfiltration to Cloud Storage  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Attacks on Industrial Enterprises Using RMS and TeamViewer
Expanding on their previous research into the use of RMS and TeamViewer in attacks on industrial enterprises, Kaspersky reports on the changes in techniques employed by the threat actors.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Kaspersky has published a blog post analyzing changes in the campaigns abusing RMS and TeamViewer that they previously reported on. This activity has been occuring from 2018 until at least early fall 2020 with all the attacks starting with a phishing email. This phishing email is customized to the recipient in terms of the content of the body of the email and filenames, but the attackers have pivoted from using custom domain names to instead using public email services. Attached to these emails is a password-protected RAR archive containiing several malicious obfuscated JS scripts masquerading as normal documents. Executing one of these scripts opens a malicious program and a legitimate PDF file. The legitimate PDF file appears to be real documents stolen from previous attacks. While this document is distracting the user, a modified version of TeamViewer with a hidden GUI is installed. Previously, at this point the TeamViewer ID was sent to an attacker-controlled C2 server. However, they are now using legitimate RMS remote administration infrastructure to transport this information using its email notification functionality. Kaspersky notes that the RMS developers have implemented code to prevent this abuse in future. With TeamViewer access established, the attackers are granted full control over the system, which they have used to install spyware and Mimikatz in order to obtain credentials for lateral movement and eventually carry out their ultimate goal of stealing funds from financial software on the network. For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/attacks-on-industrial-enterprises-using-rms-and-teamviewer-new-data/99206/>  
<https://securelist.com/attacks-on-industrial-enterprises-using-rms-and-teamviewer/87104/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: LinkedIn Private Shared Document Phishing Email
While secure messaging phishes are not new, an attempt to use a fake LinkedIn-branded secure message is. JB Bowers provides his findings on this phishing campaign in a recent SANS ISC diary entry.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Researcher JB Bowers has published an analysis of a LinkedIn Secure Messaging phishing lure. Interestingly, no such platform actually exists. The LinkedIn message claims that the recipient has been sent a "LinkedIn Private Shared Document" and a link within the message directs them to view a PDF that contains a link. Clicking the link leads to a well-built fake LinkedIn login page. Entering credentials leads to the data being exfiltrated to the campaign operator. All of the discovered phishing sites leverage legitimate cloud hosting services, such as AppSpot, Firebase, and Pantheon, making it difficult to block. With LinkedIn credentials, attackers may be able to carry out further social engineering campaigns against the victim's connections. For more information, see the SANS ISC diary in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/forums/diary/The+new+LinkedInSecureMessage/27110/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Message Quarantine Campaign with Overlay Technique
A phishing campaign leveraging a message quarantine theme has been spotted by Cofense. The researchers highlight the use of an overlay technique on the phishing landing page.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Message Quarantine Campaign with Overlay Technique
A phishing campaign leveraging a message quarantine theme has been spotted by Cofense. The researchers highlight the use of an overlay technique on the phishing landing page.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense researchers have published their analysis of a recent phishing email and associated landing page. The initial email leverages a message quarantine theme. It spoofs the victim company's help desk and claims that the recipient has emails that need to be validated via a provided link prior to receiving. If a user falls victim to this lure, they are directed to a phishing site. The site's background is a copy of the victim company's legitimate website. Overlayed on the page is an input box claiming your login timed out and requests you re-enter your password. Parameters in the link from the email are used to identify the recipient email address. This address is in turn auto-filled into the overlay and used to determine the background image that should be displayed. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/message-quarantine-campaign-overlying-potential/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Fake Office 365 Used for Phishing Attacks on C-Suite Targets
A phishing campaign targeting executives at companies in a number of regions and industries is being tracked by Trend Micro.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign targeting executives at a variety of organizations. The phishing emails, in most cases, are sent via an RDP service hosted by FireVPS. The body of the email directs a user to click a link in order to prevent their Office365 password from changing. The link leads to a compromised site hosting an Office 365 phishing kit. The URLs used for the phishing kit follow a similar pattern. The phishing kit logs any entered credentials to be retrieved by the attackers. The researchers identified a few phishing kits that were misconfigured, allowing them to view the content of the log files, which included potential attribution information regarding the developer of the phishing kit. Investigating the phishing kit developer, they discovered the kit being advertised and sold on Facebook with the earliest version being released in July 2019. During the course of their research, they also identified credentials of C-level users being sold on both English- and Russian-speaking forums. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/a/fake-office-365-used-for-phishing-attacks-on-c-suite-targets.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories February 16 2021
ICS-CERT has published three advisories that affect Hamilton-T1, Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK, and Rockwell Automation Allen-Bradley Micrologix 1100.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ICS-CERT Advisories February 16 2021
ICS-CERT has published three advisories that affect Hamilton-T1, Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK, and Rockwell Automation Allen-Bradley Micrologix 1100.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.

 **ICS Medical Advisory ICSMA-21-047-01 - Hamilton-T1**  
CVE-2020-27278 - Hard-Coded credentials in the ventilator allow attackers with physical access to obtain admin privileges for the device’s configuration interface.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 3.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:P/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:N).

CVE-2020-27282 - An XML validation vulnerability in the ventilator allows privileged attackers with physical access to render the device persistently unusable by uploading specially crafted configuration files.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:P/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).

CVE-2020-27290 - An information disclosure vulnerability in the ventilator allows attackers with physical access to the configuration interface's logs to get valid checksums for tampered configuration files.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 2.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:P/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsma-21-047-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-047-01 - Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK**  
CVE-2021-25178 - The affected product is vulnerable to a stack-based buffer overflow while processing malformed DXF and DWG files. This could allow an attacker to execute code or cause a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25177 - A type confusion issue exists when rendering malformed DXF and DWG files. This could allow an attacker to execute code or cause a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25176 - A NULL pointer dereference exists when rendering malformed DXF and DWG files. This could allow an attacker to execute code or cause a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25175 - A type conversion issue exists when rendering malformed DXF and DWG files. This could allow an attacker to execute code or cause a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25174 - A memory corruption issue exists when reading malformed DGN files. This could allow an attacker to execute code or cause a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-25173 - A memory allocation with excessive size issue exists when reading malformed DGN files. This could allow an attacker to execute code or cause a denial-of-service condition.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H)  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-047-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-047-02 - Rockwell Automation Allen-Bradley Micrologix 1100**  
CVE-2020-6111 - A vulnerability exists with the processing of ICMP packets with an invalid IPv4 length in the MicroLogix 1100. This vulnerability could allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to send malformed packets and cause the controller to enter 8H Hard Fault. This event would lead to denial-of-service conditions. To recover from the condition, the controller must be power cycled and the project redownloaded.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-047-02>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/40993499/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20February%2016%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1613527393989&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

ICS-CERT has published three advisories that affect Hamilton-T1, Open Design Alliance Drawings SDK, and Rockwell Automation Allen-Bradley Micrologix 1100.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: North Carolina College Hit with Ransomware Attack
Breach/Leak Notification: A community college in North Carolina was hit with a ransomware attack on September 13, 2020. Databreaches.net details the attack in a blog post.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Breach, Ransomware




# Overview

  
"A North Carolina-based community college suffered a ransomware attack on September 13, 2020. The attack rendered the campus unable to conduct in-person classes until September 21, 2020. According to a spokesperson, "On Sunday, Sept. 13, 2020, GTCC had an unauthorized access to the college network. Campuses were shut down for Monday, Sept. 14, 2020 to limit the extent of the unauthorized access and determine its impact." The information stolen from the college has appeared on DoppelPaymer's leak site. For more information, please see the blog located within the Reference section below."

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.databreaches.net/nc-guilford-technical-community-college-hit-with-ransomware/>

Campuses were shut down for Monday, Sept. 14, 2020 to limit the extent of the unauthorized access and determine its impact." The information stolen from the college has appeared on DoppelPaymer's leak site. For more information, please see the blog located within the Reference section below."

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.databreaches.net/nc-guilford-technical-community-college-hit-with-ransomware/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Operation North Star Analysis
McAfee researchers have published a report on Operation North Star. The report provides a unique insight into the inner workings of a major cyber espionage campaign.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Cyber Espionage




# Overview

A rare opportunity provided researchers with McAfee to see the inner workings of a major cyber espionage campaign. Using social media sites, spear-phishing, and infected documents, employees of the defense sector were targeted. Initially, there were many gaps in the analysis, however, a deeper look into the threat actor's infrastructure provided more information on their motives, tactics, techniques, and procedures. The group responsible used compromised domains, primarily in Italy, for its C2 hosting. The compromised domains included an apparel company, an auction house, and a printing company. These servers were used to host the backend server code and malicious DOTM files. Some of the hosted documents impersonated a defense contractors job profiles and other files included some rudimentary code used by the implant named Torisma. The fist stage contains an encrypted configuration file and an intermediate dropper DLL. Additionally, it also contains decryption keys for the second stage Torisma payload. Options in the backend components indicate how long the implant has been active. The first stage implant gathers information from the victim's system such as disk information, free disk space, computer name, username, and process information. Server-side ASP code was used to create a binary stream to the location it is suspected the Torisma implant was written. Additional code is used to compare the victim IP address to a list of allowed IP addresses. The second stage is downloaded if the IP address is on the allowed list. Logging is handled on the server-side by ASP code. The end goal of the payload is to execute custom shellcode. The Torisma payload is also encrypted and contains a configuration file used for C2 communication. This payload is used to monitor for remote desktop connections and new drives. The monitoring routine runs in a loop and performs several functions. C2 communication is done via custom configuration. The campaign itself is identified through campaign IDs kept by the adversary. Further technical details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



Reference

  * <https://www.mcafee.com/blogs/other-blogs/mcafee-labs/operation-north-star-behind-the-scenes/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malicious Redirects via Bogus WordPress Plugin
While investigating a series of WordPress sites performing malicious redirects, Sucuri researchers discovered a redirector and webshell installed the compromised sites.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, Webshell




# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing a campaign infecting compromised WordPress sites with two payloads, a redirector, and a webshell. The infection begins with the attackers compromising the wp-admin administration panel, likely via weak passwords. Once on the system, they install their malware via the plugin upload feature. The first plugin is a redirector, masquerading as "PHP Everywhere," that sends visitors of the site to malicious domains. These domains stood out due to their use of punycode characters. The second plugin installed is a backdoored version of the Log HTTP Requests plugin. The modified version includes the addition of FilesMan webshell code, providing attackers with full control of the file system. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/06/malicious-redirects-through-bogus-plugin.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The Anatomy of a Ryuk Ransomware Attack
A report from Sophos provides an analysis of a recent attempt by the Ryuk operators to infect a company's systems with ransomware. The attack began with a number of employees in the targeted company receiving tightly targeted spear-phishing emails.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ryuk, Ransomware




# Overview

A ransomware attack that began with employees of a company receiving tightly targeted spear-phishing emails was investigated by Sophos. It took less than three and a half hours after one of the employees opened the attachment in the spear-phishing email for the attackers to begin performing reconnaissance of the company's network. The attackers obtained administrative credentials, connected to the domain controller, and began the initial staging of the ransomware deployment within the first day. Within two days, the attackers began to deploy the Ryuk ransomware; backup servers were among the first targets. While ransom notes were dropped onto the systems, no files were actually encrypted as Ryuk was unable to execute properly. The attackers continued to try launching Ryuk for at least another week. The tools used in the attack include the Buer loader, Bloodhound, Cobalt Strike, GMER, the SystemBC SOCKS5 proxy, as well as Windows scripting and administration tools. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2020/10/14/inside-a-new-ryuk-ransomware-attack/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: WinDealer Malware used by LuoYu Threat Group
LuoYu is a threat group that has been active since 2014 and targets Korean and Japanese organizations. JPCERT/CC uncovered a backdoor named WinDealer being leveraged by this group.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** LuoYu
  *  **Associated Payloads:** WinDealer
  *  **Targets:** Korean and Japanese organizations
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft, remote command execution 



# Overview

JPCERT/CC published their analysis of the WinDealer malware, a payload being used by the LuoYu threat group in attacks against Korean and Japanese organizations. WinDealer begins by creating configurations files that it will read to determine its C2 address and other information. Additionally, a DLL module is loaded into memory to carry out the malicious functionality. It steals various data and files from the host system and saves the information to the %TEMP% folder. When WinDealer observes a new file in this folder, it is encrypted and exfiltrated to the C2 server. The malware is also capable of receiving various commands from its C2. These commands include executing a remote shell, performing screen captures, and gathering system information. The results of the command are returned to the C2 server. For more information, see the JPCERT/CC blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616715/WinDealer%20Malware%20used%20by%20LuoYu%20Threat%20Group%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635262671172&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blogs.jpcert.or.jp/en/2021/10/windealer.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1106 - Native API  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TeamTNT Upgrades Arsenal to Target Kubernetes and GPU Environments
A blog post from Trend Micro provides an analysis of recent TeamTNT payloads compared to those seen in previous campaigns.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptominer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TeamTNT
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Malicious scripts, cryptominer
  *  **Targets:** Kubernetes servers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exposed Kubernetes APIs
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing new TeamTNT payload samples and detailing recent targeting by the group. As the number of exposed Docker APIs are beginning to decrease while the number of exposed Kubernetes has been increasing, the threat actor has shifted their focus to Kubernetes. This can be seen in their development of a variety of payloads specifically designed to target various Kubernetes environments. Their newer payloads are less noisy, less generic, and have updated C2 addresses. Furthermore, the group is trying to increase the profitability of their cryptomining campaigns by having tools that target specific GPUs for an increased hash rate. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222424/TeamTNT%20Upgrades%20Arsenal%20to%20Target%20Kubernetes%20and%20GPU%20Environments%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636661502345&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use multi-factor authentication wherever possible. (M1032)
  * Limit communications with the container service to local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API and Kubernetes API Server (M1035).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/k/teamtnt-upgrades-arsenal-refines-focus-on-kubernetes-and-gpu-env.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
T1610 - Deploy Container  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1613 - Container and Resource Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

I have encountered the following information: Mozilla Foundation Security Advisories January 26
The Mozilla Foundation has issued three security advisories covering vulnerabilities addressed in Firefox, Firefox ESR, and Thunderbird.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

The Mozilla Foundation has released Firefox 85, Firefox ESR 78.7, and Thunderbird 78.7 to cover multiple vulnerabilities. All three advisories have been rated as High. Issues resolved include user-after-poison, memory corruption, insecure framing, protocol command injection, leaking of cross-origin information, and type confusion. The most serious potential impact from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities is the remote execution of arbitrary code. For further details, please refer to the appropriate advisory in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/38306087/Mozilla%20Foundation%20Security%20Advisories%20January%2026%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1611811538075&api=v2)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: HpReact Campaign
HpReact is a new campaign being carried out by APT-C-43 (aka Machete). 360 Security Center reports on the infection chain, including the use of a new backdoor named Fpyark.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: HpReact Campaign
HpReact is a new campaign being carried out by APT-C-43 (aka Machete). 360 Security Center reports on the infection chain, including the use of a new backdoor named Fpyark.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, APT




# Overview

360 Security Center has published an analysis of APT-C-43's most recent campaign, HpReact. The campaign is targeting Venezuelan military institutions in an attempt to steal secrets to support the reactionaries in the country. The infection chain begins with a phishing email containing a lure related to a policy issued by the Venezuelan authorities. Once opened, the attached document executes a malicious macro that downloads a Batch script via FTP. The Batch script, in turn, downloads an MSI installer from a remote URL. While currently using an MSI installer, the group has previously used similar infection chains that, instead, downloaded NSIS-packed files or 7z self-extracting archives. The installer masquerades as an Acrobat Reader installer in an attempt to hide the malicious activity from the user. In the background, the Fpyark backdoor components are dropped on the system alongside the required Python files and libraries. Persistence is established via scheduled tasks. Upon installation, the backdoor leverages several modules to carry out its goal of stealing military intelligence. Together the modules provide functionality for collection of network configuration, keystroke logging, file collection, screen capture, audio recording, and more. This gathered data can then be exfiltrated to the attacker over FTP, specifically through Tiny File Manager. For more information, see the 360 Total Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
HpReact Campaign
HpReact is a new campaign being carried out by APT-C-43 (aka Machete). 360 Security Center reports on the infection chain, including the use of a new backdoor named Fpyark.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, APT




# Overview

360 Security Center has published an analysis of APT-C-43's most recent campaign, HpReact. The campaign is targeting Venezuelan military institutions in an attempt to steal secrets to support the reactionaries in the country. The infection chain begins with a phishing email containing a lure related to a policy issued by the Venezuelan authorities. Once opened, the attached document executes a malicious macro that downloads a Batch script via FTP. The Batch script, in turn, downloads an MSI installer from a remote URL. While currently using an MSI installer, the group has previously used similar infection chains that, instead, downloaded NSIS-packed files or 7z self-extracting archives. The installer masquerades as an Acrobat Reader installer in an attempt to hide the malicious activity from the user. In the background, the Fpyark backdoor components are dropped on the system alongside the required Python files and libraries. Persistence is established via scheduled tasks. Upon installation, the backdoor leverages several modules to carry out its goal of stealing military intelligence. Together the modules provide functionality for collection of network configuration, keystroke logging, file collection, screen capture, audio recording, and more. This gathered data can then be exfiltrated to the attacker over FTP, specifically through Tiny File Manager. For more information, see the 360 Total Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.360totalsecurity.com/en/apt-c-43-steals-venezuelan-military-secrets-to-provide-intelligence-support-for-the-reactionaries-hpreact-campaign/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories - September 22, 2020
ICS-CERT has published two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in ICS-related systems.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

ICS-CERT has published two security advisories, ICSA-20-266-01 and ICSA-20-266-02, addressing vulnerabilities in ICS-related systems. ICSA-20-266-01 addresses two vulnerabilities in the GE Digital APM Classic tool. The first vulnerability, CVE-2020-16240, is an insecure direct object reference (IDOR) vulnerability that could allow an attacker to download sensitive data related to user accounts without having the proper privileges. The second vulnerability, CVE-2020-16244, is the result of unsalted passwords that could allow an authenticated user to obtain and decrypt password hashes. Both vulnerabilities are patched in recent versions of the software. ICSA-20-266-02 details two vulnerabilities in GE Reason S20 Ethernet Switches. CVE-2020-16242 and CVE-2020-16246 are both cross site scripting vulnerabilities, one of which could allow an attacker to perform critical application actions while the other could allow malicious JavaScript to be rendered. Both vulnerabilities have been patched by GE in recent firmware updates. We recommend reviewing the advisories, linked to in the References section, and applying any relevant updates as soon as possible.

# CVEs

A complete list of associated CVEs can be found here: 

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-266-01>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-266-02>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Evasive Maneuvers in Data Stealing Gateways
A PHP script alongside a series of data-stealing scripts was identified and analyzed by Sucuri researchers.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Stealer




# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing a PHP script that seems to be used to exfiltrate sensitive data. This PHP script is only several lines long and uses cURL to establish a session with a remote gateway and exfiltrate information from a specified stream via POST parameters. This allows attackers to send data from a victim website to a gateway script hosted at another location, which would, subsequently, relay the stolen data to the attacker. Notably, the variable to set the external gateway contains the string "AZORult," a well-known information stealer. Furthermore, the PHP script was found alongside a series of data-stealing scripts, further bolstering the theory that the PHP file acts as an exfiltration method for data stolen by malicious stealers. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/11/evasive-maneuvers-in-data-stealing-gateways.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Spammers Get Better at Impersonating Banking Services to Con Victims
Threat actors continue to exploit and leverage the current COVID-19 pandemic, as analysts witnessed a surge of phishing and malspam campaigns posing as online banking services, according to the Bitdefender Antispam Lab.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Spam




# Overview

  
Threat actors took advantage of the current COVID-19 pandemic and online Black Friday sales to launch phishing and malspam campaigns, targeting prominent banks in the financial sector, according to the Bitdefender Antispam Lab. Researchers at the Bitdefender Antispam Lab noticed singular tactics integrating social engineering and phishing techniques. Furthermore, researchers uncovered several phishing attempts associated with the campaign from banks world-wide like Bank of America, Standard Bank, Wells Fargo, La Banque Postale, and HSBC Bank, as well as the money transaction services PayPal and Western Union. According to researchers, the most intriguing of all phishing attacks is the one involving the La Banque Postale, where 97.69% of incoming emails associated with the bank were marked as spam. Scammers attempted to dupe the end-user into accessing a malicious link, allowing them to listen in on communications received from the bank. In conclusion, the increase in digital transactions, online shopping, and the management of an individual’s finances online have created new avenues of approach for threat actors and cybercriminals alike. For more information, see the Hot For Security article in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://hotforsecurity.bitdefender.com/blog/spammers-get-better-at-impersonating-banking-services-use-lingo-and-legit-layouts-to-con-victims-24805.html>
