instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Fake Oximeter Apps Distributing Malware
While monitoring COVID-19-related apps, Quick Heal discovered a fake Android application masquerading as an oximeter to install malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Fake Oximeter Apps Distributing Malware
While monitoring COVID-19-related apps, Quick Heal discovered a fake Android application masquerading as an oximeter to install malware.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Quick Heal published a blog post analyzing a malicious app masquerading as an oximeter tool. Additionally, a vaccine registration themed app distributing the same malware was also discovered. These are the latest findings in a line of Android applications using themes related to the COVID-19 pandemic to spread malware. The apps are being distributed via either the official Google Play store, unofficial Android marketplaces, and/or online repositories. Once installed on the system, it executes two functions capable of sending a malicious link to the victim's contacts via SMS and WhatsApp. The link points to a banking Trojan payload hosted on the mega.nz service. For more information, see the Quick Heal blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in messages.



# Reference

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Salfram Crypter Campaigns
Several email campaigns have been observed by Cisco Talos, all sharing one commonality: the use of a crypter, dubbed Salfram, on the first stage payloads.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Cisco Talos reports on a series of email campaigns distributing various malware families, all encrypted with the same crypter, named Salfram. The initial emails in each campaign are sent via business' website contact forms, increasing the chance it will be opened by the recipient. The content of the message claims that there are images hosted on the website that violate copyright and request the recipient review a document hosted at a provided link for more information. To send the form submissions, the operators leveraged proxy servers and automated scripting to generate and submit the lure. With regard to the links in the emails, most point to a document hosted on Google Drive. The document is a macro-emedded file that, if downloaded and executed, will begin infecting the system. Some infection chains led to the installation of various payloads, while others only delivered a single malicious payload. Regardless of the full infection chain and malware family in use, the initial payload leveraged the Salfram crypter to obfuscate its content. The crypter seems to have evolved over the course of the campaigns. Some differences include the actual code used for similar function calls. However, many similarities can be seen, such as the use of a large number of jumps and fake API calls. Ultimately, the payload is unpacked and run on the system. The researchers note that the crypter is quite advanced outside its inclusion of a string in the DOS stub that is highly trackable. For more information, see the Talos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2020/09/salfram-robbing-place-without-removing.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Security Researchers Being Targeted in New Campaign
Google's Threat Analysis Group has uncovered a campaign that is taking aim at security researchers. The blog post discusses details of the campaign and some targets.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Security Researchers Being Targeted in New Campaign
Google's Threat Analysis Group has uncovered a campaign that is taking aim at security researchers. The blog post discusses details of the campaign and some targets.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Using a fake research blog and twitter accounts, a suspected government-backed North Korean threat entity has targeted security researchers who may be working on vulnerabilities. The actors use the Twitter profiles to interact with researchers in order to gain trust. The blog contains links to claimed exploits. Information contained within the blog are write-ups for publicly disclosed vulnerabilities. The exploits in the blog could not be authenticated as working. A fake video of a previously patched Windows Defender vulnerability (CVE-2021-1647) is shown. The video is faked and is called out by targeted researchers. The actors then use one of the faked Twitter accounts to claim the video is not, in fact, faked. The actors establish initial communications and ask if the targeted researcher would like to collaborate on research together. The actor provides the victim with a Visual Studio Project which contains a DLL that is custom malware. This malware immediately communicates with C2 server domains. Additionally, the actors use a blog with a malicious link via a link on Twitter to install a malicious service on the victim machine. In addition to Twitter, other services used are LinkedIn, Telegram, Discord, Keybase, and email. Further details can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/new-campaign-targeting-security-researchers/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Social Media Buttons Used to Skim Payments
A new technique used to skim payments on checkout pages is being deployed through social media buttons. Sansec researchers provide details on this new targeting scheme.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Social Media Buttons Used to Skim Payments
A new technique used to skim payments on checkout pages is being deployed through social media buttons. Sansec researchers provide details on this new targeting scheme.

# Threat Type

  * Skimming




# Overview

Using social media buttons, threat actors are skimming from checkout pages. The malware consists of two parts: a concealed payload and a decoder, which reads the payload and performs the actions of the concealed code. Previous skimming campaigns used files, such as images, to hide the skimming code, whereas this skimming is occurring through a valid image file using malicious code in and of itself. The HTML form element is the container for the payload. It is concealed using syntax that is strongly reminiscent of the correct usage of the <svg> element. The actors have implemented a seemingly benign social media company's images. Research has shown six separate companies being used in the campaign. Those are Facebook, Google, Twitter, Instagram, YouTube, and Pinterest. The decoder interprets and executes the payload, which does not need to be injected in the same location as said payload. By finding one aspect of the malware, the analysis may not reveal the purpose of the malware itself. The malware looks like an improperly formatted svg. This same technique was observed in June 2020 by Sansec researchers. Although that malware was not as sophisticated, some of the same tactics were used. This older malware could have been used as a test for the newer malware. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://sansec.io/research/svg-malware>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: More_eggs Backdoor Delivered via LinkedIn with Fake Job Offers
More_eggs is a malware-as-a-service backdoor sold by Golden Chickens to other cybercriminals. eSentire reports on its recent usage in a spear phishing campaign targeting LinkedIn professionals with fake job offers to distribute the payload.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

eSentire discovered the more_eggs backdoor being distributed as part of a LinkedIn spear phishing campaign. Targets receive a ZIP file name based on their LinkedIn job title, attempting to lure them into opening the ZIP file. Opening the file leads to the execution of VenomLNK, the initial stage of a more_eggs infection. VenomLNK, in turn, displays a decoy job application document to distract the user while executing TerraLoader, more_eggs' plugin loader. Finally, Terraloader loads the TerraPreter payload via an ActiveX control file downloaded from AWS. The more_eggs operator is then able to interact with the victim host in order to carry out further activities, such as installing additional malware or exfiltrating data. Notably, this entire infection chain is performed by abusing legitimate Windows processes, decreasing the chances of detection. eSentire was unable to attribute this activity to a specific threat actor, but based on known more_eggs customers and previous threat activity, potential groups include FIN6, Evilnum, and Cobalt Group. For more information, see the eSentire blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.esentire.com/security-advisories/hackers-spearphish-professionals-on-linkedin-with-fake-job-offers-infecting-them-with-malware-warns-esentire>

# Overview

eSentire discovered the more_eggs backdoor being distributed as part of a LinkedIn spear phishing campaign. Targets receive a ZIP file name based on their LinkedIn job title, attempting to lure them into opening the ZIP file. Opening the file leads to the execution of VenomLNK, the initial stage of a more_eggs infection. VenomLNK, in turn, displays a decoy job application document to distract the user while executing TerraLoader, more_eggs' plugin loader. Finally, Terraloader loads the TerraPreter payload via an ActiveX control file downloaded from AWS. The more_eggs operator is then able to interact with the victim host in order to carry out further activities, such as installing additional malware or exfiltrating data. Notably, this entire infection chain is performed by abusing legitimate Windows processes, decreasing the chances of detection. eSentire was unable to attribute this activity to a specific threat actor, but based on known more_eggs customers and previous threat activity, potential groups include FIN6, Evilnum, and Cobalt Group. For more information, see the eSentire blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.esentire.com/security-advisories/hackers-spearphish-professionals-on-linkedin-with-fake-job-offers-infecting-them-with-malware-warns-esentire>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Purple Fox Botnet and Infection Chain
Expanding on previous research, Trend Micro has published a report detailing Purple Fox's infection of SQL servers for the purpose of cryptomining.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor, Cryptomining, Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Purple Fox
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Various
  *  **Targets:** SQL Servers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Brute force
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral movement via SQL, remote command execution, cryptomining



# Overview

Trend Micro has published an analysis of Purple Fox's botnet infrastructure and malware. The first-stage malware is initially executed via proces injection. It then drops and loads a DLL file into memory. Once running on the system, the malware first gets a list of C2 addresses via DNS queries. Specifically, a dynamic DNS service is used to return encoded IP addresses, which are decoded to provide the actual C2 server and port. Next, UDP is used to obtain a secondary list of C2 IPs along with configuration information for the group's various tools. Lastly, secondary payloads are obtained via HTTP, which are decrypted, decompressed, and executed into memory by the first-stage malware. The secondary payloads include an XMRig cryptominer and an SQL Server Scanner that identifies and brute forces SQL servers in order to deploy a backdoor. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056235/Purple%20Fox%20Botnet%20and%20Infection%20Chain%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639677206547&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/l/a-look-into-purple-fox-server-infrastructure.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1071.004 - DNS  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1104 - Multi-Stage Channels  
T1568 - Dynamic Resolution

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Chinese Malvertising Campaigns
Two cybercrime groups may be related have been operating malvertising campaigns since at least 2017. Confiant has released a blog detailing the latest developments on the groups and the aforementioned campaigns.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Chinese Malvertising Campaigns
Two cybercrime groups may be related have been operating malvertising campaigns since at least 2017. Confiant has released a blog detailing the latest developments on the groups and the aforementioned campaigns.

# Threat Type

  * Malvertising




# Overview

Beginning in 2017, two malvertising groups have run campaigns against a myriad of targets. Most recently, the groups have moved to almost exclusively targeting the U.S. The two groups, Nephos7 and eGobbler, have used similar TTPs in the campaigns such as the use of commercial ad servers to hide code, reverse proxies, JavaScript APIs, and WebGL-based fingerprinting. By the end of 2019, both groups had aligned patterns with large attacks in late-December 2019. In June 2020, both groups had switched focus to the U.S. The malvertising pages for both groups are very much similar in appearance. Beyond these similarities, there is no infrastructure overlap. Both groups use an .msi file with a signed installer dubbed Holcus Installer. Features of the installer include C2 server communications over HTTPS, RC4-type algorithms, PUA detection within Windows Defender, downloading and executing payloads, and communications with known C2 servers. Nephos7 was the largest digital marketer in Europe on May 24, 2020. Each group targets Windows-based machines and excludes Mac OS X. The mobile platform of choice for both is Android, although eGobbler started out as iOS targeting. Further technical details can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.confiant.com/malvertising-made-in-china-f5081521b3f0>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Initial IcedID Infection Used to Deliver XingLocker Ransomware
An initial IcedID infection led to the deployment of a variant of the Mountlocker ransomware by a threat actor that uses the name XingLocker.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Initial IcedID Infection Used to Deliver XingLocker Ransomware
An initial IcedID infection led to the deployment of a variant of the Mountlocker ransomware by a threat actor that uses the name XingLocker.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransomware Family:** XingLocker, A Mountlocker variant.
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Mountlocker
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified **.**
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Lateral movement, File encryption.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.
  *  ** **Leak Site:**** See the list of .onion sites in the Indicators of Compromise list. ****



# Overview

The threat actor named XingLocker is believed to be a client of the MountLocker ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) offering. However, XingLocker appears to provide its own leak and payment sites independently of Mountlocker. At least some of the XingLocker infrastructure appears to be shared with another ransomware actor named AstroLocker. See the Tend Micro link in the References section for a further explanation of XingLocker and AstroLocker. The DFIR Report has published an article that covers an intrusion by XingLocker that occurred in late July. IcedID was deployed during the initial compromise and a short time later it was used to download and execute a Cobalt Strike beacon. A number of tools were used to facilitate lateral movement including Adfind, BloodHound, Cobalt Strike, and PowerView. Some phases of the attack involved the use of batch scripts, for example, there were batch scripts for execution, defense evasion, and persistence tasks. Finally, just prior to the ransomware being deployed, the attackers conducted another search for files and directories, this search was conducted manually. While the DFIR Report article notes that no data was observed being exfiltrated from the systems it is possible that Cobalt Strike was used to exfiltrate data. Further information is available from the DFIR Report article linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130468/Initial%20IcedID%20Infection%20Used%20to%20Deliver%20XingLocker%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634531514720&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A list of Yara rules can be found here: [ Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/64130468/Initial%20IcedID%20Infection%20Used%20to%20Deliver%20XingLocker%20Ransomware%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634531531779&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_au/research/21/j/ransomware-operators-found-using-new-franchise-business-model.html>
  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2021/10/18/icedid-to-xinglocker-ransomware-in-24-hours/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1069 - Permission Groups Discovery  
T1069.002 - Domain Groups  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1135 - Network Share Discovery  
T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: APT28 Using Zebrocy in Malware Campaign
QuoIntelligence has been monitoring an APT28 campaign since August this year that is spreading Zebrocy Delphi malware. They indicated that the command and control servers were located in France and that the theme used in the emails was NATO based.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Info Stealer



# Overview

QuoIntelligence's latest report discloses an malware campaign that uses a NATO training as a theme. A specific governmental body in Azerbaijan was the primary target, although other NATO countries may have also been involved. The article stated that APT28 (IBM follows this group as ITG05, but it is also known as Sofacy, Sednit, Fancy Bear, and STRONTIUM) was behind the campaign. The main objective of the campaign was to infect victims with the Zebrocy malware. The malware comes in as what appears to be a valid JPG image. If a .jpg extension is added to the file name, the operating system will display the logo of the Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe which is the NATO’s Allied Command Operations in Belgium. Adding a .zip extension, though, proves that the file is really an archive file, no matter what the file headers indicate. If the file is opened by WinZip, an error is returned. For the archive to be extracted properly, WinRAR must be used. Within the archive are two files named "Course 5 – 16 October 2020", one with a .exe extension and the other with a .xls extension. The spreadsheet file is corrupted and appears to contain military information while the executable is actually the Zebrocy malware. When clicked, Zebrocy copies itself to a service directory using a different name and pads the new file with 160 bytes of random data to avoid hash-matching security applications. Data stolen from the victim system is sent by accessing a PHP page on the attacker's controlled system. For more technical details, please review the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://quointelligence.eu/2020/09/apt28-zebrocy-malware-campaign-nato-theme/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Phishing Campaign Targeting Predominantly Government Entities
A phishing campaign, active since late 2019, and targeting the education, energy, finance, government, and heath sectors in a number of geographies, has been reported by Recorded Future’s Insikt Group. The campaign has leveraged the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Phishing Campaign Targeting Predominantly Government Entities
A phishing campaign, active since late 2019, and targeting the education, energy, finance, government, and heath sectors in a number of geographies, has been reported by Recorded Future’s Insikt Group. The campaign has leveraged the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Primarily targeting governmental entities, as well as the education, energy, finance, and heath sectors, Recorded Future’s Insikt Group has identified a phishing campaign that has been active since late 2019. The most targeted countries have been Canada, India, the United States, and Turkey. Other countries targeted include, Australia, India, Qatar, the Republic of Korea, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and the United Kingdom. The campaign has largely been using Russian domains (.ru) and Insikt believes the campaign has been coordinated through the site asherintartrading.com. The site has hosted the management portal for the the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish. A number of IP addresses, including more than thirty belonging to DigitalOcean, have also been used in the campaign, along with more than two hundred domains and URLs. The URLs follow a similar naming convention in most cases. In the email noted in the report, the victim was presented with a fake Gmail login page. In addition, if the victim clicked the unsubscribe link in the email, they were presented with a different phishing page, on a different domain. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://go.recordedfuture.com/hubfs/reports/cta-2020-1027.pdf>

Other countries targeted include, Australia, India, Qatar, the Republic of Korea, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and the United Kingdom. The campaign has largely been using Russian domains (.ru) and Insikt believes the campaign has been coordinated through the site asherintartrading.com. The site has hosted the management portal for the the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish. A number of IP addresses, including more than thirty belonging to DigitalOcean, have also been used in the campaign, along with more than two hundred domains and URLs. The URLs follow a similar naming convention in most cases. In the email noted in the report, the victim was presented with a fake Gmail login page. In addition, if the victim clicked the unsubscribe link in the email, they were presented with a different phishing page, on a different domain. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://go.recordedfuture.com/hubfs/reports/cta-2020-1027.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Thalluim APT Leverages Malicious Cryptocurrency Wallet Apps
Thallium APT is performing a supply chain attack to inject their malicious code into cryptocurrency wallet apps. EST Security reports on this activity and their analysis of related samples.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Thalluim APT Leverages Malicious Cryptocurrency Wallet Apps
Thallium APT is performing a supply chain attack to inject their malicious code into cryptocurrency wallet apps. EST Security reports on this activity and their analysis of related samples.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

EST Security has published a blog post analyzing Thallium malware samples disguised as cryptocurrency wallet apps. In order to distribute their malicious code, they injected it into legitimate applications, essentially performing a supply chain attack. Two different operating systems were targeted, Windows and Android. On Windows, the code is distributed via either the wallet installer or a firmware update program. Along with the legitimate code is the threat actor's code that ensures communication is established with a C2 server. In the same way, Android APKs for legitimate wallet apps were repackaged to include the actor's code that establishes C2 communication. It was reported that unauthorized withdrawal of coins were made in some cases. Credentials were also able to be stolen by the malware. The activity has been attributed to the Thallium APT based on code overlaps, such as the use of the same mutex and string encryption method. For more information, see the EST blog post linked to in the Reference section. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.alyac.co.kr/3310>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: SMAUG Ransomware as a Service
A relatively new Ransomware as a Service (RaaS) offering, SMAUG, is discussed in an analysis by SentinelOne researchers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: SMAUG Ransomware as a Service
A relatively new Ransomware as a Service (RaaS) offering, SMAUG, is discussed in an analysis by SentinelOne researchers.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

SentinelOne published their analysis of the SMAUG RaaS offering. It has some interesting characteristics not commonly seen with other RaaS offerings. It first appeared in the threat landscape at the end of April 2020. Similar to other ransomware services, a percentage of the profit made by the purchasers is provided to the operators in order to receive the payload and services. Additionally, the operators charge a registration fee, one that is quite a bit higher than those charged by competitors (.2 BTC or $1,800). One of the most unique features of SMAUG is its multi-platofrm support, allowing encryption of Windows, Linux and macOS systems. Additionally, when building the malicious payload, an option is provided to allow a single encryption key to be used across all victim hosts in a single company. Anti-analysis, offline execution, customizable campaigns are all features advertised in their forum posts. The payloads are generated via a web-based management interface as opposed to the more common offline builder. This web portal also allows victims to decrypt a single file for free. The generated payloads for Windows are obfuscated Go binaries. On Windows, persistence is established via the LoadAppInit_DLLs Registry key. A ransom note is dropped in all folders containing encrypted files. The researchers also note that the SMAUG portal provides detailed walkthroughs for victims and affiliates. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/multi-platform-smaug-raas-aims-to-see-off-competitors/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Active CVE-2020-0688 Exploit Affects Over 247,000 Microsoft Exchange Servers
A vulnerability, CVE-2020-0688, patched in February of 2020, is being actively exploited. This Microsoft Exchange Server remote code execution vulnerability could affect more than 247,000 unpatched systems on the Internet, BleepingComputer warns.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

BleepingComputer warns that over 247,000 Microsoft Exchange Servers on the Internet have not had the February update to address a remote code execution vulnerability, CVE-2020-0688. The issues resides in the Exchange Control Panel code, which is enabled by default, and could allow an attacker to gain control of the server if successfully exploited. In a survey of Exchange servers on the Internet, Rapid7 found 405,873 Exchange servers with 61% (247,986) still vulnerable to CVE-2020-0688. They also discovered 16,577 Exchange 2007 servers, which are no longer being supported by Microsoft, that were vulnerable as well. For more details, refer to the links in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30771017/Active%20CVE-2020-0688%20Exploit%20Affects%20Over%20247%2C000%20Microsoft%20Exchange%20Servers%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1601476091435&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/over-247k-exchange-servers-unpatched-for-actively-exploited-flaw/>   
<https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/us-govt-china-sponsored-hackers-targeting-exchange-citrix-f5-flaws/>

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Microsoft patched 114 vulnerabilities across their product lines in their November Patch Tuesday. Overall, Microsoft rated the release as High. The most serious vulnerability, if successfully exploited, could potentially result in remote code execution. In some cases, detailed exploit information is available. instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Spyware Masquerading as Balochi Shayri App
Recent political activity in Pakistan has led to increased targeting of the Baloch people. In one such case, Cyble observed a fake Balochi Shayri app being used to distribute spyware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Spyware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** N/A
  *  **Targets:** Balochi Android users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake Balochi Shayri app
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft and reconnaissance 



# Overview

Cyble published a blog post analyzing a piece of spyware masquerading as a Balochi Shayri application. The malicious APK uses the name and icon associated with its legitimate counterpart from the Google Play Store. Once installed on the device, however, it does not provide legitimate functionality and instead operates in the background. The malware requests extensive permissions from the users, which are abused to execute commands issued by the operator via a C2 server. Commands include those to read and receive SMS messages, record audio, capture camera images, gather system information, and more. Based on the use of an application primarily used by the Baloch people and recent political activity in Pakistan, it is possible that state actors are using this spyware to perform reconnaissance and surveillance of users from this ethnic group. For more information, see the Cyble blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129727/Spyware%20Masquerading%20as%20Balochi%20Shayri%20App%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633631386729&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).



# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2021/10/05/fake-balochi-shayri-app-masquerading-as-legitimate-application-appears-to-be-affecting-ethnic-balochi-users/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  


 **E** **xecution - TA0041**  
T1575 – Native Code  


 **Persistence - TA0028**  
T1402 – Broadcast Receivers  


 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
T1508 – Suppress Application Icon  


 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1412 – Capture SMS Messages  
T1432 – Access Contacts List  
T1433 – Access Call Log  
T1517 – Access Notifications  
T1429 – Capture Audio  
T1512 – Capture Camera  
T1533 – Data from Local System  
T1513 – Screen Capture  


 **Impact - TA0034**  
T1447 – Delete Device Data

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Rclone Cloud Storage Software Abused To Steal Several GBs Data
During a recent suspected Sodinokibi attack, the legitimate application Rclone was abused to steal a large trove of data - a first for an IBM X-Force Incident Response engagement. This report calls attention to this attacker's technique - data theft via Rclone, the "The Swiss army knife of cloud storage.”
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Data Theft




# Overview

IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence (XFTI) believes at least one Sodinokibi affiliate is abusing Rclone, a legitimate command-line secure data transfer software, by exfiltrating a massive quantity of data from a victim’s environment to the attacker-controlled MEGA account. The researchers expect that Rclone’s abuse will increase by attackers like Sodinokibi due to its attractive capabilities, such as its ability to conduct secure data transfers, including “transfers over limited bandwidth [and/or] intermittent connections,” and sync to over 40 cloud storage services, specifically MEGA, a service preferred by Sodinokibi. The full story, including indicators of compromise, is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below. 




# Recommendations

  * See the full report in TruStar.



# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/c63d4704-2eee-44e3-ac2b-c4434c317a21>   



  * To learn more about X-Force IRIS Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Russian GRU Conducting Global Brute Force Campaign
A joint advisory from CISA, the FBI, NCSC, and NSA, provides details of a global brute force campaign being conducted by the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU).

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Brute-force




# Overview

Beginning in mid-2019 and probably ongoing, the Russian General Staff Main Intelligence Directorate (GRU) has been conducting a brute force campaign. The private sector has typically attributed the GRU activity to the well-known names APT28 or Fancy Bear, though a number of other names including Group 74, Iron Twilight, Pawn Storm, Sednit, Snakemackerel, Sofacy, Strontium, Swallowtail, Tg-4127, Threat Group-4127, Tsar Team, are also associated. IBM X-Force tracks the activity under ITG05. While the campaign has principally targeted Europe and the U.S., it is global in nature. The targeted entities include defense contractors, energy companies, government and military organizations, higher education institutions, law firms, logistics companies, media companies, political consultants and party organizations, and think tanks. The attacks are carried out using a Kubernetes cluster. The primary service targeted in the attacks has been Microsoft Office 365 cloud services, though other service providers and on-premise email servers are also targeted. If credentials are obtained they are typically used to gain an initial foothold before attempts are made to escalate privileges and move laterally. The attackers are also known to exploit vulnerabilities such as CVE-2020-0688 and CVE-2020-17144 for remote code execution or to further lateral movement within an environment. To anonymize the attacks, they are usually routed through Tor or VPN services, including those provided by CactusVPN, IPVanish, NordVPN, ProtonVPN, Surfshark, and WorldVPN. In some cases, the attacks have come directly from the Kubernetes cluster. Once an organization has been compromised, the attackers will attempt to gain a persistent foothold and exfiltrate data. Further information is available from the advisory linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Detection

  * A Yara rule can be found here:



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://media.defense.gov/2021/Jul/01/2002753896/-1/-1/1/CSA_GRU_GLOBAL_BRUTE_FORCE_CAMPAIGN_UOO158036-21.PDF>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Visa Provides PoS Malware IoCs Used in Attacks
A report from Visa's Payment Fraud Disruption team sheds light on the PoS malware that was used in recent, independent compromises of two North American merchants.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * PoS Malware




# Overview

Attackers are still compromising merchants using PoS malware, as a report from Visa's Payment Fraud Disruption (PFD) team indicates. The PFD team analyzed the malware involved in the independent compromises of two North American merchants. The malware used in the first compromise was a variant of TinyPOS. Phishing emails sent to employees of the merchant and the attackers succeeded in obtaining a number of sets of credentials, including one with administrative rights. The credentials were then used to access the the merchant's environment. The second compromise involved malware from a number of different families including, MMon (also known as Kaptoxa), PwnPOS, and RtPOS. The vector used by the attackers to gain a foothold in the merchant's systems is unknown. In both cases the attackers targeted track 1 and track 2 payment account data which was stored for later exfiltration. Further details can be found in the report linked in the Reference below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://usa.visa.com/dam/VCOM/global/support-legal/documents/new-pos-malware-samples.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Kimsuky Using Blog Sites to Deliver Malware
Cisco Talos have published details on a new campaign from Kimsuky, targeting South Korean businesses in an attempt to steal data.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Kimsuky Using Blog Sites to Deliver Malware
Cisco Talos have published details on a new campaign from Kimsuky, targeting South Korean businesses in an attempt to steal data.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Targets:** Aerospace, Think Tanks, Research agencies
  *  **Associated Threat Actor:** Kimsuky
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Drive-by Compromise
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Cisco Talos recently discovered a campaign operated by the North Korean Kimsuky APT group delivering malware to high-value South Korean targets — namely geopolitical and aerospace research agencies. The attackers used Blogspot in this campaign to host their malicious artifacts. These blogs delivered three previously unseen components - an initial beacon script, an exfiltrator, and an implant instrumentor. This instrumentor delivers three further modules, used for internal reconnaissance and keylogging. Although these modules are all previously unknown, they share a large portion of their code with the Gold Dragon/Brave Prince family of implants. This has allowed the researchers to attribute this activity to Kimsuky with high confidence. In this campaign, there is a strong focus on finding documents associated with North Korea. The research also showed that the attackers were targeting aerospace companies with work relating to South Korea. The attackers were focusing on restricted research papers and project design documents to steal. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222464/Kimsuky%20Using%20Blog%20Sites%20to%20Deliver%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636734869021&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2021/11/kimsuky-abuses-blogs-delivers-malware.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547.009 - Shortcut Modification  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Telegram Utilized for Harvesting Credentials
Using legitimate services for malicious purposes is common as it helps attackers fly under the radar. In one such case, Cofense researchers discovered attackers using the Telegram API in a phishing campaign.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing the use of the Telegram API in a recent phishing campaign. The initial phishing email spoofs an internal support address and claims that there are emails that have been blocked and need to be manually reviewed. When a user clicks the link, they are redirected to a webmail phishing page customized based on the domain of the victim email address. The most interesting aspect of this campaign is that entering credentials leads to a POST request to the legitimate Telegram API. The attackers can then retrieve the email credentials from their Telegram account. After their credentials are exfiltrated, victims are redirected to the domain associated with their email. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/telegram-utilized-credentials>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Vulnerabilities in Billing System Exploited By Ransomware Group
The Huntress ThreatOps team have traced a detected ransomware attack back to a previously unknown vulnerability in the BQE Web Suite. They have published the process of uncovering this, and more vulnerabilities in a blog post.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Targets:** Engineering Firm
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public-Facing Server
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral Movement, Ransomware Deployment



# Overview

The Huntress ThreatOps team has discovered several vulnerabilities after a number of their ransomware canary files were tripped within a customer's network. Upon investigation, alerts were discovered concerning a service account used for an SQL server. The server in question hosted BQE Web Suite 2020, and the logs indicated that a foreign IP was repeatedly sending POST requests leading up to the initial compromise. With this information, the ThreatOps team downloaded a version of the BillQuick server and managed to recreate the victim's environment. With this, the researchers used the tool 'sqlmap' to test for SQL injection vulnerabilities. With this tool, the researchers discovered many vulnerabilities, including the one that led to the infection of this engineering firm. The researchers were able to use this vulnerability to dump sensitive databases and more severely, execute code remotely. This was how the attackers were able to access the network and deploy ransomware. The Huntress ThreatOps team has been liaising with the developers of BillQuick and is in the process of patching the discovered vulnerability. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [New Vulnerabilities in Billing System Being Exploited CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/68616960/New%20Vulnerabilities%20in%20Billing%20System%20Being%20Exploited%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635430309675&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Web Application Firewalls may be used to limit exposure of applications to prevent exploit traffic from reaching the application (M1050).



# References

  * <https://www.huntress.com/blog/threat-advisory-hackers-are-exploiting-a-vulnerability-in-popular-billing-software-to-deploy-ransomware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.004 - Exploits  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Lyceum APT Group Deploying Backdoor That Uses DNS for Command and Control
A report from Zscaler ThreatLabz provides an analysis of a .NET based backdoor that uses DNS Hijacking for C&C communications that has been used in attacks by the Iranian-sponsored APT group known as Lyceum.
output:
Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Malware
* **Targets:** Organizations in the energy and telecommunication sectors located in the Middle East
* **Malware Family/Families:** DnsSystem backdoor
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Word document
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Lyceum is reported by Zscaler ThreatLabz as being an Iranian-sponsored APT group that has been operating since sometime in 2017. This threat group is known to target organizations in the energy and telecommunication sectors located in the Middle East. The group has been using a .NET-based backdoor which is a modified version of the open-source tool, DIG.net. The modifications allow the backdoor to use DNS Hijacking to provide the backdoor's C&C communications. The backdoor uses DNS queries to a DNS server under the control of the attackers and the server's responses provide commands for the backdoor to carry out. In the campaign observed by Zscaler, the backdoor is delivered via a malicious Word document that uses the AutoOpen() and AutoClose() functions to drop the embedded backdoor onto the system. The backdoor, named "DnsSystem" is also copied to the system's startup folder to achieve persistence. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/lyceum-net-dns-backdoor>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
 T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
   T1583.001 - Domains  
   T1583.002 - DNS Server  
 T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
   T1587.001 - Malware  
 T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
   T1588.002 - Tool  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1566 - Phishing  
   T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
 T1204 - User Execution  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
   T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  

**Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
 T1055 - Process Injection  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1562 - Impair Defenses  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1010 - Application Window Discovery  
 T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
 T1057 - Process Discovery  
 T1518 - Software Discovery  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.004 - DNS  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Lyceum APT Group Deploying Backdoor That Uses DNS for Command and Control
A report from Zscaler ThreatLabz provides an analysis of a .NET based backdoor that uses DNS Hijacking for C&C communications that has been used in attacks by the Iranian-sponsored APT group known as Lyceum.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Malware
* **Targets:** Organizations in the energy and telecommunication sectors located in the Middle East
* **Malware Family/Families:** DnsSystem backdoor
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Word document
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

Lyceum is reported by Zscaler ThreatLabz as being an Iranian-sponsored APT group that has been operating since sometime in 2017. This threat group is known to target organizations in the energy and telecommunication sectors located in the Middle East. The group has been using a .NET-based backdoor which is a modified version of the open-source tool, DIG.net. The modifications allow the backdoor to use DNS Hijacking to provide the backdoor's C&C communications. The backdoor uses DNS queries to a DNS server under the control of the attackers and the server's responses provide commands for the backdoor to carry out. In the campaign observed by Zscaler, the backdoor is delivered via a malicious Word document that uses the AutoOpen() and AutoClose() functions to drop the embedded backdoor onto the system. The backdoor, named "DnsSystem" is also copied to the system's startup folder to achieve persistence. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/lyceum-net-dns-backdoor>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
 T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
   T1583.001 - Domains  
   T1583.002 - DNS Server  
 T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
   T1587.001 - Malware  
 T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
   T1588.002 - Tool  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1566 - Phishing  
   T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
 T1204 - User Execution  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
   T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  

**Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
 T1055 - Process Injection  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1562 - Impair Defenses  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1010 - Application Window Discovery  
 T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
 T1057 - Process Discovery  
 T1518 - Software Discovery  

**Exfiltration - TA0010**  
 T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.004 - DNS  

**Mitigations:**

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
**M1057:**  Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: FIN7 - Archaeology and Evolution
A report from Mandiant focuses on the archaeology and evolution of the threat group known as FIN7.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Various
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** FIN7
  *  **Associated Payloads:** BEAKDROP, BIRDWATCH, CARBANAK, Cobalt Strike, CROWVIEW, DICELOADER, FOWLGAZE, GRIFFON, LOADOUT, PILLOWMINT, POWERPLANT, POWERTRASH, SUPERSOFT, TAKEOUT, TERMITE.
  *  **Targets:** Entities in the cloud services, consulting, financial services, food and beverage, media, medical equipment, software, transportation, and utilities sectors.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Atera agent installers, the compromising of third-party systems, phishing, GoToAssist, and RDP.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Various
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The financially-motivated threat group FIN7 has been active since around 2013. IBM X-Force tracks FIN7 as ITG14. A report from Mandiant, focused on the archaeology and evolution of FIN7, and provides information on the group's more recently used TTPs. Of note in the report is that FIN7 began shifting to the use of a modular PowerShell backdoor named POWERPLANT as the first stage malware in 2020, POWERPLANT remains under active development. The methods FIN7 has used to gain their initial access to systems includes Atera agent installers, the compromising of third-party systems, phishing, GoToAssist, and RDP. The sectors targeted by FIN7 are known to include cloud services, consulting, financial services, food and beverage, media, medical equipment, software, transportation, and utilities. The report notes that data theft extortion or ransomware deployment activities have occurred in a number of cases post a FIN7 intrusion. This activity is attributed to other actors that FIN7 may cooperate with. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://www.mandiant.com/resources/evolution-of-fin7>

 **Impact - TA0040**
