instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Scammers Using MalwareBytes Renewals for Phishing
MalwareBytes' Threat Intelligence Team has uncovered a scam using their brand as a lure for phishing. Using fake emails and phone calls, threat actors are targeting users of MalwareBytes' services and products for the scam.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

A series of fake renewal notices and offers to remove security services offered by MalwareBytes has led their analysts to a phishing campaign. Several reports indicate the receipt of an email stating the product for which the customer may or may not have a legitimate license for has been seen in the wild. The email states that a subscription service offered by the company has been renewed at a rate much higher than the actual rate the company charges for this product. The threat actors show a charge of between $300-500. A typical yearly subscription for the product is actually about $100. The scam uses these emails in the hopes the victim will call and try to get the charges reversed. Should victims call, they're pointed to a website wherein a technician will remotely connect to their computer and 'uninstall' the product in question. Once the product is 'removed', the promise of a refund is given. Instead, the actors ask the victim to download TeamViewer and to share their ID and password to connect to the victim machine. The actors then install a second program to achieve persistence. In the same way as a tech support scheme, the threat actors use notepad to concoct a note telling the victim of the risks of not continuing with the product. Using SysKey, the actors place a password known only to them is installed on the computer. Should this be the case, a VBS script is downloaded and placed in the Startup folder. Upon completion of these acts, the scammers attempt to have the victim restart their machine in order to complete the 'uninstall' process. After restart, a Windows license expiration is displayed with a button to click. This button opens many browser windows to give the appearance of a malware infection. The hope is that some of the victims will call the number and ask that their service be reinstated. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Scammers Using MalwareBytes Renewals for Phishing
MalwareBytes' Threat Intelligence Team has uncovered a scam using their brand as a lure for phishing. Using fake emails and phone calls, threat actors are targeting users of MalwareBytes' services and products for the scam.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

A series of fake renewal notices and offers to remove security services offered by MalwareBytes has led their analysts to a phishing campaign. Several reports indicate the receipt of an email stating the product for which the customer may or may not have a legitimate license for has been seen in the wild. The email states that a subscription service offered by the company has been renewed at a rate much higher than the actual rate the company charges for this product. The threat actors show a charge of between $300-500. A typical yearly subscription for the product is actually about $100. The scam uses these emails in the hopes the victim will call and try to get the charges reversed. Should victims call, they're pointed to a website wherein a technician will remotely connect to their computer and 'uninstall' the product in question. Once the product is 'removed', the promise of a refund is given. Instead, the actors ask the victim to download TeamViewer and to share their ID and password to connect to the victim machine. The actors then install a second program to achieve persistence. In the same way as a tech support scheme, the threat actors use notepad to concoct a note telling the victim of the risks of not continuing with the product. Using SysKey, the actors place a password known only to them is installed on the computer. Should this be the case, a VBS script is downloaded and placed in the Startup folder. Upon completion of these acts, the scammers attempt to have the victim restart their machine in order to complete the 'uninstall' process. After restart, a Windows license expiration is displayed with a button to click. This button opens many browser windows to give the appearance of a malware infection. The hope is that some of the victims will call the number and ask that their service be reinstated. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TA2722 Spoofing Philippine Government in Widespread RAT Campaigns
TA2722 is a cybercriminal threat actor that impersonates Philippine government entities in their phishing lures. Proofpoint reports on a campaign targeting various verticals in North America, Europe, and Southeast Asia with the Remcos and NanoCore RATs.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TA2722 Spoofing Philippine Government in Widespread RAT Campaigns
TA2722 is a cybercriminal threat actor that impersonates Philippine government entities in their phishing lures. Proofpoint reports on a campaign targeting various verticals in North America, Europe, and Southeast Asia with the Remcos and NanoCore RATs.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TA2722
  *  **Associated Payloads:** NanoCore, Remcos
  *  **Targets:** Shipping/Logistics, Manufacturing, Business Services, Pharmaceutical, and Energy organizations in North America, Europe, and Southeast Asia
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing links and attachments
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft, remote command execution



# Overview

Proofpoint published a blog post detailing RAT campaigns being carried out by TA2722, a cybercriminal threat actor. The group spoofs Philippine government agencies in their phishing lures, which have been observed targeting logistics, manufacturing, business services, pharmaceutical, and energy organizations in North America, Europe, and Southeast Asia that likely are engaged with these government agencies in some way. The distribution method varies, ranging from OneDrive-hosted RAR files, PDFs containing malicious links to download ISO files, or macro-enabled Excel spreadsheets. Regardless of the initial infection vector, the threat group's ultimate goal is to install the Remoces or NanoCore commodity RATs, providing them with remote control and information stealing capabilities. Proofpoint's blog post provides an analysis of several clusters of activity and the overlap indicating a link to the same threat actor. For more information, see the Proofpoint blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616952/TA2722%20Spoofing%20Philippine%20Government%20in%20Widespread%20RAT%20Campaigns%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635426224393&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/new-threat-actor-spoofs-philippine-government-covid-19-health-data-widespread>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1585 - Establish Accounts  
T1585.002 - Email Accounts  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Purple Fox EK Abuses Cloudflare and Exploits CVE-2019-1367
The Purple Fox EK is now leveraging Cloudflare as part of its delivery infrastructure. Trend Micro analyzes the infection chain associated with a recent spike in Purple Fox activity.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Purple Fox EK Abuses Cloudflare and Exploits CVE-2019-1367
The Purple Fox EK is now leveraging Cloudflare as part of its delivery infrastructure. Trend Micro analyzes the infection chain associated with a recent spike in Purple Fox activity.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Exploit Kit




# Overview

Trend Micro has published a report analyzing recent Purple Fox EK activity. Although originally delivered by the Rig exploit kit, the Purple Fox malware has since moved to leveraging its own exploit kit, which has been growing in its sophistication. The landing page was hosted on Cloudflare in order to hide behind a legitimate cloud service's infrastructure. The content of the landing page was encrypted and obfuscated. Several JavaScript libraries are referenced to perform the decryption and decoding. The encrypted code is responsible for exploiting CVE-2019-1367, an Internet Explorer vulnerability, in order to deliver and execute the Purple Fox malware to a victim host. After successful exploitation, users are redirected to the Google search engine, likely to avoid raising the victim's suspicions. Trend Micro notes they reported their discovery to Cloudflare who have since blocked communication with the discovered exploit pages. For more information, see the Trend Micro article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/i/purple-fox-ek-relies-on-cloudflare-for-stability.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Malware That Prevents Access to Pirate Sites
A piece of malware that prevents access to well-known software piracy sites is the subject of a report from Sophos.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Malware That Prevents Access to Pirate Sites
A piece of malware that prevents access to well-known software piracy sites is the subject of a report from Sophos.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A piece of malware that prevents access to well-known software piracy sites is being distributed through Discord file sharing and BitTorrent files. The versions delivered through Discord are typically a single executable file. The versions being distributed through torrent files are compressed archives containing multiple files, similar to how pirated software is typically packaged. The files are usually named as games and software packages, again, typically in the manner pirated software is named. When executed, the malware attempts to modify the system's HOSTS file. Administrative rights are required to edit the HOSTS file. If the user running the malware does not have administrative rights, the malware will ask to run with additional privileges. The HOSTS file is modified to point a large number of domains associated with software piracy to 127.0.0.1 which will prevent the victim from accessing the sites. Another payload is downloaded but this appears to simply add more domains to the HOSTS file. When executed, the malware delivers an error claiming it cannot run due to a missing DLL. This is a fake message as it is delivered whether or not the DLL exists on the system. The executables are signed with bogus certificates. It appears the malware has a kill switch as it looks for two files on the system and if they are found, it exits. The malware has no persistence mechanism. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/06/17/vigilante-antipiracy-malware/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Offensive Cyber Tools Bundled With Malware
Cybercriminals are bundling malware with offensive cyber tools being offered to Ukrainian sympathizers. Talos Intelligence has written a report on this activity and detailed the kinds of malware deployed.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian Sympathizers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Trojanized Offensive Tools
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

As the crisis in Ukraine continues, a lot of information and tools are being sold on the dark web and anonymous messaging services such as Telegram. The Talos Intelligence team has discovered that some offensive security tools sold are malware intended to compromise the buyer. In one example, a DDoS tool intended to target Russian websites was found to be an infostealer. This would dump a variety of credentials and cryptocurrency-related information. This shows that opportunistic cybercriminals are taking advantage of the situation to make money. The infostealer in question is packed and contains anti-debugging capabilities. This has been distributed since November 2021, supporting the hypothesis that this is an exploitation of ongoing events, rather than new activity. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Offense Cyber Tools Bundled With Malware IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/82641164/Offense%20Cyber%20Tools%20Bundled%20With%20Malware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1647338932829&api=v2)



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/03/threat-advisory-cybercriminals.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: AR20-259A - Iranian Web Shells
CISA has published a malware analysis report, AR20-259A, describing recent samples of web shells tied to an Iranian-based threat actor.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: AR20-259A - Iranian Web Shells
CISA has published a malware analysis report, AR20-259A, describing recent samples of web shells tied to an Iranian-based threat actor.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Web Shell, Backdoor




# Overview

CISA published AR20-259A, a malware analysis report of Iranian web shell samples. The threat actor targets information technology, government, healthcare, financial, and insurance organizations across the United States. The initial infection vector in their attacks is through the exploitation of vulnerabilities in Pulse Secure virtual private network (VPN), Citrix NetScaler, and F5 devices. After successfully exploiting one of these vulnerabilities, the attackers were observed deploying various webshells onto the system. These included the ChunkyTuna, Tiny, and China Chopper web shells. Capabilities provided with these web shells installed include the ability to execute commands, enumerate directories, download and execute additional payloads, and exfiltrate data. Two additional tools were also discovered in use, FRP and KeeThief. FRP is an open source project allowing tunneling of network connections, which the researchers believed was used by this threat actor to tunnel Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) sessions. KeeThief is another open source tool that is used to decrypt and steal credentials stored in the KeePass password manager. These credentials could then be used to move laterally. For more information, see the CISA report in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-259a>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Analysis of the LockFile Ransomware
Sophos has published an analysis of the LockFile ransomware which uses a novel approach to file encryption.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransomware Family:** LockFile
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unspecified
  *  ** **Initial Infection Vector:**** Microsoft Exchange ProxyShell vulnerabilities
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** PetitPotam NTLM relay attack, File encryption
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Emerging in July 2021, and according to Sophos, LockFile implements a novel approach to encrypting files. Instead of encrypting the whole file, it only encrypts chunks of the file. This technique may help evade detection by some ransomware protection systems due to the encrypted files looking statistically similar to an unencrypted file. LockFile has been used in attacks that exploited vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-34473, CVE-2021-34523, and CVE-2021-31207) in on-premise Microsoft Exchange servers to gain access to a system. Next, the PetitPotam NTLM relay attack has been used to gain control of the domain. LockFile attacks are human-operated, rather than automated. Files encrypted by LockFile are renamed using lowercase and have the extension .lockfile added to them. The ransom note directs the user to a ToR website to pay the ransom and obtain a decrypter. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127177/An%20Analysis%20of%20the%20LockFile%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630910608951&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/08/27/lockfile-ransomwares-box-of-tricks-intermittent-encryption-and-evasion/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1187 - Forced Authentication  
T1557 - Man-in-the-Middle  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1104 - Multi-Stage Channels

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Hydromac macOS Malware
Confiant located new macOS malware that, due to the file and C&C server names, they dubbed MapperState. After investigation, it turns out that MapperState is actually a Hydromac Root Agent.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The MapperState malware was found installed in a Confient honeypot. It had been installed by a combination of the OSX/Bundlore loader which installed OSX/Tarmac that in turn installed MapperState. Both MapperState and Tarmac use similar techniques to slow analysis. Of note is that the OSX/Bundlore loader is ARM-compatible and notarized by Apple. Given that MapperState has the ability to download and install other applications, its purpose is probably that of a loader. It also checks for installed anti-virus solutions. Searching for strings obtained from analyzing OSX/Tarmac, Confiant researchers located a flashcards app that had made public OSX/Tarmac Agent and C&C commands. Further searching of flashcards published using the same account led to flashcards containing Hydromac messages that were identical to those in MapperState. This led to the conclusion that MapperState is actually a Hydromac Root Agent. There are also a Hydromac Agent and a Hydromac Agent Plugin. It was also found that a C&C server used by older malware named Mughthesec was also used by the Hydromac Agent. Confiant concludes that the Hydromac Root Agent (MapperState), Hydromac Agent, and Mughthesec, have all been used in malware campaigns carried out through malvertising affiliates. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.confiant.com/osx-hydromac-a-new-macos-malware-leaked-from-a-flashcards-app-2af28f1caa9e>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: TimeTime Ransomware
Researchers at Minerva Labs analyzed a new, simple ransomware family named TimeTime attempting to receive ransomware via prepaid vouchers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type** : Ransomware
  *  **Targets** : Unknown
  *  **Ransomware Family** : TimeTime
  *  **RaaS Operation** : No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector** : Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions** : Data encryption



# Overview

Minerva Labs published their analysis of a new ransomware named TimeTime. This ransomware is very unsophisticated, with a low ransom demand, simple encryption routine, and no obfuscation. Upon execution, volume shadow copies are deleted to inhibit recovery. Then the encryption process begins, with the name of every file encrypted being added to a custom registry key. The ransom note dropped on the system requests that victims purchase a prepaid voucher from Paysafecard in order to retrieve their files. The purchased voucher codes are requested via a decryption utility that is also dropped by the ransomware. The researchers point out that while the ransom note claims victim data was also stolen and will be leaked if the ransom is note paid, there is no evidence that the ransomware payload is capable of performing exfiltration. For more information, see the Minerva Labs blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056432/TimeTime%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640628198948&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.minerva-labs.com/meet-the-timetime-ransomware-the-ransomware-that-asks-for-100-via-paysafecard>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: BazarLoader Used to Deploy Diavol Ransomware
The DFIR Report has published their analysis of a ransomware attack that used the BazarLoader to deploy the Diavol ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: BazarLoader Used to Deploy Diavol Ransomware
The DFIR Report has published their analysis of a ransomware attack that used the BazarLoader to deploy the Diavol ransomware.

# Attack Details

  *  **Ransomware Family:** Diavol
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransom Demand:** Yes, Unspecified amount.
  *  **Intrusion Vector:** Spearphishing, Malicious link.
  *  **Data Exfiltrated:** Yes
  *  **Data Encrypted:** Yes
  *  **Data Published:** Unknown
  *  **Additional TTPs: **See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

BazarLoader is known for being used to deploy the Ryuk and Conti ransomware. The DFIR Report has published an analysis of an attack in which BazarLoader was used to deploy the Diavol ransomware. The initial compromise was achieved using a spearphishing email that contained a link to OneDrive which directed the victim to a ZIP file that contained an ISO file. Inside the ISO was an LNK file and a DLL, the victim executing the LNK file initiating the BazarLoader infection. Multiple rounds of reconnaissance were conducted using various tools and multiple Cobalt Strike beacons were deployed on the initially compromised host. Eventually, the actor moved laterally via RDP to a host that contained shared files and installed AnyDesk and Filezilla which was used to exfiltrate data. Multiple techniques were used in attempts to obtain credentials and the actor moved on to critical hosts such as domain controllers and backup servers. On many hosts, AnyDesk was installed, and RDP access to all endpoints from the compromised central file server was established. The actual act of encrypting drives took place some 40 hours after the initial compromise and began with the execution of a batch file that stopped all services on a host, removed the Volume Shadow copies, and disabled the Windows automatic startup repair. RDP was then used to copy the Diavol ransomware executable to each system and then executed manually. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056137/BazarLoader%20Used%20to%20Deploy%20Diavol%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639554380135&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A list of Yara rules can be found here: [ YaraRules.txt](/download/attachments/74056137/BazarLoader%20Used%20to%20Deploy%20Diavol%20Ransomware%20YaraRules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639554402803&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2021/12/13/diavol-ransomware/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1197 - BITS Jobs  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1552.002 - Credentials in Registry  
T1558 - Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets  
T1558.003 - Kerberoasting  
T1558.004 - AS-REP Roasting  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1069 - Permission Groups Discovery  
T1069.002 - Domain Groups  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1135 - Network Share Discovery  
T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.001 - Remote Desktop Protocol  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service  
T1567.002 - Exfiltration to Cloud Storage  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Exposed Kubeflow Interfaces Used to Run Cryptomining Containers
A new campaign has been targeting exposed Kubeflow interfaces to install containers that carry out cryptocurrency mining according to a a report from a researcher at Cloud Security Research.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

In late May, Cloud Security Research observed an increase in deployments of TensorFlow pods on a number Kubernetes clusters. The deployments were simultaneous, which according to Cloud Security Research, indicates the targets were scanned prior and the attacks staged to execute at the same time. To carry out the attack, the attackers targeted exposed instances of Kubeflow's centralized dashboard. Two cryptomining pods were installed on each cluster. One being the Ethminer which uses the GPU for mining, the other being XMRIG which uses the CPU. Prior to the commencement of cryptomining, a pod was installed which provided the attacker's information on the environment such as CPU and GPU information. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/azure-security-center/new-large-scale-campaign-targets-kubeflow/ba-p/2425750>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Fake Roblox Package Used to Install Ransomware
Sonatype researchers have uncovered fake Roblox packages are being used to install malware that, in turn, installs ransomware on victim machines.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Fake Roblox Package Used to Install Ransomware
Sonatype researchers have uncovered fake Roblox packages are being used to install malware that, in turn, installs ransomware on victim machines.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Typosquatting
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** DarkDev or DarkDev1
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Monster Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Users of Roblox
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Typosquatted URL for installation of Roblox API
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Drops obfuscated Batch script, alter registry, drops trojan, and ransomware
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

Researchers from Sonatype have uncovered fake npm Roblox API packages being used to install malware and ransomware. Through the use of open source ecosystems, threat actors are able to deploy ransomware using PyPl, npm, and Rubygems. Noblox.js uses open-source JavaScript API for the creation of in-game scripts. At present, Noblox.js-proxy and Noblox.js-proxies have seen 387 total downloads of these malicious, typosquatted packages. The typosquats lead to Noblox's README page. The page appears normal but contains a section of obfuscated code that installs postinstall.js. This drops a Batch script that, in turn, is used to contact a C2 server for the download of the final payload, trojans and ransomware named Monster Ransomware. Attribution to DarkDev or DarkDev1 has been made at this point. Further technical details can be found within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616961/Fake%20Roblox%20Package%20Used%20to%20Install%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635430903028&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 
  * Leave Safe Browsing warnings on.



# References

  * <https://blog.sonatype.com/fake-npm-roblox-api-package-installs-ransomware-spooky-surprise>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.004 - Credential API Hooking  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.004 - Credential API Hooking  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: OMIGOD Vulnerabilities being exploited by Mirai
A group of new high severity vulnerabilities affecting Azure has been disclosed. Since these were made public, there has been an increasing number of IPs scanning and attempting to exploit them, including
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Azure Customers **  
**
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Mirai
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** OMIGOD Vulnerabilities on Azure
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Privilege Escalation



# Overview

The Mirai botnet has been observed exploiting a high severity vulnerability in the wild. Various researchers on Twitter have reported an increasing number of IPs opportunistically scanning and subsequently exploiting the recently reported vulnerabilities which are being collectively tracked as OMIGOD. These four vulnerabilities allow attackers to remotely execute code or escalate privileges on vulnerable virtual machines running on Azure. The vulnerabilities affect the Open Management Infrastructure (OMI) software agent, which runs as root, and is automatically run when certain services are deployed. It has been estimated that these vulnerabilities could affect thousands of Azure customers and expose millions of endpoints to attack. One researcher, Kevin Beaumont, has reported seeing the Mirai botnet actively exploiting these vulnerabilities, before closing port 5896 to prevent other actors from exploiting the same host. The OMIGOD collection of vulnerabilities has since been patched, and Microsoft is urging all customers to update vulnerable deployments. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128592/OMIGOD%20Vulnerabilities%20being%20exploited%20by%20Mirai%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632751756249&api=v2)



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/64128592/OMIGOD%20Vulnerabilities%20being%20exploited%20by%20Mirai%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632739729074&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Regularly scan externally facing systems for vulnerabilities and establish procedures to rapidly patch systems when critical vulnerabilities are discovered through scanning and through public disclosure (M1051).  


  * Segment externally facing servers and services from the rest of the network with a DMZ or on separate hosting infrastructure (M1030).
  * Efforts should focus on minimizing the amount and sensitivity of data available to external parties (M1056). _  
_
  * Develop a robust cyber threat intelligence capability to determine what types and levels of threat may use software exploits and 0-days against a particular organization (M1019 ).



# References

  * <https://securityaffairs.co/wordpress/122322/hacking/omigod-mirai-botnet.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Stalkerware on Android Platform
Stalkerware apps are becoming increasingly more popular on Android platforms. WeLiveSecurity has published a white paper on the proliferation of these malicious apps.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Stalkerware on Android Platform
Stalkerware apps are becoming increasingly more popular on Android platforms. WeLiveSecurity has published a white paper on the proliferation of these malicious apps.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Stalkerware




# Overview

WeLiveSecurity has analyze 86 apps from 86 different vendors classified as "stalkerware." In their report, researchers detail a multitude of security and privacy issues that exist with these applications. Actions such as controlling a victim device, taking over the account of the victim, intercepting data, framing the victim using fabricated evidence, and/or remote code execution on Android OS-based devices are all possible. Within their research, 58 applications had a total of 158 security and privacy issues. Only six of the vendors tested have fixed issues associated with the report, forty-four have failed to reply, seven promised fixes in upcoming releases, and one decided to ignore the problem and not address the security and privacy concerns. Infection typically is fast if the stalker has physical access to the victim's device(s). Speculation is that most of these threat actors are someone within the victim's family or social/work circles. The stalker must also have unlock capabilities or the device must have PINs or patterns disable. Finally, the stalker must deactivate the protection measures on the device in order to achieve their goal, whatever that may be. The stalker must configure the app and synchronize it with their monitoring service, and, presumably, root permissions must be obtained. It should be noted that there are actually three components to stalkerware. One is the attacker, another the stalker, and finally the victim. The attacker uses the stalker's account and obtained information to carry out further actions on the device. For more detailed information, please see the white paper located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/eset_android_stalkerware.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Agent Tesla Remote Access Trojan (RAT) Steals More for Less in Version 3
SophosLabs reveals more advanced methods being used in the latest version of the Agent Tesla remote access trojan. This latest version is better at evading detection and communicates in additional ways.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Agent Tesla Remote Access Trojan (RAT) Steals More for Less in Version 3
SophosLabs reveals more advanced methods being used in the latest version of the Agent Tesla remote access trojan. This latest version is better at evading detection and communicates in additional ways.

# Threat Type

  * RAT, Bot, Infostealer




# Overview

SophosLabs reports on the enhancements made in Agent Tesla version 3 over version 2. This remote access trojan (RAT) has the goal of stealing credentials from a variety of applications. Agent Tesla usually arrives as a malicious attachment in email spam. The latest version, version 3, has increased methods to avoid detection, added the ability to use a TOR proxy, and provides the option of Telegram chat protocol where exfiltrated data can be sent to a private telegram chat room. Agent Tesla uses a number of methods to make sandbox and static analysis more difficult. For example, it will grab chunks of base64-encoded, obfuscated code for the next stage from websites such as Pastebin and hastebin. Further technical information can be found in the report listed within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/02/02/agent-tesla-amps-up-information-stealing-attacks/>

  * <https://github.com/sophoslabs/IoCs/blob/master/Troj-AgentTesla.csv>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: An Analysis of APT29's Backdoor - MiniDuke
The newest variant of the backdoor known as MiniDuke has been analyzed by a researcher at CyberGeek.tech. This backdoor has been in use for a long time, but this is the first time this variant from 2019 has been fully analyzed publicly.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: An Analysis of APT29's Backdoor - MiniDuke
The newest variant of the backdoor known as MiniDuke has been analyzed by a researcher at CyberGeek.tech. This backdoor has been in use for a long time, but this is the first time this variant from 2019 has been fully analyzed publicly.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT29 (G0016), ITG11
  *  **Targets:** Government Entities
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** MiniDuke (S0051)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

A researcher at Cybergeeks.tech has analyzed a new variant of the MiniDuke malware that is currently being used by APT29. APT29 is a threat actor known by many names including Cozy Bear, CozyDuke, Cozys, Dark Halo, Duke Group, Hammertoss, Minis, Office Monkeys, Pitty Tiger, Spikerrush, StellarParticle, TEMP.Monkey, TEMP.Noble, The Dukes, TG-4127, UNC2452, and Yttrium. IBM X-Force tracks NOBELIUM as ITG11. They are associated with Russia's Foreign Intelligence service and are believed to be behind the high-profile SolarWinds compromise in 2020. MiniDuke is a backdoor generally used by APT29 as a second-stage backdoor, with the newest version being seen in 2019. The analysis mainly focuses on the communications between the malware and the C2 server, and details three different modes of communication. If the machine does not have internet access, the malware will open a named pipe and use it to connect to another machine in the network which does have internet access and use this as a proxy to exfiltrate data. There is a command for an instance of MiniDuke to set up a named pipe and listen for connections if another machine in the network requires it. If it does have internet access, the malware can exfiltrate data via either POST or PUT requests. On top of exfiltration, the malware can receive commands to manipulate files and processes and has been used as a dropper in past campaigns. ATP 29 has previously used this malware in attacks on government entities in different countries in Europe and the United States. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129834/An%20Analysis%20of%20APT29%27s%20Backdoor%20-%20MiniDuke%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633695923433&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).

An Analysis of APT29's Backdoor - MiniDuke
The newest variant of the backdoor known as MiniDuke has been analyzed by a researcher at CyberGeek.tech. This backdoor has been in use for a long time, but this is the first time this variant from 2019 has been fully analyzed publicly.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT29 (G0016), ITG11
  *  **Targets:** Government Entities
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** MiniDuke (S0051)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

A researcher at Cybergeeks.tech has analyzed a new variant of the MiniDuke malware that is currently being used by APT29. APT29 is a threat actor known by many names including Cozy Bear, CozyDuke, Cozys, Dark Halo, Duke Group, Hammertoss, Minis, Office Monkeys, Pitty Tiger, Spikerrush, StellarParticle, TEMP.Monkey, TEMP.Noble, The Dukes, TG-4127, UNC2452, and Yttrium. IBM X-Force tracks NOBELIUM as ITG11. They are associated with Russia's Foreign Intelligence service and are believed to be behind the high-profile SolarWinds compromise in 2020. MiniDuke is a backdoor generally used by APT29 as a second-stage backdoor, with the newest version being seen in 2019. The analysis mainly focuses on the communications between the malware and the C2 server, and details three different modes of communication. If the machine does not have internet access, the malware will open a named pipe and use it to connect to another machine in the network which does have internet access and use this as a proxy to exfiltrate data. There is a command for an instance of MiniDuke to set up a named pipe and listen for connections if another machine in the network requires it. If it does have internet access, the malware can exfiltrate data via either POST or PUT requests. On top of exfiltration, the malware can receive commands to manipulate files and processes and has been used as a dropper in past campaigns. ATP 29 has previously used this malware in attacks on government entities in different countries in Europe and the United States. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TA551 Campaign Switches from Valak to IcedID
TA551 campaigns have previously been observed distributing Ursnif and Valak. Recently, however, Palo Alto researchers have observed campaigns delivering IcedID instead.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Stealer 




# Overview

Palo Alto has published a blog post analyzing a change in the payload distributed by TA551 campaigns. TA551 is the designation given to a malspam distribution campaign aimed at delivering information stealing malware. The infection chain is similar regardless of the final payload. It begins with a password-protected ZIP archive attached to an email. Inside the ZIP archive is a Word document containing malicious macros designed to download an installer DLL. Finally, the main binary is downloaded by the installer DLL, persistence is established, and post-infection traffic begins. In 2019, the final payload was Ursnif. In early to mid-2020, ZLoader and Valak were both seen being distributed. Most recently, TA551 has been delivering IcedID. Even since the introduction of IcedID as the final payload, minor changes have been made to IcedID campaigns, such as the file names and paths and the run method for DLLs. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/ta551-shathak-icedid/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Operation NightScout
Operation NightScout is a supply‑chain attack discovered by ESET that has been targeting Asian users of an Android emulator named NoxPlayer.
output:
is a supply‑chain attack discovered by ESET that has been targeting Asian users of an Android emulator named NoxPlayer.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A report from ESET deals with a a supply chain attack that targeted online gamers in Asia. The objective of the attack appears to be surveillance or espionage, rather than a direct financial motivation. ESET have named the operation "NightScout". The update system for an Android emulator named NoxPlayer, which is available for PCs and Macs, was compromised, and malicious updates could be provided to NoxPlayer users. ESET first observed suspicious activity related to NoxPlayer in September 2020; however, definitive evidence was not available until January 2021. At that point, ESET informed the company who produce NoxPlayer. According to ESET's report, the company denied being affected. The report also notes that ESET telemetry shows about 100K of ESET's users having NoxPlayer installed but only five users are reported to have received the malicious updates. This demonstrates that the campaign is very tightly targeted, with the victims being located in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Sri Lanka. Three variants of the malicious updates have been observed. Further information is available from the ESET report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/02/01/operation-nightscout-supply-chain-attack-online-gaming-asia/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TunnelVision Exploiting VMware Horizon
TunnelVision is an Iranian-aligned threat actor operating in the Middle East and United States. SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing the group's exploitation of VMware Horizon in recent campaigns.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TunnelVision Exploiting VMware Horizon
TunnelVision is an Iranian-aligned threat actor operating in the Middle East and United States. SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing the group's exploitation of VMware Horizon in recent campaigns.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Reverse shell
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TunnelVision
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PowerShell reverse shell
  *  **Targets:** Middle East, United States
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of VMware Horizon servers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote command execution, credential harvesting, lateral movement



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing TunnelVision and their recent activity. TunnelVision, an Iranian-aligned threat actor operating in the Middle East and United States, is known for their use of 1-day vulnerability exploits and tunneling tools. In recent cases, they have used the Log4Shell exploit to target VMware Horizon servers. The exploit is used to execute PowerShell commands that will download files and return command outputs via a webhook. The group additionally uses PowerShell reverse shells to perform further post-compromise actions. Two different reverse shells were identified that ultimately provided backdoor access, allowing TunnelVision to execute recon commands, add a backdoor user, harvest credentials, tunnel RDP traffic, and deploy further reverse shells. The researchers noted an overlap between this group and those called Phosphorus by Microsoft and Charming Kitten or Nemesis Kitten by CrowdStrike. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74059306/TunnelVision%20Exploiting%20VMware%20Horizon%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645640136017&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Update VMware Horizon to patch the Log4j vulnerability.
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/log4j2-in-the-wild-iranian-aligned-threat-actor-tunnelvision-actively-exploiting-vmware-horizon/>

T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning

T1608.002 - Upload Tool

 **Execution - TA0002**

T1059.001 - PowerShell

T1136 - Create Account  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
T1543.003 - Windows Service  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
T1003.002 - Security Account Manager  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.001 - Remote Desktop Protocol  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

T1572 - Protocol Tunneling

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: The IISerpent SEO Trojan
ESET has published a report on a server-side Trojan named IISerpent that carries out a form of SEO fraud.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: The IISerpent SEO Trojan
ESET has published a report on a server-side Trojan named IISerpent that carries out a form of SEO fraud.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** IISerpent SEO Trojan
  *  **Targets:** Microsoft IIS Servers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Manipulating server responses to search engine queries, **** Execution (TA0002, T1569, T1569.002), Persistence (TA0003, T1546), Command and Control (TA0011, T1071, T1071.001)
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Resource Development (TA0042, T1587, T1587.001), Impact (TA0040, T1565, T1565.002)



# Overview

According to a report from ESET, IISerpent is a Trojan that runs as an extension on IIS servers. It conducts a form of SEO fraud by manipulating the server's HTTP responses to search engine crawlers. The manipulation is achieved by intercepting all HHTP requests to the server and modifying the responses to include a list of backlinks, or redirect the search engines to another site chosen by IISerpent’s operators. The backlinks and redirections are controlled by IISerpent’s configuration or through relaying the search engine's request to its C&C server to obtain instructions. The beneficiary of the search engine manipulation is an unrelated third-party site chosen by the IISerpent operators. Normal traffic to and from an infected IIS server is not changed as it is ignored by IISerpent. ESET was unaware of how the infected servers were initially compromised to allow the installation of the IISerpent extension. Further information, including a technical analysis of IISerpent, is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/61374568/The%20IISerpent%20SEO%20Trojan%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629162112536&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/08/11/iiserpent-malware-driven-seo-fraud-service/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Agent Tesla Delivered via WIM Archives
Archive files are commonly used by attackers to hide their malware from detection by email security gateways. Trustwave discovered the use of WIM (Windows Imaging Format) to deliver Agent Tesla to victims.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Trustwave published a blog post analyzing the use of WIM (Windows Imaging Format) files to deliver the Agent Tesla RAT. The emails spotted with WIM attachments spoofed courier companies and claimed the attachment is an invoice. The WIM file format can be opened using an archiving tool, such as 7Zip, PowerISO, or PeaZip. If successfully opened, an executable file is extracted. All samples analyzed by Trustwave were delivering the Agent Telsa malware. This malware is a .NET RAT providing remote access to its operator with a focus on exfiltrating sensitive data. By being carried in an archive, the chances of an email security gateway detecting the payload are decreased. Organizations, however, should consider WIM files attached to emails suspicious and monitor accordingly. For more information, see the Trustwave blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Monitor for suspicious file formats attached to emails, such as WIM files.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trustwave.com/en-us/resources/blogs/spiderlabs-blog/another-archive-format-smuggling-malware/>

# Threat Type

# Overview

Trend Micro discovered a credential stealing campaign that began in early 2020. The campaign has mainly targeted the customers of Canadian and U.S. banks. A malicious Excel file is used to kick off the infection chain by using a VBA AutoOpen macro to drop an AHK script compiler and an AHK script file. AHK is an open-source scripting language that runs on Windows. When the compiler is executed, it runs the script which is a client for downloading and executing further AHK payloads. It is also used for creating persistence by creating an autorun link in the startup folder and profiling the victim system. Commands issued to the malware by its C&C server are downloaded as individual scripts for each task. This means there is no single, large payload on the victim system and allows the operator to create custom commands for victims as required. The malware's primary function is to steal credentials from victims' browsers. The browsers it targets include Edge, Internet Explorer, Chrome, Firefox, and Opera. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/l/stealth-credential-stealer-targets-us-canadian-bank-customers.html>

I have encountered the following information: Shadow Domains: Credential Stealing Campaign Targets German Telecom Customers
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence discovered a credential stealing campaign that aims to steal customer login credentials of a German telecommunications company. The campaign likely began June 2020 and, as of December 2020, was still active.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Credential Stealing




# Overview

IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence discovered a phishing campaign focused on stealing credentials belonging to the customers of a German-based telecommunications company. The researchers estimate the campaign began June 2020 and is still active (as of January 2021). Evidence was also indicating that there is a mobile device element to this campaign, although the details of this portion of the campaign is unclear. It is assessed that one possible reason for this campaign is to gain unauthorized account access in order to add malicious domain/subdomain forwarding and masking entries to existing, legitimate accounts. The full story, including indicators of compromise, is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.   


# Recommendations

  * Use complex account passwords that are at least 12-14 characters in length and are a combination of letters (upper and lower case), numbers and special characters
  * If possible, enable MFA.
  * View any unsolicited SMS message with suspicion, especially any that encourage clicking an unfamiliar link.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IOCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IOCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Do not install unapproved apps on a device that has access to the corporate network.



# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/320c373b-9775-49df-b3e4-89c2230532a0>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ransomware Ads Being Banned at a Rapid Pace
Hot on the heels of the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack, cybercrime forums, threat groups, and others are reevaluating their business model. According to several reports of varying sources, even Darkside has claimed to have taken itself offline.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ransomware Ads Being Banned at a Rapid Pace
Hot on the heels of the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack, cybercrime forums, threat groups, and others are reevaluating their business model. According to several reports of varying sources, even Darkside has claimed to have taken itself offline.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Due to what is being described as indiscriminate targeting, many forums, repos, and even some threat groups are taking steps to ensure a "proper vetting" of targets occurs prior to attack. The forums and repos have gone so far as to ban any ransomware ads placed on the sites. Any type of ad touting ransomware is removed. Leading the way in this effort is the XSS Russian-speaking forum. RaaS gangs such as REvil, LockBit, DarkSide, Netwalker, Nefilim, Babuk, and others have been using these forums to recruit new members, partners, and affiliates. The owner of XSS feels that ransomware is bringing "unwanted attention to the site and has become dangerous and toxic," according to a quote obtained by Bleeping Computer. Many of the RaaS gangs are purportedly leaving the forums for others that are more welcoming of their type of activity, such as exploit.in. This move will, most likely, be a temporary one as more and more forums are banning these gangs/actors. Forum admins have also stated they will remove all ransomware-related topics as well as affiliate programs. 

In a surprise move, DarkSide has claimed to have ceased operations. This closure is a result of the attack on the Colonial Pipeline that caused major interruptions in the flow of petroleum to large sections of the eastern United States. DarkSide has released a "press release" stating they are apolitical and will vet targets before any future attacks. Colonial Pipeline reportedly paid nearly $5M in cryptocurrency to obtain a decryption key from the actors. One well-known threat actor, UNKN, stated the operations ceased due to the loss of access to the public data leak site, payment servers, and CDN servers "at the request of law enforcement agencies," and cryptocurrency being moved to an unknown wallet. DarkSide has confirmed UNKN's claims. DarkSide also announced the requirement of providing decryption keys to each target that have been attacked and would compensate all financial obligations by May 23, 2021. 

REvil has imposed new restrictions on the targeting of entities. Affiliates are now required to obtain permission in order to target an organization. According to the representative of REvil, health care, education, etc. are all prohibited targets as are government sectors of any country. Further information can be found in the links located within the Reference section below. 

# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/ransomware-ads-now-also-banned-on-exploit-cybercrime-forum/>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/darkside-ransomware-servers-reportedly-seized-operation-shuts-down/>
  * <https://www.intel471.com/blog/darkside-ransomware-shut-down-revil-avaddon-cybercrime>
  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/popular-russian-hacking-forum-xss-bans-all-ransomware-topics/>

Hot on the heels of the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack, cybercrime forums, threat groups, and others are reevaluating their business model. According to several reports of varying sources, even Darkside has claimed to have taken itself offline.
