instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ESPecter - A Persistant UEFI Bootkit
A report from ESET provides their analysis of a UEFI bootkit they've named ESPecter that is able to persist on the EFI System Partition.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ESPecter - A Persistant UEFI Bootkit
A report from ESET provides their analysis of a UEFI bootkit they've named ESPecter that is able to persist on the EFI System Partition.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** UEFI Bootkit
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** ESPecter
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

ESPecter, named by ESET who discovered it, is a UEFI bootkit that traces its roots back to 2012 when it was a legacy BIOS bootkit. According to ESET the major change in the bootkit was the move to targeting UEFI systems with little other change in ESPecter's components. The sample analyzed by ESET was found on a compromised system. Also found was a user-mode client component that has the ability to log keystrokes and steal documents. ESET believes that ESPecter is primarily used for espionage. The method used to distribute ESPecter remains unknown. To achieve the infection of a system, a legitimate Windows Boot Manager binary is modified to allow the attacker to execute ESPecter early in the boot process and provides the ability to bypass Windows Driver Signature Enforcement allowing ESPecter to load its unsigned driver. However, Secure Boot must be disabled for this to work on Windows 8 and later. Secure Boot is not supported on versions of Windows prior to Windows 8. ESET has been unable to determine how the attackers were able to disable Secure Boot but note that they could have achieved it through having physical access to the system, Secure Boot may have already been disabled, or by exploiting a vulnerability in the UEFI firmware. The driver is used to load two user-mode payloads, WinSys.dll and Client.dll, which are used to log keystrokes, take screenshots, collect and exfiltrate documents, handle C&C communications, and can download further payloads. ESET was not able to attribute ESPecter to a known threat actor but given that there are debug messages in Chinese in the user-mode client component, it is possibly the work of an unknown Chinese-speaking actor. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129821/ESPecter%20-%20A%20Persistant%20UEFI%20Bootkit%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633658531914&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/10/05/uefi-threats-moving-esp-introducing-especter-bootkit/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1106 - Native API  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1542 - Pre-OS Boot  
T1542.003 - Bootkit  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1036.003 - Rename System Utilities  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.003 - Time Based Evasion  
T1542 - Pre-OS Boot  
T1542.003 - Bootkit  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.006 - Code Signing Policy Modification  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
T1564.001 - Hidden Files and Directories  
T1564.005 - Hidden File System  
T1601 - Modify System Image  
T1601.001 - Patch System Image  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1010 - Application Window Discovery  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1120 - Peripheral Device Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1025 - Data from Removable Media  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1029 - Scheduled Transfer  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1104 - Multi-Stage Channels  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Cyber Espionage Campaign - CostaRicto
The BlackBerry Research and Intelligence team named a cyber espionage campaign they have been tracking "CostaRicto". The targets of the campaign have been located in Africa, the Americas, Asia, Australia, and Europe, with no apparent focus on a particular industry sector, although a number of the victims have been financial institutions.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cyber Espionage Campaign




# Overview

CostaRicto is a cyber espionage campaign that has been named, and tracked, by the BlackBerry Research and Intelligence team for some months. According to the BlackBerry team, the threat actors behind the campaign may be a mercenary APT group, hired to carry out the campaign. This conclusion is due to several factors including custom malware and tooling, and the VPN proxy and SSH tunnelling methods used, which are described as "complex". The vector used to gain initial access to the victim systems is unknown but the presumption is through stolen credentials, possibly obtained on the black market or through phishing attacks. Once the attackers have gained access to a system, SSH tunnels are established and a payload stager is executed using a scheduled task. The backdoor that is installed is named SombRAT, and it communicates with its C&C servers using DNS tunneling. C&C traffic is encrypted using RSA-2048, domains are hard coded, and subdomains are generated using a domain generation algorithm. It is delivered in one of two ways. The first is within a PowerSploit reflective loader. The second is a custom dropper employing a virtual machine mechanism that decodes and then installs the payload. Further details and a detailed technical analysis is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.blackberry.com/en/2020/11/the-costaricto-campaign-cyber-espionage-outsourced>

I have encountered the following information: TSA PreCheck Scam
A post on the Abnormal Security blog reports a TSA PreCheck scam that was discovered on November 9.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** TSA PreCheck users.
  *  **Lure:** TSA PreCheck membership renewal.
  *  **Payload:** Phishing page.
  *  **Compromised Data:** Significant PII



# Overview

Phishing emails are being used to conduct a TSA PreCheck scam. Abnormal Security discovered the scam on November 9. The emails advise the recipient that their TSA PreCheck program will expire in six months but that they can renew now using the instructions and link provided in the email. The link in the email Abnormal analyzed led to the domain airportscreening[.]com. If a victim follows through the application process, they will be asked to provide a significant amount of personal information including all previous names, place of birth, all addresses from the past five years, criminal history, and passport number. They will be informed there are two parts to the process, their application which is payable through PayPal, and a subsequent security interview which is payable at the interview. The page notes that the victim will be contacted to finalize their interview scheduling, which may take several weeks. They are eventually taken to a PayPal page with the details for the charge prefilled. The site even has a refund policy page but notes that filing a dispute or issuing a chargeback could result in a delay of weeks to any refund. Of course, it's all a scam and the timeframes provide the attackers breathing space before victims discover they've been defrauded. Abnormal also provide some information on the entities that are potentially behind the scam. See the Abnormal blog post link in the Reference section below for more details. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155220/TSA%20PreCheck%20Scam%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637815886544&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://abnormalsecurity.com/blog/tsa-precheck-scam>

 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1119 - Automated Collection

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: AvosLocker Ransomware Behavior
A report from Qualys provides a behavior analysis of the Windows and Linux versions of the AvosLocker ransomware.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomeware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransomware Family:** AvosLocker
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malspam, Proxyshell vulnerabilities.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data exfiltration, file encryption.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

AvosLocker is a ransomware-as-a-service offering that first appeared in mid-2021. Its affiliates are provided access to a control panel and the operators offer many services including DDoS attacks. AvosLocker initially offered Windows ransomware but has also added a variant that targets Linux machines. A report from Qualys notes that AvosLocker is spread using spam emails, earlier reporting from another vendor notes that in January the AvosLocker operators or affiliates were exploiting the Microsoft Exchange Proxyshell vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-34473, CVE-2021-31206, CVE-2021-34523, and CVE-2021-31207) to gain access to systems. The Qualys report provides a listing of the command line options available for both the Linux and Windows versions and details of the encryption process, data from the victim system is exfiltrated prior to encryption. The ransom notes left on the encrypted systems provide a unique ID for the victim and instructions to connect to the AvosLocker TOR site to make a payment to obtain a decryption key. The site notes that if the victim does not pay the ransom, their data will be offered for sale. Further information is available from the Qualys report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81134277/AvosLocker%20Ransomware%20Behavior%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1646708831450&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.qualys.com/vulnerabilities-threat-research/2022/03/06/avoslocker-ransomware-behavior-examined-on-windows-linux>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Hartford School District Hit by Ransomware
Breach Notification: Hartford School District in Connecticut has postponed their first day of school due to a cyber attack. According to a statement issued by the school district, a ransomware attack caused system outages preventing them from being able to operate the schools.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Hartford School District Hit by Ransomware
Breach Notification: Hartford School District in Connecticut has postponed their first day of school due to a cyber attack. According to a statement issued by the school district, a ransomware attack caused system outages preventing them from being able to operate the schools.

# Threat Type

  * Breach




# Overview

Hartford School District in Connecticut issued a statement informing the public that the schools would delay opening due to critical systems being down after a ransomware attack. Specifically, they note that the system that organizes bus routes was unable to be restored in time for schools opening. The following is part of the statement published on the school district's website:

"We have been informed by Metro Hartford Information Services (MHIS), our City of Hartford shared services team that manages our network infrastructure, that the ransomware virus caused an outage of critical systems and the restoration of those systems are not complete. This includes the system that communicates our transportation routes to our bus company and it is preventing our ability to operate schools on Tuesday."

BleepingComputer reports that the ransomware family is rumored to be Hermes. Additionally, the mayor of Hartford has stated that no data was stolen to their knowledge and there is no plan to pay a ransom, although supposedly no ransom demand was given as part of the attack. Further details can be found in BleepingComputer's report in the Reference section.

# Reference

  * <https://www.hartfordschools.org/hps-opening-postponed-tuesday-sept-8/>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/ransomware-delays-first-day-of-school-for-hartford-connecticut/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: WooCommerce Skimmer Spoofs Checkout Page
A compromise of a client website led Sucuri to uncover a WooCommerce skimmer spoofing a checkout page to steal credit card details.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Malicious JavaScript code
  *  **Targets:** E-commerce customers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Compromised admin credentials
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft



# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing a WooCommerce skimmer spoofing a checkout page for the purpose of credit card detail theft. Interestingly, the victim site was not an e-commerce platform; however, due to the skimmer looking for a "my-account" keyword which was present on the site, it successfully loaded. When the keyword condition is met, JavaScript code inserted into the themes header.php file is executed and loads malicious JavaScript from a remote server. The domain hosting this malicious code masquerades as a jquery resource to evade detection. The JavaScript is responsible for rendering a fake checkout form that exfiltrates entered credit card details to the remote server. The incident investigation determined the likely infection vector was brute-forcing of a WordPress admin account. Additionally, a malicious user was found logged into the WordPress database at the time of investigation. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222180/WooCommerce%20Skimmer%20Spoofs%20Checkout%20Page%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636473577897&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use multi-factor authentication wherever possible. (M1032)
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)



# References

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/11/woocommerce-skimmer-spoofs-checkout-page.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1078.003 - Local Accounts  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1136 - Create Account  
T1136.001 - Local Account  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1110 - Brute Force  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: vjw0rm Leveraging New Obfuscation Technique
vjw0rm is a malicious JavaScript program capable of propagating across removable storage devices and receiving instructions from a C2 server. A SANS Internet Storm Center (ISC) researcher has identified a sample of this worm leveraging new obfuscation techniques.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Worm




# Overview

Although it has been around since 2018, a SANS ISC researcher has identified a recent version of the vjw0rm malware using new obfuscation techniques to avoid detection. The script was discovered being delivered by a phishing campaign. To perform obfuscation, a malicious data blob is passed to a custom decoding function. The malicious blob is comprised of a string of Unicode characters and the function translates each of the character codes of those characters to ASCII characters. Decoding part of the blob reveals some plaintext, such as a Registry key containing the string "vjw0rm," indicating this is a sample of the vjw0rm malware. Once on a system this worm connects to a C2 server from which it can receive a variety of commands. Additionally, its worming functionality allows it to spread across removable drives. For more information, see the SANS ISC blog post in the Reference section.

X-Force Threat Intelligence researchers used the information provided in the SANS ISC post to identify over a dozen additional samples and a few other C2 servers tied to this variant of the vjw0rm malware. The indicators of compromise (IoCs) identified are provided alongside this report.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/forums/diary/Old+Worm+But+New+Obfuscation+Technique/26792/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: DanaBot Used To DDoS Ukrainian Ministry of Defense
Zscaler has been tracking a threat actor using DanaBot to conduct a DDoS attack. This attack, targetting the Ukrainian MoD, began on the 2nd of March. It is unclear who the actor behind this attack is, as it could be hacktivism, something state sponsored, or a false-flag attack.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: DanaBot Used To DDoS Ukrainian Ministry of Defense
Zscaler has been tracking a threat actor using DanaBot to conduct a DDoS attack. This attack, targetting the Ukrainian MoD, began on the 2nd of March. It is unclear who the actor behind this attack is, as it could be hacktivism, something state sponsored, or a false-flag attack.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** DDoS
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian Ministry of Defense
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** DanaBot
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Denial of Service



# Overview

Zscaler has reported on a threat actor using DanaBot to launch a DDoS attack. The target was the Ukrainian Ministry of Defense's webmail server. DanaBot was first seen in 2018 and is a malware-as-a-service platform, meaning threat actors pay for access to the platform, which is managed by a third party. The affiliates are tracked using an affiliate ID, with the attacked behind the DDoS being tracked as affiliate 4. This DDoS began on the 2nd March, and the server is still online and reachable at the time the report was published. The attack was conducted using the download and execute command to download a simple executable. This executable implements an HTTP DDoS attack against a hard-coded target. A very similar executable was used in November 2021 in a DDoS attack against a Russian language electronics forum from affiliate 4. Although the timing and target of the attack suggests a relationship to the ongoing Ukraine crisis, the threat actor is currently unattributable. For more information please see the link in the references section. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81134155/DanaBot%20Used%20To%20DDoS%20Ukrainian%20Ministry%20of%20Defense%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1646654084072&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/danabot-launches-ddos-attack-against-ukrainian-ministry-defense>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service  
T1498.001 - Direct Network Flood

Zscaler has reported on a threat actor using DanaBot to launch a DDoS attack. The target was the Ukrainian Ministry of Defense's webmail server. DanaBot was first seen in 2018 and is a malware-as-a-service platform, meaning threat actors pay for access to the platform, which is managed by a third party. The affiliates are tracked using an affiliate ID, with the attacked behind the DDoS being tracked as affiliate 4. This DDoS began on the 2nd March, and the server is still online and reachable at the time the report was published. The attack was conducted using the download and execute command to download a simple executable. This executable implements an HTTP DDoS attack against a hard-coded target. A very similar executable was used in November 2021 in a DDoS attack against a Russian language electronics forum from affiliate 4. Although the timing and target of the attack suggests a relationship to the ongoing Ukraine crisis, the threat actor is currently unattributable. For more information please see the link in the references section. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81134155/DanaBot%20Used%20To%20DDoS%20Ukrainian%20Ministry%20of%20Defense%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1646654084072&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/danabot-launches-ddos-attack-against-ukrainian-ministry-defense>

T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Dridex Variant Delivered Via Phishing Emails
FortiGuard Labs has published a report that provides an analysis of a new variant of Dridex being delivered via phishing emails.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Dridex Variant Delivered Via Phishing Emails
FortiGuard Labs has published a report that provides an analysis of a new variant of Dridex being delivered via phishing emails.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Banking Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Dridex
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Excel file attached to a phishing email.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Data Exfiltration
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A new variant of Dridex has been discovered by FortiGuard Labs. The new variant is delivered using phishing emails with a malicious Excel file attached. The sample email shown in the FortiGuard report purports to be about updated US Import Tariffs. If the recipient opens the attached Excel file, and macros are enabled, data from certain cells in the Excel sheet are written to a local file. This file is an .hta file. The Excel file contains both an auto-run VBA macro and an Excel 4.0 Macro. The macros call mshta.exe to execute the .hta file which downloads the actual Dridex payload and using wmic.exe creates a new Rundll32 process which loads the Dridex payload. The anti-analysis techniques and C&C communications protocols are similar to prior variants of Dridex. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127542/New%20Dridex%20Variant%20Delivered%20Via%20Phishing%20Emails%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631510252409&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Banking Trojan Affecting Up To 100 Organizations in Brazil
Symantec Researchers have reported an ongoing campaign affecting organizations in Brazil, where users are being infected with a banking trojan which attempts to steal banking credentials.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Banking Trojan
  *  **Targets:** Banks, Brazil
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential Harvesting



# Overview

Symantec has published details on a campaign targeting up to 100 organizations in Brazil. This activity has been ongoing since late August 2021, with attacks occurring as recently as October. Researchers have attributed this activity to the same actors as were reported by ESET in 2020. The campaign involves a banking trojan, which is prevalent in South American cybercrime. The trojan will sit on the victim's computer and monitor their online activities. Once the user navigates to a URL that matches a hardcoded list of URLs, it will replace the web page with a false login screen in an attempt to harvest the victim's banking credentials. The initial infection vector is unknown, but it is speculated that this will have come from a phishing campaign or malvertising. From these links, the victims are then redirected to an AWS URL, where an MSI file is downloaded. If the victim runs this file, a secondary C2 server is contacted to download a zip file containing a malicious DLL, as well as other legitimate executables. This malicious DLL is a large file to avoid scanning by antivirus software and uses search-order hijacking to load the malicious code. It then uses Windows Registry or Windows Management Instrumentation to achieve persistence. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616948/Banking%20Trojan%20Affecting%20Up%20To%20100%20Organizations%20in%20Brazil%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635417609563&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 



# References

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/banking-trojan-latam-brazil>

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1546 - Event Triggered Execution  
T1546.003 - Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.001 - Dynamic-link Library Injection  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**

T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.002 - GUI Input Capture

# Threat Details

  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** FIN8
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Sardonic, and BADHATCH
  *  **Targets:** Known to target the financial, hospitality, retail, and restaurant sectors.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Owowa Malicious IIS Module
A campaign targeting South East Asian government organizations is leveraging IIS modules to install malware. Kaspersky has published their analysis of the payload, which they have named Owowa.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer, RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Owowa
  *  **Targets:** Asian government organizations
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential theft, remote command execution



# Overview

Kaspersky published a blog post analyzing a malicious IIS module dubbed "Owowa." Not much is known about the infection chain or post-compromise actions, but a sample of the payload was found for analysis by researchers. The malicious module is capable of running on IIS servers that expose Exchange's Outlook Web Access (OWA). When loaded, it is capable of stealing credentials from the OWA login page as well as run commands issued by the attacker. It hooks an ISS event to inspect the content of HTTP requests, and when a successful OWA authentication attempt is observed, the credentials are encrypted and logged to a file on the system. This file can later be retrieved by the attacker. To issue commands, the attacker submits specific usernames to the OWA authentication page. Depending on what username is submitted, the malware will either exfiltrate the log file, delete the contents of the log file, or execute the contents of the password field via PowerShell, the results of which is sent back to the attacker. Victimology includes government organizations in Malaysia, Mongolia, Indonesia and the Philippines. The researchers were unable to attribute the activity to a known threat actor but provide their analysis of potential related personas and payloads based on PDB paths observed. For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056224/Owowa%20Malicious%20IIS%20Module%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639670484269&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/owowa-credential-stealer-and-remote-access/105219/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

When loaded, it is capable of stealing credentials from the OWA login page as well as run commands issued by the attacker. It hooks an ISS event to inspect the content of HTTP requests, and when a successful OWA authentication attempt is observed, the credentials are encrypted and logged to a file on the system. This file can later be retrieved by the attacker. To issue commands, the attacker submits specific usernames to the OWA authentication page. Depending on what username is submitted, the malware will either exfiltrate the log file, delete the contents of the log file, or execute the contents of the password field via PowerShell, the results of which is sent back to the attacker. Victimology includes government organizations in Malaysia, Mongolia, Indonesia and the Philippines. The researchers were unable to attribute the activity to a known threat actor but provide their analysis of potential related personas and payloads based on PDB paths observed. For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056224/Owowa%20Malicious%20IIS%20Module%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639670484269&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/owowa-credential-stealer-and-remote-access/105219/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Analysis of RedLine Stealer
RedLine Stealer is a widely-used piece of malware, the results of which are a large part of the information being sold on the dark web. Researchers at Recorded Future have published an in-depth analysis of the malware and its history.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** RedLine Stealer
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

RedLine Stealer is an infostealer malware that is currently the largest contributor of stolen information being sold on Russian-speaking sites on the dark web. Researchers from Insikt Group at Recorded Future have analyzed the malware and published a comprehensive report on the malware's capabilities. The infostealer has been distributed since early 2020 by a group known as "REDGlade" or "Glade". According to these actors, there are two subscription licenses available - a lifetime license for 800 dollars, or monthly service for 150 dollars. This malware is normally distributed via phishing emails, as well as over social media. It has also been found masquerading as legitimate programs, including as an installer for Telegram. Once installed, the malware can perform a wide array of functions. At its core, it can steal usernames, passwords, cookies, saved credentials, and credit card information from browsers. It can also gather files from cryptocurrency cold wallets and other locations. Beyond that, RedLine Stealer is capable of performing basic download and execute functions, meaning it can be used as a loader in a multi-stage attack. RedLine is being continually developed by a competent C# developer, and so new versions of this malware are being released regularly. The volume of advertisements for log information stolen by this malware has increased over the past year, which corresponds to the increase in interest across many dark web sources. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130400/An%20Analysis%20of%20RedLine%20Stealer%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634311309492&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files (M1038).



# References

  * <https://go.recordedfuture.com/hubfs/reports/mtp-2021-1014.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1120 - Peripheral Device Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ransomware Drove Public Data Breaches in 2020
IBM X-force Threat Intelligence has published a brief report following up on findings from the 2020 Threat Index related to public data breaches.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ransomware Drove Public Data Breaches in 2020
IBM X-force Threat Intelligence has published a brief report following up on findings from the 2020 Threat Index related to public data breaches.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Public breach data reveals several telling trends for 2020. First, ransomware attacks drove data breaches, making up 36% of data breaches as ransomware attackers incorporate data theft and leaks into their arsenal. In addition, manufacturing, government, and media/telecommunications appeared to be hit hardest by data breaches in 2020. Lastly, data breaches in 2020 appeared to peak in March, suggesting that breach trends may be loosely connected to COVID-19 pandemic trends as many organizations made abrupt changes to operations in March 2020. The full story and analysis is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/f62b5b9d-bddf-4a29-9fd9-864bc8f289b8>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Shadow Academy Targets Universities
RiskIQ have identified a series of attacks against some twenty universities that have occurred from July though to October. The attacks use TTPs similar to Silent Librarian. However, the indicators are not sufficient to attribute the attacks to Silent Librarian. RiskIQ has dubbed the threat actors, Shadow Academy.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Espionage, Financial Theft




# Overview

The Mabna Institute (also known as Cobalt Dickens, Silent Librarian, TA407) is tracked by IBM-Force as Hive0082. Nine Iranians associated with the Mabna Institute were indicted by the U.S. Department of Justice in 2018 for a number of attacks on universities and companies, and the Mabna Institute was alleged to be a state sponsored operation. RiskIQ has identified a series of attacks against some twenty universities that occurred through the second half of this year. The TTPs used in the attacks are similar to those associated with the Mabna Institute attacks. RiskIQ notes that despite the similarities, they are insufficient to attribute the attacks to the Mabna Institute. RiskIQ has dubbed the actors behind the attacks as Shadow Academy. RiskIQ's investigation began when an attack against the Louisiana State University was identified. The attack consisted of a spoofed login page used by students. Domain shadowing, carried out by obtaining a domain's account credentials and using them to register subdomains, was used in the attack. In this case a subdomain was used to host the phishing pages. The objective of the attacks is to obtain sensitive information and conduct espionage operations. The universities targeted in the attacks were located in Afghanistan, Australia, the UK, and the USA. Other URLs used by Shadow Academy were aimed at credential and financial theft and targeted services such as online banking, Amazon, and Instagram. RiskIQ also identified another attack named Murrez who is believed to be associated with a group named W4coders, and may be a competitor to Shadow Academy. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.riskiq.com/blog/external-threat-management/shadow-academy/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Vulnerabilities in Western Digital Replay Protected Memory Block
Western Digital has issued a white paper on two vulnerabilities within its RPMB protocol. The vulnerabilities could allow for the threat actor to make a legitimate host believe the state of the RPMB is different from its true state.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Western Digital's Replay Protected Memory Block is a protocol used to provide the ability for a host to store data in specific memory areas in an authenticated and replay-protected manner. This protocol has been found to have two separate vulnerabilities. The first prompts the host to conclude the data write failed. The data request contains a write value, address, and a MAC on those values. If the actor is able to intercept the request, they can modify it, which, subsequently, causes the MAC verification to fail. This action prevents the request from being committed to the RPMB. The adversary is then able to forward the initial request and intercept its status. The memory contents are updated without notification to the host. The second vulnerability allows the host to believe a portion of the data was, in fact, written. However, a different piece of data was written than initially thought. The attacker could cause the host to lose state, such as cutting power. The uncommitted write is kept with the attacker. Once online again, the host may attempt to issue an authenticated data write request to the previous location with different data. The attacker could intercept the new request and, instead, forward the old request. Further technical details can be found in the white paper and report located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982541/Vulnerabilities%20in%20Western%20Digital%20Replay%20Protected%20Memory%20Block%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605553835710&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://documents.westerndigital.com/content/dam/doc-library/en_us/assets/public/western-digital/collateral/white-paper/white-paper-replay-protected-memory-block-protocol-vulernabilities.pdf>

  * <https://www.westerndigital.com/support/productsecurity/wdc-20008-replay-attack-vulnerabilities-rpmb-protocol-applications>
  * <https://kb.cert.org/vuls/id/231329>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Snip3 Crypter RAT Delivery Service
A new Crypter-as-a-Service (CaaS) has been observed and analyzed by researchers at Morphisec. In a blog post on the CaaS, Morphisec describes the capabilities and associated IoCs of the malware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Researchers at Morphisec have analyzed a highly sophisticated CaaS that is used in the delivery of numerous RATs onto target machines. The crypter employs advanced detection bypass techniques, including executing PowerShell code with remotesigned parameter, validating the existence of Windows Sandbox and VMWare virtualization, using Pastebin and top4top for staging, and compiling RunPE loaders on the endpoint in runtime. The name Snip3 comes from the username found in current and previous variants of the malware. First observed in early-February and still ongoing, the variant has proven to be evasive and very few security products are able to detect it. The first stage of the crypter is a VB Script that loads and moves execution on to the second-stage, a PowerShell script. At present, four versions containing 11 sub-versions have been seen in this first stage. The second stage, a PowerShell script, contains similarities to the VBS versions and appears to be dynamic, based on configuration data seen in this stage. The script is able to detect script execution within various sandbox environments, such as Microsoft Sandbox, VMWare, and others. If a virtual environment is detected, the script is terminated and the RAT is not loaded. Interestingly, the malware author has built in a script that can detect the elusive Microsoft Sandbox environment by extracting the Manufacturer string. The second stage RAT observed by Morphisec contains GZIP source code and is executed in runtime. The third stage RAT payloads are chosen by the user and executed within memory. Most often ASyncRAT or RevengeRAT are observed as the RAT payloads. There was one instance each of Agent Tesla and NetWire RATs seen in analysis. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.morphisec.com/revealing-the-snip3-crypter-a-highly-evasive-rat-loader>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TeamTNT Delivers Malware with New Detection Evasion Tool
TeamTNT is a threat group known for compromising Docker infrastructure for cryptomining and credential theft purposes. AT&T Alien Labs discovered their latest tactic, using an open source detection evasion tool to hide their activities.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TeamTNT Delivers Malware with New Detection Evasion Tool
TeamTNT is a threat group known for compromising Docker infrastructure for cryptomining and credential theft purposes. AT&T Alien Labs discovered their latest tactic, using an open source detection evasion tool to hide their activities.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

AT&T Alien Labs published a blog post analyzing TeamTNT's use of an open source tool for detection evasion. The tool, libprocesshider, has been available on Github since 2014. It uses the ld preloader to hide processes from process information programs, such as ps and lsof, which decreases the chance of detection. In order to implement this tool, TeamTNT has hidden a base64-encoded script in their existing cryptomining and ircbot payloads. The script is responsible for modifying DNS configurations, setting persistence, dropping and installing libprocesshider as a service, downloading the IRC bot configuration, and covering tracks. After installation, libprocesshider ensures the primary malicious process is hidden from process viewer tools. For more information, see the AT&T blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Protection

## Yara Rule
    
    
    rule teamTNT_hideproc
    
    
    {  
    meta:  
    sha256 = "02cde4109a12acb499953aa8c79917455b9f49837c7c1dbb13cbcf67e86a1555"  
      
    strings:  
    $code1 = {48 8B 15 ?? ?? 00 00 48 8B 85 ?? ?? FF FF 48 89 C7 FF D2 48 89 [2-5] 48 [3-6] 00 74 ?? 48 8D 8D F0 FD FF FF 48 8B 85 ?? FD FF FF BA 00 01 00 00 48 89 CE 48 89 C7 E8 ?? FD FF FF 85 C0 74 ?? 48 8D 85 F0 FD FF FF 48 8D 35 ?? ?? 00 00 48 89 C7 E8 ?? ?? FF FF 85 C0 75 ?? 48 8B [2-5] 48 8D 50 13 48 8D 85 F0 FE FF FF 48 89 C6 48 89 D7 E8 ?? ?? FF FF 85 C0 74 22 48 8B 15 ?? ?? 00 00 48 8D 85 F0 FE FF FF 48 89 D6 48 89 C7 E8 ?? ?? FF FF 85 C0 }  
    $s1 = "readdir64"  
    $s2 = "dlsym"  
    $s3 = "_ITM_deregisterTMCloneTable"  
    $s4 = "frame_dummy"  
      
    condition:  
    uint16(0) == 0x457f and  
    filesize < 25000 and  
    all of them  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://cybersecurity.att.com/blogs/labs-research/teamtnt-delivers-malware-with-new-detection-evasion-tool>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Political Action Committee Spoof Drops Emotet
One of Emotet's latest campaigns, as identified by Area 1 Security, leverages recent hype surrounding President Trump’s decision to halt U.S. funding for the World Health Organization as a lure.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Area 1 Security has published their analysis of an email claiming to come from the Political Action Committee (PAC) that ultimately leads to an Emotet infection. The email specifically request recipients support President Trump’s decision to halt U.S. funding for the World Health Organization. The links in the body of the email all lead to legitimate PAC websites, adding to its legitimacy. However, also included in the email is a malicious attachment. As is common with Emotet, this attachment uses embedded macros to run PowerShell commands that using WMI to download the payload from one of a list of compromised WordPress websites. The payload is saved to a temporary folder and executed, at which point it checks into the C2 server. Commands can then be received to perform a variety of actions, including its common tactic of installing additional malware families. For more information, see the Area 1 Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.area1security.com/blog/pac-trump-election-emotet-phishing/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: FakeCop Spyware Targeting Japanese Android Users
Cyble is reporting a malware campaign that uses fake apps to deliver the FakeCop spyware to Japanese Android users.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: FakeCop Spyware Targeting Japanese Android Users
Cyble is reporting a malware campaign that uses fake apps to deliver the FakeCop spyware to Japanese Android users.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Japanese Android users.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** FakeCop
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Smishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of user and device information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

FakeCop is an Android information stealer that has capabilities including the collection and exfiltration of user and device information, generating user notifications, editing stored SMS messages, and the sending or deleting of SMS messages. A campaign distributing FakeCop is targeting Japanese users. It appears that the campaign is using SMS messages that contain links to URLs on the free DNS service, duckdns. These lead to fake apps masquerading as security or anti-virus apps that are available in Japan. If a victim installs one of the apps, while installing it searches for security applications and if found, will create a notification that asks the user to disable or uninstall the security app. This is so the fake app can persist on the device. To obtain a C&C server address, FakeCop contacts a proxy server that provides the C&C address. Further information can be found through the link provided in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68617106/FakeCop%20Spyware%20Targeting%20Japanese%20Android%20Users%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635737779956&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2021/10/28/new-variant-of-fakecop-targeting-users-from-japan/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application   
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means 

**Execution - TA0041**  
T1575 - Native Code 

**Persistence - TA0028**  
T1402 - Broadcast Receivers 

**Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
T1508 - Suppress Application Icon   
T1418 - Application Discovery   
T1575 - Native Code   
T1406 - Obfuscated Files or Information 

**Collection - TA0035**  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages   
T1432 - Access Contacts List   
T1533 - Data from Local System 

**Impact - TA0034**  
T1447 - Delete Device Data

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Dridex Activity on the Rise
A rise in Dridex activity over the past week has prompted SANS' Internet Storm Center (ISC) to publish an analysis of this recent activity.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Malspam




# Overview

Until this past week, Dridex activity had seemingly come to a halt; however, new activity has been uncovered by the ISC. A VirusTotal search revealed three documents containing the Dridex malspam malware. The documents obtained followed the same infection process as previous iterations of Dridex. In order to deploy Dridex on a vulnerable Windows host, the victim must download the document and enable macros. Upon doing so, the macro will cause Powershell to retrieve a DLL over HTTPS encrypted traffic. This DLL is the installer for Dridex and is immediately run. Post-infection, Dridex makes HTTPS calls in order to obtain the requisite malspam data. Persistence is obtained via three simultaneous methods: Windows Registry update, scheduled task, and Windows Startup menu shortcut. The malware uses existing EXE files to load the malware. The specific DLLs used by Dridex are named in such a way that they match legitimate DLLs and would be run by corresponding EXEs. Beyond any blatant changes, the Dridex malware is unchanged and traffic patterns are the same. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/diary/Recent+Dridex+activity/26550>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Royal Ripper Multi-Stage Phishing Attack
Leveraging a multi-stage attack chain, a threat actor, dubbed "Royal Ripper" by PhishLabs, is attempting to steal banking credentials.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

  
PhishLabs reports on a multi-stage phishing campaign being carried out by a threat actor they've named Royal Ripper. The campaign begins with an SMS lure impersonating a government agency, telecommunications company, or online payment service. They specifically analyzed the case of a lure that poses a tax notice from HM Revenue and Customs claiming the recipient is owed a tax return. Visiting the link leads to a fake UK government tax refund form that first requests the victim's name and postcode. After this, it requires further information including credit card details and a bank routing number. This routing number, in turn, is used to identify the corresponding bank and redirect victims to a phishing page masquerading as that associated institution. This page is aimed at harvesting bank account credentials. An open directory contains the various phishing pages, lookups for the routing numbers, and any stolen credentials. The credit card information gathered in the first stage is also saved to this open directory. For more information, see the PhishLabs blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Always be suspicious of unsolicited emails or SMS messages.




# Reference

  * <https://info.phishlabs.com/blog/royal-ripper-multi-stage-phishing-attack-adapts-to-victim-input>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Chimera APT Updates OwlProxy Malware
While responding to an incident, Lab52 uncovered new OwlProxy malware samples. This malware is leveraged by the Chimera APT group for remote command execution.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

Lab52 published a blog post detailing updates to the OwlProxy malware, a proxy tool leveraged by Chimera for remote command execution. The new samples provide the same capabilities as the older versions, acting as a proxy between the victim DMZ and internal network to execute commands remotely. The major change implemented in the new versions is a move from the use of port 80 to port 443 (SSL). Additionally, some of the strings in the remote address have changed, varying across samples. During their research, Lab52 also identified a dropper, dubbed OwlInstaller, that extracts the OwlProxy payload from its resources in order to install it on the system. An additional C2 server path has been observed that provides several functions, including downloading and uploading files, as well as getting a list of drives and directories. For more information, see the Lab52 blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://lab52.io/blog/chimera-apt-updates-on-its-owlproxy-malware/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: CISA MARs on Malware Associated with Pulse Secure Compromises
CISA has published five malware Analysis reports (MARs) that provide information on malware that was installed on compromised Pulse Secure devices.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

 Included are malware that provides a backdoor to the attackers, a webshell, credential stealers, an installer, and one file that manipulates and executes '/bin/umount'. Further information is available from the MARs linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

 **From CISA**

  * Maintain up-to-date antivirus signatures and engines.
  * Keep operating system patches up-to-date.
  * Disable File and Printer sharing services. If these services are required, use strong passwords or Active Directory authentication.
  * Restrict users' ability (permissions) to install and run unwanted software applications. Do not add users to the local administrators group unless required.
  * Enforce a strong password policy and implement regular password changes.
  * Exercise caution when opening e-mail attachments even if the attachment is expected and the sender appears to be known.
  * Enable a personal firewall on agency workstations, configured to deny unsolicited connection requests.
  * Disable unnecessary services on agency workstations and servers.
  * Scan for and remove suspicious e-mail attachments; ensure the scanned attachment is its "true file type" (i.e., the extension matches the file header).
  * Monitor users' web browsing habits; restrict access to sites with unfavorable content.
  * Exercise caution when using removable media (e.g., USB thumb drives, external drives, CDs, etc.).
  * Scan all software downloaded from the Internet prior to executing.
  * Maintain situational awareness of the latest threats and implement appropriate Access Control Lists (ACLs).



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-236a>

  * [https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-236b](https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-236a "Follow link")

  * Restrict users' ability (permissions) to install and run unwanted software applications. Do not add users to the local administrators group unless required.
  * Enforce a strong password policy and implement regular password changes.
  * Exercise caution when opening e-mail attachments even if the attachment is expected and the sender appears to be known.
  * Enable a personal firewall on agency workstations, configured to deny unsolicited connection requests.
  * Disable unnecessary services on agency workstations and servers.
  * Scan for and remove suspicious e-mail attachments; ensure the scanned attachment is its "true file type" (i.e., the extension matches the file header).
  * Monitor users' web browsing habits; restrict access to sites with unfavorable content.
  * Exercise caution when using removable media (e.g., USB thumb drives, external drives, CDs, etc.).
  * Scan all software downloaded from the Internet prior to executing.
  * Maintain situational awareness of the latest threats and implement appropriate Access Control Lists (ACLs).



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-236a>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Ransomware Variant Uses Golang Packer
Researchers have discovered a new ransomware payload using a Golang packer for obfuscation and detection evasion. CrowdStrike's analysis reveals similarities to the HelloKitty and FiveHands ransomware families.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

CrowdStrike published a blog post analyzing a new ransomware payload that leverages a Golang packer. Packing the malware with a Golang packer using the latest Golang release makes debugging it much more difficult for researchers. In order to unpack the payload, a decryption key must be passed as a command line argument. The primary payload, which is written in C++, is then loaded into memory. A help option reveals that the executable can also take arguments to limit file encryption to a specific path and disable some of its default operations. RSA encryption is performed, a .locked extension is appended to encrypted files, and a ransom note is dropped onto the system. Victims are requested to contact the operator via a Tor portal for further instructions. The note also claims that data has been stolen from the network. Similar C++ functions, the CLI arguments, an embedded public key, the appending of magic bytes to encrypted files all indicate that this ransomware is based off of the HelloKitty and FiveHands ransomware families. For more information, see the CrowdStrike blog post in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/new-ransomware-variant-uses-golang-packer/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Operation StealthyTrident
Operation StealthyTrident is the name given by ESET to a long running campaign that has been targeting agencies of the Mongolian government. The campaign delivered malware through a compromised software company.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

is the name given by ESET to a long running campaign that has been targeting agencies of the Mongolian government. The campaign delivered malware through a compromised software company.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Campaign, APT




# Overview

A messaging application named Able Desktop was, according to a report from ESET, used to deliver malware to victims. Able Desktop is widely used by Mongolian government agencies. Beginning around December in 2017, Trojanized installers were used to deliver the malware. The report further notes that Able's update system was probably compromised and also used to deliver malware. The malware included a backdoor named HyperBro and two RATs, Korplug (PlugX) and Tmanger. ESET named the campaign . In the early stages of the campaign, HyperBro was the installed malware, but in July 2020 the compromised update system began delivering Tmanger. The Trojanized installers were used to deliver HyperBro or Korplug. The group known as LuckyMouse appear to be behind the campaign. LuckyMouse is a Chinese threat group and is also known by several other names including APT27, Bronze Union, Emissary Panda, Hippo, Iodine, Iron Tiger, and TG-3390. IBM X-Force tracks LuckyMouse as Hive0006. ESET also discovered relationships between LuckyMouse and TA428 due to one of the Tmanger C&C server addresses also being used by the ShadowPad backdoor. Further information about the campaign and the malware involved can be found in ESET's report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2020/12/10/luckymouse-ta428-compromise-able-desktop/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: MooBot Targeting UNIX CCTV DVR With Zero Day
CNCERT and Qthoo 360 have published a joint report regarding MooBot, a botnet discovered in September 2019, targeting UNIX CCTV DVR with a zero day vulnerability.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: MooBot Targeting UNIX CCTV DVR With Zero Day
CNCERT and Qthoo 360 have published a joint report regarding MooBot, a botnet discovered in September 2019, targeting UNIX CCTV DVR with a zero day vulnerability.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, Zero Day



# Overview

CNCERT and Qthoo 360 have jointly published findings on a zero day being exploited by MooBot. The targeted device in question is UNIX CCTV DVR. The attack was first noticed in early June. By the end of June, a sample of the new version of MooBot had been captured and examined. A patch for UNIX CCTV DVR was released by the end of August. MooBot scans port 8000 for vulnerable devices and then attempts to exploit the remote command injection vulnerability. This port is used to update the system time with an NTP server, but the software does not validate the ntpdate parameters. Thus, an attacker could inject a command along the lines of "ntpdate -d -t 1 time.nist.gov & whoami", where "whoami" could be replaced with a malicious command. For vulnerable devices and more details, refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/33983073/MooBot%20Targeting%20UNIX%20CCTV%20DVR%20With%20Zero%20Day%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606165480671&api=v2)

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: NetWire and Remcos Malware Campaign Targeting US Taxpayers
With the U.S. tax season here, it is not surprising attackers will use this theme as a lure. In one such case discovered by Cybereason, tax-themed documents are being used to spread the NetWire and Remcos malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: NetWire and Remcos Malware Campaign Targeting US Taxpayers
With the U.S. tax season here, it is not surprising attackers will use this theme as a lure. In one such case discovered by Cybereason, tax-themed documents are being used to spread the NetWire and Remcos malware.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Cybereason published a blog post analyzing an email campaign distiburing the NetWire and Remcos RATs. It begins with a lure document using a tax theme to entice users into opening the file. If the user enables macros as requested, a DLL is written to disk and subsequently injected into a Notepad process. This DLL acts as a loader, injecting additional malicious code that downloads the OpenVPN client and a Trojanized DLL in order to perform DLL side-loading. Persistence is created via a .lnk file. The sideloaded DLL unpacks and injects the next stage into memory. Finally, a image file is downloaded from imgur, a legitimate file hosting service. This image file uses steganography to hide the actual payload, either the NetWire or Remcos RAT. With the final payload installed on the system, attackers can perform a variety of actions on the victim host, such as downloading additional payloads, stealing data, and more. For more information, see the Cybereason blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/cybereason-exposes-malware-targeting-us-taxpayers>
