instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Pawn Storm Google Drive and IMAP RATs
Pawn Storm has begun to use less sophisticated techniques in their attacks, likely to thwart attribution. Trend Micro reports on their tactics and malware in a recent blog post.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Trend Micro has published a blog post analyzing recent Pawn Storm activity. They highlight that the activity appears to lack sophistication, likely to obscure it being attributed to an APT. The attack chain begins with widespread credential phishing and brute force attacks against public facing email, LDAP, Microsoft Autodiscover, SMB, and SQL servers. The compromised accounts are then used to send out spear phishing emails to their true targets. The specific campaign Trend Micro focused on in the blog post begins with a phishing email that attempts to convince a user to open an RAR file containing a self-extracting archive. The self-extracting archive, in turn, contained two executables. The first one is a decoy file that requests a password for decryption, but regardless of the entered password, an error message is displayed. The second file is the malicious payload. After establishing persistence via the Startup directory, it is able to function as a RAT that communicates via Google Drive. It periodically polls a Google Drive account for the presence of a command file. If discovered, the contained commands are executed, the output is saved to a Google Drive file in the same account, and the command file is deleted. A keylogger was also observed being installed. Collected keystrokes are saved locally, but exfiltration is not built in and would have to be performed by the RAT. Trend Micro notes that they also observed samples of similar RATs that communicated over IMAP instead of Google Drive. Furthermore, the malware has been improved to add improvements such as encryption. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/l/pawn-storm-lack-of-sophistication-as-a-strategy.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Android Malware WAPDropper Signs Up For Premium Services
Check Point Research reports on a new Android malware package that, when installed, signs the victim up for premium services.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Android



# Overview

Check Point Research discloses details of a two stage malware package that runs on Android called WAPDropper. The first stage is the dropper module that retrieves and installs the second stage module. The second stage module's responsibility is to subscribe the victim device to premium services, thus causing the victim financial loss. Some of the services require that a CAPTCHA step be successfully passed for the subscription to succeed. WAPDropper uses a Chinese company known for its image recognition software, called "Super Eagle", to provide the solution for the CAPTCHA problem. After the malware is installed and running, it hides its icon to thwart the victim from uninstalling. If the infected device does not have a proxy or VPN configured, stage one will also download additional malware payloads. For more details, see the Check Point article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/33983826/Android%20Malware%20WAPDropper%20Signs%20Up%20For%20Premimum%20Services%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606331014509&api=v2)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Hive0097 Activity
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence uncovered malicious activity (tracked by X-Force as Hive0097) that is potentially being carried out by Cloud Atlas, a Russian state-sponsored APT.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Hive0097 Activity
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence uncovered malicious activity (tracked by X-Force as Hive0097) that is potentially being carried out by Cloud Atlas, a Russian state-sponsored APT.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

In mid-November 2020, IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence uncovered a malicious document mimicking a legitimate English-language article from the Russian-language Azeri newspaper, the Daily Sabah. This led to the further discovery of several malicious, military and policy-themed document files dating back to early-2019, as well as tactics, techniques, and procures (TTPs) that are consistent with the APT group Cloud Atlas. Cloud Atlas has been active since at least 2014, with the most recently available public reporting published in August 2019. Although firm attribution cannot be made, it is suspected that the activity X-Force tracks as Hive0097 is likely the APT group Cloud Atlas, suggesting the group has remained active throughout 2020. This is based on both X-Force analysis and alignment with established TTPs and uncovered documents files attributed to Cloud Atlas. instruction:
I have encountered the following information: XAMPP Servers Hosting Agent Tesla and Formbook
A report from RiskIQ provides information on the use of Internet-facing XAMPP servers to host malware such as Agent Tesla and Formbook.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Malware Family/Families:**[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331/), Formbook
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Servers running XAMPP are being used to host malware.



# Overview

XAMPP is an Apache distribution containing MariaDB, PHP, and Perl that is intended to make installation simple but is not intended to be used for production deployments. A report from RiskIQ provides information on the use of Internet-facing XAMPP servers that are being used to host malware such as Agent Tesla and Formbook. It is not clear from the report if the XAMPP servers have been set up by the actors behind the malware, or whether the servers have been compromised by the actors. A number of the hosts observed distributing the malware used dynamic DNS names. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59539651/XAMPP%20Servers%20Hosting%20Agent%20Tesla%20and%20Formbook%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1628643059745&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date ([M1049](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1049/)).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs ([M1031](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1031/), [M1035](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1035/), [M1037](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1037/)).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level ([M1051](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1051/)).



# References

  * <https://community.riskiq.com/article/40000d46/description>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Fleeceware Deceives Millions of Minecraft Users
The security team at Avast discovered one of seven malicious mobile applications employing a new tactic called fleeceware to exploit end-users of the popular game Minecraft through Google Play, enticing gamers to downloading malicious applications for monetary gain.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Fleeceware Deceives Millions of Minecraft Users
The security team at Avast discovered one of seven malicious mobile applications employing a new tactic called fleeceware to exploit end-users of the popular game Minecraft through Google Play, enticing gamers to downloading malicious applications for monetary gain.

# Threat Type

  * Application Vulnerability 




# Overview

Researchers at Avast assessed a surge of malicious mobile applications that can be downloaded which offer new skins, colorful wallpapers, and modifications for the game Minecraft. According to researchers, this new tactic is categorized as fleeceware and is commonly employed as an attractive service for end-users, typically offering a free trial that only lasts a few days. Once the free trial has ended, the malicious mobile application gradually begins charging exorbitant amounts, up to $30 per week. This tactic has proven effective due to the majority of their target pool being young children and teenagers who tend to overlook the particulars of the service to which they are subscribing to. In conclusion, the security team at Avast encourages the public to stay wary of new applications and provides actions to take in the event they fall victim to fleeceware. For more information, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.avast.com/fraudulent-minecraft-apps-on-google-play-avast>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: DDoS Attacks Targeting Ukrainian Websites Analyzed
A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack targeting Ukrainian government organizations and banks caused temporary outages from February 15-16th.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian Financial and Government Organizations
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Katana bot (derivative of Mirai) 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Botnet 
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** DDoS
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Cado Security reports that between February 15-16th a number of Financial, Government, and Military websites fell victim to a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack. Network traffic to bank sites - Privat Bank and Oschad Bank - was seen spiking as the the attack commenced along with customer reports of the websites being unavailable. Some Privat Bank customers in the Ukraine received SMS messages crafted by adversaries warning that ATMs would not work on February 15th. In addition, a BGP hijack against the Privat Bank's IP space caused traffic routing issues for users. The report also mentions other components to the attack such as DDoS attacks against .gov.ua DNS servers. The news outlet, tsn.ua, named zsu.gov.ua and mil.gov.ua as specific Ukrainian government victims. The Ukrainian Ministry of Defense also confirmed the attack via Twitter. The report calls out Mirai and derivative Katana as likely botnets used to launch the attack. It goes on to name exploited Avtech network cameras as the launch point for the attacks. Overall, Cado Security's report calls these attacks moderately impactful. They were not particularly successful but the combination of methods suggests there is a base level of sophistication coordinated by the adversary. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81133648/DDoS%20Attacks%20Targeting%20Ukrainian%20Websites%20Analyzed%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645985381594&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root (M1026).
  * Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic (M1037).
  * Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038).
  * Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040).
  * Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses (M1047).
  * Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software (M1049).
  * Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques (M1056).



# References

  * <https://www.cadosecurity.com/technical-analysis-of-the-ddos-attacks-against-ukrainian-websites/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.005 - Botnet  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Media Land LLC Bulletproof Hosting Service
Bulletproofing hosting (BPH) providers offer services that appeal to internet-based criminals. RiskIQ has published an article analyzing one of these providers, Media Land LLC.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Bulletproof Hosting



# Overview

RiskIQ published an article analyzing Media Land LLC, a well-known bulletproof hosting provider. Bulletproof hosting services allow cyber criminals to use seemingly legitimate infrastructure to carry out their malicious purposes with a reduced risk of disruption by the provider. RiskIQ's blog post specifically focuses on Media Land LLC and its infrastructure. Additional findings regarding the company were able to be made based on connections to its head, Alexander Volosovik. Media Land LLC is tied to two Autonomous Systems (AS), AS206728 and AS211805, only one of which has IP blocks assigned to it. These IP blocks appeared in late 2019. Hosted on these IP blocks are servers used for various malicious purposes, such as malware hosting, phishing, and botnet control. Some of the servers can be tied directly to Volosovik, while others are likely rented out to other threat actors. The researchers also uncovered various suspicious domains registered to Media Land or its owners but hosted on Alibaba infrastructure. Many of the domains were spoofed pages used for phishing credentials. For more information, see the RiskIQ blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://community.riskiq.com/article/49db7be3>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Web Skimming Attacks Using Google Tag Manager
Malicious code injected into compromised eCommerce sites often tries to hide under the guise of legitimate services. Avast published a blog post analyzing one such case where Google Tag Manager was abused for web skimming.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Web skimming code
  *  **Targets:** eCommerce customers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of eCommerce platform vulnerabilities
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft



# Overview

Avast published a blog post analyzing a web skimming campaign that abuses Google Tag Manager to inject malicious code. Google Tag Manager provides a method of loading custom code. After a eCommerce site is compromised, often via CMS vulnerabilities, the attackers inject the Google Tag Manager reference into the site's checkout pages. Google Tag Manager, in turn, loads custom code into the page. In this case, the JavaScript code is responsible for rendering a fake payment form onto the legitimate checkout page. Any data entered into this form is base64-encoded and exfiltrated via WebSockets back to attacker. Avast observed two websites targeted by this threat actor, one in Argentina and one in Saudi Arabia. For more information, see the Avast blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057921/Web%20Skimming%20Attacks%20Using%20Google%20Tag%20Manager%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643659398403&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/pavlinakopecka/web-skimming-attacks-using-google-tag-manager/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.001 - Domains  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.003 - Web Portal Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1132.001 - Standard Encoding

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Preventive Security Service and Arid Viper Activity
After taking action against hackers in Palestine, Facebook has released their findings on the two threat groups behind the malicious activity.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Preventive Security Service and Arid Viper Activity
After taking action against hackers in Palestine, Facebook has released their findings on the two threat groups behind the malicious activity.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cyber Espionage, Influence Operations




# Overview

Facebook published a blog post detailing their findings on two distinct threat groups operating in Palestine. The first is the Preventive Security Service (PSS), the Palestinian Authority’s internal intelligence organization. The group leveraged social engineering to convince victims to download malware to their devices. The malware used by the group included low-sophistication custom malware and open-source malware tools. Their Android malware masquerades as a chat application and collects device metadata that will be exfiltrated to Firebase. SpyNote was also used for remote device access and call monitoring. On Windows, the NJRat and HWorm malware families were used. Lastly, fictitious personas on social media were used for social engineering. Arid Viper is an APT in Palestine. Infrastructure leveraged by the group is tied to iOS and Android malware, phishing campaigns, and C2 servers. The group has built a sophisticated iOS surveillanceware that can be installed on non-jailbroken devices and uses a public jailbreak for escalating privileges. It was distributed as part of a fully functional chat application. Micropasia was used on Windows, while malware families similar to FrozenCell and VAMP were used on Android devices. Facebook released a full report detailing Arid Viper's campaign and the malware used. For more information, see the blog post and report linked to in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://about.fb.com/news/2021/04/taking-action-against-hackers-in-palestine/>

  * <https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Technical-threat-report-Arid-Viper-April-2021.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Variant of Necro Botnet Discovered With Added Capabilities
Necro, a classic botnet family, first discovered in 2015, was written in Python. On March 2nd, Netlab 360 discovered two samples of a new variant of Necro. Keksec, also known as Kek Security is the threat actor group responsible for the botnet. The botnet has been found on both Windows and Linux systems.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Variant of Necro Botnet Discovered With Added Capabilities
Necro, a classic botnet family, first discovered in 2015, was written in Python. On March 2nd, Netlab 360 discovered two samples of a new variant of Necro. Keksec, also known as Kek Security is the threat actor group responsible for the botnet. The botnet has been found on both Windows and Linux systems.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, Cryptomining




# Overview

Necro, a classic botnet family first discovered in 2015, was written in Python. On March 2nd, Netlab 360 discovered two samples of a new variant of Necro. It spreads via scanning for and exploiting vulnerabilities within TerraMaster NAS (CVE_2020_35665), Zend web application framework (CVE-2021-3007), Laravel PHP web framework (CVE-2021-3129), and Oracle WebLogic application server ( CVE-2020-14882). Enhancements Include TOR C2, Dynamic DGA C2, and exploits against newer vulnerabilities. Keksec, also known as Kek Security is the threat actor group responsible for the botnet. The botnet attacks both Windows and Linux systems. While the botnet always uses Python, on Linux it also makes use of bash, while on Windows it uses PowerShell. On windows it also uses code from the rootkit project known as r77-rootkit which is loaded by using a piece of shellcode using process injection from another project known as sRDI. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside tis report.



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/necro-upgrades-again-using-tor-dynamic-domain-dga-and-aiming-at-both-windows-linux/>

  * <https://www.lacework.com/the-kek-security-network/>

Tell me about the following threat: Internet of Threats: IoT Botnets Drive Surge in Attacks
X-Force Threat Intelligence researchers have published a report on Internet of Things (IoT) attack activity observed over the course of 2020, specifically focusing on IoT botnets.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Internet of Threats: IoT Botnets Drive Surge in Attacks
X-Force Threat Intelligence researchers have published a report on Internet of Things (IoT) attack activity observed over the course of 2020, specifically focusing on IoT botnets.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Vulnerability, Botnet




# Overview

X-Force Threat Intelligence released their analysis of 2020 IoT attack activity, which heavily revolved around IoT botnets. The report details significant trends observed, including the botnet families leveraged, devices exploited, and industries targeted. An overview of the most active botnet malware families is provided. This includes the Mozi botnet, Gafgyt, Echobot, Loli, and ZeroShell. Alongside the report, the researchers provide detailed recommendations on how users can protect their networks and devices from falling victim to such an attack. The full story, analysis, and mitigation advice is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below. 

# Recommendations

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Evilnum Group Releases PyVil RAT
According to a new report from Cybereason, the Evilnum group has released a new malware dubbed PyVil RAT.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

A new RAT has been observed by Cybereason's Nocturnus team. The RAT, PyVil RAT is being distributed by the cyber group, Evilnum. The group has been active for at least the past two years using a variety of tools. The group has historically targeted the Financial Technology industry and uses the Know Your Customer procedure to begin infection. Included in the new malware are deviations from the infection chain, persistence, infrastructure, and tools observed including modified, legitimate executables, a multi-process delivery of the payload, and the PyVil RAT. The new infection chain begins with spearphishing emails with attached ZIP archives containing LNK files, which drop a JavaScript Trojan. The attached files masquerade as utility bills, credit card photos, and driver license photos. Upon execution, a JavaScript file is written and executed which, in turn, replaces the LNK file with a PDF. This JavaScript is merely a dropper and has no C2 communication capabilities. This is but the first step in the new infection chain that culminates with the delivery of the PyVil RAT. After the PDF is placed, the JS file is copied which leads to the execution of ddpp.exe embedded in the LNK file. A registry key is entered for persistence and a scheduled task is created. The scheduled task is responsible for retrieving payloads. The executable ddpp.exe is a Java Web Start Launcher that has been trojanized to execute malicious code. The functionality of ddpp.exe is that of a downloader for next stage infection. From this point, shellcode is unpacked and connects to a C2 using a GET request. The malware downloads another encrypted executable, saved as fplayer.exe, which is then executed with a new scheduled task. This downloaded executable acts as an additional downloader. The payload is loaded into memory and is a fileless RAT. Again, at this point, the file is executed with a scheduled task named "Adobe Update Task." Several arguments are executed with this EXE file. This particular file appears to be a trojanized version of "Stereoscopic 3D driver Installer." When this file is executed, further shellcode is unpacked and connects to the C2 via a GET request. A final payload is received, which is the PyVil RAT. This RAT is heavily obfuscated to prevent decompiling the payload. The RAT has several functions such as: keylogger, running cmd commands, taking screenshots, obtaining more Python scripts, dropping and unloading executables among others. C2 communications are accomplished by POST HTTP requests and are RC4 encrypted with hardcoded keys. The C2 domain changes frequently but appears to resolve to the same three IP addresses. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/no-rest-for-the-wicked-evilnum-unleashes-pyvil-rat>

According to a new report from Cybereason, the Evilnum group has released a new malware dubbed PyVil RAT.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Spook Ransomware a Potential Prometheus Derivative
Sentinel Labs have reported on a new ransomware strain known as 'Spook'. This ransomware is potentially linked to Prometheus malware, and this relationship is explored in the report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Spook, Prometheus, Thanos
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Disk Encryption, System Enumeration



# Overview

Sentinel Labs have published an analysis of a new strain of ransomware named Spook. Spook ransomware was first identified in late September 2021, and its extortion model resembles many other ransomware families. Spook may be linked to Prometheus ransomware, which itself is derived from Thanos ransomware. There are several notable similarities between Spook, Prometheus, and Thanos, although this could be attributed to the leak of a builder for Thanos. Not only are there code similarities, the ransom note and URL structure for the payment site is very similar, supporting the connection between these different ransomware strains. Spook ransomware can encrypt disks while offline and can achieve this in minutes. Once this is done, the malware makes changes to prominently display the ransom note. Another notable similarity between the three ransomware strains mentioned previously is the method of checking for and killing processes that would disrupt the encryption process. Spook published the names of all companies that have been attacked, regardless of whether or not they paid the ransom demand. They also publish whether or not the victim paid the ransom. If the ransom is not paid, the attackers advertise the victim's data for sale. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68617109/Spook%20Ransomware%20a%20Potential%20Prometheus%20Derivative%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635767456589&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Ensure backups are stored off system and is protected from common methods adversaries may use to gain access and destroy the backups to prevent recovery (M1053).



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/spook-ransomware-prometheus-derivative-names-those-that-pay-shames-those-that-dont/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
T1547.004 - Winlogon Helper DLL  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Resurgence of The Emotet Botnet Malware
TrendMicro has recently posted an update of the Emotet botnet malware. This malware was thought to be “shut down” due to recent international law enforcement operations that took control of Emotet’s network infrastructure.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Trickbot, Ryuk, Conti 
  * **Targets:** Asia-Pacific and EMEA Region
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spam
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Botnet, Credentials Stolen



# Overview

Emotet is one of the most prolific malware types utilized by threat actors. Past reporting indicates that the Emotet botnet malware has been utilized by a number of threat actors to compromise endpoints and networks. Emotet has also been utilized to create a botnet that is marketed as malware as a service (MaaS). After the international law enforcement operation known as Ladybird, it was assessed that the botnet and the adjacent infrastructure had been taken down. TrendMicro now believes that the Emotet botnet malware returned and is once again operational. The newest version of Emotet now utilizes Excel 4.0 to execute downloads. Emotet malware has continued to change and uses several techniques to avoid detection. Two techniques employed by the latest version of Emotet include using .ocx on the file extension and deploying carets in URLs. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/e/bruised-but-not-broken--the-resurgence-of-the-emotet-botnet-malw.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1591.004 - Identify Roles  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1598 - Phishing for Information  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

Resurgence of The Emotet Botnet Malware
TrendMicro has recently posted an update of the Emotet botnet malware. This malware was thought to be “shut down” due to recent international law enforcement operations that took control of Emotet’s network infrastructure.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Clipboard banker
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Allcome
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Clipboard hijacking



# Overview

G DATA published a blog post analyzing Allcome, a clipboard banker being sold on underground forums as a malware-as-a-service. The payload is a small executable capable of monitoring the clipboard and replacing its contents when certain conditions are meant. It attempts to replace cryptocurrency wallet addresses, PayPal email addresses, and Steam trade offers URLs present on the clipboard with those controlled by the attacker. The C2 URL and attacker's replacement data are encrypted and stored in the PE resources. Upon connecting to the C2 URL, the server confirms that the operator of the malware is a valid customer. Persistence is established via a scheduled task. The researchers note that there are minimal checks in place to avoid incorrect replacements, so the victim is likely to notice odd behavior early on. For more information, see the G DATA blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058986/Allcome%20Clipboard%20Banker%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645115743655&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.gdatasoftware.com/blog/2022/02/37239-allcome-clipbanker-is-a-newcomer-in-malware-underground-forums>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1115 - Clipboard Data  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Recent MAN1 Campaigns
In a recent blog post, researchers at Walmart investigated MAN1 infrastructure in order to identify different malicious payloads in use by the threat actor.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Walmart has published a blog post analyzing recent MAN1 campaigns. MAN1 is a e-crime threat group active since at least 2014. They recently launched a Hancitor campaign with a new final payload in use, CobaltStrike. After decoding the Hancitor payload and retrieving the CS payload, the researchers identified the watermark for the CS beacon. This allowed them to pivot to further samples, specifically honing in on the one that communicated with the associated IP address. This led to the discovery of a CS stager deploying an Amadey bot, Further investigation into the associated infrastructure led to the discovery of an IP range being leveraged by MAN1. To identify what other payloads were being delivered by the CS stager, other payloads hosted on the same IP were analyzed. These discovered payloads included a CS Beacon, downloaders, spreaders, exploit scripts using DoublePulsar and EternalBlue to spread downloaders, and the Zeppelin ransomware. For more information, see the Walmart blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://medium.com/walmartglobaltech/man1-moskal-hancitor-and-a-side-of-ransomware-d77b4d991618>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TigerRAT - New RAT on the Block
VMWare has published a blog detailing TigerRAT, a new malware that shares similarities with malware previously used by Andariel, a subset of Lazarus.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown though shares similarities with Andariel
  *  **Associated Payloads:** TigerRAT
  *  **Targets:** N/A
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Manipulate files, execute remote commands, log keystrokes, remote control over victim machine



# Overview

TigerRAT is a new RAT discovered by the Korean Internet & Security Agency (KISA). Analysis by VMWare unveils capabilities associated with the malware. TigerRAT has the ability to manipulate files, execute remote commands, log keystrokes, and remotely view and control the victim machine. The RAT originates from a loader app. Within the sample analyzed, configuration data for C2 communication is stored in encrypted form in the malware. This communication is disguised to appear as normal HTTP web traffic using port 443. The payload is structured in a 4-byte size, 16-byte key, and base64 encoded. Decryption of the payload executes the malware in memory. C2s are decrypted using CryptorDES. Various commands can be sent and received from the C2, such as those for gathering victim machine information as well as module updates. Further information can be found in the source article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055861/TigerRAT%20-%20New%20RAT%20on%20the%20Block%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639505009316&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction. (M1017)
  * Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts. (M1018)
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc. (M1021)
  * Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root. (M1026)
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries. (M1031)
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking. (M1038)
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior. (M1040)
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing. (M1045)
  * Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses. (M1047)
  * Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software. (M1049)



# References

  * <https://blogs.vmware.com/security/2021/12/tigerrat-advanced-adversaries-on-the-prowl.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1134.002 - Create Process with Token  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087.001 - Local Account  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Return of the GravityRAT
As GravityRAT returns with new capabilities and versions, new reports on GravityRAT are being published that detail the latest developments on this Android, Mac, and Windows malware set thought to have been eradicated.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Spyware




# Overview

Between 2015 and 2018, a Windows malware family dubbed GravityRAT was active. Around 2018, the focus had shifted to include Android in its repertoire. The spyware initially targeted the Indian armed forces but appears, now, to be more indiscriminate in its targeting of Indian users. Using several Android apps, the spyware is targeting users of mobile platform travel apps such as: Travel Mate, used for travellers in India. This particular app is a legitimate app on the Google Play store. The modified version appears to have been modified for the sole purpose of installing the spyware; the code for Travel Mate is available on Github. Once modified, attackers change the name to Travel Mate Pro. Upon installation, the app attempts to gain access to photos, media, and files stored on the victim's device. The functionality is of the typical garden variety spyware. Exfiltration of device data, contact lists, email addresses, call, and text logs is the purpose of this instance. The code used is not based on any similar code or other spyware apps. The C2 address is hardcoded and is used to download files of varying types to the device. The spyware issues commands to obtain system info, search for doc types files, list running processes, log keystrokes, and more. New versions of GravityRAT are written in .NET and Python; the .NET versions target Sharify and MelodyMate, and the Python version targets GoZap. Multiplatform versions include StrongBox, TeraSpace, OrangeVault, and CvStyler. Android versions include SavitaBhabi (also a Windows version). An assumption can be made that the current version of GravityRAT uses similar infection methods to previous versions - targeting users by sending them links to the malicious apps. The main modification is that the RAT can now infect multiple platforms, including macOS. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/gravityrat-the-spy-returns/99097/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The Mespinoza (Pysa) Ransomware Group TTPs
A report from Palo Alto's Unit 42 provides some statistics and TTPs associated with the Mespinoza (aka Pysa) ransomware group.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

The Mespinoza, also known as Pysa, ransomware group has been operating for more than a year according to a report from Palo Alto's Unit 42. While the group's attacks are global in nature, the United States is the most affected country with 55 percent of the victims listed on the Mespinoza leak site being located there. The most affected sectors are Education, Manufacturing, and Retail, in that order. While the group typically accesses its victims using RDP, they also use a backdoor Unit 42 refer to as Gasket. It is written in Go, obfuscated using an open-source tool named Gobfuscate, and installed prior to the deployment of the ransomware. Another tool used by the group, also written in Go and makes use of open-source code (Chisel project), is named MagicSocks. It uses the Chisel client to connect to a Chisel server controlled by the group. Once the group has attained a foothold in a system, a number of other tools including ADRecon, SessionGopher, Advanced IP Scanner, Advanced Port Scanner, PowerShell scripts, and built-in Windows utilities are used for reconnaissance and obtaining credentials and to facilitate lateral movement. Infected systems are searched for what are considered to be sensitive files by both extensions, and a list of keywords that are matched against filenames. C&C communications are carried out using DNS tunneling and TXT queries, the protocol is based on the open-source project named Chashell. Originally, C&C communications were carried out over HTTP, this is now used as a fallback. Finally, the Mespinoza ransomware is deployed using three batch scripts and PsExec to copy and run the scripts, on infected systems. The scripts attempt to disable antivirus systems, kill certain processes that hold files open, delete the restore points and volume shadow copies, and leave ransom notes. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/gasket-and-magicsocks-tools-install-mespinoza-ransomware/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Pay2Key Ransomware Targets Israeli Companies
Researchers at Check Point recently discovered an unusual amount of ransomware attacks being reported by Israeli companies. According to analysts, infamous ransomware strands like REvil and Ryuk were discovered to be engaged in this momentum of attacks; however, amongst those strands, the previously unknown ransomware, Pay2Key, was discovered.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware 




# Overview

Analysts at Check Point Research assessed a surge of ransomware attacks, which included a new ransomware variant, Pay2Key, targeting Israeli companies. According to the security team at Checkpoint, the initial surge of attacks started in October and continued to increase in tempo, while requesting bitcoin payments once a victim is successfully compromised by their scheme. Checkpoint writes that threat actors probably exploited poorly secured RDP services to initiate the compromises. Once compromised, and to avoid detection and mitigate their detectable network footprint; threat actors set up a pivot point on the local network for C2 services. Researchers also assessed, that the encryption scheme is effective, as they observed the usage of AES and RSA algorithms, preventing a decrypter for victims. Although, it is still unclear who developed the ransomware and why are they targeting only Israeli companies, researchers at Checkpoint, are actively investigating. For more information, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/ransomware-alert-pay2key/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Linux Distributions Vulnerable to Account Escalation
A vulnerability in Polkit's pkexec component opens Linux distributions to local privilege escalation, Qualys researchers report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Overview

A local privilege escalation vulnerability exists in nearly every Linux distribution. A memory corruption issue in polkit's pkexec allows for the exploitation of this vulnerability. Polkit is installed, by default, on every major Linux distribution and can allow any user to obtain root privileges on a victim computer. The researchers have verified the vulnerability, developed an proof-of-concept exploit, and executed the exploit. The result was full root privileges on distributions of Ubuntu, Debian, Fedora, and CentOS. Vulnerable for over 12 years, the potential for exploitation is far-reaching. Additionally, a video of the proof-of-concept exploit has been released. Red Hat has released mitigation measures to counter the vulnerability. It is unclear if this mitigation measure works on all affected Linux distributions. CVE-2021-4034 has been given a CVSS v3 score of 7.8 indicating a high security vulnerability. Further details including a code breakdown can be found in the source links located within the Reference section below.

# Vulnerability Details

### Type of Vulnerability (OS, Software, Hardware)

  * OS Vulnerability
  * Most Linux distributions vulnerable



### CVE Details

  * Memory Corruption in Polkit's pkexec utility
  * Can be used to gain root privileges for unprivileged accounts



### Proof of Concept

  * A proof-of-concept is available [here](https://vimeo.com/669715589?embedded=true&source=vimeo_logo&owner=42884007)



# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-4034



# Protection

  * Mitigation measures from Red Hat can be found here: [Red Hat Mitigation Measures.txt](/download/attachments/74057643/Red%20Hat%20Mitigation%20Measures.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643232626799&api=v2)
    * NOTE: These measures may not work on all Linux distributions
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking. (M1038)
  * Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system. (M1048)
  * Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring. (M1050)
  * Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk. (1051)



# References

  * <https://blog.qualys.com/vulnerabilities-threat-research/2022/01/25/pwnkit-local-privilege-escalation-vulnerability-discovered-in-polkits-pkexec-cve-2021-4034>
  * <https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2021-4034>
  * [https://vimeo.com/669715589?embedded=true&source=vimeo_logo&owner=42884007](https://vimeo.com/669715589?embedded=true&source=vimeo_logo&owner=42884007)
  * <https://www.qualys.com/2022/01/25/cve-2021-4034/pwnkit.txt>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Hello Kitty Ransomware Added DDoS Extortion Threat
An FBI Flash notes that the Hello Kitty ransomware operators have in some cases used an additional extortion threat, that of a DDoS attack.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Hello Kitty (S0617), FiveHands (S0618)
  *  **RaaS Operation:** No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploiting SonicWall vulnerabilities or using compromised credentials.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and Exfiltration of data, Encrypting of files.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.
  *  **Leak Site:** Hello Kitty uses the Babuk leak site.



# Overview

The FBI has published a Flash alert that provides IoCs associated with the Hello Kitty ransomware which is also known as FiveHands. In addition, the alert advises that in some cases, victims have been threatened that a DDoS attack will be launched on their public website should the ransom not be paid within the specified timeframe. The DDoS threat is on top of the typical threat of publication of the victim's sensitive data. The Flash also notes that Hello Kitty is known to have achieved their initial compromises through exploiting vulnerabilities in SonicWall products (CVE-2021-20016, CVE-2021-20021, CVE-2021-20022, CVE-2021-20023) or using compromised credentials. Hello Kitty uses the Babuk leak site for publication. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68617290/Hello%20Kitty%20Ransomware%20Added%20DDoS%20Extortion%20Threat%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635834059601&api=v2)



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here:[ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/68617290/Hello%20Kitty%20Ransomware%20Added%20DDoS%20Extortion%20Threat%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635865048311&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2021/211029.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1135 - Network Share Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: MalSmoke Campaign Distributing Zloader
Check Point is reporting on a campaign that began around early November being conducted by threat actors known as MalSmoke and is distributing Zloader.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Zloader
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Privilege escalation, Evasion, collection, and exfiltration of data.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Zloader is well-known malware that has been used to deploy a variety of malware, including some well-known ransomware families. A report from Check Point provides an analysis of a campaign being carried out by the threat actors known as MalSmoke that is distributing Zloader. The report notes that the countries most affected by the campaign are the United States followed by Canada though there are victims in at least twenty other countries, with a total of 2170 unique victim IP addresses as of January 2nd. How the MalSmoke actors gain initial access to a victim system is not provided in the report. The documented infection chain begins with the installation of Atera's legitimate remote management application which is used to deploy an agent which provides full access to the system. A series of .bat files are then uploaded to the victim system which carries out a number of operations that include modifying Windows Defender preferences and disabling Windows tools such as cmd.exe and Taskmgr.exe that can be used to detect and investigate malicious activity. Perhaps the most interesting feature of the attack is the use of mshta.exe to load appContast.dll, which has a valid Microsoft signature but has been modified. An explanation of how the modification of the file while retaining the valid signature is provided in the Check Point report. The Zloader payload is in the form of a DLL and is loaded using regsvr32.exe. More detailed information can be found in the Check Point report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056653/MalSmoke%20Campaign%20Distributing%20Zloader%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641446855452&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2022/can-you-trust-a-files-digital-signature-new-zloader-campaign-exploits-microsofts-signature-verification-putting-users-at-risk/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1072 - Software Deployment Tools  
T1106 - Native API  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1569 - System Services  
T1569.002 - Service Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts  
T1037.005 - Startup Items  
T1133 - External Remote Services  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1219 - Remote Access Software  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1489 - Service Stop  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery  
T1529 - System Shutdown/Reboot
